As they crossed the finish line, he gave the victory to Kishane Thompson of Jamaica. However, after a few moments of further review, it was actually Noah Lyles of the United States who took the gold medal.\n\nTo be perfectly fair, Lyles and Thompson couldn't have been much closer. Lyles edged it out with a final time of 9.784 that was .005 better than Thompson at 9.789.\n\nTeam USA also took the bronze with Fred Kerley running a 9.81. Kenneth Bednarek then finished second from last at 9.88.\n\nThe other finishers are as follows with Akani Simbine of South Africa in fourth at 9.82, Lamont Marcell Jacobs of Italy in fifth at 9.85, Letsile Tebogo of Botswana in sixth at 9.86, and another Jamaican in Oblique Seville being last at 9.91.\n\nThis was a major moment for the competitor and his country in this specific event. No American had won the 100m final since 2004 when Justin Gatlin did so in Athens. It was also the first gold medal and second total in the career of Lyles.\n\nThere's only shame in missing that call with how very close that it came down to being. It did admittedly take away some from the achievement, though, with it being Lyles who actually won it moments later.\n\nLyles celebrates 100-meter dash win: 'America, I told you I got this'\n\nNoah Lyles had a strong message for the United States after winning the Olympic gold medal at the 100-meter dash in Paris.\n\n\"America, I told you I got this,\" Lyles said.\n\nLyles crossed the finish line with a time of 9.79 in a photo finish to win track and field's biggest event in the Olympics. He beat Jamaica's Kishane Thompson who also ran a time 9.79. His fellow American in Fred Kerley finished in third by posting a 9.81 time to earn the bronze medal.\n\nLyles is the first American track star to win the Olympic gold medal at the men's 100 since Justin Gatlin won gold at the 2004 Olympics in Athens. This is his second Olympic medal, claiming bronze in the 200-meter dash in the 2020 Tokyo Games in 2021.\n\nLyles entered the Paris Olympics as the reigning world champion in the 100 and 200.", {"uri": "8259934505", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "10:55:05", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T10:55:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T10:54:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://ktbb.com/post/?p=1344249", "title": "Title of the Page", "body": "SAINT-DENIS, France -- Since last August, Noah Lyles has stood firm and unequivocal in his belief that the title of \"world's fastest man\" belongs to him.\n\nOn Sunday night at the Stade de France, he proved it.\n\nWith a personal-best 9.784-second time that edged him past a world-class field full of elite sprinters, Lyles walked away with his first Olympic gold medal in the 100-meter final.\n\nHe earned the victory by beating the man with the world's fastest time this year, Jamaica's Kishane Thompson, by 0.005 of a second.\n\n\"We were waiting for the names to pop up, and I'm going to be honest, I came over [to Thompson] and I was like: 'I think you got that one, big dawg!'\" Lyles said in his postrace news conference. \"Something said I need to lean, and I was like, 'I'm going to lean,' because it's that type of race.\"\n\nIt was the closest 100-meter final since at least Moscow in 1980 -- or perhaps ever. Back then, Great Britain's Allan Wells narrowly beat Silvio Leonard in 10.25 seconds in an era when timing didn't go down to the thousandths of a second.\n\nAccording to Omega, the official timekeeper of all Olympics events, at the 65.15-meter mark, Lyles hit his peak speed, and he was trailing at that point. That peak reached 43.6 km/h or 27.1 mph, and he maintained that rate the rest of the race.\n\n\"What's crazy is my [biomechanist] Ralph Mann, before I left for Paris, he's like, 'This is how close first and second is going to be away from each other,'\" Lyles said, holding his hand up with a narrow space between his index finger and thumb. \"I can't believe how right he was.\"\n\nLyles is the first American to win the celebrated race since Justin Gatlin in 2004.\n\nIf Lyles makes the 200-meter finals Wednesday night, he'll have an opportunity to claim a second gold medal.\n\nLyles' only other Olympic medal is a bronze, which he earned in the 200 at the Tokyo Games three years ago.\n\nSunday's 100-meter final included the defending Olympic gold medalist at the distance, Marcell Jacobs of Italy; Thompson, the Jamaican who entered with the world's fastest time this year (9.77); and two of Lyles' American teammates, Kenny Bednarek and Fred Kerley.\n\nKerley came in third, earning bronze in 9.81 seconds. Bednarek finished seventh, with a time of 9.88 seconds.\n\nThompson's time in the final was only 0.02 of a second slower than what he posted at Jamaican trials earlier this summer. That blistering 9.77-second showing seemed a clear indication he would end up on the podium in Paris.\n\n\"I'm going to be disappointed, but I'm super happy and grateful at the same time,\" Thompson said. \"I just got to take it as what it is and just move forward from here.\"\n\nIt appeared Thompson was leading for much of the sprint, until Lyles bolted in across the final 10 meters. Even then, it seemed evident the race was heading toward a thrilling photo finish.\n\n\"I wasn't patient enough with my speed myself,\" Thompson said.\n\nDuring the semifinal round an hour and a half earlier, Team Jamaica appeared to put the rest of the runners on notice. Thompson's 9.80 semifinal sprint was the fastest of the round. Just behind him in a personal-record 9.81 seconds was fellow Jamaican Oblique Seville, who ran in a separate heat that included Lyles.\n\nSeville had history with Lyles, having faced him in the Bahamas in June. Seville won it, sneaking just past Lyles in 9.82 seconds. Lyles finished 0.03 of a second later.\n\n\"Going to Jamaica and getting beat by Oblique, and still saying I ran .85, and I'm still constantly moving forward and moving forward,\" Lyles said, \"I knew that when the time came for me to be able to say, 'This is the final, this is where I need to put it together,' I was going to do it.\"\n\nIt was after Lyles won the 100-meter world championship in Budapest, Hungary, last August when he began leaning into the \"world's fastest man\" nickname.\n\n\"Everybody knows that the title goes to the Olympic champion, and the world champion,\" Lyles said last week. \"Which, I am one of ... and soon to be another one of.\"", "source": {"uri": "ktbb.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KTBB"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8259776458", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "09:14:47", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T09:14:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T09:13:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://www.pakistantoday.com.pk/2024/08/05/us-sprinter-noah-lyles-wins-100m-gold-by-0-005-of-a-second/", "title": "US sprinter Noah Lyles wins 100m gold by 0.005 of a second", "body": "Since last August, Noah Lyles has unwaveringly claimed the title of \"world's fastest man.\" On Sunday night at the Stade de France, he backed up his words with action.\n\nLyles clinched his first Olympic gold medal in the 100-meter final, clocking a personal-best time of 9.784 seconds. This narrow victory, achieved by just 0.005 seconds over Jamaica's Kishane Thompson, confirmed his status.\n\nIn the postrace news conference, Lyles recounted the tense moments before the result was announced. \"We were waiting for the names to pop up, and I told Thompson, 'I think you got that one, big dawg!' But something told me to lean, so I did because it was that kind of race.\"\n\nThis final was the closest since at least the 1980 Moscow Olympics when Great Britain's Allan Wells narrowly defeated Silvio Leonard in 10.25 seconds, an era before thousandths of a second timing.\n\nOmega, the official Olympic timekeeper, noted that Lyles hit his peak speed of 43.6 km/h (27.1 mph) at the 65.15-meter mark, trailing at that point but maintaining that speed through the finish.\n\nLyles' biomechanist Ralph Mann had predicted the narrow margin between first and second. \"Before I left for Paris, he showed me how close it would be,\" Lyles said, illustrating a small gap with his fingers. \"I can't believe how accurate he was.\"\n\nLyles is the first American to win the prestigious race since Justin Gatlin in 2004. He now has a chance for a second gold if he makes the 200-meter finals on Wednesday.\n\nLyles previously won a bronze in the 200 at the Tokyo Games three years ago.\n\nSunday's final featured a stellar lineup, including defending Olympic gold medalist Marcell Jacobs of Italy, Jamaica's Kishane Thompson with the year's fastest time, and American teammates Kenny Bednarek and Fred Kerley.\n\nKerley took bronze with a time of 9.81 seconds, while Bednarek finished seventh at 9.88 seconds.\n\nThompson's time was just 0.02 seconds slower than his Jamaican trials performance, suggesting a strong podium finish. \"I'm disappointed but also super happy and grateful,\" Thompson said. \"I just have to take it as it is and move forward.\"\n\nThompson appeared to lead for most of the race until Lyles surged in the final 10 meters, pushing the race to a thrilling photo finish. \"I wasn't patient enough with my speed,\" Thompson admitted.\n\nIn the semifinals, Team Jamaica made a statement. Thompson's 9.80-second sprint was the fastest, with fellow Jamaican Oblique Seville just behind at 9.81 seconds. Seville had previously edged out Lyles in the Bahamas in June with a time of 9.82 seconds.\n\nReflecting on that loss, Lyles said, \"Going to Jamaica and getting beat by Oblique, I knew when it came time for the final, I was going to put it together.\"\n\nAfter winning the 100-meter world championship in Budapest last August, Lyles embraced the \"world's fastest man\" moniker. \"Everyone knows Lyles finished behind the pair, in 9.83.\n\nLyles, running third from the outside in Lane 7, was perhaps invisible to Thompson, running third from the inside in Lane 4, as Lyles leaned his head over the finish line for gold.\n\nAmerican Fred Kerley captured the bronze medal, running the final in 9.81 seconds. Team USA's Kenneth Bednarek finished seventh, in 9.88 seconds.\n\nThompson was competing in his first Olympic Games. His initial reaction was one of celebration, then confusion, as he looked skyward with the rest of the crowd to watch the video replay.\n\nThompson ran up front for the majority of the race, only to get edged out by Lyles in the slimmest of margins at the finish line.\n\nLyles won the bronze in the men's 200-meter final at the Tokyo Olympics in 2021. He was outspoken in his lust for gold in Paris, at one point comparing an NBA championship unfavorably to finishing first in a track and field event.\n\n\"You know the thing that hurts me the most is that I have to watch the NBA Finals and they have 'world champion' on their head,\" Lyles said last year. \"World champion of what? The United States? Don't get me wrong, I love the U.S. at times, but that ain't the world. That is not the world. We are the world. We have almost every country out here thriving, putting on their flag to show they are represented. There ain't no flags in the NBA.\"\n\nLyles talked a big game. Sunday, he backed it up.\n\nHis 9.78-second time in Sunday's final was also a personal best, beating the mark he set last year in the World Athletics Championships in Budapest. Lyles captured the 100-meter gold and set his previous personal best in the final in 9.83 seconds.\n\nThe United States had not won gold in the men's 100-meter event since Justin Gatlin at the 2004 {"uri": "2024-08-443934299", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "23:39:12", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T23:39:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T23:20:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://clutchpoints.com/olympics-news-noah-lyles-reaction-photo-finish-100m-final", "title": "Noah Lyles' instant reaction after photo finish in 100m final", "body": "Team USA sprinter Noah Lyles clinched the gold medal, marking the first American victory in the 100-meter event in two decades. Lyles set a personal best with a time of 9.784 seconds, edging out Jamaica's Kishane Thompson, who earned silver with a time of 9.789 seconds. Team USA's Fred Kerley took bronze, finishing just .02 seconds behind Thompson at 9.81 seconds.\n\nAfter the race, the runners waited for the photo review to determine the results, and it took a few moments to confirm the winner. Lyles later told reporters that he initially thought Thompson had won.\n\nNoah Lyles making the United States and his mother proud\n\nUpon being declared the 100-meter champion, the 27-year-old Lyles swiftly tore off his race bib, approached the nearest camera, and delivered an extremely confident message to America.\n\n\"America, I told you I got this,\" said the jubilant Lyles.\n\nFollowing his message to the United States, Lyles located his family in the stands to share the celebration. His mother's response to his victory made the moment even more memorable.\n\nAmid the ongoing celebrations and the lingering excitement among the spectators, Lyles made his way to his mother in the stands. The moment they shared was filled with emotion. Lyles definitely made his momma proud.\n\nAmerica's first gold medal since Justin Gatlin\n\nLyles is the first American sprinter to clinch Olympic gold in the men's 100 meters since Justin Gatlin's triumph at the 2004 Athens Games. This victory adds to his Olympic medal collection, which includes a bronze in the 200 meters from the Tokyo 2020 Olympics (held in 2021). Lyles entered the Paris Olympics as the reigning world champion in both the 100 and 200 meters.\n\nHe's also a six-time world champion gold medalist, but winning Sunday's Olympic gold in the 100 meters may be the highlight of his career so far.\n\nSouth Africa's Akani Simbine secured fourth place with a time of 9.82 seconds, while Italy's Lamont Marcell Jacobs came in fifth at 9.85 seconds.\n\nBotswana's Letsile Tebogo followed closely in sixth with a time of 9.86 seconds. Kenny Bednarek from the USA and Jamaica's Oblique Seville rounded out the field in seventh and eighth places, clocking times of 9.88 and 9.91 seconds, respectively.\n\nAccording to World Athletics, this race marked the first time in history that eight men have completed a wind-legal 100-meter race in under 10 seconds.\n\nIn the semifinals, Thompson and his Jamaican teammate Oblique Seville posted the fastest times in their heats, with Thompson finishing in 9.80 seconds and Seville in 9.81 seconds. Lyles came in third in his heat with a time of 9.83 seconds.\n\nNoah Lyles also aiming for 200m gold\n\nNoah Lyles will kick off his quest for the 200-meter gold on Monday with the first round of heats. He will compete in the sixth heat alongside Jamaica's Bryan Levell and Canada's Andre De Grasse, the defending 200-meter champion from Tokyo who didn't make it to the 100-meter final.\n\nThe first heat begins at 7:55 p.m. local time in Paris (1:55 p.m. ET). The top three finishers in each heat will advance to the semifinals on Wednesday, with the final set for Thursday.\n\nLyles aims to be the first man since Usain Bolt to win both the 100-meter and 200-meter events at the Olympics.", "source": {"uri": "clutchpoints.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "ClutchPoints"}, "authors": [{"uri": "nathan_yasis@clutchpoints.com", "name": "Nathan Yasis", {"uri": "2024-08-443865799", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "20:41:52", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T20:41:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T14:38:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/sports/articles/2024-08-04/noah-lyles-wins-olympic-100-by-five-thousandths-of-a-second-among-closest-finishes-in-games-history", "title": "Noah Lyles Wins Olympic 100 by Five-Thousandths of a Second, Among Closest Finishes in Games History", "body": "SAINT-DENIS, France (AP) -- Noah Lyles won the Olympic 100 meters by .005 seconds Sunday, waiting some 30 seconds after the finish of an excruciatingly close sprint to find out he'd beaten Kishane Thompson of Jamaica.\n\nThe word \"Photo\" popped up on the scoreboard after Lyles and Thompson dashed to the line. Lyles paced the track with his hands draped over his head. Finally, the numbers came up. Lyles won in 9.784 seconds to edge out the Jamaican by five-thousandths of a tick of the clock.\n\nAmerica's Fred Kerley came in third at 9.81 and defending champion Marcell Jacobs finished fifth.\n\nThis was the closest 100-meter since at least Moscow in 1980 -- or maybe even ever. Back then, Britain's Allan Wells narrowly beat Silvio Leonard in an era when timing didn't go down into the thousandths of a second.\n\nLyles is the first American to win the celebrated race since Justin Gatlin in 2004.\n\nAnd 9.784 also marks a personal best for Lyles, who has been promising to add his own brand of excitement to track and certainly delivered this time.\n\nHe will be a favorite later this week in the 200 meters -- his better race -- and will try to join Usain Bolt as the latest runner to win both Olympic sprints.\n\n___\n\nTHIS IS A BREAKING NEWS UPDATE. AP's earlier story follows below.\n\nNoah Lyles finished behind Jamaica's Oblique Seville in the semifinal of the Olympic 100 meters Sunday but still advanced for a rematch in the gold-medal race later in the evening.\n\nSeville is now 2-0 this season against Lyles after finishing in 9.81 seconds, good for a .02-second margin over the American champion.\n\nSeville got off to a stronger start than Lyles, and the American made up ground over the last 40 meters but couldn't completely close the gap. Lyles also lost his opening-round heat -- to Britain's Louie Hinchliffe on Saturday. Hinchliffe finished third in the semifinal and did not advance.\n\nJoining Lyles in the eight-man final will be Jamaica's Kishane Thompson, who won his semifinal in 9.80 seconds, the fastest time in the three semifinal. Thompson also has the world's best time this year at 9.77; he and Seville are trying to put Jamaica back on top of the Olympic podium for the first time since Usain Bolt retired after the 2016 Games.\n\nDefending champion Marcell Jacobs of Italy finished third in the second semifinal and advanced because his 9.92 was the best among sprinters who didn't automatically qualify by finishing in the top two in their heats.\n\nAlso in the final will be Americans Kenny Bednarek and Fred Kerley, Botswana's Letsile Tebogo and South Africa's Akani Simbine.\n\nOther gold medals on the line Sunday night at the Stade de France are in men's hammer throw and women's high jump, where Yaroslava Mahuchikh tries to bring Olympic gold to her war-torn home country of Ukraine.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9790103", "eventUri": "eng-9790103", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.2313725490196079, "wgt": 207, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "2024-08-444226269", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "07:58:05", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T07:58:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T23:46:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.fultonsun.com/news/2024/aug/04/lyles-wins-a-historically-close-olympic-sprint/", "title": "Lyles wins a historically close Olympic sprint", "body": "SAINT-DENIS, France -- Noah Lyles paced on the far end of the track, hands folded over the top of his head, wistfully looking up at a scoreboard that would, sooner or later, flash an answer he's been seeking over three sweat-soaked years.\n\nWas all that toil since the last Olympics -- all the work on the practice track and in the weight room in the name of finding a centimeter here or a millisecond there -- really going to be worth all the trouble?\n\nTen seconds passed, then 20. Then, nearly 30. And then, the answer popped up.\n\nYes, Lyles is the 100-meter champion at the Paris Olympics. The World's Fastest Man.\n\nJust not by very much.\n\nThe American showman edged out Jamaica's Kishane Thompson on Sunday by five-thousandths of a second -- that's .005 of one tick of the clock -- in a race for the ages.\n\nThe final tally in this one: Lyles 9.784 seconds, Thompson 9.789.\n\nThe new champion said that before he left for Paris, one of his physio guys ensured him this race would be a squeaker.\n\n\"He said, 'This is how close first and second are going to be,'\" Lyles said as he pinched his thumb and his forefinger together so they were almost touching. \"I can't believe how right he was.\"\n\nFor perspective, the blink of an eye takes, on average, .1 second. That was 20 times longer than the gap between first and second.\n\nIt was so close, that when the sprinters crossed the line and the word \"Photo\" popped up next to the names of Lyles, Thompson and five others in the eight-man field, Lyles walked over to the Jamaican and said \"I think you got the Olympics dog.\"\n\nThompson, who raced three lanes to the left of Lyles and had no clue where he was on the track, wasn't convinced.\n\n\"I was, 'Wow, I'm not even sure, because it was that close,'\" the Jamaican said.\n\nTime would tell. It always does. When Lyles' name came up first, he snatched his name tag off the front of his bib and held it to the sky. Moments later, he shouted at the TV camera: \"America, I told you I got this!\"\n\nThe first four racers were separated by less than .03. The top seven all finished within .09 of each other.\n\nAmerica's Fred Kerley came in third at 9.81. \"That's probably one of the most beautiful races I've been in,\" he said.\n\nIn the photo finish, Kerley's orange shoe crossed the line before anyone, or anything. But it's the chest breaking the barrier that counts. Lyles' chest crossed first.\n\nThis was the closest 1-2 finish in the 100 since at least Moscow in 1980 -- or maybe even ever.\n\nBack then, Britain's Allan Wells narrowly beat Silvio Leonard in an era when the electronic timers didn't go into the thousandths of a second. The same was true in 1932, when Eddie Tolan won the Olympics' first ever photo finish.\n\nLyles conceded that during the excruciating wait, he was pretty sure he had dipped his chest just a tad too soon. Dipping, it turns out, is one of the few things he doesn't work on over and over again at his training track in Florida.\n\n\"But I would say I have a decent history with dipping,\" he said, recalling races he won in high school and as a junior.\n\nThe 9.784 marked a new personal best for Lyles and made him the first American champion in the marquee race at the Olympics since Justin Gatlin in 2004.\n\nLyles is hoping to go even bigger than that, and maybe take this sport back to a day when it was Carl Lewis and Edwin Moses lighting up the track -- a must-see affair, the likes of which Lyles headlined in front of around 80,000 on a warm night at the Stade de France.\n\nThe mission started after Lyles settled for a bronze medal in Tokyo in his favorite -- and then, only -- sprint, the 200. Those COVID-impacted Games were a terrible experience for Lyles. He rededicated himself to bettering his mental health, but also looked for a new mission -- the 100 meters and, with it, a chance at track immortality.\n\nThe practice was tough for a sprinter never known as a great starter, but he stuck with it. When he won the world championships last year, then backed it up by winning the 200, his goal for Paris was very much in sight.\n\nBut when he came into the Olympic final having finished second in both his qualifying races and staring across at one sprinter who had run faster than him this year -- Thompson -- and another who had beaten him twice this year -- Jamaica's Oblique Seville -- he knew this would be no coronation.\n\nThompson added another roadblock when, during the introduction, he let out a primal scream, the likes of which Lyles has been unleashing in some of his biggest races.\n\n\"I thought 'Man, that's my thing, that's crazy,'\" Lyles said.\n\nLyles galloped and leapt about 20 yards down the track before returning to the starting line, where the runners waited some three minutes for the gun to finally sound.\n\nIt was worth the wait.\n\nNow, the question that could be debated for years is: What was the difference in this one?\n\nCould it have been Lyles' closing speed and that lean into the line that he thought was mistimed?\n\nWas it his ability to stay in reach of everyone among this straight line of sprinters over the first 60 meters -- a skill he's been working on in tedious practice after practice since he took on the shorter sprint?\n\nThe answer: all that and more.\n\n\"Everyone in the field came out knowing they could win this race,\" Lyles said.\n\nIt took 9.784 seconds, then about 30 seconds more, for the scoreboard to flash the name of the man who actually did.\n\n\"Seeing that name, I was like 'Oh my gosh, there it is!'\" Lyles said.\n\nGold (and bronze) for Ukrainian high jumpers\n\nYaroslava Mahuchikh won Olympic gold in the high jump for her war-torn country of Ukraine and, as a bonus, had company. Her teammate Iryna Gerashchenko won the bronze and the teammates hopped, skipped and jumped around the track parading their blue-and-yellow flags in a heartfelt celebration.\n\nMahuchikh needed fewer tries to clear the winning height of 2 meters than Australia's Nicola Olyslagers, and so, added the sport's biggest prize of all -- Olympic gold -- to her world championship and world record.\n\nKerr vs Ingebrigtsen is a go for heated men's 1,500\n\nThe best rivalry in track will culminate Tuesday when reigning world champion Josh Kerr of Britain takes on defending Olympic champion Jakob Ingebrigtsen of Norway.\n\nThey squared off in Sunday's semifinal, too, and Ingebrigtsen edged out the Brit, looking over to him twice as they surged down the homestretch, to win a race that felt like it meant more than it should have in 3:32.38.\n\n\"They should be expecting one of the most vicious and hardest 1,500s the sport's seen in a very long time,\" Kerr said.\n\nDid Ingebrigtsen agree?\n\n\"Depends who you ask, maybe,\" he said. \"I mean, racing is what you want it to be.\"\n\nNoah Lyles, of the United States, in lane seven, wins the men's 100-meter final at the 2024 Summer Olympics, Sunday, Aug. 4, 2024, in Saint-Denis, France. (AP Photo/David J. Phillip)\n\nNoah Lyles of the United States shouts as he arrives in the stadium for the men's 100-meter final at the 2024 Summer Olympics, Sunday, Aug. 4, 2024, in Saint-Denis, France. (AP Photo/Rebecca Blackwell)\n\nNoah Lyles, of the United States, second left, celebrates as he wins the men's 100-meter final ahead of Kishane Thompson, of Jamaica, at the 2024 Summer Olympics, Sunday, Aug. 4, 2024, in Saint-Denis, France. (AP Photo/David J. Phillip)\n\nNoah Lyles, of the United States, celebrates as he wins the men's 100-meter final at the 2024 Summer Olympics, Sunday, Aug. 4, 2024, in Saint-Denis, France. (AP Photo/Petr David Josek)\n\nNoah Lyles, of the United States, reacts ahead of his men's 100-meters semifinal at the 2024 Summer Olympics, Sunday, Aug. 4, 2024, in Saint-Denis, France. Lyles paced the track with his hands draped over his head. Finally, the numbers came up. Lyles won in 9.784 seconds to edge out the Jamaican by five-thousandths of a tick of the clock.\n\nAmerica's Fred Kerley came in third at 9.81 and defending champion Marcell Jacobs finished fifth.\n\nTHIS IS A BREAKING NEWS UPDATE. AP's earlier story follows below.\n\nNoah Lyles finished behind Jamaica's Oblique Seville in the semifinal of the Olympic 100 meters Sunday but still advanced for a rematch in the gold-medal race later in the evening.\n\nSeville is now 2-0 this season against Lyles after finishing in 9.81 seconds, good for a .02-second margin over the American champion.\n\nSeville got off to a stronger start than Lyles, and the American made up ground over the last 40 meters but couldn't completely close the gap. Lyles also lost his opening-round heat -- to Britain's Louie Hinchliffe on Saturday. Hinchliffe finished third in the semifinal and did not advance.\n\nJoining Lyles in the eight-man final will be Jamaica's Kishane Thompson, who won his semifinal in 9.80 seconds, the fastest time in the three semifinal. Thompson also has the world's best time this year at 9.77; he and Seville are trying to put Jamaica back on top of the Olympic podium for the first time since Usain Bolt retired after the 2016 Games.\n\nDefending champion Marcell Jacobs of Italy finished third in the second semifinal and advanced because his 9.92 was the best among sprinters who didn't automatically qualify by finishing in the top two in their heats.\n\nAlso in the final will be Americans Kenny Bednarek and Fred Kerley, Botswana's Letsile Tebogo and South Africa's Akani Simbine.\n\nOther gold medals on the line Sunday night at the Stade de France are in men's hammer throw and women's high jump, where Yaroslava Mahuchikh tries to bring Olympic gold to her war-torn home country of Ukraine.\n\nAP Summer Olympics: {"uri": "8259282560", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "01:46:35", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T01:46:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T01:45:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://wjla.com/sports/olympics/noah-lyles-wins-paris-olympics-100-meter-by-five-thousandths-of-a-second-over-jamaica", "title": "Noah Lyles wins Paris Olympics 100-meter by five-thousandths of a second over Jamaica", "body": "SAINT-DENIS, France (AP) -- Noah Lyles paced on the far end of the track, hands folded over the top of his head, wistfully looking up at a scoreboard that would, sooner or later, flash an answer he's been seeking over three sweat-soaked years.\n\nWas all that toil since the last Olympics -- all the work on the practice track and in the weight room in the name of finding a centimeter here or a millisecond there -- really going to be worth all the trouble?\n\nTen seconds passed, then 20. Then, nearly 30. And then, the answer popped up.\n\nYes, Lyles is the 100-meter champion at the Paris Olympics. The World's Fastest Man.\n\nJust not by very much.\n\nThe American showman edged out Jamaica's Kishane Thompson on Sunday by five-thousandths of a second -- that's .005 of one tick of the clock -- in a race for the ages.\n\nThe final tally in this one: Lyles 9.784 seconds, Thompson 9.789.\n\nThe new champion said that before he left for Paris, one of his physio guys ensured him this race would be a squeaker.\n\n\"He said, 'This is how close first and second are going to be,'\" Lyles said as he pinched his thumb and his forefinger together so they were almost touching. \"I can't believe how right he was.\"\n\nFor perspective, the blink of an eye takes, on average, .1 second. That was 20 times longer than the gap between first and second.\n\nIt was so close, that when the sprinters crossed the line and the word \"Photo\" popped up next to the names of Lyles, Thompson and five others in the eight-man field, Lyles walked over to the Jamaican and said \"I think you got the Olympics dog.\"\n\nThompson, who raced three lanes to the left of Lyles and had no clue where he was on the track, wasn't convinced.\n\n\"I was, 'Wow, I'm not even sure, because it was that close,'\" the Jamaican said.\n\nTime would tell. It always does. When Lyles' name came up first, he snatched his name tag off the front of his bib and held it to the sky. Moments later, he shouted at the TV camera: \"America, I told you I got this!\"\n\nThe first four racers were separated by less than .03. The top seven all finished within .09 of each other.\n\nAmerica's Fred Kerley came in third at 9.81. \"That's probably one of the most beautiful races I've been in,\" he said.\n\nIn the photo finish, Kerley's orange shoe crossed the line before anyone, or anything. But it's the chest breaking the barrier that counts. Lyles' chest crossed first.\n\nThis was the closest 1-2 finish in the 100 since at least Moscow in 1980 -- or maybe even ever.\n\nBack then, Britain's Allan Wells narrowly beat Silvio Leonard in an era when the electronic timers didn't go into the thousandths of a second. The same was true in 1932, when Eddie Tolan won the Olympics' first ever photo finish.\n\nLyles conceded that during the excruciating wait, he was pretty sure he had dipped his chest just a tad too soon. Dipping, it turns out, is one of the few things he doesn't work on over and over again at his training track in Florida.\n\n\"But I would say I have a decent history with dipping,\" he said, recalling races he won in high school and as a junior.\n\nThe 9.784 marked a new personal best for Lyles and made him the first American champion in the marquee race at the Olympics since Justin Gatlin in 2004.\n\nLyles is hoping to go even bigger than that, and maybe take this sport back to a day when it was Carl Lewis and Edwin Moses lighting up the track -- a must-see affair, the likes of which Lyles headlined in front of around 80,000 on a warm night at the Stade de France.\n\nThe mission started after Lyles settled for a bronze medal in Tokyo in his favorite -- and then, only -- sprint, the 200. Those COVID-impacted Games were a terrible experience for Lyles. He rededicated himself to bettering his mental health, but also looked for a new mission -- the 100 meters and, with it, a chance at track immortality.\n\nThe practice was tough for a sprinter never known as a great starter, but he stuck with it. When he won the world championships last year, then backed it up by winning the 200, his goal for Paris was very much in sight.\n\nBut when he came into the Olympic final having finished second in both his qualifying races and staring across at one sprinter who had run faster than him this year -- Thompson -- and another who had beaten him twice this year -- Jamaica's Oblique Seville -- he knew this would be no coronation.\n\nThompson added another roadblock when, during the introduction, he let out a primal scream, the likes of which Lyles has been unleashing in some of his biggest races.\n\n\"I thought 'Man, that's my thing, that's crazy,'\" Lyles said.\n\nLyles galloped and leapt about 20 yards down the track before returning to the starting line, where the runners waited some three minutes for the gun to finally sound.\n\nIt was worth the wait.\n\nNow, the question that could be debated for years is: What was the difference in this one?\n\nCould it have been Lyles' closing speed and that lean into the line that he thought was mistimed?\n\nWas it his ability to stay in reach of everyone among this straight line of sprinters over the first 60 meters -- a skill he's been working on in tedious practice after practice since he took on the shorter sprint?\n\nThe answer: all that and more.\n\n\"Everyone in the field came out knowing they could win this race,\" Lyles said.\n\nIt took 9.784 seconds, then about 30 seconds more, for the scoreboard to flash the name of the man who actually did.\n\n\"Seeing that name, I was like 'Oh my gosh, there it is!'\" Lyles said.", "source": {"uri": "wjla.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "WJLA"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jordan_Lyles", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"uri": "8259060272", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "20:16:26", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T20:16:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T20:15:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://www.espn.com/olympics/story/_/id/40726446/noah-lyles-wins-gold-us-100m-hair-breadth", "title": "Lyles wins gold for U.S. in 100m by hair's breadth", "body": "SAINT-DENIS, France -- Since last August, Noah Lyles has stood firm and unequivocal in his belief that the title of \"world's fastest man\" belongs to him.\n\nSunday night at the Stade de France, he proved it.\n\nWith a 9.79-second time that edged him past a world-class field full of elite sprinters, Lyles walked away with his first Olympic gold medal in the 100-meter final.\n\nHe earned the victory by beating the man with the world's fastest time this year, Jamaica's Kishane Thompson, by 0.0005 of a second.\n\nIf Lyles makes the 200-meter finals Wednesday night, he'll have an opportunity to claim a second gold medal.\n\nLyles' only other Olympic medal is a bronze, which he earned in the 200 at the Tokyo Games three years ago.\n\nSunday's 100-meter final included the defending Olympic 100-meter gold medalist, Marcell Jacobs of Italy; Thompson, the Jamaicanwho entered with the world's fastest time this year (9.77); and two of Lyles' American teammates, Kenny Bednarek and Fred Kerley.\n\nKerley came in third, earning bronze in 9.81 seconds. Bednarek finished seventh, with a time of 9.88 seconds.\n\nDuring the semifinal round an hour and a half earlier, Team Jamaica appeared to put the rest of the runners on notice. Thompson's 9.80 semifinal sprint was the fastest of the round. Just behind him in a personal-record 9.81 seconds, was fellow Jamaican Oblique Seville, who ran in a separate heat that included Lyles.\n\nSeville had history with Lyles, having faced him in the Bahamas in June. Seville won it, sneaking just past Lyles in 9.82 seconds. Lyles finished 0.01 seconds later.\n\nIt was after Lyles won the 100-meter world championship in Budapest, Hungary, last August when he began leaning into the \"world's fastest man\" It was also the second time in the last 60 years that the top two finishers ran the same time measuring into the hundredths.\n\nThe 27-year-old American's torso crossed the finish line first, leading to his victory.\n\n\"We were waiting for the names to pop up, and I'm going to be honest, I came over [to Thompson] and I was like: 'I think you got that one, big dawg!'\" Lyles said in a post-race news conference. \"Something said I need to lean, and I was like, 'I'm going to lean,' because it's that type of race.\"\n\nHere is a photo breakdown of Lyles' historic win:\n\nThe strong field in the final included three Americans -- Lyles, Fred Kerley (who earned a bronze) and Kenneth Bednarek -- plus two Jamaicans -- Thompson and Oblique Seville. Lyles didn't have the best of starts off the blocks, but made up for it once the race commenced.\n\nLyles quickly made up ground as the race went on. He inched closer and closer to the finish line, putting him in prime position for a medal.\n\nLyles didn't lead the race until the final and most important moment. At first glance, it looked like Jamaica's Thompson won the gold. But, with the distance closing, Lyles pushed his torso past Thompson at the last second.\n\nIt took almost half a minute for the official winner of the race to be announced. Lyles and Thompson stood near each other while looking at the video board, awaiting the result.\n\nOnce it was confirmed Lyles won the gold, he lifted his bib to the sky, yelled: \"America. Even fewer then go on to win among the greatest of athletic achievements in a gold medal.\n\nHowever, Noah Lyles now knows for himself that it really can be anyone.\n\nLyles won his first-ever gold medal on Sunday with his narrow victory in the 100m final of the 2024 Paris Olympics. Afterward, he has since reflected on who he is as a person as well as an athlete in a post on social media. None of those things held him back from this achievement, though, which means they won't hold back anyone else either.\n\n\"I have Asthma, allergies, dyslexia, ADD, anxiety, and Depression. But I will tell you that what you have does not define what you can become,\" wrote Lyles on Twitter. \"Why Not You!\"\n\nThat's a powerful message from Lyles after running the race of his life in France.\n\nLyles won his first gold medal, including his second in the Olympics, by five thousandths of a second. He finished with a time of 9.784 while the silver medalist, Kishane Thompson of Jamaica, finished at 9.789. It was unbelievably close to call but, after a few moments of review, it was Lyles who was deemed as the victor.\n\nLyles' victory also represented a major moment in the event for the United States. No American had won the 100m final since Justin Gatlin in Athens back in 2004. That's a 20-year streak that he ended today with this finish.\n\nWe're all capable of incredible things in some form or another. Lyles reminded each of us of that with what he shared following one of the most significant moments he may ever have.\n\nNoah Lyles is on top of the world right now after winning Olympic gold in the 100-meter dash on Sunday. He narrowly defeated Kishane Thompson of Jamaica with a time of 9.784 seconds in an incredible photo finish.\n\nNot long after, Lyles took to social media to celebrate his win via X. He tweeted a few photos of himself after the race along with the caption \"I Told You America I Got This!\".\n\nThose were the same words he said directly into the camera after learning he had won.\n\nLyles won by a mere 0.005 seconds, the closest 100-meter dash finish at the Olympics since at least 1980. He also become the first American to win the event since 2004. It is the sprinter's second overall Olympic medal after he won bronze in the 200-meter dash at the Tokyo Olympics, and his first gold.\n\nLyles appeared to be trailing Thompson for much of the contest before he leaped ahead in the final 10 meters. {"uri": "8259243051", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "00:45:09", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T00:45:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T00:44:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/inside-story-noah-lyles-incredible-003449808.html", "title": "The Inside Story of Noah Lyles' Incredible 100-M Win", "body": "Noah Lyles of Team United States celebrates winning the gold medal in the Men's 100m Final on day nine of the Olympic Games Paris 2024 at Stade de France. Credit - Jean Catuffe -- Getty Images\n\nNoah Lyles and his long-time sports psychologist, Diana McNab, have been executing a pre-race routine all season long. Together, they come up with a sort of script, which lays out the psychological game plan on race day -- from what Lyles should think when he wakes up, when he arrives at the track, when he's warming up, when he's in the blocks, and so on. This mental script is meant to produce strong physical results.\n\nAs per their practice, McNab got on the phone with Lyles the night before his 100-m race in Paris, and rang her Zen chimes three times while Lyles did breathing exercise before visualizing each element of the script.\n\n\"Always Zen chimes!\" says McNab.\n\nThe plan paid off on Sunday night, when Lyles won the most incredible, dramatic, and contested 100-m final in Olympic history. In a photo finish, Lyles edged out Kishane Thompson of Jamaica by five-thousandths of a second on Sunday night at Stade de France.\n\nWhen Lyles woke up on Sunday, his first step was to \"imagine you are 12-15-old Noah - laughing, fun, fearless,\" according to the script that McNabb shared with TIME after the race. At the end of his warmup, he was to be as loose as a \"Raggedy Ann-Doll.\" When he entered the track, he needed to \"look around and take in the thousands of spectators and energy in the stadium\" -- something he could not do in Tokyo, where there were no fans and Lyles went home with a disappointing bronze medal in the 200 m. In the last 20-meters, he was to be \"flying down the track. No one can stop me. I am on fire. I have a God-given extra gear.\"\n\nAnd when he crosses the finish line, according to the script, he'll have a personal-best time, finish in first place, smile, and feel a sense of relief.\n\nCheck, check, check, check. The only thing missing, really, was the agonizing wait for Lyles, Thompson, and bronze-medalist Fred Kerley as the judges settled the photo finish. Then he could let out a cackle on the track, take his victory lap, and officially back up the brash words he had been saying all year: the 100 m was now his.\n\nLyles finished second in his semifinal heat Sunday, to Oblique Seville of Jamaica. Was Lyles not fast enough on this night, or was he just preserving some energy in the tank? \"I told him to try to win,\" said Lyles' coach, Lance Brauman. \"I thought, to be honest with you, Oblique ran a hell of a race.\"\n\nEven Lyles' mother, Keisha, was a bit anxious in the Stade de France stands. Seville and Thompson, who had already run the fastest time of the year going into the Olympics, were looking formidable. She called up Lyles' agent and shared her candid observation.\n\n\"This final,\" said Keisha, \"is going to be a b-tch.\"\n\nBetween the semi and the final, Brauman told Lyles to run more aggressively between 30 and 50 meters. He told him that the next time he saw Lyles, he'd be looking at the 100-m Olympic champion. Brauman told his charge that the showman shows up in the big moment. McNab and Lyles also spoke: she told him to loosen up and stop carrying tension in his body.\n\nDuring his track introduction for the final, Lyles triple-jumped -- plus two or three more hops -- about a quarter way down the track. He was the only finalist to do so: his walk-out was not at all subdued. Does Brauman worry that Lyles' showmanship would sap his energy or risk injury?\n\n\"I try not to watch, to be totally honest,\" says Brauman. \"He does what he does. If I got caught up in that I'd be a nervous wreck all the time.\"\n\nRead More: Noah Lyles Brings His Speed and Sizzle To The Olympics\n\nLyles' reaction time at the gun -- 0.178 seconds -- was tied for worst in the race. \"Dang, I'm amazing,\" said Lyles afterward. \"That's crazy. I thought I was a little better than that, but that goes to prove that reaction time does not win races.\" While Thompson was three lanes over, Seville was running to Lyles' left, within his peripheral vision. \"I was very fortunate to have Oblique Seville right next to me,\" said Lyles. \"Because all throughout the year, I feel like he's been hitting that acceleration that I wasn't hitting. So I was like, the fact that he's here means I'm not gonna let him go.\" Seville finished in last place.\n\nAs Lyles' top-end speed kicked in, Brauman -- who was seated along the backstretch near the finish and didn't have a good view of the start -- started feeling hopeful. \"I felt really good when I saw where he was at 60,\" said Brauman. \"OK, we're in the mix.\" Lyles leaned at the finish, which he wasn't supposed to do, since that causes the slightest bit of deceleration that can cost a sprinter. \"I thought I leaned too early,\" said Lyles. But he got away with it. Barely. Like, really, really barely.\n\nAs the runners and 80,000 fans at Stade de France stared at the scoreboard, wondering who won, Lyles went up to Thompson. and told him he thought the title was his. \"Bro, I think you got that one big dog,\" Lyles told him. \"And then my name popped up. And I'm like, 'Oh my gosh, I'm amazing.\"\n\nNBC put a microphone on Keisha. She screamed so loud, a producer told her she had to turn the volume on her headphones down.\n\nRead More: 6 Track-and-Field Rivalries to Watch at the Paris Olympics\n\nThe times that appeared on the board -- 9.79 seconds -- were the same for Lyles and Thompson. So why wasn't the race some sort of draw? Turns out, Lyles won his gold medal in 9.784 seconds. Thompson got his silver in 9.789 seconds. American Fred Kerley got bronze in 9.81 seconds.\n\nLyles has guaranteed a sweep of the 100 m, 200 m, and 4 X 100 relay. Usain Bolt accomplished that feat over three straight Games, in Beijing, London, and Rio. Lyles is promising less drama in the 200 m, where he's the reigning three-time World Champion, on Thursday night.\n\n\"When I come off the turn,\" Lyles said on Sunday, his opponents \"will be depressed.\"", "source": {"uri": "sports.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo Sports"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Noah_Lyles", "type": "person", {"uri": "8259942507", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "10:59:56", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T10:59:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T10:59:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://www.gpb.org/news/2024/08/05/in-photo-finish-american-noah-lyles-wins-100-meter-final-claim-olympic-gold", "title": "In a photo finish, American Noah Lyles wins 100-meter final to claim Olympic gold", "body": "NPR is in Paris for the 2024 Summer Olympics. For more of our coverage from the games head to our latest updates.\n\nSAINT-DENIS, France -- Noah Lyles has been claiming to be \"the fastest man alive\" since becoming the reigning world champion in the 100-meter race last year.\n\nAfter Sunday night's race, the American can now claim that title without contest.\n\nLyles ran 9.79 seconds, a personal best, in the Sunday night competition at Stade de France, to claim his first Olympic gold.\n\nAhead of start time, Lyles, known for his dramatics and showmanship, came onto the track with arms raised to whip up the crowd, finishing his pre-race show by darting up and down about a quarter of the 100-meter distance he was about to run.\n\nOnce the shot fired, the American got a classically sluggish start but accelerated enough to beat Jamaica's Kishane Thompson, who -- before tonight -- was the fastest man this year. He also posted 9.79, prompting a nail-biting few moments as everyone in the stadium waited for the photo finish results to develop.\n\nComputers show Lyles leaned forward to cross the line five-thousandths of a second faster than Thompson.\n\nBefore the final results posted, Lyles told reporters he thought it was Thompson who finished first, not him.\n\n\"I was like, oh man I'm really gonna have to swallow my pride, which I don't have a problem doing. Respect deserves respect, and everybody in the field to be honest came out knowing that they could win this race.\"\n\nFred Kerley of the U.S. came in third place .02 seconds later to win bronze.\n\nLyles' victory in the 100m is the first U.S. gold in the Olympic event since Justin Gatlin won in 2004.\n\nAs for Thompson, he'll be the first Jamaican to make it to the podium since Usain Bolt's Olympic reign ended with the Rio de Janeiro Games in 2016.\n\n\"This is the closest medal,\" Thompson said after the race. \"I couldn't see him, but I thought he was seeing me. He said, 'Hey Kishane I thought you got it,' and I said, 'I am not sure.' \"\n\nIn the semifinal, fellow Jamaican Oblique Seville ran a personal best 9.81, finishing ahead of Lyles by .02 after the American had another rough start.\n\nLyles' celebrity rose after last month's release of the Netflix docuseries Sprint, which follows several of the fastest runners currently at the Paris Games in their quest for Olympic gold.\n\nLyles is the reigning world champion in the 100m and the 200m. It's also why the showman already liked to call himself the \"fastest man alive.\" He also won the bronze in the 200-meter race at the Tokyo Olympics three years ago.\n\nUltimately, Lyles is chasing Bolt's world record in both. Bolt's 100-meter record is 9.58 seconds.\n\nLyles is not known for his start out of the blocks. In fact, an official timing analysis of the final showed that for the first 40 meters of Sunday's gold-medal race, he was in last place.\n\nIt's why the 200-meter is his better event. He'll have a chance to prove that on Thursday night.\n\nIf he does win, Lyles would be the first male sprinter to achieve the Olympic sprint double since Bolt did it at Rio in 2016.\n\nAt a post-race press conference, Lyles was asked to look in to the future.\n\nHe said sprinting greats should be seen at the same level as basketball superstars -- and have their own big sponsorships. {"uri": "2024-08-443889131", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "21:34:32", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T21:34:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T20:47:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.postandcourier.com/arena/cfb-nfl/fans-in-disbelief-over-slow-mo-video-of-noah-lyles-olympic-finish/article_2751c6e2-a48a-574b-b0a3-e91f11583a42.html", "title": "Fans In Disbelief Over Slow-Mo Video Of Noah Lyles' Olympic Finish", "body": "On Sunday afternoon, U.S. sprinter Noah Lyles won his first-ever Olympic gold medal after narrowly securing first place in the men's 100m at the 2024 Paris Games.\n\nLyles (27) barely beat out Jamaican silver medalist Kishane Thompson by less than 0.01 seconds (five-thousandths of a second). In fact, the finish was so close that the official Olympic time for both Lyles and Thompson is the exact same at 9.79 seconds. The top four sprinters all had times within 0.03 seconds of each other.\n\nThe end of this race made for a fantastic photo finish, with all eight participants in the frame. In the image, you can Lyles leaning his head forward just enough to surpass Thompson and secure victory.\n\nEven in a slow-motion video of Lyles' finish, it's very hard to tell that he won. That's how close the race was. You can also see that Lyles wouldn't have secured any medal had it not been for his last-second effort.\n\nThis was just Lyles' second Olympic medal in his career. He won bronze in the 200m race at the 2020 Tokyo Olympics.\n\nFans couldn't believe how close the race was when the slow-motion video surfaced online. They took to social media to leave their thoughts.\n\n\"The fact that Noah Lyles won this race is insane.. five one thousandths of a second!!!\"\n\n\"Probably one of the craziest finishes I ever seen\"\n\n\"What a finish\"\n\n\"This has to be one of the best final 10 meters ever ran in the Olympics, my lord\"\n\n\"Crazy\"\n\nIn the 100m semifinal, Lyles came in second place, right behind Jamaica runner Oblique Seville. He went viral for taunting Seville at the finish line but ultimately lost that race. In the end, it didn't matter because Lyles got the last laugh in the final.\n\nLyles grew up in Gainesville, Florida. He initially committed to compete for the Florida Gators but instead decided to go pro along with his brother Josephus Lyles.\n\nLyles will also compete in the men's 200m race. Round one will begin on Monday, August 5, at 2:30 p.m. ET.\n\nRelated: U.S. Sprinter Noah Lyles Loses Race After Taunting Opponent At Finish Line\n\nRelated: Olympic Runner Zablon Ekwam In Tears After {"uri": "2024-08-443904127", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "22:11:42", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T22:11:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T22:05:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://clutchpoints.com/olympic-news-dwyane-wade-magic-johnson-noah-lyles-gold-medal-win", "title": "Dwyane Wade, Magic Johnson get real on Noah Lyles' gold medal win", "body": "Noah Lyles has proved that he is the fastest man in the world after winning the 100 meters at the Paris Olympics. Some former NBA players and gold medalists in their respective sports reacted to Lyles winning gold in Paris, and it was nothing but love from them.\n\nDwyane Wade was one of the first former NBA players to shout out Lyles but he did it by supporting his nail color. Wade has received backlash before for painting his nails, but it looks like Lyles does it too. At this point, there's not much you can say to Lyles since he's a gold medalist, and Wade seems to love it.\n\nMagic Johnson wasn't sitting on his couch like most people were watching the race, instead, he was on a yacht celebrating Lyles' win.\n\n\"It's the first time in 20 years that the US brings home the gold in the Men's 100! Wow - what an exciting race!! @LylesNoah,\" Johnson said on X, formerly Twitter.\n\nNoah Lyles wins his first gold medal\n\nNoah Lyles crossed the finish line in the 100 meters with a winning time of 9.79, and it was a perfect photo finish that showed the U.S. sprinter leaning his head forward to capture the gold. Kishane Thompson ran a 9.79 to finish in second place and Fred Kerley ran a 9.81 to finish in third place.\n\nLyles became the first American sprinter to win an Olympic gold medal in the men's 10 since Justin Gatlin at the 2004 Athens Games. Lyles knew how hard it would be, but he was ready for the test and came out victorious.\n\n\"It's the one I wanted, it's the hard battle, it's the amazing opponents,\" Lyles said after the race. \"Everybody came prepared for the fight and I wanted to prove that I'm the man among all of them, I'm the wolf among wolves.\"\n\nIn the first round of the 100 meters that took place on Aug. 3, Lyles finished second behind Great Britain's Louie Hinchcliffe. Despite second place, Lyles stayed confident.\n\n\"These boys said they ain't coming to play,\" Lyles said after the first round. \"And I guess that's my first lesson in underestimating the power of an Olympics. When somebody's on the line, they say they're going to give it their all or nothing.\n\n\"I was more expecting that they would just fall in line, and they didn't, they took it as 'I got one shot and I'm going to take it.' And to be honest, I should have expected that knowing that this is the Olympics. But this is my first time in an Olympic 100. I didn't. That's on me, and I won't let that happen again.\"\n\nLyles isn't done going for gold, and he'll be participating in the 200 meters on Aug. 4.", "source": {"uri": "clutchpoints.com", "dataType": {"uri": "2024-08-443891098", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "21:42:16", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T21:42:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T21:39:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.wyff4.com/article/noah-lyles-photo-finish-video-usa-olympics/61785741", "title": "Watch: USA's Noah Lyles wins 100-meter gold in thrilling photo finish", "body": "ABOVE VIDEO: Noah Lyles won his first Olympic gold medal in an epic photo finish, edging Jamaica's Kishane Thompson by five thousandths of a second. American Fred Kerley took bronze. Can't see the above video? Click here.\n\nHow close was the race for \"fastest man in the world?\" It came down to a photo finish.\n\nNoah Lyles won the Olympic 100 meters by .005 seconds Sunday, waiting some 30 seconds after the finish of one of the closest sprints in history to find out he'd beaten Kishane Thompson of Jamaica.\n\nThe word \"Photo\" popped up on the scoreboard next to the names of Lyles, Thompson and five others after they crossed the line. Lyles paced the track with his hands draped over his head. Finally, the numbers came up. Lyles won in 9.784 seconds to edge out the Jamaican by five-thousandths of a tick of the clock.\n\nAmerica's Fred Kerley came in third at 9.81. The top seven all finished within .09 of each other.\n\nThis was the closest 1-2 finish in the 100 since at least Moscow in 1980 -- or maybe even ever. Back then, Britain's Allan Wells narrowly beat Silvio Leonard in an era when the electronic timers didn't go down into the thousandths of a second.\n\nLyles became the first American to win the marquee event in Olympic track since Justin Gatlin in 2004. The 9.784 also marks a personal best for Lyles.\n\nHe will be a favorite later this week in the 200 meters -- his better race -- and will try to join Usain Bolt as the latest runner to win both {"uri": "2024-08-443894400", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "21:49:37", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T21:49:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T20:11:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.espn.co.uk/olympics/story/_/id/40726446/noah-lyles-wins-gold-us-100m-hair-breadth", "title": "Lyles wins gold for U.S. in 100m by .005 seconds", "body": "Previously covered Florida State for Orlando Sentinel and Georgia Tech for Macon Telegraph\n\nSAINT-DENIS, France -- Since last August, Noah Lyles has stood firm and unequivocal in his belief that the title of \"world's fastest man\" belongs to him.\n\nSunday night at the Stade de France, he proved it.\n\nWith a personal-best 9.784-second time that edged him past a world-class field full of elite sprinters, Lyles walked away with his first Olympic gold medal in the 100-meter final.\n\nHe earned the victory by beating the man with the world's fastest time this year, Jamaica's Kishane Thompson, by 0.005 seconds.\n\nIt was the closest 100-meter final since at least Moscow in 1980 -- or perhaps ever. Back then, Great Britain's Allan Wells narrowly beat Silvio Leonard in 10.25 seconds in an era when timing didn't go down to the thousandths of a second.\n\nLyles is the first American to win the celebrated race since Justin Gatlin in 2004.\n\nIf Lyles makes the 200-meter finals Wednesday night, he'll have an opportunity to claim a second gold medal.\n\nLyles' only other Olympic medal is a bronze, which he earned in the 200 at the Tokyo Games three years ago.\n\nSunday's 100-meter final included the defending Olympic 100-meter gold medalist, Marcell Jacobs of Italy; Thompson, the Jamaican who entered with the world's fastest time this year (9.77); and two of Lyles' American teammates, Kenny Bednarek and Fred Kerley.\n\nKerley came in third, earning bronze in 9.81 seconds. Bednarek finished seventh, with a time of 9.88 seconds.\n\nDuring the semifinal round an hour and a half earlier, Team Jamaica appeared to put the rest of the runners on notice. Thompson's 9.80 semifinal sprint was the fastest of the round. Just behind him in a personal-record 9.81 seconds was fellow Jamaican Oblique Seville, who ran in a separate heat that included Lyles.\n\nSeville had history with Lyles, having faced him in the Bahamas in June. Seville won it, sneaking just past Lyles in 9.82 seconds. Lyles finished 0.01 seconds later.\n\nIt was after Lyles won the 100-meter world championship in Budapest, Hungary, last August when he began leaning into the \"world's fastest man\" nickname.\n\n\"Everybody knows that the title goes to the Olympic champion, and the world champion,\" Lyles said last week. \"Which, I am one of ... and soon to be another one of.\"", "source": {"uri": "8259244981", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "00:48:58", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T00:48:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T00:48:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://time.com/7007700/noah-lyles-paris-olympics-100-m-win/", "title": "The Inside Story of Noah Lyles' Incredible 100-M Win", "body": "Noah Lyles and his long-time sports psychologist, Diana McNab, have been executing a pre-race routine all season long. Together, they come up with a sort of script, which lays out the psychological game plan on race day -- from what Lyles should think when he wakes up, when he arrives at the track, when he's warming up, when he's in the blocks, and so on. This mental script is meant to produce strong physical results.\n\nAs per their practice, McNab got on the phone with Lyles the night before his 100-m race in Paris, and rang her Zen chimes three times while Lyles did breathing exercise before visualizing each element of the script.\n\n\"Always Zen chimes!\" says McNab.\n\nThe plan paid off on Sunday night, when Lyles won the most incredible, dramatic, and contested 100-m final in Olympic history. In a photo finish, Lyles edged out Kishane Thompson of Jamaica by five-thousandths of a second on Sunday night at Stade de France.\n\nWhen Lyles woke up on Sunday, his first step was to \"imagine you are 12-15-old Noah - laughing, fun, fearless,\" according to the script that McNabb shared with TIME after the race. At the end of his warmup, he was to be as loose as a \"Raggedy Ann-Doll.\" When he entered the track, he needed to \"look around and take in the thousands of spectators and energy in the stadium\" -- something he could not do in Tokyo, where there were no fans and Lyles went home with a disappointing bronze medal in the 200 m. In the last 20-meters, he was to be \"flying down the track. No one can stop me. I am on fire. I have a God-given extra gear.\"\n\nAnd when he crosses the finish line, according to the script, he'll have a personal-best time, finish in first place, smile, and feel a sense of relief.\n\nCheck, check, check, check. The only thing missing, really, was the agonizing wait for Lyles, Thompson, and bronze-medalist Fred Kerley as the judges settled the photo finish. Then he could let out a cackle on the track, take his victory lap, and officially back up the brash words he had been saying all year: the 100 m was now his.\n\nLyles finished second in his semifinal heat Sunday, to Oblique Seville of Jamaica. Was Lyles not fast enough on this night, or was he just preserving some energy in the tank? \"I told him to try to win,\" said Lyles' coach, Lance Brauman. \"I thought, to be honest with you, Oblique ran a hell of a race.\"\n\nEven Lyles' mother, Keisha, was a bit anxious in the Stade de France stands. Seville and Thompson, who had already run the fastest time of the year going into the Olympics, were looking formidable. She called up Lyles' agent and shared her candid observation.\n\n\"This final,\" said Keisha, \"is going to be a b-tch.\"\n\nBetween the semi and the final, Brauman told Lyles to run more aggressively between 30 and 50 meters. He told him that the next time he saw Lyles, he'd be looking at the 100-m Olympic champion. Brauman told his charge that the showman shows up in the big moment. McNab and Lyles also spoke: she told him to loosen up and stop carrying tension in his body.\n\nDuring his track introduction for the final, Lyles triple-jumped -- plus two or three more hops -- about a quarter way down the track. He was the only finalist to do so: his walk-out was not at all subdued. Does Brauman worry that Lyles' showmanship would sap his energy or risk injury?\n\n\"I try not to watch, to be totally honest,\" says Brauman. \"He does what he does. If I got caught up in that I'd be a nervous wreck all the time.\"\n\nRead More: Noah Lyles Brings His Speed and Sizzle To The Olympics\n\nLyles' reaction time at the gun -- 0.178 seconds -- was tied for worst in the race. \"Dang, I'm amazing,\" said Lyles afterward. \"That's crazy. I thought I was a little better than that, but that goes to prove that reaction time does not win races.\" While Thompson was three lanes over, Seville was running to Lyles' left, within his peripheral vision. \"I was very fortunate to have Oblique Seville right next to me,\" said Lyles. \"Because all throughout the year, I feel like he's been hitting that acceleration that I wasn't hitting. So I was like, the fact that he's here means I'm not gonna let him go.\" Seville finished in last place.\n\nAs Lyles' top-end speed kicked in, Brauman -- who was seated along the backstretch near the finish and didn't have a good view of the start -- started feeling hopeful. \"I felt really good when I saw where he was at 60,\" said Brauman. \"OK, we're in the mix.\" Lyles leaned at the finish, which he wasn't supposed to do, since that causes the slightest bit of deceleration that can cost a sprinter. \"I thought I leaned too early,\" said Lyles. But he got away with it. Barely. Like, really, really barely.\n\nAs the runners and 80,000 fans at Stade de France stared at the scoreboard, wondering who won, Lyles went up to Thompson. and told him he thought the title was his. \"Bro, I think you got that one big dog,\" Lyles told him. \"And then my name popped up. And I'm like, 'Oh my gosh, I'm amazing.\"\n\nNBC put a microphone on Keisha. She screamed so loud, a producer told her she had to turn the volume on her headphones down.\n\nRead More: 6 Track-and-Field Rivalries to Watch at the Paris Olympics\n\nThe times that appeared on the board -- 9.79 seconds -- were the same for Lyles and Thompson. So why wasn't the race some sort of draw? Turns out, Lyles won his gold medal in 9.784 seconds. Thompson got his silver in 9.789 seconds. American Fred Kerley got bronze in 9.81 seconds.\n\nLyles has guaranteed a sweep of the 100 m, 200 m, and 4 X 100 relay. Usain Bolt accomplished that feat over three straight Games, in Beijing, London, and Rio. Lyles is promising less drama in the 200 m, where he's the reigning three-time World Champion, on Thursday night.\n\n\"When I come off the turn,\" Lyles said on Sunday, his opponents \"will be depressed.\"", "source": {"uri": "time.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "TIME"}, "authors": [{"uri": "sean_gregory@time.com", "name": "Sean Gregory", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], {"uri": "2024-08-443869237", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "20:48:28", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T20:48:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T20:20:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://thegrio.com/2024/08/04/noah-lyles-wins-olympic-100/", "title": "Noah Lyles wins Olympic 100 by five-thousandths of a second, among closest finishes in Games history", "body": "Lyles is the first American to win the celebrated race since Justin Gatlin in 2004\n\nSAINT-DENIS, France (AP) -- Noah Lyles won the Olympic 100 meters by .005 seconds Sunday, waiting some 30 seconds after the finish of an excruciatingly close sprint to find out he'd beaten Kishane Thompson of Jamaica.\n\nThe word \"Photo\" popped up on the scoreboard after Lyles and Thompson dashed to the line. Lyles paced the track with his hands draped over his head. Finally, the numbers came up. Lyles won in 9.784 seconds to edge out the Jamaican by five-thousandths of a tick of the clock.\n\nAmerica's Fred Kerley came in third at 9.81 and defending champion Marcell Jacobs finished fifth.\n\nThis was the closest 1-2 finish in the 100 since at least Moscow in 1980 -- or maybe even ever. Back then, Britain's Allan Wells narrowly beat Silvio Leonard in an era when the electronic timers didn't go down into the thousandths of a second.\n\nThank goodness they do now.\n\nLyles is the first American to win the celebrated race since Justin Gatlin in 2004.\n\nAnd 9.784 also marks a personal best for Lyles, who has been promising to add his own brand of excitement to track and certainly delivered this time.\n\nHe will be a favorite later this week in the 200 meters -- his better race -- and will try to join Usain Bolt as the latest runner to win both Olympic sprints.\n\nFor perspective, the blink of an eye takes, on average, .1 second, which was 20 times longer than the gap between first and second in this one.\n\nWhat was the difference? Maybe Lyles' closing speed and his lean into the line. He and Thompson had two of the three slowest bursts from the blocks, and Thompson had what sufficed for a \"lead\" at the halfway point.\n\nBut this would take more than 10 seconds to decide. {"uri": "8259505963", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "05:58:28", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T05:58:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T05:57:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.postandcourier.com/arena/cfb-nfl/fans-protest-noah-lyles-gold-medal-due-to-controversial-finish/article_ca22c11e-c173-5d1b-a8be-6629d38f5a5c.html", "title": "Fans Protest Noah Lyles' Gold Medal Due to Controversial Finish", "body": "USA sprinter Noah Lyles won his first-ever Olympic gold medal in dramatic fashion. In Sunday's men's 100m final at the 2024 Paris Olympics, Lyles came in first after a last-second lean towards the finish line.\n\nLyles beat out Jamaican sprinter Kishane Thompson by just five-thousandths of a second, one of the closest finishes fans will ever witness. The official record has Lyles and Thompson finishing with the same time of 9.79 seconds, but Lyles still picked up the win by a minuscule amount.\n\nAfter the race, fans noticed that Thompson may have been robbed of gold. In a photo that is going viral on social media with over seven million views, Thompson's foot is clearly well over the finish line before Lyles is.\n\nHowever, Lyles won because his torso was over the line before Thompson's. The official Olympic rules state that the first runner whose torso reaches the finish line wins the race.\n\nDespite what the rule clearly states, fans still protested Lyles' gold medal, believing Thompson was more deserving of the win.\n\n\"KINDA SILLY THAT A FOOT RACE ISNT DECIDED BY FEET\"\n\n\"This race should boycott because my good friend Noah Lyles did not win this race. Head, shoulder, and foot will let anyone win.\"\n\n\"So, what body part has to cross the line first? Because if it's the foot, I haven't seen a pic yet that has Noah Lyles ahead. Did buddy from Jamaica get robbed?\"\n\n\"Noah Lyles crossed the finish line after the Jamaican's foot crossed but apparently who actually crosses the line first physically doesn't matter\"\n\n\"Total robbery! Y'all know Noah Lyles did not win that race! Kishanes foot been over that line before Lyles head!\"\n\nThis win gave Lyles his second Olympic medal ever, with his first coming in the 2020 Tokyo Olympics, where he won bronze in the 200m race. Turns out he wasn't alone.\n\nPer Chris Chavez of CITIUS Mag, Thompson recalled an interaction with Lyles after the race. While Thompson didn't know who won, Lyles thought the Jamaican star had captured the gold medal.\n\n\"I couldn't see him, but I thought he was seeing me. So he said, 'Hey Kishane, I think you got it done,' but I wasn't really sure,\" Thompson said. \"I could have seen who was to my left and to my right, but he was to my far right, so I wasn't sure. This is my closest race.\"\n\nIn just about the closest conclusion possible, Lyles snapped a 20-year gold drought for United States men in the Olympic event. The Tokyo Games bronze medalist also won his first-ever Olympic gold medal.\n\nAlthough a favorite entering Paris, Lyles finished second in his heat and second in the semifinal to Jamaica's Oblique Seville. Lyles ran the final in 9.784 seconds, narrowly edging out Thompson (9.789) and U.S. bronze medalist Fred Kerley (9.81).\n\n\"I knew when the time came for me to be able to say, 'This is the final, this is where I need to put it together,' I knew I was going to be able to do it,\" Lyles said.\n\nThompson will not compete in the 200-meters, but Lyles will look to claim more gold in the event. {"uri": "8259069936", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "20:29:34", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T20:29:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T20:28:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.centralmaine.com/2024/08/04/noah-lyles-wins-mens-100-by-razor-thin-margin/", "title": "Noah Lyles wins men's 100 by razor-thin margin", "body": "Noah Lyles, in Lane 7, outleans Kishane Thompson, in Lane 4, to win the men's 100-meter dash Sunday at the Summer Olympics in Saint-Denis, France. David J. Phillip/Associated Press\n\nSAINT-DENIS, France -- Noah Lyles won the Olympic 100 meters by .005 seconds Sunday, waiting some 30 seconds after the finish of an excruciatingly close sprint to find out he'd beaten Kishane Thompson of Jamaica.\n\nThe word \"Photo\" popped up on the scoreboard after Lyles and Thompson leaned across the finish line. Lyles paced the track with his hands draped over his head. Finally, the numbers came up. Lyles won in 9.784 seconds to edge out the Jamaican by five-thousandths of a second.\n\nFred Kerley of the U.S. came in third at 9.81. defending champion Marcell Jacobs of Italy finished fifth.\n\nThis was the closest 100-meter final since at least Moscow in 1980 - or maybe even ever. Back then, Britain's Allan Wells narrowly beat Silvio Leonard in an era when timing didn't go down into the thousandths of a second.\n\nLyles is the first American to win the 100 since Justin Gatlin in 2004.\n\nThe winning time of 9.784 marks a personal best for Lyles, who has been promising to add his own brand of excitement to track and field, and certainly delivered this time.\n\nHe will be a favorite later this week in the 200 - his better race - and will try to dislodge Usain Bolt as the most recent sprinter to win both Olympic sprints.\n\nCopy the Story Link\n\nSend questions/comments
