{"uri": "2024-08-443924714", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "23:10:18", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T23:10:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T22:06:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://eu.jsonline.com/story/sports/olympics/2024/08/04/olympic-track-live-results/74665582007/", "title": "Olympic track live updates: Noah Lyles is World's Fastest Man in 100 meters photo finish", "body": "After a disappointing performance in 2021, a fire was lit under Noah Lyles to become the fastest man in the world. He just needs to improve by 1%.\n\nThompson ran a 9.79 (.789) to finish second and the USA's Fred Kerley came in third, posting a time of 9.81 to get bronze.\n\nSAINT-DENIS, France -- Noah Lyles is the fastest man in the world.\n\nThe U.S. sprinter won the 100 at the Paris Olympics. Lyles crossed the finish line with a gold-medal winning time of 9.79 (.784) in a photo finish to win track and field's marquee sprint event. It took a photo view to reveal Lyles had beaten Jamaica's Kishane Thompson by five-thousandths of a second\n\nThe runners had to wait for photo review moments after the race and didn't know who won seconds after the race. Lyles told reporters following the race that he thought Thompson had won.\n\n\"I did think Thompson had it at the end,\" Lyles said. \"I went up to him when we were waiting and I said, 'I think you got that one big dog.' And then my named popped up and I'm like, 'Oh my gosh, I'm amazing.'\n\n\"I wasn't ready to see (my name). That's the first time I have ever said that in my head, that I wasn't ready to see it. ... It was hard for me to picture where we were. I guess that was a good thing.\"\n\nThe moment belonged to Lyles inside a packed house at Stade de France as soon as the announcement was made. Lyles is the first American sprinter to win an Olympic gold medal in the men's 100 since Justin Gatlin won gold at the 2004 Athens Games.\n\n\"It's the one I wanted, it's the hard battle, it's the amazing opponents,\" Lyles said after the race. \"Everybody came prepared for the fight and I wanted to prove that I'm the man among all of them, I'm the wolf among wolves.\"\n\nLyles came into the Olympics confident. He ran a personal-best 9.81 at last month. He told USA TODAY Sports that he wanted to win multiple Olympic gold medals. He's well on his way to achieving his goal.\n\nThe 100 victory earned Lyles his first ever Olympic gold medal. He received a bronze in the 200 at the Tokyo Olympics. He's also a six-time world champion gold medalist, but Sunday's Olympic gold medal in the 100 might be the crowning achievement of his career thus far.\n\n\u27a4 Get Olympics updates in your texts! Join USA TODAY Sports' WhatsApp Channel\n\n\u27a4 The USA TODAY app gets you to the heart of the news -- fast. Download for award-winning coverage, crosswords, audio storytelling, the eNewspaper and more.\n\nWhat determines victory in Olympic photo finish?\n\nJust after the men's 100-meter race concluded, NBC's Mike Tirico gave a brief explanation of how track and field race winners are determined. In his explanation, Tirico said Olympic races determine a victor when any part of the leading runner's torso crosses the vertical plane of the finish line.\n\nUSA Track & Field, the governing body that oversees Team USA's international track and field competitions, has similar language published in its 2024 USATF Competition Rules.\n\nOn page 67 of the document, under Rule 163 (which concerns running competitions), the first point states: \"Competitors shall be placed at the finish line in the order in which any part of their bodies (i.e., the 'torso,' as distinguished from the head, neck, arms, hands, legs, or feet) reaches the finish line.\" - Lorenzo Reyes\n\nWhen does Noah Lyles run next?\n\nLyles will start his pursuit of 200-meter gold Monday with round 1 heats. He's in the sixth heat with Jamaica's Bryan Levell and Canada's Andre De Grasse, the defending 200-meter champion from Tokyo. De Grasse did not qualify for the 100 final. The first heat starts at 7:55 p.m. Monday in Paris (1:55 p.m. ET). The top three in each heat advance to the semifinals, which are Wednesday. The final is Thursday.\n\nKeisha Caine Bishop on Noah Lyles' dreams of turning pro\n\nNoah Lyles' mother knew her sons' dream of becoming professional track stars when they were still teenagers.\n\n\"In 10th grade they wanted to go professional out of high school and I was like are you crazy,\" Keisha Caine Bishop, the mother of Noah and Josephus, told USA TODAY Sports this summer.\n\nIn July 2016 when Noah was 19 years old, he and his younger brother, Josephus, 18 at the time, turned professional and signed a contract with Adidas instead of competing collegiately for the University of Florida.\n\n\"I had to go back and apologize,\" Caine Bishop said. \"I realized that's not fair to kill somebody's dream, especially if they are willing to do the work, and they were willing to do the work.\"\n\nNoah and Josephus have been running professionally since. Josephus isn't on the Olympic team in Paris but ran the 100 and 200 at Olympic trials. - Tyler Dragon\n\nNBC broadcaster incorrectly calls 100 meters race winner\n\nIf you thought Noah Lyles missed out on the gold medal in the 100-meter dash, you weren't the only one.\n\nNBC broadcaster Leigh Diffey was into the moment like the rest of the audience taking in the 100 meters, but he seemed a bit more decisive with his call than what the eye told. As the sprinters crossed the line, the cameras panned to Jamaican sprinter Kishane Thompson and Diffey declared Thompson the winner, not Lyles.\n\n\"Jamaica's gonna do it, Kishane Thompson is a gold medalist, on debut,\" Diffey declared, before going silent.\n\nThe competitors were all huddled waiting for photo evidence of the finish. When the photo did come in, it was Lyles who was the winner of the race, by five-thousandths of a second over Thompson.\n\nLyles' victory secures the USA's first gold medal in the 100 meter in 20 years, and solidifies his standing as the fastest man in the world. - Joseph Rivera\n\nAccording to World Athletics, it's the first time in history that eight men have broken 10 seconds in a wind-legal race.\n\nUSA's Juliette Whittaker makes it through to 800 final\n\nJuliette Whittaker will be the only American woman in the 800-meter final after squeaking through the semifinals Sunday night.\n\nWhittaker, 20, nabbed the third and final 800-meter spot on Team USA at the Olympic trials but is now the only one of them left. Allie Wilson did not make it out of the first round, and Nia Akins fell short in the semifinals.\n\nAfter making the final and running a personal best of 1 minute, 57.76 seconds, Whittaker said she feels like she's playing with house money now.\n\n\"I think I'm just so excited now just to see what I can do tomorrow, without any expectation,\" she said. \"Even if I get last in the final, I will be overjoyed just to make it that far. So yeah, I'm just excited.\" - Tom Schad\n\n3 Americans qualify for men's 1500-meter final\n\nThere will be plenty of red, white and blue in the men's 1500-meter final.\n\nAll three Americans left in the field qualified for the final, with Yared Nuguse and Hobbs Kessler finishing first and second in one of the two semifinals to advance. Both ran under 3 minutes, 32 seconds.\n\nCole Hocker also cruised into the final after placing third in his semi and spending most of the race shadowing two of the medal favorites: Jacob Ingebrigsten of Norway and Josh Kerr of Great Britain.\n\n\"That was just the very last bit of confidence that I needed, heading into the final,\" said Hocker, who ran collegiately at Oregon. - Tom Schad\n\nUSA's Vashti Cunningham finishes fifth in women's high jump\n\nSAINT-DENIS, France - Team USA women's high jumper Vashti Cunningham missed out on a medal for the third consecutive Olympics Sunday. Still, despite a troubling back injury this season, she recorded her highest Olympic finish ever (fifth place). The daughter of former Philadelphia Eagles quarterback Randall Cunningham cleared the bar at 1.86, 1.91 and 1.95 meters, but failed on three attempts to clear 1.98 to fall out of medal contention.\n\nThe gold medal went to Ukrainian Yaroslava Mahuchikh, who cleared 2.0 meters in fewer attempts than silver medalist Nicola Olyslagers of Australia. Ukrainian Iryna Gerashchenko and Australia's Eleanor Patterson tied for the bronze.\n\nCunningham narrowly qualified for the Paris Olympics, but entered ranked No. 7 in the world. She recorded finishes of 13th at the Rio Games in 2016 and sixth at the Tokyo Games in 2021.\n\n\"I felt good about my performance. I was happy when I made the bar and when I missed the bar, I knew what I was doing wrong,\" Cunningham said. \"I just need to go back to the drawing board and work on a few things.\"\n\nAsked if she's committed to making a run at the 2028 Games in Los Angeles, Cunningham said, \"Absolutely. I'm only going to be 30 years old, guys.\" - Chase Goodbread\n\nWeather forecast for 100 final\n\nThere is no rain in the forecast for the men's 100 final. It's expected to be slightly cloudy and 71 degrees at the start of the race. The women's sprinters in Saturday's 100 final had to deal with rainy conditions.\n\nAll three American sprinters advance to 100 final\n\nNoah Lyles, Fred Kerley and Kenny Bednarek all advanced to the 100 showdown Sunday night. Lyles and Kerley placed second in their respective heats. Bednarek qualified on time.\n\nJamaica's Kishane Thompson (9.80) and Oblique Seville (9.81) have the top times entering the final.\n\nJamaica's Kishane Thompson won his third and final heat at 9.80 in what was a quick semifinal. Fred Kerley placed second at 9.84 to get the second automatic qualifying spot.\n\nNoah Lyles second in heat, qualifies for 100 final\n\nSAINT-DENIS, France -- Noah Lyles is going to have to make some adjustments ahead of the 100 final.\n\nLyles placed second his first semifinal heat, running a 9.83. Jamaica's Oblique Seville won the heat and looked at Lyles as he crossed the finish line in a personal-best time of 9.81.\n\nLyles lost to Great Britain's Louie Hinchliffe in the opening round. But all that matters is he qualified for Sunday's final.\n\nThe top two from each heat plus the next two fastest times advance to the final.\n\nHow many events is Noah Lyles going to run at Paris Olympics?\n\nNoah Lyles is slated to run the 100, 200 and 4x100 relay.\n\nQuincy Hall, Michael Norman, Christopher Bailey advance to 400 semis\n\nSAINT-DENIS, France -- All three Team USA runners advanced in the men's 400.\n\nChristopher Bailey took second in the first heat of the men's 400 to move on to the semifinal. Heat No. 1 also featured Great Britian's Matthew Hudson-Smith who has the fastest time in the world this year (43.74). Hudson-Smith won the first heat timing at 44.78.\n\nMichael Norman ran a fast 44.10 to win the second heat.\n\nQuincy Hall, the U.S. Olympic track and field trials gold medalist, sped by Australia's Reece Holder down the home stretch and crossed the line with a first-place time of 44.28 in the fourth heat.\n\nThe top three in each heat automatically advanced to Tuesday's semifinal round. Norman qualified to the semifinal with the fastest time.\n\nWhat time does Noah Lyles run the 100 semifinals?\n\nThe semifinal in the 100 is at 2:05 p.m. ET. Lyles is in the first heat and will run in lane No. 4.\n\nJamaica's Kishane Thompson is the fastest man in the world this year with a world-leading time of 9.77. Thompson eased up in the opening round in Paris and still ran a 10.00 to finish first in his heat. Thompson's Jamaican teammate, Oblique Seville, has defeated Lyles before and can make the podium.\n\nLyles' American teammates, Kenny Bednarek and Fred Kerley, are threats to reach the podium. Bednarek and Kerley both ran 9.97 to advance to the semis.\n\nThe defending Olympic champ, Marcell Jacobs of Italy, can't be counted out, either.\n\nWhat is world record in 100?\n\nThe world record in the 100 is 9.58 set by Jamaica's Usain Bolt in 2009.\n\nWhat is Olympic record in the 100?\n\nUsain Bolt ran 9.63 to win a gold medal and set the Olympic record at the 2012 London Games.\n\nLast time American won gold medal in men's 100 at Olympics\n\nJustin Gatlin was the last American male to win an Olympic gold medal in the 100. Gatlin won gold at the 2004 Athens Games. Team USA's best medal in the 100 since then has been silver medals won at the 2016 Olympics (Gatlin) and 2020 Games (Fred Kerley).", "source": {"uri": "jsonline.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8259197309", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "23:33:54", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T23:33:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T23:32:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://www.on3.com/pro/news/noah-lyles-celebrates-100m-gold-medal-win-with-epic-social-media-post-olympics/", "title": "Noah Lyles celebrates 100M gold medal win with epic social media post", "body": "USA track and field star Noah Lyles is on top of the world right now after winning Olympic gold in the 100-meter dash on Sunday. He narrowly defeated Kishane Thompson of Jamaica with a time of 9.784 seconds in an incredible photo finish.\n\nNot long after, Lyles took to social media to celebrate his win via X. He tweeted a few photos of himself after the race along with the caption \"I Told You America I Got This!\" It was the same words he said directly into the camera after learning he had won.\n\nLyles won by a mere 0.005 seconds, the closest 100-meter dash finish at the Olympics since at least 1980. He also become the first American to win the event since 2004. It is the sprinter's second overall Olympic medal after he won bronze in the 200-meter dash at the Tokyo Olympics, and his first gold.\n\nLyles appeared to be trailing Thompson for much of the contest before he leaped ahead in the final 10 meters. He will also have an opportunity to take home another gold medal in the 200-meter finals on Wednesday night.\n\nThat in mind, he won't have long to celebrate this victory before having to prepare for the next race.\n\nAbout two months before his historic photo finish to win the gold medal in the 100-meter dash at the 2024 Paris Olympic Games, American Noah Lyles essentially called his shot.\n\nLyles was coming off the best race of his career, a 9.85-second 100-meter dash at the Racers Grand Prix on June 2. But that wasn't good enough for first place.\n\nInstead, first place went to Jamaica's Oblique Seville, who clocked a 9.82.\n\nEven knowing the Olympics were coming up, Lyles didn't seem stressed at all. In fact, he seemed motivated and energized. And he made a promise of sorts.\n\n\"I say every year, when I get beat y'all need to be scared as s***, because next time you see me you gone be f***** worried,\" Noah Lyles told the Jamaica Observer.\n\nOf course, as things played out, Noah Lyles would get his revenge on Seville. Seville actually finished in last in the 100-meter dash final in Paris, clocking a 9.91 -- still an absurdly fast time, of course.\n\nInstead, it was a different Jamaican that Lyles edged out for the win by five-thousandths of a second: Kishane Thompson. Lyles clocked a 9.784 for the win, his fastest time yet. {"uri": "2024-08-443897575", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "21:59:00", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T21:59:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T20:22:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://fansided.com/posts/noah-lyles-olympics-gold-100-meters-nba-twitter-hate-watch", "title": "NBA Twitter hate watches Noah Lyles secure world's fastest man title", "body": "Athletics - Olympic Games Paris 2024: Day 8 / Hannah Peters/GettyImages\n\nIf the 100-meter gold at the Olympics is used to determine the world's fastest man, Noah Lyles is him. Lyles is notorious for talking...a lot of smack. This isn't new, as Lyles frequently backs up his boasting. At the Paris Olympics, Lyles failed in his quest to win the 200-meter gold. However, his true test was in the 100 meters, which he won by a nose, quite literally.\n\nLyles had a lot of ground to make up in very little time. As one of the best finishers in the sport, Lyles is notorious for his closing speed. Despite a valiant effort by Kishane Thompson of Jamaica, who held the lead until the last possible moment, Lyles was able to beat him out by several thousandths of a second.\n\nThe 27-year-old Lyles congratulated Thompson after the race, waiting on a photo finish that took all too long to appear on-screen. Upon winning, Lyles pointed to the camera and told all Americans what he's been saying all along: I told you so.\n\nWhy do NBA fans dislike Noah Lyles?\n\nThe majority of Americans were thrilled Lyles took home gold on Sunday night in Paris. The key word in that statement is most.\n\nNBA fans have a love-hate relationship with Lyles. On the one hand, he's one of the best athletes of his generation. On the other, he doesn't consider the Boston Celtics -- or any team which wins the NBA title -- to be world champions. After the World Championships in Budapest a year ago, Lyles unleashed a quote that makes sense as it pertains to track and field, but not necessarily basketball.\n\n\"You know the thing that hurts me the most is that I have to watch the NBA Finals and they have 'world champion' on their head,\" Lyles said. \"World champion of what? The United States? Don't get me wrong, I love the U.S. at times, but that ain't the world...We are the world.\"\n\nNBA fans had a field day with such a statement for obvious reasons. The Celtics aren't losing to a professional basketball team in Turkey. Next question.\n\nNBA fans didn't want Noah Lyles to win gold\n\nIf there were any group of Americans rooting against Lyles, it was NBA fans. The tweets would have been impeccable. Unfortunately for them, however, Lyles lived up to the hype and held up his end of the bargain, winning gold by the narrowest of margins.\n\nAll we can do is respect the hustle. {"uri": "8259320529", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "02:39:26", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T02:39:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T02:38:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.forbes.com/sites/katelynhutchison/2024/08/04/noah-lyles-clinches-100-meter-gold-at-the-paris-olympics/", "title": "Noah Lyles Clinches 100 Meter Gold At The Paris Olympics", "body": "The man of the hour is newly crowned Olympic champion Noah Lyles. During the 100-meter dash final, the two-time Olympian ran a personal best of 9.79 seconds to clinch his first Olympic title.\n\nLyles is the American record holder in the 200-meter dash and has earned six world championship titles. He made his Olympic debut in Tokyo, where he earned bronze in the 200-meter dash. Since then, he has not lost a major championship in the event.\n\nAlthough the 100-meter dash is not Lyle's strongest event, he managed to earn a spot in what can be called the toughest 100-meter dash final in history. At every global championship but the 2015 world championships, 10 seconds flat would always, at the very least, make the final. During the 2015 world championships, the slowest qualifying time was 9.99 seconds.\n\nThis year, five athletes ran 10 seconds flat or faster but still did not make the final. The last person to make it into this year's Olympic final was 200-meter dash Olympic silver medalist Kenny Bednarek at 9.93 seconds.\n\nJoining Bednarek and Lyles was Tokyo silver medalist Fred Kerley, putting all three Americans in the final. 2012 was the last Olympics where all three USA men made the 100-meter dash final.\n\nAlthough Lyles was able to pull off earning an Olympic title, his journey in this event was not easy.\n\nLyles ran at a meet in Jamaica where he lost to Oblique Seville, one of Jamaica's top sprinters. In that race, Seville looked smooth, while Lyles looked like he had expended more energy to run as well as he did.\n\nThe world champion only came into the Olympics ranked third, with Jamaica's Kishane Thompson and Kenya's Ferdinand Omanyala ranked first and second. Thompson's world-leading time of 9.77 seconds and Omanyala's time of 9.79 seconds are faster than Lyles' previous lifetime best.\n\nIn round one of the Paris 100-meter dash, NCAA champion and Great Britain athlete Louie Hinchcliffe beat Lyles. In the semi-finals today, Seville handed Lyles another second-place finish. Fans and spectators were concerned for Lyle's odds of securing gold and even making the podium after not winning either qualifying round.\n\nConsidering the top four fastest men going into the final ran 9.80 seconds, 9.81 seconds, 9.83 seconds, and 9.84 seconds, it was clear that if Lyles wanted gold, he would need to run the best race of his life.\n\nThe world champion did not have a stellar start to his race in the final, but he is mostly known for his vicious top-end speed, where he can close significant gaps on his competition in the last 30 meters of his race.\n\nThis graphic shows how Lyles was in eighth place for the first 40 meters of the race. He moved from seventh to third place in just 10 meters. Even at 90 meters, he was only in second. It took until the last moment for Lyles to pull off his first Olympic gold medal. Readers can click here to see the analysis of the other competitors.\n\nThe most interesting part of the anticipation for the results is that neither Lyles nor Thompson thought they won after racing. During the press conference, Lyles and Thompson recounted the moment they crossed the finish line.\n\n\"After that race, I came up. We were waiting for the names to pop up,\" said Lyles. \"I'm going to be honest. When I came over, I was like, 'I think you got that big dawg'.\"\n\nThompson went on to express how, from his perspective, he thought Lyles had beaten him because he couldn't see Lyles based on the lanes they were in.\n\n\"It was really a close race because I couldn't really see Noah,\" said Thompson. \"When we both crossed the line... he came to me and said, 'Hey man, I think you got it,' but I was like, 'I'm not even sure' because it was that close.\"\n\nTheir names appeared on the results list, with Lyles and Thompson having the same time of 9.79 seconds. However, Lyles' name appeared first because he won by .005 of a second.\n\nThis is Thompson's first Olympic games, and he has already earned a silver medal at just 23-years old. Kerley did not have the most typical year, but he managed to pull together a season's best and earn the USA another spot on the podium.\n\nThe reigning Olympic champion Marcell Jacobs placed fifth overall while running a season's best. Respect should also be given to Akani Simbine, who placed fourth, and Letsile Tebogo, who placed sixth, as they ran national records for their respective home countries.\n\nAlthough Bednarek did not place as high as he hoped, he has a chance to redeem himself during the 200-meter dash. Seville has the opportunity to appear on Jamaica's 4x100-meter relay.\n\nLyles has talked extensively about wanting to earn four Olympic gold medals from the 100-meter and 200-meter dash, the 4x100-meter relay, and the 4x400-meter relay. So far, he has one down and three more to go.\n\nIf Noah Lyles can win the 200-meter dash, he will be the first man since Carl Lewis in 1984 to win both sprint medals at the Olympics.\n\nThe next event Lyles will contest is the 200-meter dash, which begins on August 5th at 1:55 p.m. EST. He will compete in the 4x100-meter relay on August 9th and must wait to see if he is chosen for the 4x400-meter relay on August 10th.", "source": {"uri": "forbes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8259112168", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "21:26:09", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T21:26:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T21:25:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.ctpublic.org/2024-08-04/in-a-photo-finish-american-noah-lyles-wins-100-meter-final-to-claim-olympic-gold", "title": "In a photo finish, American Noah Lyles wins 100-meter final to claim Olympic gold", "body": "NPR is in Paris for the 2024 Summer Olympics. For more of our coverage from the games head to our latest updates.\n\nSAINT-DENIS, France -- Noah Lyles has been claiming to be \"the fastest man alive\" since becoming the reigning world champion in the 100-meter race last year.\n\nAfter Sunday night's race, the American can now claim that title without contest.\n\nLyles ran 9.79 seconds, a personal best, in the Sunday night competition at Stade de France, to claim his first Olympic gold.\n\nAhead of start time, Lyles, known for his dramatics and showmanship, came onto the track with arms raised to whip up the crowd, finishing his pre-race show by darting up and down about a quarter of the 100-meter distance he was about to run.\n\nOnce the shot fired, the American got a classically sluggish start but accelerated enough to beat Jamaica's Kishane Thompson, who -- before tonight -- was the fastest man this year. He also posted 9.79, prompting a nail-biting few moments as everyone in the stadium waited for the photo finish results to develop.\n\nComputers show Lyles leaned forward to cross the line five-thousands of a second faster than Thompson.\n\nFred Kerley of the U.S. came in third place .02 seconds later to win bronze.\n\nLyles' victory in the 100m is the first U.S. gold in the Olympic event since Justin Gatlin won in 2004.\n\nAs for Thompson, he'll be first Jamaican to make it to the podium since Usain Bolt's Olympic reign ended with the Rio de Janeiro Games in 2016.\n\nIn the semifinal, fellow Jamaican Oblique Seville ran a personal best 9.81, finishing ahead of Lyles by .02 after the American had another rough start.\n\nLyles' celebrity rose after last month's release of the Netflix docuseries Sprint, which follows several of the fastest runners currently at the Paris Games in their quest for Olympic gold.\n\nLyles is the reigning world champion in the 100m and the 200m. It's also why the showman already liked to call himself the \"fastest man alive.\" He also won the bronze in the 200-meter race at the Tokyo Olympics three years ago.\n\nUltimately, Lyles is chasing Bolt's world record in both. Bolt's 100-meter record is 9.58 seconds.\n\nLyles is not known for his start out of the blocks, which is why the 200-meter is his better event. He'll have a chance to prove that on Thursday night.\n\nIf he does win, Lyles would be the first male sprinter to achieve the Olympic sprint double since Bolt did it at Rio in 2016.", "source": {"uri": "2024-08-443861022", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "20:29:47", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T20:29:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T20:18:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.dcnewsnow.com/news/local-news/virginia/alexandria/noah-lyles-pulls-out-olympic-100-in-photo-finish/", "title": "Noah Lyles pulls out Olympic 100 in photo finish", "body": "SAINT-DENIS, France (AP) -- Noah Lyles won the Olympic 100 meters by .005 seconds Sunday, waiting some 30 seconds after the finish of an excruciatingly close sprint to find out he'd edged out Kishane Thompson of Jamaica.\n\nThe world \"Photo\" popped up on the scoreboard after Lyles and Thompson dashed to the line. Lyles paced the track with his hands draped over his head. Finally, the numbers came up. Lyles won in 9.784 seconds to edge out the Jamaican by five-thousandths of a tick of the clock.\n\nAmerica's Fred Kerley came in third at 9.81 and defending champion Marcell Jacobs finished fifth.\n\nThis was the closest 100-meter since at least Moscow in 1980 -- or maybe even ever. Back then, Britain's Allan Wells narrowly beat Silvio Leonard in an era when timing didn't go down into the thousandths of a second.\n\nLyles is the first American to win the celebrated race since Justin Gatlin in 2004.\n\nAnd 9.784 also marks a personal best for Lyles, who has been promising to add his own brand of excitement to track and certainly delivered this time.\n\nHe will be a favorite later this week in the 200 meters -- his better race -- and will try to join Usain Bolt as the latest runner to win both Olympic sprints.", "source": {"uri": "dcnewsnow.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8259056538", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "20:12:17", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T20:12:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T20:11:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://time.com/7007483/team-usa-noah-lyles-wins-100-m-olympic-gold/", "title": "Noah Lyles, the World's Fastest Man, Wins 100-M Olympic Gold", "body": "The world's fastest man is still the world's fastest man.\n\nTeam USA's Noah Lyles, the defending world champion in the 100 m, won the Olympic gold medal in that race on Sunday night at Stade de France, becoming the first male sprinter from the United States to earn a 100-m Olympic title in two decades. Lyles ran the race in 9.784 seconds; Kishane Thompson of Jamaica won silver with a time of 9.789 seconds, while the U.S.'s Fred Kerley won bronze, in 9.81 seconds.\n\nLyles, also the three-time defending 200-m world champion, backed up brash predictions of sprint domination. He has historically enjoyed more success in the 200; Lyles finished seventh at the U.S. Olympic trials in the 100 m in 2021, failing to make the American team.\n\n\"I'm here to race anybody who wants it,\" he declared to TIME before the Olympics. \"The deeper the field, the better I run. I know I'm going to win. Because I'm never going to break nerve.\"\n\nThe Olympics are now a scene of Lyles' greatest triumph, rather than his most transformative failure. Lyles struggled to improve his mental health before the Tokyo Olympics, as pandemic isolation darkened the mood of the athlete's typically extroverted persona. Plus, the murder of George Floyd in 2020 added to his stress. And once he arrived in Tokyo, the lack of electricity in a stadium with no fans also held Lyles back.\n\nRead More: Noah Lyles Brings His Speed and Sizzle To The Olympics\n\nBut an underperformance in Tokyo, where he finished third in the 200 m, a race where he was the favorite, sparked Lyles to revise his training. Recalling his memories from Tokyo in a meeting with reporters in Paris this week, Lyles said: \"This is not fun. This is not cool. This is not what I wanted. This is not what I thought it was going to be like. And that's literally the last few thoughts I had going into my mind as I got into the blocks. And it sucked.\"\n\nLyles, the favorite in the 200 m that year as he had run the world's fastest time of the year going into Tokyo, finished a disappointing third. He broke down in tears while meeting with reporters afterwards, in detailing his difficult mental-health journey, and guilt that his younger brother Josephus, another elite sprinter, hadn't made the Olympics with him. (Josephus did not qualify for Paris.)\n\nComing out of Tokyo, Lyles decided to revamp his training program. In essence, he'd work smarter, not necessarily harder. (Though by all accounts, Lyles still grinds for hours on the track.) Since 2021, Lyles has put on some 10 lb. of muscle, which has allowed him to position his body at more efficient angles in the blocks, and generate more force and higher speeds at the beginning of his races. He's worked with a biomechanist to improve his start time, long considered his weakness. Winning a silver medal at the 60-m indoor world championships in Glasgow earlier this year gave Lyles confidence that these efforts were paying off.\n\n\"There are tons of people out there who claim that I have horrible starts,\" said Lyles last week. \"But you know, somebody with a horrible start can't get a silver medal or run 6.43 in the 60.\"\n\nRead More: Which Olympic Sport Is Hardest on the Body?\n\nLyles set out to conquer the 200 m; that final is on Aug. 8, followed by the 4x100 relay the next night. The last male Olympian to sweep those three events was Usain Bolt.\n\n\"I get to finally say it, I'm showing up to an Olympic Games not depressed,\" Lyles said in Paris. \"And it feels amazing. It's a lot of joy, a lot of joy. And even though there's hard times in the moment, I can always think back to the last Olympics and be like, \"No, this one is, is not the same. This one is way better.' And I'm ready to show it.\"\n\nHe showed it. And his very best could still be coming.", "source": {"uri": "time.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "TIME"}, "authors": [{"uri": "sean_gregory@time.com", "name": "Sean Gregory", "type": "author", {"uri": "8259971365", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "11:18:38", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T11:18:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T11:16:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.peacefmonline.com/pages/sports/olympics/202408/507260.php", "title": "Where The Greatest Ever Olympic 100m Final Was Won", "body": "A spectacular pre-race lightshow and dramatic music during a lengthy wait for the starting pistol at an expectant Stade de France heightened the senses.\n\nBut even those dazzling theatrics could not quite do justice to the events which unfolded in the 10 seconds that followed.\n\nAs Noah Lyles celebrated wildly, his first Olympic triumph confirmed, others were left stunned after witnessing one of the most remarkable Olympic 100m showdowns of all time.\n\nAmerican Lyles had taken victory by five-thousandths of a second from Jamaica's Kishane Thompson in a dramatic photo finish, winning in 9.79 seconds.\n\nAll eight men finished within 0.12secs of the gold medal, with last-placed Jamaican Oblique Seville crossing the line in 9.91 - a time good enough for fourth at the Tokyo Games.\n\nAnd it meant, for the first time, that eight men had run under 10 seconds in a wind-legal race - making it the fastest race of all time.\n\nFour-time Olympic champion Michael Johnson said it was \"absolutely\" the best 100m final he has ever seen \"bar none\".\n\n\"The final lived up to the hype. Going through the rounds it looked like a foregone conclusion that Kishane Thompson would win as he was the one who came in as the fastest man in the world,\" Johnson said on BBC TV.\n\n\"We had this amazing race where you could throw a blanket over the finishing line.\n\n\"We didn't even know who won for a few minutes.\"\n\nHow Lyles came from nowhere to win Olympic gold\n\n'He can hold speed and endurance a really long time' - Johnson on Lyles\n\nNot until the big screen inside the stadium displayed the official results, after an agonising wait, did anybody truly know Lyles had taken gold.\n\nIt was not until the very last metres on the eye-catching purple track that he was even in contention.\n\nLyles tied with Letsile Tebogo for the slowest reaction time of anyone in the field, a time of 0.178 notably down on Fred Kerley's lightning 0.108.\n\nYet Tebogo would go on to cross the line in sixth, while Kerley could only hold on for bronze.\n\n\"Lyles didn't even have a medal 10 metres out. He didn't have a hope of winning,\" Olympic medallist Steve Cram said on BBC TV.\n\nLyles was in last place with 40 metres of the race gone.\n\nBy halfway he was seventh.\n\nBut the 27-year-old hit his top speed of 43.6 kilometres per hour at 60 metres to enter medal contention, then closed far better than any rival to clinch the ultimate prize with his very last stride.\n\nThompson, the fastest man in the world this year with a best time of 9.77, maintained a lead from 30 metres into the race, to 10 metres from the finish line.\n\nIt was the finest margins which determined the outcome, as Lyles covered the distance between 80-90 metres in 0.84 and the final 10 metres in 0.86 - compared to 0.85 and 0.87 for Thompson.\n\n\"I did think [Thompson] had it at the end. I went up to him while we were waiting, and said 'I think you've got that, good going,' and then my name popped up and I'm like 'oh my gosh, I'm amazing',\" Lyles said.\n\n\"I'm going to be honest, I wasn't ready to see it and that's the first time I've ever said that. I wasn't ready to see it.\"\n\nReflecting on narrowly missing out on gold, 23-year-old Thompson said: \"I wasn't patient enough with myself to let my speed bring me at the line, in the position that I know I could have gone to, but I have learned from it.\"\n\nThe drama at the head of the race inspired world records behind it.\n\nThe finishing times for Akani Simbine, Lamont Marcell Jacobs, Tebogo, Kenny Bednarek and Seville were all world records for fourth to eighth place finishers in a 100m race.\n\nSouth Africa's Simbine ran a personal best for fourth and said: \"Missing the medal by 0.01, it's actually really crazy, but yeah, I'm pretty happy.\"\n\nLyles building legacy with each global gold\n\nLyles has long positioned himself as the heir to Usain Bolt's throne, combining on-track performances with off-track flair in his bid to establish himself as the new superstar of men's athletics.\n\nNot afraid to raise expectations through his own comments, Lyles has spoken about his desire to break the long-standing 100m and 200m records set by Jamaica's eight-time Olympic champion Bolt, who retired in 2017.\n\nThe American also claimed he will target four golds in Paris by adding the men's 4x400m relay to his schedule after winning the world 100m, 200m and 4x100m title in Budapest 12 months ago.\n\nLyles will next pursue the Olympic 200m title as a three-time defending world champion in the event, although he had to settle for bronze on his Games debut in Tokyo three years ago.\n\n\"Lyles had a bad Tokyo and since then he's really been looking for big moments,\" said Johnson.\n\n\"He wants to be a global superstar. He talks about Usain Bolt and the type of person he was. He's talked about his sport and voiced his frustration about how it doesn't give you that platform.\"\n\nIt is 16 years since Bolt strolled to the first of his three Olympic 100m golds in Beijing, showboating as he crossed the line but still clocking a world record 9.69 - which he improved to the still-standing mark of 9.58 in 2009.\n\nLyles is yet to get close to that time, running under 9.80 for the first time to win on Sunday night, while his 200m best of 19.31 also trails Bolt's best (19.19).\n\nBut, like Bolt, Lyles stars on the sport's grandest stages and he continues to amass global golds at a considerable rate.\n\n\"Noah Lyles is able to back it up,\" Olympic heptathlon champion Denise Lewis said on BBC TV.\n\n\"He has been amplifying the need for people to take this sport more seriously, deliver and respect the athletes for what they deliver, which is sensational entertainment every single time.\n\n\"To do this here, with the amphitheatre of the lights, the drama, everything, is just brilliant.\"\n\nJohnson added: \"He is here to create a legacy and he has put the first stamp down on that legacy by taking this title in such imperious fashion.\"", "source": Lyles paced the track with his hands draped over his head. Finally, the numbers came up. Lyles won in 9.784 seconds to edge out the Jamaican by five-thousandths of a tick of the clock.\n\nAmerica's Fred Kerley came in third at 9.81 and defending champion Marcell Jacobs finished fifth.\n\nLyles finished behind Jamaica's Oblique Seville in the semifinal of the Olympic 100 meters, but still advanced for a rematch in the gold-medal race later in the evening.\n\nSeville is now 2-0 this season against Lyles after finishing in 9.81 seconds, good for a .02-second margin over the American champion.\n\nSeville got off to a stronger start than Lyles, and the American made up ground over the last 40 meters but couldn't completely close the gap. Lyles also lost his opening-round heat -- to Britain's Louie Hinchliffe on Saturday. Hinchliffe finished third in the semifinal and did not advance.\n\nMORE OLYMPICS\n\nHow Paris healed a 44-year-old wound for a N.J. judo family\n\nI've found the Jerseyiest place at the Paris Olympics\n\nRutgers 'power couple' finds joy in shared Olympic dream\n\nTwo N.J. swimmers turned a Somerset County pool into an Olympic hotbed\n\nSydney McLaughlin-Levrone aces 1st test as she defends her gold medal at the Paris Olympics\n\nJoining Lyles in the eight-man final will be Jamaica's Kishane Thompson, who won his semifinal in 9.80 seconds, the fastest time in the three semifinal. Thompson also has the world's best time this year at 9.77; he and Seville are trying to put Jamaica back on top of the Olympic podium for the first time since Usain Bolt retired after the 2016 Games.\n\nDefending champion Marcell Jacobs of Italy finished third in the second semifinal and advanced because his 9.92 was the best among sprinters who didn't automatically qualify by finishing in the top two in their heats.\n\nAlso in the final will be Americans Kenny Bednarek and Fred Kerley, Botswana's Letsile Tebogo and South Africa's Akani Simbine.\n\nOther gold medals on the line Sunday Thompson, the fastest man in 2024 so far, also clocked 9.79s but was five-thousandths of a second behind Lyles.\n\nFred Kerley of USA won the bronze medal with a tome of 9.81s. The fourth place went to South African sprinter Akani Simbine who finished the race in 9.82s.\n\nTokyo Olympics gold medalist Marcell Jacobs of Italy was fifth after finishing with a time of 9.85s.\n\nIn a race of the finest margins Lyles triumphed. He is now the first American runner to win the gold medal in the 100m event after Justin Gatlin's win in the 2004 Olympics in Athens.\n\nBotswana's Letsile Tebogo came sixth in 9.86s while American Kenny Bednarek finished seventh with a time of 9.88s. Jamaican Oblique Seville came eighth with a time of 9.91s in what would be a race that will be talked about for ages.\n\nLyles, who started in lane seven, outside of Seville and inside of Tebogo was just off to an average start but his long strides helped him catch up with the leaders.\n\nHe opened up after the 40m mark and pushed harder as Lyles and Thompson crossed the finish line at the same time, with five-thousandth of a second separating them.\n\nThe 69,000 Stade de France was treated to an amazing race and as the runners took guard at the starting blocks, there was a pin drop silence.\n\nLyles and Kerley embraced in a hug while Thompson, who was sure to have won the race, roared only to understand the magnitude of the difference a five-thousandth of a second can make.\n\nThe officials took some time to examine the photo-finish and declared Lyles the winner, who avenged his Tokyo Olympics mediocre run, by his standards, where he won the 200m bronze medal.", {"uri": "8259158275", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "22:34:04", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T22:34:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T22:32:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.lemonde.fr/en/sports/article/2024/08/04/lyles-wins-olympic-100m-gold-in-closest-finish-in-modern-history-it-s-the-one-i-wanted_6709056_9.html", "title": "Lyles wins Olympic 100m gold in closest finish in modern history: 'It's the one I wanted'", "body": "World champion Noah Lyles roared to victory in 9.79 seconds to claim gold in a dramatic men's Olympic 100m final in Paris on Sunday, August 4, the closest Olympic 100m finish in modern history as just five-thousandths of a second separated him from Jamaica's Kishane Thompson.\n\nBoth were given the rounded-up time of 9.79 seconds but the American's name carried the all-important .784 to Thompson's .789. It made Lyles the first American, male or female, to win the event since Justin Gatlin took gold in the 2004 Athens Games.\n\n\"It's the one I wanted,\" said Lyles, whose winning time was a personal best. \"It's the hard battle, it's the amazing opponents. Everybody's healthy, everybody came prepared for the fight and I wanted to prove that I'm the man amongst all of them. I'm the wolf amongst wolves.\"\n\nLyles' victory was only confirmed after a photo finish. The American said of the wait for the final results: \"I went up to Kishane and I was like, 'I'm going to be honest, bro, I think you had that one.' And I was fully prepared to see his name pop up and to see my name pop up, I'm like goodness gracious. I'm incredible.\"\n\nLyles added: \"It's been a rollercoaster, ups and downs. I'm usually a guy who likes to come out blazing in all my rounds, especially in the 200m. But the 100m, it's my first time here on the Olympic stage.\"\n\nThe relatively unknown Thompson, the fastest man this year with a best of 9.77 seconds, said he hadn't been \"fresh enough\" over the final 30 meters.\n\n\"I couldn't really see Lyles, I wasn't sure,\" 23-year-old Thompson said of the photo-finish. \"It was that close. I'm going to take it and move forward from here. Everybody loves a winner so I would have loved to win today, but I loved the competition overall.\"\n\nLyles' US teammate Fred Kerley took bronze in 9.81 seconds, just one-hundredth ahead of South African Akani Simbine, who timed 9.82 seconds.\n\n\"I don't feel any frustration because I'm facing the best in the world,\" said Kerley, the 2022 world champion and Olympic silver medallist over 100m three years ago at the Tokyo Games.\n\n\"At the end of the day, not many people can say they came to the Olympic Games,\" Kerley said. \"Whoever came off the best is the best. It's my second time around and I'm going off with a medal.\"\n\nIn an astonishing race, defending champion Marcell Jacobs of Italy was fifth in 9.85 seconds, Botswana's Letsile Tebogo sixth in 9.86 seconds, American Kenny Bednarek seventh in 9.88 seconds and Jamaican Oblique Seville eighth in 9.91 seconds.\n\nStarting in lane seven, outside Seville and inside Tebogo, Lyles got off to an average start but was soon into his stride pattern. Head tucked down through to the 40-meter mark, the American opened up, but the whole field pushed him all the way. As Lyles dipped for the line with Thompson charging alongside him, the crowd erupted and a photo-finish was called before Lyles was confirmed as gold medallist.\n\nThere was an electric pre-race atmosphere in a 69,000-capacity Stade de France, a light show and booming music keeping the crowd entertained as the sprinters adjusted their starting blocks. The lights then went off and the sprinters leaving the track to remake their entrance like prize fighters in a colosseum, with each sprinter individually introduced behind an image of their name above their flag.\n\nThompson roared, hands clenched in fists as his head rolled back. Kerley patted his heart. Lyles bounded out like a kangaroo, bouncing 20 meters down the track. Jacobs was the definition of cool, raising both arms and calmly walking to his blocks.\n\nThen came the moment where the sprinters set, at the starter's beck and call.\n\nThe wait seemed interminable. The music continued, the crowd clapped in unison, then the sprinters stood in their lanes, rocking from foot to foot and the tension was palpable, while the only sound was that of a helicopter whirring overhead. The shot was fired and the field moved as if one up the purple track to the dramatic denouement.\n\nThe photo-finish officials examined the evidence and Lyles walked away with gold to bury the demons of the Tokyo Olympics three years ago where he harvested a mere 200m bronze. Asked whether he was confident of doubling up in the 200m, an event in which he is a three-time world champion, Lyles was in no doubt.\n\n\"100 percent,\" he said. \"That's my better event and now that I've got a new PR in the 100, I'm ready to take it to the 200.\"", "source": {"uri": "lemonde.fr", "dataType": "news", "title": "Le Monde.fr"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Justin_Gatlin", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Justin Gatlin"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paris", "type": "loc", "score": 3, "label": {"uri": "8259728383", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "08:43:14", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T08:43:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T08:42:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://ktbb.com/post/?p=1344161", "title": "Title of the Page", "body": "(PARIS) -- American sprinter Noah Lyles won the gold in the 100 meters at the Paris Olympics in a photo finish, edging out Jamaican Kishane Thompson for gold and taking the title of the world's fastest man.\n\nLyles finished in 9.79 seconds -- officially 9.784 -- edging out Thompson by just .005 seconds for the gold. Thompson, after cruising through the qualifying rounds, was the favorite in the race.\n\nFellow American Fred Kerley took the bronze medal in 9.81 seconds.\n\nLyles set a personal best time of 9.79 seconds in the win. Thompson has a personal best of 9.77 seconds, but couldn't match that in Paris.\n\nHistorically a slow starter, Lyles again had to run down the fastest starters. He had a reaction time of 0.178, tied for worst in the field. Kerley, however, had a race-best 0.108 reaction time, the fastest in the field and a big reason he was able to race onto the podium.\n\nIt was the first time an American had won the 100 meters since 2004 when Justin Gatlin took the title in Athens. It's also the first time since 2004 that two Americans finished on the podium. Jamaica, led by world record holder Usain Bolt, had dominated the sprints for the last two decades.\n\nKerley, 29, had taken silver at the Tokyo Games and was looking to move up one spot on the podium. Instead, he settled for bronze with a season's best time.\n\nLyles may have been the favorite going into Paris, but he'd looked like anything but a sure thing in the heats. He finished second in his opening race and said afterward he'd misjudged the speed of the field. He finished second again in the semifinal to Jamaican Oblique Seville, who cruised to a 9.81, while Lyles had to make up for a slow start as he qualified for the final with a 9.83.\n\nThompson had run a 9.80 in the semifinals -- the fastest time of any of the qualifiers for the final -- without even showing max effort.\n\nThe defending champion from Tokyo, Italy's Lamont Marcell Jacobs, finished fifth with a time of 9.85. The time was a season's best for Jacobs, who was a surprise winner in 2021 and hasn't reached those heights in the three years since Tokyo.\n\nLyles was the defending world champion in the 100 meters from last year. He ran a 9.83 in the final in Budapest as he won gold.\n\nIt also took a run of just 9.83 seconds to win the U.S. trials earlier this summer.\n\nLyles, 27, has surged into the best in the world in the 100 meters after already establishing himself as the best at the 200 meters. Lyles has said his goal was to win double gold and the 100 meters was the hardest of those two. He won both 100 and 200 at the world championships in 2023.\n\nThe 200-meter heats begin Monday with the final on Aug. 8.\n\nLyles is also likely to compete in the 4x100 meter relay on Aug. 9 as he tries to complete a sweep of three golds like he did in Budapest at the world championships.", "source": {"uri": "ktbb.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KTBB"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": Noah Lyles (USA) came home with gold / Erick W. Rasco/Sports Illustrated\n\nSunday, after one of the most highly-anticipated events of the entire Olympics to crown the world's fastest man, Noah Lyles is a gold medal Olympian. It was not easy, as the photos would show.\n\nThe win would come down to a photo finish separated by just thousandths of a second (he beat the silver medalist, Kishane Thompson, by .005 seconds, and the bronze medalist, Fred Kerley of the U.S. by .02 seconds). The competition matched the hype of the moment, as Lyles had to battle back from a group-worst reaction time off the blocks.\n\nAfter the race, it was too close to call with a naked eye. Broadcasters called it wrong. Fans watching at home called it wrong. Even Lyles called it wrong.\n\nAccording to Sports Illustrated senior writer Greg Bishop, who was on site to tell the story, Lyles approached Thompson after the 10-second event and said, \"Hey, man,\" Lyles told him, \"I think you got it.\"\n\nOf course, no one is happier to be wrong in this instance than Lyles.\n\nLyles came to win this race and announce himself to the world. Mission accomplished. He took bronze in the 200m at Tokyo. {"uri": "8259127530", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "21:48:59", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T21:48:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T21:47:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/m-incredible-noah-lyles-backs-204311675.html", "title": "'I'm incredible': Noah Lyles backs up fighting talk with gold in dramatic Olympic 100m final", "body": "World champion, Olympic champion. Noah Lyles talked an awful lot of talk in the build-up to Paris 2024, but tonight he backed up the bluster with blistering speed on the Stade de France track, surging past the field to pip them all on the line. There can be no argument now. \"What's the title of Olympic champion?\" Lyles said, referring to \"the fastest man on the planet\" tag that goes with gold. \"Amen.\"\n\nIt doesn't matter that he didn't get near the world record he said he'd break, finishing in 9.79. It doesn't matter that the winning margin was only five thousandths of a second, a time too miniscule to comprehend. Jamaica's Kishane Thompson had been burdened with the title of heir to Usain Bolt after running the fastest time this year, and he led for 99m of this race. But Lyles fought back from dead last at 40m and they crossed the line together.\n\nThompson roared in celebration but his face dropped when the giant screen displayed \"photo finish\" by his name. They stared up from purgatory, waiting for the verdict.\n\n\"Kishane, I think you got it, man,\" Lyles told Thompson, with a pat on the shoulder.\n\nThompson looked pained. \"Come on, man!\" he shouted at the screen, urging it to move. \"Come on, man!\"\n\nLyles paced with his hands on his head. Then the result came and Lyles was off again, one moment ripping the name from his chest and raising it to the gods, the next streaking across the hammer field with the stars and stripes flapping in the wind. Thompson was awarded silver as Lyles' US teammate Fred Kerley took bronze.\n\n\"I was prepared to see his name pop up,\" Lyles said. \"I saw my name pop up and I said, 'Goodness gracious, I'm incredible'. It's the one I wanted. It's the hard battle, the amazing opponents, everybody was healthy and came to fight. I'm the wolf among wolves.\"\n\nThompson hoped to be the first Jamaican man since Bolt to win a global 100m title.\n\n\"I'm a bit disappointed but I'm super happy and grateful at the same time,\" he said. \"I wasn't patient enough with my speed and myself, I should have let my speed bring me to the line. I've learned from it. I couldn't see Noah, but I think he could see me and said, 'hey, Kishane, I thought you got it'. But he was too far to my right so I wasn't sure. This is my closest race. It was that close.\"\n\nThe US prides itself on its dominance in track and field but an American had not won this race for 20 years, not since Justin Gatlin in Athens. Bolt won the next three in Beijing, London and Rio before Italy's Lamont Marcell Jacobs stunned the world in Tokyo. Jacobs finished fifth here in 9.85 sec, behind South Africa's Akani Simbine who came fourth in 9.82.\n\nOne by one, Lyles picked them all off.\n\n\"It was hard for me to picture where we were, and I guess that was a good thing,\" he said. \"I was fortunate to have [Jamaica's] Oblique Seville next to me because all throughout the year he's been hitting that acceleration that I wasn't hitting. I wasn't going to let him go.\"\n\nThis could be just the start. Lyles still has the 200m, his strongest event, as well as a 4x100m showdown with the Jamaicans.\n\n\"There's plenty more. {"uri": "8259162369", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "22:40:13", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T22:40:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T22:38:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.nbcsandiego.com/paris-2024-summer-olympics/see-noah-lyles-win-mens-100m-in-wild-photo-finish-by-just-005-of-a-second/3587340/", "title": "See Noah Lyles win men's 100m in wild photo finish by fraction of a second", "body": "American Noah Lyles edged the competition by five-hundredths of a second in an electrifying sprint in Paris to become \"World's Fastest Man.\"\n\nIn front of a roaring crowd filling Paris' Stade de France, Noah Lyles sprinted to gold on Sunday in a photo finish for the men's 100m, edging Jamaican competitor Kishane Thompson by just 0.005 of a second.\n\nNow \"the fastest man in the world,\" the American track star waited with his seven fellow runners for a call on the wildly tight race before word came in that he'd won his first gold medal.\n\nThompson placed for silver just a fraction of a second behind Lyles. American teammate Fred Kerley, who won silver at the Tokyo Olympics, went home with the bronze with a time of 9.81.\n\nLyles' sprint was a personal best time of 9.79 in a race among eight of the fastest men in the world.\n\nWith body positioning part of the winning formula at the finish line, it's important to note Olympic rules base the official finish off the torso of the runner, from the clavicle down. So, crossing feet and arms don't count.\n\nWith his win, Lyles becomes the first American to win an Olympic gold in the 100 with his 9.79 since Justin Gatlin's 9.85 in 2004.\n\nSpeaking after the race, the Alexandria, Va., native got emotional talking about his late high school track coach, Rashawn Jackson. Jackson, a coach at Alexandria City High School, died earlier this summer, the school announced in July.\n\n\"I remember when I was running on the back stretch and I was like, 'This one's for you, man', and I thought he was going to be here to see it,\" Lyles said before pausing to fight back tears.\n\n\"I know that he's watching...because he believed that I was gonna be a 100 meter runner just as much as I was going to be a 200 meter runner.\"\n\nEarlier this year, Lyles said he wanted to win four gold medals at the Paris Games. He said winning his first in the 100m dash put him \"on Cloud 9.\"\n\n\"I just got the hardest one out of the way,\" he said, adding that he's still got competition in other races.\n\n\"I felt that [the 100m] was the one that could have slipped away from me.\"\n\nNext up for Lyles is the men's 200m on Tuesday, an event in which he is the reigning world champion.\n\nLyles won bronze at the Tokyo Olympics in the 200m, at a time when he was vocal about struggling with his mental health.\n\nOvercoming those struggles, Lyles has had an outstanding year on the track, and has made no secret of his wish to go for gold in both the 100m and 200m.", "source": {"uri": "nbcsandiego.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NBC 7 San Diego"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8260108146", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "12:43:13", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T12:43:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T12:42:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.givemesport.com/noah-lyles-last-after-40m-of-mens-100m-final-paris-olympics/", "title": "Noah Lyles was LAST after 40m of the 100m final as fascinating analysis emerges of race", "body": "Highlights Noah Lyles stunned everybody with a last-minute lead to win his first Olympic gold in a photo-finish sprint at the Stade de France. The 100m final was record-breaking; the first time every athlete ran under 10 seconds, showcasing the slim margins between the competitors. Lyles' surprise victory over Thompson by 0.005 seconds led to a heartfelt reaction.\n\nTeam USA sprinter Noah Lyles claimed a stunning 100m title at the Stade de France in the men's final, despite being outside the medal places for most of the race. Post-race analysis has shown how Lyles was sat in eighth place for the first 50m of the race before moving through the gears to claim his first Olympic gold in a remarkable victory.\n\nAthletics journalist Jonathan Gault posted on X: \"Olympic 100m race analysis. Noah Lyles was last at 30 metres and did not lead at any point until the final steps. But he was leading when it counted.\" A graphic was also posted by Gault that showed how Lyles was in seventh place as late as halfway into the race and wasn't the front-runner in the final until its very last moments.\n\nMen's 100m Final at Paris Olympics\n\nLyles pipped Jamaican Kishane Thompson to the title by 0.005 seconds, with the win being decided in a photo-finish. Thompson had looked set to claim the gold medal, after moving into the lead 30 metres into the race and remaining there until the final stages when Lyles snatched victory. The American eventually finished with a new personal best time of 9.79.\n\nGIVEMESPORT's Key Statistic: The 100m final at the Paris Olympics was the first time ever that every athlete ran under 10 seconds.\n\nThe post-race analysis also demonstrated the wafer-thin margins that separate athletes at this high level of competition, with just 0.12 seconds between Lyles in first place and Oblique Seville in eighth. Defending champion Lamont Jacobs of Italy had a disappointing end to the race and slipped out of the medal places and into fifth despite being third until the final 30 metres. The race was officially the fastest in history, with all eight men finishing in under 10 seconds.\n\nNoah Lyles' Reaction to Winning 100m Gold\n\nThe victor, Lyles, expressed his surprise at the result after the race, saying: \"I did think [Thompson] had it at the end. I went up to him while we were waiting, and said 'I think you've got that, good going', and then my name popped up, and I'm like 'oh my gosh, I'm amazing.' I'm going to be honest, I wasn't ready to see it and that's the first time I've ever said that. I wasn't ready to see it. It was hard for me to picture where we were, and I guess that was a good thing. I was fortunate to have [Jamaica's] Oblique Seville next to me because all throughout the year he's been hitting that acceleration that I wasn't hitting. I wasn't going to let him go.\"\n\nKishane Thompson's reaction to 100m final\n\nThompson reflected on his disappointment at missing out on gold, an achievement that would have made him the first Jamaican to win a global 100m title since Usain Bolt: \"I'm a bit disappointed, but I'm super happy and grateful at the same time,\" he said. \"I wasn't patient enough with my speed and myself, I should have let my speed bring me to the line. I've learned from it. I couldn't see Noah, but I think he could see me and said, 'hey, Kishane, I thought you got it'. But he was too far to my right, so I wasn't sure. This is my closest race. It was that close.\"\n\nMen's 100m final\n\nPosition\n\nAthlete\n\nCountry\n\nTime\n\n1.\n\nNoah Lyles\n\nUSA\n\n9.79\n\n2.\n\nKishane Thompson\n\nJAM\n\n9.79\n\n3.\n\nFred {"uri": "2024-08-443896662", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "21:56:35", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T21:56:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T21:56:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://eu.northjersey.com/story/sports/olympics/2024/08/04/olympic-track-live-results/74665582007/", "title": "Olympic track live updates: Noah Lyles is World's Fastest Man in 100 meters photo finish", "body": "After a disappointing performance in 2021, a fire was lit under Noah Lyles to become the fastest man in the world. He just needs to improve by 1%.\n\nSAINT-DENIS, France -- Noah Lyles is the fastest man in the world.\n\nThe U.S. sprinter won the 100 at the Paris Olympics. Lyles crossed the finish line with a gold-medal winning time of 9.79 (.784) in a photo finish to win track and field's marquee sprint event. It took a photo view to reveal Lyles had beaten Kishane Thompson by five-thousandths of a second\n\nThompson ran a 9.79 (.789) to finish second and Fred Kerley came in third, posting a time of 9.81 to get bronze.\n\nThe runners had to wait for photo review moments after the race and didn't know who won seconds after the race. Lyles told reporters following the race that he thought Thompson had won.\n\n\"I did think Thompson had it at the end,\" Lyles said. \"I went up to him when we were waiting and I said, 'I think you got that one big dog.' And then my named popped up and I'm like, 'Oh my gosh, I'm amazing.'\n\n\"I wasn't ready to see (my name). That's the first time I have ever said that in my head, that I wasn't ready to see it. ... It was hard for me to picture where we were. I guess that was a good thing.\"\n\nThe moment belonged to Lyles inside a packed house at Stade de France as soon as the announcement was made. Lyles is the first American sprinter to win an Olympic gold medal in the men's 100 since Justin Gatlin won gold at the 2004 Athens Games.\n\n\"It's the one I wanted, it's the hard battle, it's the amazing opponents,\" Lyles said after the race. \"Everybody came prepared for the fight and I wanted to prove that I'm the man among all of them, I'm the wolf among wolves.\"\n\nLyles came into the Olympics confident. He ran a personal-best 9.81 at last month. He told USA TODAY Sports that he wanted to win multiple Olympic gold medals. He's well on his way to achieving his goal.\n\nThe 100 victory earned Lyles his first ever Olympic gold medal. He received a bronze in the 200 at the Tokyo Olympics. He's also a six-time world champion gold medalist, but Sunday's Olympic gold medal in the 100 might be the crowning achievement of his career thus far.\n\n\u27a4 Get Olympics updates in your texts! Join USA TODAY Sports' WhatsApp Channel\n\n\u27a4 The USA TODAY app gets you to the heart of the news -- fast. Download for award-winning coverage, crosswords, audio storytelling, the eNewspaper and more.\n\nWhen does Noah Lyles run next?\n\nLyles will start his pursuit of 200-meter gold Monday with round 1 heats. He's in the sixth heat with Jamaica's Bryan Levell and Canada's Andre De Grasse, the defending 200-meter champion from Tokyo. De Grasse did not qualify for the 100 final. The first heat starts at 7:55 p.m. Monday in Paris (1:55 p.m. ET). The top three in each heat advance to the semifinals, which are Wednesday. The final is Thursday.\n\nKeisha Caine Bishop on Noah Lyles' dreams of turning pro\n\nNoah Lyles' mother knew her sons' dream of becoming professional track stars when they were still teenagers.\n\n\"In 10th grade they wanted to go professional out of high school and I was like are you crazy,\" Keisha Caine Bishop, the mother of Noah and Josephus, told USA TODAY Sports this summer.\n\nIn July 2016 when Noah was 19 years old, he and his younger brother, Josephus, 18 at the time, turned professional and signed a contract with Adidas instead of competing collegiately for the University of Florida.\n\n\"I had to go back and apologize,\" Caine Bishop said. \"I realized that's not fair to kill somebody's dream, especially if they are willing to do the work, and they were willing to do the work.\"\n\nNoah and Josephus have been running professionally since. Josephus isn't on the Olympic team in Paris but ran the 100 and 200 at Olympic trials. - Tyler Dragon\n\nNBC broadcaster incorrectly calls 100 meters race winner\n\nIf you thought Noah Lyles missed out on the gold medal in the 100-meter dash, you weren't the only one.\n\nNBC broadcaster Leigh Diffey was into the moment like the rest of the audience taking in the 100 meters, but he seemed a bit more decisive with his call than what the eye told. As the sprinters crossed the line, the cameras panned to Jamaican sprinter Kishane Thompson and Diffey declared Thompson the winner, not Lyles.\n\n\"Jamaica's gonna do it, Kishane Thompson is a gold medalist, on debut,\" Diffey declared, before going silent.\n\nThe competitors were all huddled waiting for photo evidence of the finish. When the photo did come in, it was Lyles who was the winner of the race, by five-thousandths of a second over Thompson.\n\nLyles' victory secures the USA's first gold medal in the 100 meter in 20 years, and solidifies his standing as the fastest man in the world. - Joseph Rivera\n\nAccording to World Athletics, it's the first time in history that eight men have broken 10 seconds in a wind-legal race.\n\nUSA's Juliette Whittaker makes it through to 800 final\n\nJuliette Whittaker will be the only American woman in the 800-meter final after squeaking through the semifinals Sunday night.\n\nWhittaker, 20, nabbed the third and final 800-meter spot on Team USA at the Olympic trials but is now the only one of them left. Allie Wilson did not make it out of the first round, and Nia Akins fell short in the semifinals.\n\nAfter making the final and running a personal best of 1 minute, 57.76 seconds, Whittaker said she feels like she's playing with house money now.\n\n\"I think I'm just so excited now just to see what I can do tomorrow, without any expectation,\" she said. \"Even if I get last in the final, I will be overjoyed just to make it that far. So yeah, I'm just excited.\" - Tom Schad\n\n3 Americans qualify for men's 1500-meter final\n\nThere will be plenty of red, white and blue in the men's 1500-meter final.\n\nAll three Americans left in the field qualified for the final, with Yared Nuguse and Hobbs Kessler finishing first and second in one of the two semifinals to advance. Both ran under 3 minutes, 32 seconds.\n\nCole Hocker also cruised into the final after placing third in his semi and spending most of the race shadowing two of the medal favorites: Jacob Ingebrigsten of Norway and Josh Kerr of Great Britain.\n\n\"That was just the very last bit of confidence that I needed, heading into the final,\" said Hocker, who ran collegiately at Oregon. - Tom Schad\n\nUSA's Vashti Cunningham finishes fifth in women's high jump\n\nSAINT-DENIS, France - Team USA women's high jumper Vashti Cunningham missed out on a medal for the third consecutive Olympics Sunday. Still, despite a troubling back injury this season, she recorded her highest Olympic finish ever (fifth place). The daughter of former Philadelphia Eagles quarterback Randall Cunningham cleared the bar at 1.86, 1.91 and 1.95 meters, but failed on three attempts to clear 1.98 to fall out of medal contention.\n\nThe gold medal went to Ukrainian Yaroslava Mahuchikh, who cleared 2.0 meters in fewer attempts than silver medalist Nicola Olyslagers of Australia. Ukrainian Iryna Gerashchenko and Australia's Eleanor Patterson tied for the bronze.\n\nCunningham narrowly qualified for the Paris Olympics, but entered ranked No. 7 in the world. She recorded finishes of 13th at the Rio Games in 2016 and sixth at the Tokyo Games in 2021.\n\n\"I felt good about my performance. I was happy when I made the bar and when I missed the bar, I knew what I was doing wrong,\" Cunningham said. \"I just need to go back to the drawing board and work on a few things.\"\n\nAsked if she's committed to making a run at the 2028 Games in Los Angeles, Cunningham said, \"Absolutely. I'm only going to be 30 years old, guys.\" - Chase Goodbread\n\nWeather forecast for 100 final\n\nThere is no rain in the forecast for the men's 100 final. It's expected to be slightly cloudy and 71 degrees at the start of the race. The women's sprinters in Saturday's 100 final had to deal with rainy conditions.\n\nAll three American sprinters advance to 100 final\n\nNoah Lyles, Fred Kerley and Kenny Bednarek all advanced to the 100 showdown Sunday night. Lyles and Kerley placed second in their respective heats. Bednarek qualified on time.\n\nJamaica's Kishane Thompson (9.80) and Oblique Seville (9.81) have the top times entering the final.\n\nJamaica's Kishane Thompson won his third and final heat at 9.80 in what was a quick semifinal. Fred Kerley placed second at 9.84 to get the second automatic qualifying spot.\n\nNoah Lyles second in heat, qualifies for 100 final\n\nSAINT-DENIS, France -- Noah Lyles is going to have to make some adjustments ahead of the 100 final.\n\nLyles placed second his first semifinal heat, running a 9.83. Jamaica's Oblique Seville won the heat and looked at Lyles as he crossed the finish line in a personal-best time of 9.81.\n\nLyles lost to Great Britain's Louie Hinchliffe in the opening round. But all that matters is he qualified for Sunday's final.\n\nThe top two from each heat plus the next two fastest times advance to the final.\n\nHow many events is Noah Lyles going to run at Paris Olympics?\n\nNoah Lyles is slated to run the 100, 200 and 4x100 relay.\n\nQuincy Hall, Michael Norman, Christopher Bailey advance to 400 semis\n\nSAINT-DENIS, France -- All three Team USA runners advanced in the men's 400.\n\nChristopher Bailey took second in the first heat of the men's 400 to move on to the semifinal. Heat No. 1 also featured Great Britian's Matthew Hudson-Smith who has the fastest time in the world this year (43.74). Hudson-Smith won the first heat timing at 44.78.\n\nMichael Norman ran a fast 44.10 to win the second heat.\n\nQuincy Hall, the U.S. Olympic track and field trials gold medalist, sped by Australia's Reece Holder down the home stretch and crossed the line with a first-place time of 44.28 in the fourth heat.\n\nThe top three in each heat automatically advanced to Tuesday's semifinal round. Norman qualified to the semifinal with the fastest time.\n\nWhat time does Noah Lyles run the 100 semifinals?\n\nThe semifinal in the 100 is at 2:05 p.m. ET. Lyles is in the first heat and will run in lane No. 4.\n\nJamaica's Kishane Thompson is the fastest man in the world this year with a world-leading time of 9.77. Thompson eased up in the opening round in Paris and still ran a 10.00 to finish first in his heat. Thompson's Jamaican teammate, Oblique Seville, has defeated Lyles before and can make the podium.\n\nLyles' American teammates, Kenny Bednarek and Fred Kerley, are threats to reach the podium. Bednarek and Kerley both ran 9.97 to advance to the semis.\n\nThe defending Olympic champ, Marcell Jacobs of Italy, can't be counted out, either.\n\nWhat is world record in 100?\n\nThe world record in the 100 is 9.58 set by Jamaica's Usain Bolt in 2009.\n\nWhat is Olympic record in the 100?\n\nUsain Bolt ran 9.63 to win a gold medal and set the Olympic record at the 2012 London Games.\n\nLast time American won gold medal in men's 100 at Olympics\n\nJustin Gatlin was the last American male to win an Olympic gold medal in the 100. Gatlin won gold at the 2004 Athens Games. Team USA's best medal in the 100 since then has been silver medals won at the 2016 Olympics (Gatlin) and 2020 Games (Fred Kerley).", "source": {"uri": "northjersey.com", "dataType": "news", "title":
