{"uri": "8259066734", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "20:24:40", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T20:24:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T20:23:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://thyblackman.com/2024/08/04/noah-lyles-worlds-fastest-man-wins-gold-in-100-meters-at-paris-olympics/", "title": "Noah Lyles: World's Fastest Man Wins Gold in 100 Meters at Paris Olympics.", "body": "(ThyBlackMan.com) In a breathtaking finish at the Paris Olympics, Noah Lyles emerged victorious as the world's fastest man, claiming the gold medal in the 100 meters sprint. With a time of 9.79 seconds, Lyles crossed the finish line in a dramatic photo finish, edging out Kishane Thompson and Fred Kerley. The moment of triumph was not only a personal achievement for Lyles but also a significant milestone for American sprinting, as he became the first American to win the Olympic gold in the men's 100 meters since Justin Gatlin in 2004.\n\nNoah Lyles' rise to the pinnacle of sprinting has been nothing short of extraordinary. Born on July 18, 1997, in Gainesville, Florida, Lyles showed early signs of his athletic prowess. His parents, Keisha Caine and Kevin Lyles, were both competitive athletes, which perhaps laid the foundation for his future success. Growing up in a family that valued sports, Lyles and his younger brother Josephus, who is also a sprinter, were encouraged to pursue their athletic ambitions from a young age.\n\nLyles attended T.C. Williams High School in Alexandria, Virginia, where he began to make a name for himself in track and field. His impressive performances in high school competitions caught the attention of scouts and led to a scholarship offer from the University of Florida. However, Lyles decided to turn professional straight out of high school, signing with Adidas in 2016. This bold move set the stage for his rapid ascent in the world of professional sprinting.\n\nLyles' journey to the Paris Olympics was marked by numerous victories and setbacks. He first burst onto the international scene in 2016, when he won gold in the 200 meters at the World U20 Championships in Bydgoszcz, Poland. This victory was a precursor to his future dominance in the sport. However, his path was not without challenges. Injuries and the pressure of living up to the high expectations often tested his resolve.\n\nIn 2018, Lyles established himself as a force to be reckoned with by winning the Diamond League title in both the 100 meters and 200 meters. His charismatic personality and unique fashion sense, often sporting colorful hair and eclectic outfits, made him a fan favorite. But it was his performance on the track that truly set him apart. In 2019, he won gold in the 200 meters at the World Championships in Doha, Qatar, solidifying his status as one of the world's top sprinters.\n\nThe atmosphere at Stade de France was electric on the night of the 100 meters final. Fans from around the world had gathered to witness the showdown of the fastest men on the planet. The anticipation was palpable as the athletes took their positions on the starting blocks. Lyles, with his trademark focus and determination, was ready to seize the moment.\n\nAs the starting gun fired, the sprinters exploded off the blocks. The race was neck-and-neck, with Lyles, Thompson, and Kerley matching each other stride for stride. The tension reached its peak as they approached the finish line, with no clear winner in sight. It was only after a few agonizing moments of photo review that Lyles was declared the winner, his time of 9.79 seconds cementing his place in history.\n\nThe reaction to Lyles' victory was immediate and overwhelming. Social media platforms were flooded with messages of congratulations and admiration. Celebrities, fellow athletes, and fans from around the world praised Lyles for his incredible achievement. His victory was seen as a triumph not only for himself but also for American sprinting, which had been longing for a new champion in the men's 100 meters.\n\nOne notable fan reaction came from Usain Bolt, the legendary sprinter and former world record holder in the 100 meters. Bolt took to Twitter to congratulate Lyles, calling him the \"next big thing\" in sprinting. This endorsement from one of the greatest sprinters of all time added an extra layer of significance to Lyles' victory.\n\nIn his post-race interviews, Lyles was emotional as he reflected on his journey and the support he had received along the way. He dedicated his win to his family, coaches, and fans, emphasizing the importance of their unwavering belief in him. Lyles also spoke about the challenges he had faced, including dealing with injuries and the mental pressure of competing at the highest level. His candid and heartfelt words resonated with many, further endearing him to fans worldwide.\n\nNoah Lyles' victory in the 100 meters at the Paris Olympics is more than just a personal achievement; it represents a new era in sprinting. His success has inspired a new generation of athletes to pursue their dreams with passion and determination. Lyles' journey from a young boy with big dreams to the fastest man in the world is a testament to the power of perseverance and hard work.\n\nLyles' influence extends beyond the track. His vibrant personality, distinctive style, and commitment to using his platform for positive change have made him a role model for many. He has been vocal about issues such as mental health, racial equality, and the importance of staying true to oneself. His advocacy and authenticity have earned him respect and admiration from fans and fellow athletes alike.\n\nAs Noah Lyles basks in the glory of his Olympic gold medal, the future looks incredibly bright. He has expressed his desire to continue competing at the highest level and to break more records. With his combination of speed, charisma, and determination, there is no doubt that Lyles will continue to be a dominant force in the world of sprinting.\n\nFans eagerly await his next races and the possibility of witnessing more historic moments. For now, however, they celebrate his incredible achievement in Paris and the excitement he has brought to the sport of track and field. Noah Lyles, the world's fastest man, has etched his name in the annals of Olympic history, and his legacy will undoubtedly inspire generations to come.\n\nNoah Lyles' victory in the 100 meters at the Paris Olympics is a momentous occasion in the world of athletics. His journey, marked by determination, resilience, and unwavering support, has culminated in a triumph that will be remembered for years to come. As he continues to blaze a trail on and off the track, Noah Lyles stands as a shining example of what can be achieved through hard work, passion, and the belief that anything is possible.", "source": The competition matched the hype of the moment.\n\nAfter the race, it was too close to call with a naked eye. Broadcasters called it wrong. Fans watching at home called it wrong. Even Lyles called it wrong.\n\nAccording to Sports Illustrated senior writer Greg Bishop, who was on-site to tell the story, Lyles approached Thompson after the 10-second event and said, \"Hey, man,\" Lyles told him, \"I think you got it.\"\n\nOf course, no one is happier to be wrong in this instance than Lyles.\n\nLyles came to win this race and announce himself to the world. {"uri": "2024-08-443897750", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "21:59:30", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T21:59:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T21:51:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.on3.com/pro/news/noah-lyles-celebrates-with-his-mom-after-incredible-100m-gold-medal-win/", "title": "Noah Lyles celebrates with his mom after incredible 100M gold medal win", "body": "American sprinter Noah Lyles is officially the world's fastest man. He managed to pull off a win in razor-thin fashion, after he started out slow in the blocks in Sunday's 100-meter dash final. In bringing home the gold medal, Lyles became the first American to win the event in 20 years. Lyles finished with a time of 9.79 seconds, barely edging out Kishane Thompson of Jamaica.\n\nOnce he won, Lyles had to go into the stands to hug his mother, who was there for the special occasion.\n\nIn a finish for the ages in the 100-meter dash, America's Noah Lyles narrowly edged out Jamaica's Kishane Thompson by five-thousandths of a second to take the gold medal.\n\nIt was as much of a photo finish as there's been in the Olympics in years. And even with the photo it's somewhat hard to determine the winner at the finish.\n\nThe finish was so close that Lyles and Thompson spent an agonizingly long few seconds simply looking up at the scoreboard with their hands on their head after the race, waiting for the winner to be announced.\n\nNoah Lyles' reaction to bringing home the gold medal\n\nWhen Lyles learned he had won, he reacted jubilantly, bouncing up and down the track, taking his pinned USA label from the front of his jersey and holding it up to the crowd. He then turned to the camera and yelled, \"America, I told you!\"\n\nNoah Lyles posted a 9.78-second time in the event to take home the gold.\n\nHe needed every bit of it, too. That was something he might not necessarily have factored in when he initially arrived in Paris, perhaps just a touch overconfident.\n\nLyles ran a 10.04 second time in qualifying, watching some finish ahead of him. He remarked afterward that he was surprised by the level of competition.\n\n\"These boys said they ain't coming to play,\" Lyles said, via ESPN. \"And I guess that's my first lesson in underestimating the power of an Olympics. When somebody's on the line, they say they're going to give it their all or nothing.\n\n\"The plan was first. But it didn't happen. Second is fine. We'll make sure from here on out it's first ... Now I don't have to hold back.\"\n\nNoah Lyles certainly held nothing back in the final of the 100-meter dash, running a blazing time to secure the gold medal. Now he'll get the chance to add to his tally by taking the 200-meter dash, an event he also had circled coming into Paris.\n\nLyles was the reigning 100-meter dash World Champion and took home a bronze medal in the 200-meter dash during the 2020 Tokyo Olympics. Here's how Lyles finished in 100-meter dash, highlights", "body": "Outside of Sha'Carri Richardson, sprinter Noah Lyles is arguably the most well-known American track and field athlete at the 2024 Paris Olympics.\n\nPrior to this year's games, Lyles had said he wanted to win gold in each of the four major sprinting events in Paris: the 100-meter dash, 200-meter dash, 4x100-meter relay, and 4x200-meter relay. Lyles had his first shot at Olympic immortality today with the 100-meter.\n\n2024 PARIS OLYMPICS: Follow USA TODAY's full coverage here\n\nThe finals were not Lyles' first race of the day, though. The 100-meter semifinals took place earlier today as well, with Lyles finishing second in his heat, two-hundredths of a second off the winner, Jamaica's Oblique Seville (9.81). That result spawned this viral picture of Lyles eyeing down the man who beat him.\n\nAnother Jamaican, Kishane Thompson, also ran a 9.8 in the semifinals to seed himself above Lyles. Still, despite having not won either of the two qualifying races leading up to the finals, Lyles was still a popular pick to win gold.\n\nHere's how the race played out.\n\nOlympics News: Stephen Nedoroscik won bronze for pommel horse, and then went viral\n\nThe race was tremendously close. Not even the announcers knew who won, thinking that Thompson earned the win on initial viewing. But it was Lyles who barely edged out every other racer. Even on repeat views in slow motion, it was hard to determine just when Lyles finished compared to the other athletes.\n\nFirst-, second- and third-place finishers win gold, silver and bronze, respectively.\n\nLyles' win gave America its first gold in the 100-meter since Justin Gatlin at the 2004 Athens Olympics. Lyles' dream of winning four golds at these games is still alive and well.\n\nHeats for the 200-meter will happen on Monday. Lyles' first race will happen at 8:30 a.m. ET. {"uri": "8259174665", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "22:58:10", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T22:58:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T22:57:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.postandcourier.com/arena/the-spun/this-insane-photo-shows-how-close-the-mens-100m-dash-was/article_1a2d7ed7-e7a0-542f-bd2d-8d6561113cc2.html", "title": "This Insane Photo Shows How Close The Men's 100M Dash Was", "body": "Noah Lyles narrowly won Sunday's 100-meter dash to earn his first career Olympic gold medal. He didn't leave any time to spare.\n\nThe race was so close that NBC's announcers declared Jamaica's Kishane Thompson the winner. However, Lyles furiously made up ground to cross the finish line five-thousandths of a second earlier.\n\nFred Kerley was right behind them, finishing .02 seconds behind the gold and silver medalists at 9.81 seconds. Everyone anxiously awaited the review before learning the winner.\n\nNo race will bring more meaning to the term \"photo finish,\" so here's a snapshot of the dramatic ending at Paris from Dan Wetzel of Yahoo Sports:\n\nAs explained on the NBC broadcast, the runner's chest must cross the finish line first to declare a winner. But the 27-year-old needed a superb finish to medal, let alone earn the title of \"Fastest Man in the World.\"\n\nLyles will look to add more Olympic gold to his collection by winning the men's {"uri": "8259056528", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "20:12:30", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T20:12:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T20:11:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://uproxx.com/sports/noah-lyles-won-gold-100-meter-mens-olympic-final-video/", "title": "Noah Lyles Won Gold By .005 Seconds In the Greatest 100m Olympic Final", "body": "Noah Lyles has had an eventful past year, and while he came into the Olympics as the reigning world champion, he was not considered the favorite for the gold medal. That title belonged to Jamaica's Kishane Thompson, who had the fastest time in the world this year (9.77) and ran the fastest time in the semifinals (9.80).\n\nIn fact, Lyles hadn't won either of his first two races at the Olympics, coming second in both the preliminary heat and in his semifinal. However, they don't hand out medals for the heats or semis, and when it came time for the finals, we were treated to perhaps the greatest 100 meter race in history. Thompson came out hot, pushed by American Fred Kerley, but it was Lyles who ran them down on the outside to win gold in a photo finish by an outrageous five thousandths of a second.\n\nBoth Lyles and Thompson ran 9.79, but Lyles did it in 9.784, while Thompson was 9.789 -- with a reminder the timing is to your torso, not your feet.\n\nKerley finished in bronze medal position with a 9.81, while South Africa's Akani Simbane missed out on a medal by the narrowest of margins, running a 9.82. It was a truly incredible race and the tension only built in the immediate aftermath, as all three medalists stared up at the board waiting for official results to come through, as Thompson thought he had won, thinking Kerley was closest to him not realizing Lyles was on the outside right alongside as well.", "source": {"uri": "uproxx.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "UPROXX"}, "authors": "https://uproxx.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/nl2.jpg?w=640", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9790103", "eventUri": "eng-9790103", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": {"uri": "2024-08-444201691", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "07:33:51", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T07:33:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T07:07:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.nytimes.com/athletic/5680407/2024/08/05/lyles-100m-mann-stickman-biomechanics-start/", "title": "How Noah Lyles became Olympic 100m champion: A 300-page textbook, biomechanics and a stickman", "body": "Sixty metres into the men's 100 metre Olympic final in Paris and Noah Lyles is third. He is three hundredths of a second down on Jamaica's Kishane Thompson and his compatriot Fred Kerley.\n\nYet, and this may sound bizarre, that is exactly where he needs to be.\n\nLyles has unmatched top-end speed. He wins like Usain Bolt used to, opening up his stride (to a ridiculous 2.5 metres) and eating up ground on others before cruising past. He holds form while they struggle and decelerate.\n\nThe headline is Lyles winning by five hundredths of a second in the closest men's 100m Olympic final ever -- and the hardest for which to qualify. Lyles (9.78) ran the fastest time in an Olympic 100m final since Bolt's Olympic record (9.63) in London back in 2012.\n\nHis victory was never in question over that final 40 metres. Lyles can close anyone. He did it in 2023 to win the World Championships and again in trials to reach Paris.\n\nThe final frontier for him to become Olympic champion was the start... so here's the story of how a 75-year-old and a stickman helped give Lyles the edge.\n\n\"Your reaction times suck,\" says Ralph Mann.\n\nIt is July 2023 and the former Olympian -- he won 400m hurdles silver at the 1972 Munich Olympics -- who holds a PhD in biomechanics, is helping to coach Lyles on his block starts.\n\nAt Lyles' training base in Clermont, Florida, Mann, now 75, has a marquee set up by the side of the track. There are a series of cameras pointed at the blocks, and a laptop running software that is going to eke the final per cent out of Lyles' starts.\n\nOver the last 40 years, Mann has watched and collected data on over 500 of the best athletes. \"We know what it takes to be an elite starter,\" he says. Mann has written an epic 300-page plus textbook on the mechanics of sprinting and hurdling. What he doesn't know isn't worth knowing.\n\nMann has applied that knowledge and decades of experience into a software, created in 1999, which generates a stickman that overlays the video of the sprinter in the blocks. Adjusted for body size and weight (to Lyles), it shows where the limbs should be as the sprinter sets and springs out the blocks. If you've ever played a Mario Kart ghost race, it's that, just applied to sprinting.\n\nThey can go frame-by-frame to see how Lyles moves compared to the most effective/efficient method, and it becomes a coaching tool for the session with real-time feedback.\n\nLyles' problems were that his hips were too far back when he set and his foot turnover was poor on the first few steps. Compared to the stickman, Lyles was not compact enough in the drive phase (as the athletes get up to speed), his feet were coming up too high between steps and his contact time (how long the feet are on the floor) was too long. The ankles weren't rigid enough, either.\n\nIn short, there was plenty to improve.\n\nIt meant that steps four to seven, which are all about extending range after getting out with the first three, would come up short compared to better starters. Mann explains to Lyles that the only way he can get faster is by reducing the time between steps and keeping contact time minimal. White tape was put horizontally across the track to give Lyles a visual representation of where he should be landing at specific steps (three and seven).\n\nLyles knows how the model works. When he asks Mann what he has set it at, he replies \"what we need to make you famous\". Lyles speaks about doing what works according to the model, in terms of his form, rather than what feels good. He has fully bought in.\n\nHe is loud and, to some, borderline arrogant, but Lyles shows vulnerability with Mann.\n\n\"Let's see your precious model beat me,\" he says, imploring Mann to set the model at better than Lyles' absolute best. \"Let it run away, let me get embarrassed,\" says Lyles. At one stage, Mann stands over Lyles in the blocks and physically moves his hips forwards in the set position. Lyles, half-joking, half-serious, says he feels like he isn't even in the blocks.\n\nThere were green shoots of this working in February.\n\nAfter losing six previous times, Lyles finally beat Christian Coleman over 60m indoors. Coleman (6.34) is the world record holder, but Lyles edged him out by one hundredth to take the U.S. indoors title in 6.43. Coleman got out faster, quicker with his foot turnover and first to reach his second step, but Lyles was in contention enough (sixth at halfway, 30m) to close hard and took it on the line -- you'll see a theme developing.\n\nFor a guy who could not break 6.5 seconds in 2023, it was huge. Coleman then beat Lyles at the World Indoors in Glasgow in March, but Lyles ran 6.47 in the semi-final and 6.44 in the final.\n\nFast forward to Paris.\n\nMann was right: Lyles' reaction times do suck, by Olympic standards anyway. He was the joint-slowest to react in the final (178ms, with Letsile Tebogo), 26th of 27 among semi-finalists (167ms) and 46 of the 70 men in the heats, who did not false start, reacted quicker (161ms).\n\nThat is one of the hardest parts to train. Nobody wants to false start in the Olympics and the 80,000 capacity Stade de France is loud. Lyles responding slower than others did not help, but it would not be the difference between gold and silver.\n\nLyles, in lane seven because he finished third in his semi-final, takes his second and third steps before Thompson in lane three. It shows great foot turnover given he was the last to get out.\n\nHis form and mechanics are good, even if he doesn't accelerate as quickly through the drive phase as the Jamaican, or Tokyo 2020 100m champion Marcell Jacobs. Lyles was last up until 40 metres, but by 30 metres was moving at the same speed as Thompson.\n\nThe 60m split is the one that matters: 6.44. Lyles is suddenly third, having jumped four places from the 50m mark, going past Marcell Jacobs (lane nine), Akani Simbine (lane five), Tobogo and Oblique Seville. The latter two are outside and inside Lyles respectively.\n\n\"I was fortunate to have Seville next to me because, all throughout the year, he's been hitting that acceleration that I wasn't hitting,\" said Lyles. \"I wasn't going to let him go.\"\n\nThough as Mann once said: \"Noah's biggest competition is Noah.\" His 60m split in the final was only one hundredth off what he managed at the U.S. Indoors. At the Paris Diamond League in June 2023, Lyles won in 9.97, going through 60m in 6.55. He saved one of his best starts ever for the final.\n\nThompson and Fred Kerley went through 60m in 6.41 seconds, but both had already well hit terminal velocity and were slowing. Lyles peaked slightly later than the pair and held form for longer, slower to decelerate.\n\nLyles' extra stride length adds up. Across the full race, Lyles (44) took one fewer step than Thompson (45). The Jamaican might dwarf Lyles for arm or leg size, but strong arms can only pull an athlete to the line a certain amount. There is no replacement for good mechanics.\n\nLyles closed the last 40 metres in 3.35 seconds, the fastest in the race. Thompson closed in 3.38. Five others, barring Simbine who finished hard in fourth, covered the last 40 metres in 3.4 seconds or slower. \"I wasn't patient enough with my speed -- I should have let it bring me to the line\" accepted Thompson.\n\nIn his book -- it's a textbook, really -- Mann lists a series of athletes as the best in certain categories. There are the most talented, the most professional, most driven and best representatives of the sport, but he puts Lyles as one of his favourites.\n\nAfter 100m gold in Paris, and a legitimate shot at doing the double with the 200m, Lyles ought to put Mann in his favourites too.\n\n\"Ralph Mann, before I left for Paris, said this is how close first and second is going to be away from each other,\" said Lyles, bringing his index finger and thumb close together to gesture an inch. \"I can't believe how right he was.\"", "source": {"uri": "nytimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The New York {"uri": "2024-08-443922319", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "23:04:49", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T23:04:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T22:20:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://bleacherreport.com/articles/10130784-noah-lyles-says-i-told-you-america-i-got-this-after-winning-olympic-gold-medal", "title": "Noah Lyles Says 'I Told You America I Got This!' After Winning Olympic Gold Medal", "body": "The track star said he could be the person who gave the United States its first gold medal in the 100-meter since 2004, and he did on Sunday.\n\nAfter winning gold in a miraculous photo finish, Lyles posted some photos from the race with the caption, \"I Told You America I Got This!\"\n\nAfter the race, he also talked about how having the gold medal in his hands \"fueled\" him.\n\nLyles ran a personal-best 9.784-second time, but the race couldn't have been much closer. He edged out Jamaica's Kishane Thompson by just 0.005 seconds in a race that came down to a photo review.\n\nLyles said that he wasn't even aware he had won until a few moments after the race was over. He even told Thompson that he thought he had won.\n\n\"We were waiting for the names to pop up, and I'm going to be honest, I came over [to Thompson] and I was like: 'I think you got that one, big dawg!'\" Lyles said per ESPN's Coley Harvey. \"Something said I need to lean, and I was like, 'I'm going to lean,' because it's that type of race.\"\n\nThompson entered Sunday's race with the fastest time in the world this year at 9.77 seconds, but Lyles had just enough to take gold at the Olympics. America's Fred Kerley won bronze with a time of 9.81 seconds.\n\nLyles, 27, earned his first gold medal with Sunday's win. {"uri": "8259114227", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "21:31:46", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T21:31:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T21:28:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/noah-lyles-wins-olympics-100m-212625193.html", "title": "Noah Lyles wins Olympics 100m final by 0.005sec", "body": "For Noah Lyles, a masterplan three years in the making came down to five thousandths of a second. This shamelessly extravagant showman, the self-appointed heir to Usain Bolt, is the Olympic 100m champion after one of the tensest, tightest finals ever seen.\n\nJust 12 hundredths separated first from seventh, but in the end the glittering lights of the Stade de France flashed in the red, white and blue of the United States, just as he had envisaged it. It is becoming a custom at these Olympics for athletics champions to mark their triumphs by ringing a giant bell. Lyles, rest assured, rang it for all it was worth, as if to herald the dawn of his sprint supremacy.\n\nThe winning time, 9.79 seconds, was the fastest of his life. Naturally, it paled against the 9.69 and 9.64 that Bolt ran in the first two of his three Olympic finals, but this was beside the point: Lyles had chosen these Paris Games as his moment to become an icon, and he delivered.\n\nBounding halfway down the back straight as soon as his name was announced, waggling his fingers frenziedly in the warm-up, you feared he would burn himself out before the starting gun. But he screened out all the diversions - the Jamaican threat, the ominous countdown music, the interminable hold in the blocks - to produce his finest race under the greatest strain. \"This is the one I wanted,\" he said. \"I'm the wolf among wolves.\"\n\nSometimes Lyles' braggadocio can grate. Sometimes his habit of asking his every move to be documented by a Netflix crew can smack of a man with a Messiah complex. Now, though, he can serve up the ultimate rebuke to his critics: a first Olympic gold medal, and the undisputed status as the fastest man in the world.\n\nIt was far too close for comfort, with Lyles and Jamaica's Kishane Thompson dipping for the line in a photo finish. But the American, who takes hubris to levels at which even Bolt might have blushed, will not care one iota. His quest to be the dominant track star of his generation is proceeding exactly to plan.\n\nIt was Lyles' sheer composure that told in the end. Where Thompson, just 23, faltered over the final strides, Lyles, with six world golds already banked, hit a top speed with which nobody could live. Although he left it late - as he always does in the 100, not his specialist event - he ultimately timed his surge to perfection. Draping himself in the Stars and Stripes, he posed for the cameras as though taunting his detractors. At last, he has the prize to demonstrate why he turns up to press conferences declaring: \"The champ is here!\"\n\nWhile Lyles might not be to everybody's taste, with his ostentatious nail art and his penchant for wearing a cap that says \"Made It\" under the peak, he is essential for his sport. He is the most charismatic figure in this field by a distance, never passing up the chance to talk up his credentials as a saviour.\n\nThompson, by contrast, is young and unused to such intensity of scrutiny: after one of his heats here, he refused interviews and instead fist-bumped every interviewer with the words \"one love\". Each to his own, but Lyles understands the game. He recognises that in this of all events, the personality matters as much as the sport, and he is only too happy to fill the void.\n\nLyles said he knew this final would be resolved by the most slender margins. \"A guy in biomechanics came down before I came down and said, 'It's going to be this much, that's how close it's going to be.' And, gosh, he was right. I came with aggression, but after that 9.83 in the semi-final I was done with aggression. My sports therapist told me, 'You need to let go, you're holding on. Let go and release it.'\"\n\nHe can be a bundle of contradictions. For all the self-agrandisement, he has spoken openly of his struggles with depression and has brought no fewer than three therapists with him to Paris. With his fame having grown hugely through his Netflix exposure, he has been besieged by selfie-chasers at the athletes' village. At times, he said, he has even needed to find quiet corners of the cafeteria with his girlfriend, the Jamaican sprinter Junelle Bromfield, to collect his thoughts. But after this crowning glory, he will bask in the glow to his heart's content.\n\nIt was a luminously high-quality final, with Louie Hinchliffe the first 100m semi-finalist in Olympic history to run under 10 seconds without making the cut. The duel had been drawn, as Lyles and Oblique Seville stared each other down over the final strides.\n\nAthletics needed a final like this, frankly, and it needed a champion like Lyles. The spectacle formed the sharpest contrast to the tumbleweed version in Tokyo three years ago, when Italy's Lamont Marcell Jacobs, a self-styled \"crazy long jumper\", bolted from obscurity to claim the crowd. This time, there was both a passionate crowd and a winner worthy of the occasion.\n\nLyles, you sense, is only just starting in his bid to colonise the headlines. As a 200m specialist, it is his abiding mission to hunt down Bolt's world record of 19.19. For now, though, the 100m title, the most precious of all in Olympic sport, is his. \"I hope you guys like Noah,\" he grinned, \"because I got a lot more coming.\"\n\nThe image shows that Lyles was eighth and last after 40m, made up five places by 60m and and was ahead only on the finish line.\n\nThompson led from 30m and lost it on the line. Kerley had silver up to 80m before Lyle's storming finish.\n\nIn June, Seville beat Lyles during the 100m in the Racers Grand Prix held in Kingston, Jamaica. Seville stared down Lyles at the finish line as they crossed.\n\nHe said he was coming to build a legacy and to win three gold medals. Plenty of schadenfreude was waiting for him but he backed up his braggadocio.\n\nIt was a world record time for fourth, fifth, sixth, seventh and eighth places.\n\nLyles, Simbine and Jacobs (the defending champions) all ran personal bests.\n\nAmazing catch-up by Lyles after Thompson perhaps became preoccupied with Kerley outside him. He wins by five-thousandths of a second.\n\nThat's one of the closest finals we've seen, 12 hundredths of a second between first and last place.\n\nHe somehow made it from fourth to first in the last 20m and both men reciorded 9.79:\n\nAfter being held on the start line for a good two minutes longer than necessary. Too long a build-up. The sprinters are getting frustrated as we wait for the music to end. Is that the reason for the delay? Blimey. Into the blocks at last.\n\nThompson starts like a train but Lyles powers through at the end to make it look like a dead heat. Photo finish. Oddly Seville was a victim of nominative determinism and leant back at the finish which cost him a number of places.\n\nThompson had that won but seemed to think he only had to beat Kerley and hadn't bargained for Lyles' explosive finish.\n\nComes out with his arms crossed like a West Ham fan then yells and enacts the moment Dr David Banner turns into the Hulk. Noah Lyles also roars and then bounces 30m up the track, pogoing away and shouting 'Yeah!'\n\nKenny Bednarek jumped the gun... on his entrance. Hopefully for the last time tonight.\n\nTo soundtrack the light show at Stade de France. Enjoyin the lights racing up the purple 100m straight.\n\n'The time is now,' he says. And we see footage of The Fastest Men on the Planet\u2122 played to a shonky cover version of Time After Time.\n\nMichael Johnson goes for Thompson, Jess Ennis-Hill exposes herself to splinters and says Jamaica and Denise Lewis splits the difference and plumps for Oblique (/) Seville.\n\nJust skimming through the exchanges and it appears that Kishane Thompson is the overwhelming favourite now at a best priced 4-6. Noah Lyles, favourite yesterday, is now as long as 5-2 and Oblique Seville is 14-1.\n\nThompson is 23, ran his PB, 9.77sec, in the Jamaica trials and has been tipped all week by Usain Bolt to win for the Rock.\n\nYou can follow all the action from the track and field with Richard Aikman over here.\n\nHughes was fifth with 10.01. Richardson doesn't make the final.\n\n\"That's his level at the moment and he's had a very good Olympics but there's lots more to come.\"\n\nAnd both Jacobs and Bednarek beat Hinchliffe's mark so he won't make the final.\n\nHinchliffe was some way back in third with 9.97. Waiting game for him.\n\nSeville was sharp out of the blocks and looked like he was easing up. Hinchliffe did not have the best start but powered through. Lyles looks like he might still have something in the tank, too.\n\nThe first two qualify and the two next quickest across the three semis.\n\nLyles runs his palm down his mouth when introduced. I have to admit I don't get the reference. My first thought was something obscene but I'm not sure that's what it was about.\n\nA recap of the five fastest this year\n\nWhat do I admire the most? The technical expertise he has shared for 24 years but also the perspective. He is never coaxed towards hyperbole. He assesses everyone on their merits and puts their achievement into a broad global and historical context. He provides a sharp contrast with other BBC athletics experts.\n\nHow Paris Olympics developed one of the world's fastest tracks - using mussel shells\n\nThe Olympic record FYI is Usain Bolt's 9.63sec from London 2012, the world record is also his, 9.58sec from the 2009 World Championships in Berlin.\n\nZharnel Hughes: Flight simulator and Usain Bolt have helped my shot at Olympic glory\n\nHence St Lucia had to wait until tonight for this moment:\n\nGood evening and welcome to live coverage of the men's 100m final at 8.50pm preceded by the three semi-finals at 7.05pm to establish those who will go on to compete for the blue riband of men's athletics, the claims of the 1,500m partisans notwithstanding. Two team GB athletes go in the semi-finals, the national record holder Zharnel Hughes is in the third having qualified 10th fastest in 10.03, three-hundredths of a second off his best for the season. Hughes won his semi-final in Tokyo in 9.98 three years ago but, you may well recall, false-started in the final from lane four and was disqualified.\n\nThe second British semi-fnalist is Louie Hinchliffe from Sheffield who has been taken under the wing of the great Carl Lewis at the University of Houston. Hinchliffe, all but unknown until his emergence at the NCAA championships this year, is the third fastest qualifier with 9.98 in yesterday's heats, again three-hundredths of a second off his best for the season. He has a remarkable body shape for an elite sprinter, more of a bustler than a glider, but he generates so much power and his technique is ever more refined by the month. It would be a remarkable story for him even to make the final but his form is good enough to make it a probability.\n\nThe world champion, Noah Lyles, is alongside Hinchliffe in the first semi-final and ran a personal best 9.81 only 15 days ago at London's Olympic Stadium in the Diamond League so we shouldn't read too much into yesterday's 10.04. Ferdinand Omnayala of Kenya and Jamaica's Kishane Thompson have both gone under 9.8sec this season while USA's Fred Kerley, silver medallist in Tokyo and the quickest man in the field with a PB of 9.76, has run under 9.9sec. Defending champion, Marcell Jacobs of Italy, crept in with 10.05 but has run 9.92 this season as he makes his way back from injury.\n\nIf you are of the hat-wearing persuasion, hang on to it.", In the men's 100m race on Sunday, Lyles just barely came out on top, defeating Jamaica runner Kishane Thompson by just five-thousandths of a second.\n\nLyles pulled off this win despite being in last place nearly halfway through the race. But he closed in on his opponents towards the end and on a last-second lean, he just passed the finish line in first.\n\nBBC commentator and USA Olympic legend Michael Johnson was calling the race. At first glance, many thought Thompson finished first, but Johnson knew it was Lyles all along.\n\n\"It was Noah. It's Noah,\" Johnson kept repeating.\n\nIn the 100m semifinal, Lyles went viral for his taunt of Oblique Seville as he crossed the finish line. His first came in the 200m race in the 2020 Tokyo Olympics, where he won bronze. Lyles will get another chance at a medal on Monday, August 5, in the Paris Games' 200m race.\n\nJohnson won four gold medals back in the 1990s. The sprinting legend won the 4x400m relay in the 1992 Barcelona Olympics, the 200m and 400m races in the 1996 Atlanta Olympics, and the 400m race in the 2000 Sydney Olympics. {"uri": "8259197264", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "23:33:54", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T23:33:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T23:32:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://larrybrownsports.com/olympics/analyst-explains-noah-lyles-win-100m/637107", "title": "Analyst explains how Noah Lyles won 100m despite his foot not crossing first", "body": "Aug 4, 2024; Paris, FRANCE; Noah Lyles (USA) celebrates winning the men's 100m final during the Paris 2024 Olympic Summer Games at Stade de France. Mandatory Credit: Kirby Lee-USA TODAY Sports\n\nNoah Lyles managed to become an Olympic gold medalist by the slimmest possible margin.\n\nLyles took home the gold in the men's 100-meter race at the Paris Games on Sunday in a thrilling photo finish. With a time of 9.784 seconds, Lyles beat out silver medalist Kishane Thompson of Jamaica (9.789 seconds) by a mere five-thousandths of a second. Fellow American Fred Kerley rounded out the podium with a time of 9.81 seconds to win bronze.\n\nMany viewers were confused though because the photo finish revealed that Thompson's foot had actually crossed the finish line before Lyles' did. As a result, FS1's Emmanuel Acho, who lettered in track in high school, clarified things in a post to X. The reason why Lyles won the race, Acho explained, is because the clock stops when the runner's torso crosses the finish line. The first body part to cross the line does NOT determine the winner.\n\nInterestingly enough, Thompson would have been the gold-medal winner had he leaned in with his chest at the finish line like Lyles did (which the above photo shows that Thompson did not do). That is how absolutely narrow the margins can be in Olympic competition.\n\nThe razor-thin victory by Lyles, who already won bronze in the 200m at the 2020 Tokyo Olympics, did admittedly throw many people off. Even the NBC announcer calling the race live mistakenly thought that Thompson had won.", "source": {"uri": "larrybrownsports.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Larry Brown Sports"}, "authors": Mandatory Credit: James Lang-USA TODAY Sports Credit - James Lang -- USA TODAY Sports/Reuters\n\nNoah Lyles, the world's fastest man, won a gold medal in the 100-m final on Sunday in a race that came down to a remarkable photo finish.\n\nThe meet was decided by just .005 seconds, as NBC commentators originally declared Jamaica's Kishane Thompson as the winner. \"I went up to him afterward, while we were waiting. I even said, 'Bro I think you got that one, big dog,\" NBC reports that Lyles told Thompson before the scoreboard revealed that the Florida native crossed the finish line with a time of 9.784 seconds. Thompson, the silver medalist, did so in 9.789. Team USA's Fred Kerley followed closely at 9.81 seconds, securing the bronze.\n\nRead More: The Inside Story of How Noah Lyles Pulled Off That Incredible 100-M Win\n\nIn track and field, the end of an athlete's lap is determined by the moment their torso crosses the finish line. While it may appear that other competitors' feet reached the finish line first, the photo displays Lyles, in lane seven, with his chest meeting the mark.\n\nThis victory was undoubtedly fueled by Lyles' finish in 2021, when the 27-year-old was unsatisfied after he took home bronze in Tokyo. After that point, the track-and-field star became even more determined. \"I'm here to race anybody who wants it,\" Lyles told TIME in an interviewer earlier this year. \"The deeper the field, the better I run. I know I'm going to win. Because I'm never going to break nerve.\"\n\nThis marks the first U.S. gold in this event since 2004.\n\nLyles is also hoping to medal in the 200m race, for which he is the favorite. {"uri": "8260063801", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "12:14:50", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T12:14:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T12:14:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://hollywoodlife.com/2024/08/05/noah-lyles-wins-100-m-sprint-in-photo-finish/", "title": "Noah Lyles Wins Historically Close 100-Meter Sprint in Photo Finish", "body": "The American showman ran a personal best of 9.79 seconds (technically, it was 9.784) -- finishing just 0.005 seconds ahead of Jamaica's Kishane Thompson -- to secure his first Olympic gold medal. He's America's first gold medalist in the 100 meters in 20 years since Justin Gatlin won at the 2004 Athens Olympics.\n\nThompson took silver with a 9.789. Fred Kerley, who won silver in the Tokyo Olympics, added a bronze to his resume with a personal best time of 9.81. Five of the top six times were personal bests, a season best, or a national record. Oblique Seville ran a 9.91 and finished last.\n\nThe 27-year-old said that before he left for Paris, one of his physio guys assured him this race would be a squeaker.\n\n\"He said, 'This is how close first and second are going to be,'\" Lyles recounted as he pinched his thumb and forefinger together so they were almost touching. \"I can't believe how right he was.\"\n\nComputers showed Lyles leaned forward -- his torso had to cross the finish line -- to cross the line five-thousandths of a second faster than Thompson.\n\nBefore the final results were posted, Lyles told reporters he thought it was Thompson who finished first, not him.\n\n\"I was like, oh man, I'm really gonna have to swallow my pride, which I don't have a problem doing. Respect deserves respect, and everybody in the field, to be honest, came out knowing that they could win this race.\"\n\nPreviously, Lyles talked about wanting more spirited competition with his cohorts. More trash-talking. More races. More of the best facing off.\n\n\"Everybody has their own vibe. I'm a showman,\" Lyles declared in the documentary series Sprint on Netflix.\n\n\"I feel like almost an artistic director. You have all these other athletes as stars, rock stars, popular wherever they go. Track and field needs to be the same. And I'm not gonna be happy until I see that accomplished.\"\n\nAnd it's not just trash talk with his track and field competitors. Lyles and the NBA -- players and fans -- have had some beef since he spoke at last year's World Championships in which he won the 100 and 200.\n\nLyles mocked the league's labeling of its NBA Finals winners as \"world champions\" by openly asking, \"World champion of what? The United STATES?\"\n\n\"That ain't the world,\" he continued amid laughter from reporters. \"That is not the world. We are the world. We have almost every country out here fighting, thriving, putting on their flag to show that they're represented. There ain't no flags in the NBA.\"\n\nNBA players and media didn't find Lyles' ridicule so amusing. They argued that the league comprises the best basketball players from around the globe and is therefore the best hoops competition on the planet despite not being an official world championship.\n\nLyles' comments sparked a firestorm of criticism and clap-backs. Kevin Durant tweeted: \"Somebody help this brother.\" ESPN's Stephen A. Smith called Lyles \"flagrantly ignorant.\"\n\nFast forward to Saturday and the start of the men's 100 competition at Stade de France. Lyles finished second in his first-round heat, and his many detractors tweeted their delight about his potential downfall in Paris. He took second again in his semifinal early Sunday, giving his critics more hope.\n\nLyles ended up having the last laugh. And he has the chance to win three more golds to match Carl Lewis' track and field record of four golds at the 1984 Olympic Games. He'll be an even bigger favorite to win his next event -- the 200 meters.\n\n\"I'll be winning,\" Lyles guaranteed. \"None of them is winning. When I come off the turn, they will be depressed.\" Lyles was referring to his opponents in the 200. But we don't think Lyles plans on eating any of his words anytime soon.\n\n\"I'm a true believer that the moment isn't bigger than me,\" Lyles said on Netflix. \"The moment was made for me.\"", {"uri": "2024-08-443918946", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "22:52:06", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T22:52:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T22:49:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.cbsnews.com/news/noah-lyles-wins-gold-photo-finish-100-meter-sprint-paris-olympics/", "title": "Noah Lyles wins Olympic gold in 100-meter sprint after astonishing photo finish", "body": "American sprinter Noah Lyles won gold in the men's 100-meter sprint Sunday on day nine of the 2024 Paris Olympics in a finish so close even the announcers didn't know who won the race.\n\nAfter the official times came in, Lyles was determined to have crossed the finish line just a hair ahead of Jamaica's Kishane Thompson, with the men posting respective times of 9.784 and 9.789 seconds. According to the Associated Press, Lyles' .005-second lead was one of the closest sprints in the Games' history.\n\nTeam USA's Fred Kerley claimed the bronze with a time of 9.81 seconds.\n\nDespite a slow start off the blocks, Lyles picked up the pace down the stretch in Paris' Stade de France to secure his first Olympic gold medal.\n\nLyles is the first American to win gold in the 100-meter event since Justin Gatlin in 2004. He took to social media after the win, posting a picture of his signature \"Kamehameha\" celebration from the Japanese television series \"Dragon Ball.\"\n\nOutside of the Olympics, Lyles won three world championships last summer, in the 100-meter, 200-meter, and 4x100-meter relay - the first person to do so since legendary sprinter Usain Bolt. In a news conference after the championship, Lyles made headlines for criticizing the NBA.\n\nLyles previously won a bronze medal in the 200-meter sprint at the Tokyo Olympics. He is set to compete again in the 200-meter and the 4x100-meter relay in Paris.", "source": {"uri": "cbsnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "CBS News"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8259264300", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "01:19:00", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T01:19:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T01:17:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://trinidadexpress.com/sports/local/king-noah/article_3e32b2a4-52c7-11ef-8e47-1be62224e42d.html", "title": "KING NOAH", "body": "Noah Lyles backed up his hype with a superb come-from-behind victory in the Olympic Games men's 100 metres final at the Stade de France, here in Paris, yesterday.\n\nLyles surged to the line to edge past Jamaican powerhouse Kishane Thompson, the American striking gold in a personal best 9.79 seconds. Thompson was credited with the same time but had to settle for silver, Lyles winning by just five-thousandths of a second. Lyles' USA teammate, Fred Kerley completed the podium, grabbing bronze in 9.81.\n\nThompson looked a winner for most of the race. Even Lyles thought his Jamaican rival had done enough for gold, almost congratulating him as they waited on the result to show up on the giant scoreboard.\n\n\"I was like, 'I'm going to be honest, I think you got that one.' But then my name popped up, and I was like, 'Oh my god, I'm amazing'.\"\n\nIt was truly an amazing run from Lyles, the showman clawing his way back following a very ordinary start.\n\nThough there was no Trinidad and Tobago representation in the Olympic century final, at least two members of the Team TTO contingent here in Paris would be pleased to see Lyles at the top of the podium at today's victory ceremony.\n\nLike Lyles, men's 400m semifinalist Jereem \"The Dream\" Richards is part of the Lance Brauman camp, while TTO sprint coach Keston Bledman is an assistant to head coach Brauman at the training group's Florida base.\n\nLyles is a colourful character, his outgoing personality drawing a great deal of attention to track and field. Among the spectators in the stadium yesterday were famous American rapper Snoop Dog and NBA superstar Jayson Tatum.\n\n\"I had so many commercials going around and so many people, like Snoop Dog is out here, saying that I'm going to be the one. I'm not going to say it's not pressure,\" Lyles continued, \"it's definitely pressure. Saying that the moment is not bigger than me, that the moment was meant for me, constantly saying that it's going to be the thing I need.\"\n\nLyles handled the pressure well, leading home the first wind-legal race in history with eight men under ten seconds.\n\nSouth African Akani Simbine finished fourth in a national record time of 9.82. Italy's defending Olympic champion Lamont Jacobs was fifth in 9.85, with sixth spot going to Letsile Tebogo in 9.86--a new Botswana record. American Kenny Bednarek and Jamaican Oblique Seville were seventh and eighth, respectively, clocking 9.88 and 9.91.\n\nSeville had sent a semi-final warning, winning the opening heat in 9.81 seconds with Lyles second in 9.83. Simbine topped heat two in 9.87. Only Thompson was faster than Seville in the penultimate round of the Olympic Games blue riband event, taking heat three in 9.80, ahead of Kerley, the runner-up in 9.84.\n\nLyles and Thompson improved in the championship race. Seville, though, did not, and had to settle for the cellar position. Thompson said he was pleased to secure a podium finish.\n\n\"I'm super grateful. I came out here and finished injury-free. I think you guys know my past issues with injuries. I am a bit disappointed, but I am happy at the same time. I am going to take it as what it is and move forward from here. I wasn't patient enough with myself to let my speed bring me at the line, in the position that I know I could have gone to, but I have learnt from it.\n\n\"I'm feeling very good,\" Thompson continued. \"My body language will not show it because I am not an expressive guy, but I am glad. I know that Jamaica would have wanted me to get the gold, everybody loves winners. I would have loved to win today, but big up to the whole field.\"\n\nKerley said that though gold was his goal, bronze was \"special\".\n\n\"This is the Olympic Games we are talking about. The world doesn't understand that the best eight in the world was at the line.\"", "source": {"uri": "trinidadexpress.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Trinidad Express Newspapers"}, "authors": [], Please try again later.\n\nSAINT-DENIS, France - Noah Lyles looked up at the video board next to the other seven fastest men in the world, all of them still trying to settle what 100 meters and less than 9.8 seconds could. They wanted to know, like the rest of packed Stade de France, who had claimed the title of Fastest Man in the World.\n\nSkip to end of carousel\n\nGet the latest updates on the 2024 Olympics\n\n(Washington Post illustration)\n\nTrack all the Paris Olympic medal counts country by country, and see the breakdown of medals by U.S. athletes. Get live updates from Paris and keep up with the latest by signing up for The Sports Moment: Olympics Edition.\n\nEnd of carousel\n\nThe first name flashed, and Lyles's grand vision had come vividly to life. Three years after a disappointing bronze in Tokyo and the depths of depression, Lyles won the 100-meter final at the Paris Olympics in a photo finish over silver medalist Kishane Thompson of Jamaica and bronze medalist Fred Kerley. On the score board, Lyles and Thompson both saw 9.79 seconds. On the official clock, it was Lyles 9.784, Thompson 9.789.\n\nWith the fastest 100 meters of his life, Lyles had bagged the first of what he plans to be three gold medals this week. Lyles has already won the hardest of his three races, against an electric field in which every sprinter finished in 9.91 seconds or faster. He has won 27 consecutive 200-meter races, and the United States is a heavy favorite in the 4x100-meter relay.\n\nBefore the race, Lyles beat his chest and begged the roaring crowd for more noise. Afterward, he ran to the crowd and hugged his mother, Keisha Caine Bishop, who when Lyles was a child would sleep sitting up and back-to-back with her son so he could ease his asthma.\"You so blessed, Noah,\" Caine Bishop told him. \"I'm so glad. I'm so glad. I'm so proud.\"\n\nLyles entered the Paris Games as the reigning world champion and seemingly in peak form. He won the U.S. Olympic trials 100 meters in 9.83 seconds, then lowered his personal best to 9.81 seconds at a Diamond League meet in London two weeks before the Olympics. With justification, he targeted a time in the 9.7s.\n\nplayPlay now\n\nNaN min\n\nFollow on\n\nPodcast episode\n\nSpotify\n\nApple\n\nGoogle\n\nAmazon\n\nOnce in Paris, though, Lyles struggled with the Olympic environment. In two separate media briefings, Lyles raised his discomfort with the recognition he drew in the Athletes Village, saying he at times resorted to wearing a hat and glasses when he left his room. In Saturday's first-round heat, Lyles started slow, ran even with the pack and finished second to Britain's Louie Hinchliffe, the current NCAA champion.\n\nLyles vowed he would learn from his casual effort, and he righted himself Sunday evening. He finished second in his semifinal heat in 9.83 seconds, tied for the second-best time of his career. That's serious. I want a sneaker.\n\n'There's no money in spikes, there's money in sneakers. Even Michael Johnson didn't own a sneaker.\n\nNoah Lyles (right) and Kishane Thompson nervously waited for the winner of the 100m\n\n'The amount of medals we bring back, the notoriety we get, the fact that that didn't happen, I think that's crazy. It has to happen.'\n\nLyles ran a personal best of 9.79 seconds to win his first Olympic gold medal, but he was only declared the winner in a photo finish, with him admitting he thought Thompson had beaten him.\n\n\"After the race, while we were still waiting for the names, I came up to Kishane and said, 'I think you have a big dog,'\" Lyles said.\n\n\"When my name came up, I was like, 'Oh my god, I'm amazing.' I wasn't ready to see my name.\"\n\nLyles is now confident he can confirm his 100m title with victories in the 200m and the 4x100m relay, just as he did at the world championships.\n\n\"I'm pretty sure, I can't lie,\" he said. \"I'm going to win. The journey started after 2021 when I got the bronze medal and I said, 'I have to change.'\n\n'Now I'm going around as an Olympic champion. I have that title as the fastest man in the world. {"uri": "8259235941", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "00:34:31", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T00:34:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T00:33:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/olympics/noah-lyles-olympics-100m-final-result-2024-b2591133.html", "title": "'I'm incredible': Noah Lyles backs up fighting talk in dramatic Olympic 100m final", "body": "Our mission is to deliver unbiased, fact-based reporting that holds power to account and exposes the truth.\n\nWhether $5 or $50, every contribution counts.\n\nSupport us to deliver journalism without an agenda.\n\nWorld champion, Olympic champion. Noah Lyles talked an awful lot of talk in the build-up to Paris 2024, but he backed up the bluster with a late, late burst on the Stade de France track, surging past the field to pip them all on the line. There can be no argument now. \"What's the title of the Olympic champion?\" Lyles said, referring to the 'fastest man on the planet' tag that goes with gold. \"Amen.\"\n\nIt doesn't matter that he didn't get near the world record he said he'd break, finishing in 9.79; or that it came down to five thousandths of a second, quicker than the time it takes the human eye to blink; or that he finished second in his heat and his semi-final too. Lyles delivered when it mattered most.\n\nJamaica's Kishane Thompson had been burdened with the title of heir to Usain Bolt after running the fastest time this year, and he led for 99m of this race. But Lyles fought back from dead last at 40m, and they crossed the line together.\n\nThompson roared in celebration but his face dropped when the giant screen displayed \"photo finish\" by his name. They stared up from purgatory, waiting for the verdict.\n\n\"Kishane, I think you got it, man,\" Lyles told Thompson, with a pat on the shoulder.\n\nThompson looked pained. \"Come on, man!\" he shouted at the screen, urging it to move. \"Come on, man!\"\n\nLyles paced with his hands on his head. Then the result came and Lyles was off again, one moment ripping the name from his chest and raising it to the gods, the next streaking across the hammer field with the stars and stripes flapping in the wind. Thompson was awarded silver as Lyles' US teammate Fred Kerley took bronze.\n\n\"I was prepared to see his name pop up,\" Lyles said. \"I saw my name pop up and I said, 'Goodness gracious, I'm incredible'. It's the one I wanted. It's the hard battle, the amazing opponents, everybody was healthy and came to fight. I'm the wolf among wolves.\"\n\nLyles is the closest thing athletics has right now to a global superstar. He was placed front and centre of the Netflix documentary Sprint, which aimed to sprinkle a little of the Drive to Survive magic in athletics' direction. It is a sport always fighting attention, for a more permanent place in the entertainment-scape.\n\nHe embraced the role with extreme main-character energy. \"I'm the third fastest human to ever live,\" he bragged in one of the opening scenes. \"Soon to be the first.\"\n\nHis swagger was not always endearing but it was undeniably compelling. He spoke with raw honesty about the torment of failing in the spotlight, and about the depression he suffered. So when he looked into the camera and said he would become Olympic champion, you knew he meant it.\n\nAnother quote ran: \"I'm a true believer that the moment isn't bigger than me, the moment was made for me.\"\n\nWell, this was his moment. The US prides itself on its dominance in track and field but an American had not won this race for 20 years, not since Justin Gatlin in Athens. Bolt won the next three in Beijing, London and Rio before Italy's Lamont Marcell Jacobs stunned the world in Tokyo. Jacobs finished fifth here in 9.85 sec, behind South Africa's Akani Simbine who came fourth in 9.82.\n\nOne by one, Lyles picked them all off.\n\n\"It was hard for me to picture where we were, and I guess that was a good thing,\" he said. \"I was fortunate to have [Jamaica's] Oblique Seville next to me because all throughout the year he's been hitting that acceleration that I wasn't hitting. I wasn't going to let him go.\"\n\nThompson hoped to be the first Jamaican man since Bolt to win a global 100m title.\n\n\"I'm a bit disappointed but I'm super happy and grateful at the same time,\" he said. \"I wasn't patient enough with my speed and myself, I should have let my speed bring me to the line. I've learned from it. I couldn't see Noah, but I think he could see me and said, 'hey, Kishane, I thought you got it'. But he was too far to my right so I wasn't sure. This is my closest race. It was that close.\"\n\nFor Lyles, this could be just the start. He still has the 200m to come, his strongest event, as well as a 4x100m showdown with the Jamaicans.\n\n\"There's plenty more,\" he promised. \"I hope you guys like Noah because I've got a lot more {"uri": "8259075847", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "20:38:46", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T20:38:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T20:36:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://larrybrownsports.com/olympics/announcer-leigh-diffey-botched-call-olympics-noah-lyles-sprint/637100", "title": "Announcer botched call of photo finish in Olympics 100-meter sprint", "body": "United States track and field star Noah Lyles became the new fastest man in the world on Sunday, and the race was so close that even the announcer botched the call as the sprinters crossed the finish line.\n\nLyles beat Jamaica's Kishane Thompson by just five thousandths of a second in the men's 100-meter sprint. The race ended in a true photo finish, but NBC announcer Leigh Diffey was for some reason certain that Thompson won.\n\n\"This is close, Jamaica's gonna do it!\" Diffey said. \"Kishane Thompson is a gold medalist!\"\n\nThe call would have been excellent had Thompson actually won. Instead, Diffey's enthusiastic commentary was followed by several seconds of silence as everyone waited to see whether Thompson or Lyles prevailed in the photo finish. Unfortunately for Diffey, it was the latter.\n\nLyles was trailing until the end of the sprint, and Diffey thought Kishane held the American off. The unofficial photo finish showed just how close the race was:\n\nDiffey probably wishes he could have that one back.\n\nLyles is the first American sprinter to win the 100-meter race in 20 years. The gold medal was his first. Lyles was viewed as a favorite to win a gold medal at the Tokyo Olympics in 2020, but a blunder may have cost him the win then. {"uri": "8259137985", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "22:13:41", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T22:13:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T22:02:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://japantoday.com/category/paris-2024-olympics/lyles-wins-olympic-100m-gold-in-closest-finish-in-modern-history", "title": "Lyles wins Olympic 100 meters gold in closest finish in modern history", "body": "World champion Noah Lyles roared to victory in 9.79 seconds to claim gold in a dramatic men's Olympic 100 meters final in Paris on Sunday.\n\nLyles won in the closest Olympic 100 meters finish in modern history -- just five thousandths of a second separated him from Jamaica's Kishane Thompson who clocked the same time of 9.79 seconds.\n\nIt made Lyles the first American, male or female, to win the event since Justin Gatlin took gold in the 2004 Athens Games.\n\n\"It's the one I wanted,\" said Lyles. \"It's the hard battle, it's the amazing opponents. \"Everybody's healthy, everybody came prepared for the fight and I wanted to prove that I'm the man among all of them. I'm the wolf amongst wolves.\"\n\nLyles' victory was only confirmed after a photo-finish.\n\nThe American said of the wait for the final results: \"I went up to Kishane and I was like, 'I'm going to be honest, bro, I think you had that one'.\n\n\"And I was fully prepared to see his name pop up and to see my name pop up, I'm like goodness gracious. I'm incredible.\"\n\nLyles' U.S. teammate Fred Kerley took bronze in 9.81 seconds, just one-hundredth ahead of South African Akani Simbine, who timed 9.82 seconds.\n\nIn an astonishing race, defending champion Marcell Jacobs of Italy was fifth in 9.85 seconds, Botswana's Letsile Tebogo sixth in 9.86 seconds, American Kenny Bednarek seventh in 9.88 seconds and Jamaican Oblique Seville eighth in 9.91 seconds.\n\nStarting in lane seven, outside Seville and inside Tebogo, Lyles got off to an average start but was soon into his stride pattern.\n\nHead tucked down through to the 40-meter mark, the American opened up, but the whole field pushed him all the way.\n\nAs Lyles dipped for the line with Thompson charging alongside him, the crowd erupted and a photo-finish was called before Lyles was confirmed as gold medallist.\n\nThere was an electric pre-race atmosphere in a 69,000-capacity Stade de France, a light show and booming music keeping the crowd entertained as the sprinters made the final adjustments to their starting blocks.\n\nThe lights were then shut off, the sprinters leaving the track to remake their entrance like prize fighters in a colosseum.\n\nEach sprinter was individually introduced behind an image of their name above their flag.\n\nThompson roared, hands clenched in fists as his head rolled back. Kerley patted his heart.\n\nLyles bounded out like a kangaroo, bouncing 20 meters down the track. Jacobs was the definition of cool, raising both arms and calmly walking to his blocks.\n\nThen came the moment where the sprinters set, at the starter's beck and call.\n\nThe wait seemed interminable. The music continued, the crowd clapped in unison as if to hurry the starter, then the sprinters stood in their lanes, rocking from foot to foot and the tension was palpable.\n\nThe cameras panned one more and then it was time, the only sound that of a helicopter's wings whirring overhead.\n\nThe shot was fired and the field moved as if one up the purple track.\n\nThe photo-finish officials examined the evidence and Lyles walked away with gold to bury the demons of the Tokyo Olympics three years ago where he harvested a mere 200m bronze.\n\nAsked whether he was confident of doubling up in the 200m, an event in which he is a three-time world champion, Lyles was in no doubt.\n\n\"100 percent,\" he said. \"That's my better event and now that I've got a new PR in the 100, I'm ready to take it to the 200.\"\n\n\u00a9 2024 AFP", "source": {"uri": "japantoday.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Japan Today"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": of the Olympics' marquee events since Justina Gaitlen in 2004.\n\nLyles races again in the men's 200-meter dash on Thursday and will once again be among the favorites for the gold medal.", "source": {"uri": "8259186176", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "23:19:16", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T23:19:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T23:15:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/american-sprinter-noah-lyles-no-230153459.html", "title": "American sprinter Noah Lyles is no longer a meme. He's a stunning redemption story.", "body": "SAINT-DENIS, France -- Every gimmick, every cry for attention, every time he set himself up to be a meme and ridiculed, it made you wonder if Noah Lyles knew what he was getting himself into, what laid in wait on the other side of another stink bomb in Paris. It wouldn't have been the end of the world. Life would have gone on. He would have continued to get sponsors, be famous, sprint around the world and live the life he wants.\n\nBut it would have felt so transparently like an act - and one that few would have had an appetite to see continue another four years.\n\nAmericans have been intrigued by Lyles, they've been entertained by Lyles, they've been bombarded with Lyles in every way, shape and form leading up to these Olympics.\n\nBut until Sunday here at Stade de France they've had little reason at the Olympics to do anything but roll their eyes at Lyles.\n\nThat all changed with a well-timed dip. With a fortunate lean. With a few thousands of a second.\n\nOne of the biggest trash talkers in American sports is now one of its biggest heroes. He ended a 20-year drought in the 100 meters. He officially buried his Tokyo flop. He won the gold.\n\nRedemption, anyone?\n\n\"Oh, I knew once the year started, that this was not 2021,\" Lyles said. \"I knew every step of the way it was not 2021. I'm still constantly moving forward, moving forward, moving forward. And I knew that when the time came for me to be able to say, 'This is the final, this is where I need to put together.' I was going to do it.\"\n\nBut he had to actually do it. And until literally the final stride, that seemed like it might not be possible.\n\nLyles didn't win his preliminary heats. He looked like he might be off his game here in Paris. Others were in better form, and maybe, just maybe, all the pressure he heaped on himself trying to be Noah Lyles the transcendent superstar, rather than Noah Lyles the world's best sprinter, might be getting to him on the stage you only get once every four years.\n\nHere's what I thought during introductions for the 100 when Lyles came hopping out of the tunnel and running almost at a full sprint for 20 yards or so: He's trying too hard. Lyles always tries too hard.\n\nA lot of people who don't really know much about track would have only known the following things about Lyles. He talked about winning three gold medals in Tokyo, but only came away with one bronze. His focus shift to the 100 and the \"world's fastest man\" moniker felt even more audacious. And, in a major pop culture faux pas, he went after NBA players for calling themselves \"world champions\" after winning the title because the NBA is a league and the world is the world.\n\nAgain, trying too hard. Making himself the country's most annoying literalist. But also making himself famous.\n\nWhere one side of that coin begins and the other ends in this social media era, who can say? If Muhammad Ali had Twitter and YouTube instead of Howard Cosell, it might have gotten a little old too.\n\nBut if you can back it up on the track? That's the jackpot of American zeitgeist.\n\nLyles knew it. He believed it. Then he did it. And even after all that talk, it stunned him a little bit he when it actually happened and his name flashed first.\n\n\"I'm gonna be honest, I wasn't ready to see it,\" he said. \"And that's the first time I've ever, like, said that in my head, like, I wasn't ready to see it.\"\n\nPeople like Lyles usually see themselves dominating. Putting on a show because it's all a show.\n\nAnd it was indeed that, just a different kind than what anyone could have predicted.\n\nHalfway through he looked dead in the water. Then the gap closed.\n\n\"When I saw where he was at 60, I was like 'OK, we're in the mix,'\" his coach Lance Brauman said. \"But I thought at 80, I was like, 'Holy cow, he's right there.'\"\n\nThe finish was blur. It seemed like nearly the entire field hit the line together.\n\n\"Probably one of the best races I've been in in a long time,\" Fred Kerley said. \"It came down to whoever can dip the best at the last two meters.\"\n\nFor several seconds, there was a hush.\n\nNo names were coming up on the scoreboard. The result of the biggest race of Lyles' life was in suspended animation. He figured Jamaica's Kishane Thompson probably had it.\n\n\"I went up to him after where we were waiting,\" Lyles said. \"I even said, 'Bro, I think you got that one, big dog.\"\n\nThe stakes here were higher than a gold medal. He doesn't want to just be a sprinter, he wants to be a star. Those two things could only coexist if he hit the line first. After three years of talk, this was about reputation and redemption. \"And then my name popped up,\" he said. \"And I'm like, 'Oh my gosh, I'm amazing.'\"", "source": {"uri": "sports.yahoo.com", {"uri": "8259131698", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "21:56:56", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T21:56:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T21:54:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://www.theepochtimes.com/sports/noah-lyles-wins-olympic-100-by-5-thousandths-of-a-second-5699537", "title": "Noah Lyles Wins Olympic 100 by 5-thousandths of a Second", "body": "SAINT-DENIS, France -- Noah Lyles won the Olympic 100 meters by .005 seconds Sunday, waiting some 30 seconds after the finish of one of the closest sprints in history to find out he'd beaten Kishane Thompson of Jamaica.\n\nThe word \"Photo\" popped up on the scoreboard next to the names of Lyles, Thompson and five others after they crossed the line.\n\nLyles paced the track with his hands draped over his head. Finally, the numbers came up. Lyles won in 9.784 seconds to edge out the Jamaican by five-thousandths of a tick of the clock.\n\nLyles said he thought he had given the win away by dipping at the line too soon, so he went up to Thompson and told him, \"Bro, I think you got that one.\"\n\n\"But then my name popped up and I'm like 'Oh my gosh, amazing!'\"\n\nAmerica's Fred Kerley came in third at 9.81.\n\n\"That's probably one of the most beautiful races I've been in,\" he said.\n\nThe top seven all finished within .09 of each other.\n\nThis was the closest 1-2 finish in the 100 since at least Moscow in 1980 -- or maybe even ever. Back then, Britain's Allan Wells narrowly beat Silvio Leonard in an era when the electronic timers didn't go down into the thousandths of a second. The same was true in 1932, when Eddie Tolan won the Olympics' first ever photo finish.\n\nThank goodness they do now.\n\n\"I thought I had [him] cleared,\" Thompson said. \"But I wasn't sure. It was so close.\"\n\nLyles became the first American to win the marquee event in Olympic track since Justin Gatlin in 2004.\n\nThe 9.784 also marks a personal best for Lyles, who has been promising to add his own brand of excitement to track and certainly delivered this time.\n\nHe will be a favorite later this week in the 200 meters -- his better race -- and will try to join Usain Bolt as the latest runner to win both Olympic sprints.\n\nFor perspective, the blink of an eye takes, on average, .1 second, which was 20 times longer than the gap between first and second in this one.\n\nWhat was the difference? Maybe Lyles' closing speed and that lean into the line that he thought was mistimed.\n\nHe and Thompson had two of the three slowest bursts from the blocks, and Thompson had what sufficed for a \"lead\" at the halfway point. The photo finish actually shows Kerley's orange shoe well in front of everything at the finish line. But it's the chest breaking the barrier that counts, and Lyles beat everyone by a sliver.\n\nWhen the American learned he had added the Olympic title to the 100 meters he won at world championships last year, he pulled off his name tag and raised it to the sky, then brought his hands to his side and pointed at the camera.\n\n\"America, I told you I got this!\" he yelled into the camera.\n\nThey squared off in Sunday's semifinal, too, and Ingebrigtsen edged out the Brit, looking over to him twice as they surged down the homestretch, to win a race that felt like it meant more than it should have in 3:32.38.\n\n\"They should be expecting one of the most vicious and hardest 1,500s the sport's seen in a very long time,\" Kerr said.\n\nDid Ingebrigtsen agree?\n\n\"Depends who you ask, maybe,\" he said. \"I mean, racing is what you want it to be.\"", "source": {"uri": "theepochtimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "www.theepochtimes.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri":
