{"uri": "8259103655", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "21:14:58", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T21:14:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T21:13:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://newsday.co.tt/2024/08/04/american-noah-lyles-wins-mens-olympic-100m-title-in-photo-finish/", "title": "American Noah Lyles wins men's Olympic 100m title in photo-finish - Trinidad and Tobago Newsday", "body": "The \"fastest man in the world\" has been raging for weeks, long before the track and field segment of the 2024 Paris Olympic Games got started this week.\n\nIn a dramatic men's 100-metre final at the Stade de France on August 4, USA's Noah Lyles, the reigning 100m and 200m world champion, had an emphatic say in the argument when he edged Jamaica's Kishane Thompson by 0.005 seconds to take the Olympic title.\n\nIn a tense final which saw all eight athletes dipping under the ten-second barrier, Lyles clocked a time of 9.784 seconds, with Thompson clocking 9.789. Both athletes were officially given a time of 9.79, with Lyles' late surge and critical dip at the line proving to be the difference between the two sprinters in a tense photo-finish.\n\nRunning out of lane seven, Lyles, who was beaten earlier in the day in the first semifinal by Jamaica's Oblique Seville, looked to be out of contention midway through the final as both Thompson and USA's Fred Kerley led the pack. Using his lethal top-end speed, Lyles gained ground on the leaders in the final 40 metres and just managed to pip Thompson on the line - achieving a new personal best in the process.\n\nAfter the race, both men waited anxiously to see the final result, and it was Lyles who was filled with elation as his first-place finish was confirmed.\n\nKerley ensured the US copped two medals in the final, as he grabbed third in 9.81. South Africa's Akani Simbine ran a national record and placed fourth in 9.82.\n\nTokyo 2021 Olympic champion Lamont Marcell Jacobs ran a season's best for fifth spot in 9.85, with Botswana's Letsile Tebogo (9.86) also breaking a national record with his sixth-placed finish.\n\nUSA's Kenny Bednarek (9.88) and Seville (9.91) finished seventh and eighth respectively. The latter athlete cut a disappointing figure after the race as he told SportsMax he had felt discomfort in his groin during the race.\n\nThe men's 100m final was a far cry from the women's 100m final on August 3, as the winner, Lyles, and the eighth-placed Seville were separated by just 0.12 seconds. The gap was closer than the distance between women's 100m champion Julien Alfred and silver medallist Sha'Carri Richardson, who clocked 10.72 and 10.87 seconds respectively.\n\nLyles will try to further enhance his case in the \"fastest man\" argument when he faces the starter in heat six of the men's 200m from 2.30 pm (TT time) on August 5.", "source": {"uri": "newsday.co.tt", "dataType": {"uri": "8259900181", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "10:38:14", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T10:38:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T10:31:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/last-halfway-olympic-gold-100m-102155716.html", "title": "From last at halfway to Olympic gold at 100m, how Noah Lyles won greatest final ever", "body": "By the time Noah Lyles started the Olympic 100m final, he was already last. Lyles took 0.0178 sec to react to the gun and begin his race. That might sound quick but in a sport measured in thousandths of a second, he had just given up 0.07 to one his biggest rivals, fellow American Fred Kerley.\n\nThe man Lyles most feared, Jamaica's Kishane Thompson, was just as sluggish, reacting in 0.0176. Yet Thompson is the fastest man this year for a reason. He is a 100m specialist with power and a long stride, and he emerged from his drive phase at 30m with the lead.\n\nBy contrast, and despite being the 100m world champion, Lyles is a 200m runner by trade. His strength is in his top speed but he takes a little while to get there, and his slow start has sometimes been an Achilles heel. At 30m he was dead last, eighth out of eight.\n\nCrucially, though, Lyles was now travelling towards the finish line quicker than anyone else. Between 50m and 60m he made a rapid, stunning climb from eighth to third as he reached his peak speed of the race, 43.6km/hr (27.1mph).\n\nAt this point, the leader Thompson (43.2km/hr) and second-place Kerley (43.1km/hr) had already hit their top speed and they were fighting to maintain it. Thompson, running in his first Olympic final, was clearly tensing up, grimacing and straining for the line.\n\n\"I wasn't patient enough with myself to let my speed bring me to the line in the position that I know I could have gone to,\" Thompson later admitted. \"But I have learned from it.\"\n\nThis is where Lyles came into his element. His speed endurance is his strength, which is why he is such a successful 200m sprinter. He is also an experienced campaigner, having run in Olympic and world finals with memories of both success and failure to call upon. Lyles stayed calm and composed, holding his smooth running style all the way to the line.\n\n\"To be honest, I was like, if I'm running 9.83 in the semi-finals I'm going to be hard to beat,\" he said. \"I called my therapist and she was like, 'you need to let go, you need to let it flow', I was like, 'alright, I'm going to trust you'.\"\n\nHe still had one last job to do. The photo finish shows how Lyles body is leaning forwards, head dragging the torso through the line with the legs trailing behind. If Lyles' lean is around 60 degrees from the track, Thompson's is more like 75.\n\nTechnically, Thompson's right hallux was the first body part to complete this Olympic final. But finish lines only recognise the chest. Lyles won gold by five thousandths of a second, quicker than the time it takes to blink.\n\n\"I did think [Thompson] had it at the end,\" Lyles admitted. \"I went up to him while we were waiting, and said \"I think you've got that, good going', and then my name popped up and I'm like 'oh my gosh, I'm amazing'.\"\n\nHe had overcome not only seven rival finalists but the weight of American expectation, delivering Olympic men's 100m gold for the first time in 20 years, since Justin Gatlin in Athens.\n\n\"I had so many commercials going around and so many people, like Snoop Dog is out here, saying that I'm going to be the one. I'm not going to say it's not pressure, it's definitely pressure. Saying that the moment is not bigger than me, that the moment was meant for me, constantly saying that it's going to be the thing I need.\"\n\nIt was a moment that encapsulated Lyles: drama, entertainment, sheer theatre. Michael Johnson called it the greatest 100m final he had ever seen. \"We had this amazing race where you could throw a blanket over the finishing line,\" said the American sprint legend. \"We didn't even know who won for a few minutes.\"", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jordan_Lyles", "type": It had been highly anticipated as Lyles talked his game, which included taking a shot at the NBA.\n\nHe backed up his claims, winning gold in a photo finish on Sunday, Aug. 4. He became the first male USA runner to win gold in the 100-meter dash since 2004.\n\nJust about every moment of the race was tense and exciting, from the longer-than-usual wait to Lyles' celebration with his mother. As hours have passed since the race, photos are still flooding the internet.\n\nHere are some of the best photos and videos from the 100-meter dash at the 2024 Paris Olympics.\n\nMORE: Full results, highlights from Day 3 of track and field at 2024 Paris Olympics\n\nCameras caught just about every angle of this year's 100-meter final. Overhead shots, side-by-side views, and even graphics that show the runners at each frame of the race.\n\nThis overhead shot, taken right at the finish line, provides a different angle of just how close the race really was. You might still think that Kishane Thompson in lane 4 edged out Lyles in lane 7 even after looking at this picture.\n\nHere's a slightly different angle at the finish line, where it's a little clearer that Lyles won...right?\n\nThis overhead view, taken roughly midway through the race, gives an idea of how much ground Lyles, third from the bottom, had to make up on Thompson, third from the top -- and practically every other runner in the field.\n\nStill not convinced? Check out the overlay of the race roughly every 10 meters. Lyles was actually in last place at the 40m mark.\n\nThe view from behind provides a similar perspective of how far ahead Thompson appeared to be with just 50 meters remaining.\n\nEven among the blur caused by their blazing speeds, you can see the determination on both Thompson's and Lyles' faces as they lunge for the finish line.\n\nNothing was final until the official photo-finish photo below was inspected by the race officials.\n\nAfter sprinting at max speeds of over 20 mph for just under 10 seconds, Thompson and Lyles stand still, waiting to find out who will be wearing the gold medal -- an unusual sight for any Olympic sprinting event.\n\nAmong the thousands of photos of Lyles' celebration -- from defiantly showing off his name card to ringing the victory bell -- this triumphant picture of Lyles wearing the American flag like a superhero's cape projected near one of the most iconic structures in the world might just be the defining image of the 2024 Paris Olympics.\n\nFinally, amid a sea of cameras and spectators from all over the world, the fastest and most famous man on the planet, if only for a moment, slows down to find his family and embrace his biggest fan -- his mother.\n\nThey say pictures are worth 1,000 words, but you really only need one to sum up the 2024 Olympic men's 100m final: Legendary.", "source": {"uri": "sportingnews.com", {"uri": "8259081950", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "20:45:24", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T20:45:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T20:44:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://brobible.com/sports/article/legendary-announcer-leigh-diffey-never-saw-noah-lyles-coming-in-insane-100m-dash-final-comeback/", "title": "Legendary Announcer Leigh Diffey Never Saw Noah Lyles Coming In Insane 100M Dash Final Comeback", "body": "The 100-Meter Dash is one of the most anticipated events of every Summer Olympics, no matter if it's the men's or women's race. This year's men's final was one of the absolute best and closest in Olympic history, needing a photo finish to decide the winner.\n\nThat winner ended up being the USA's Noah Lyles, who edged Jamaican Kishane Thompson at the line by 5 thousandths of a second in a time of 9.79. But, the legendary play-by-play man Leigh Diffey never saw Lyles coming, completely screwing up the call of the race.\n\nNoah Lyles, who is trying to accomplish the prestigious 100M-200M double, got off to a slow start in the race, and looked out of gold medal contention halfway. But, an incredible second-half of the race won him the gold medal.\n\nBut, listen to the call of Leigh Diffey. He never saw Noah Lyles coming until it was too late. American Fred Kerley was stride for stride with Thompson the entire race, and that's apparently where his eyes went as the race went on.\n\nAs Thompson crossed the line, out-leaning Kerley, Diffey thought that Thompson had won, exclaiming \"Kishane Thompson is a gold medalist!\"\n\nBut, that's not what had happened. Noah Lyles had hawked Thompson down. In fact, it wasn't until Lyles went crazy upon seeing the result on the screen inside the Stade de France that Diffey realized what had just happened.\n\nThat was a really tough race to call, as the race happens fast enough to begin with, and a late comeback like that can come out of nowhere But, I'm sure that Leigh Diffey would like to have one of the biggest race calls of his life back.\n\nAs for Lyles, he is much closer now to winning that double. If he does it, he will be the first American to accomplish it since Carl Lewis in 1984. {"uri": "8259108514", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "21:20:32", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T21:20:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T21:19:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.boston.com/sports/sports/2024/08/04/noah-lyles-100-meter-olympics-video/", "title": "Noah Lyles wins 100-meter by five-thousandths of a second, among closest finishes in Olympics history", "body": "SAINT-DENIS, France (AP) -- Noah Lyles won the Olympic 100 meters by .005 seconds Sunday, waiting some 30 seconds after the finish of one of the closest sprints in history to find out he'd beaten Kishane Thompson of Jamaica.\n\nThe word \"Photo\" popped up on the scoreboard next to the names of Lyles, Thompson and five others after they crossed the line. Lyles paced the track with his hands draped over his head. Finally, the numbers came up. Lyles won in 9.784 seconds to edge out the Jamaican by five-thousandths of a tick of the clock.\n\nAmerica's Fred Kerley came in third at 9.81. The top seven all finished within .09 of each other.\n\nThis was the closest 1-2 finish in the 100 since at least Moscow in 1980 -- or maybe even ever. Back then, Britain's Allan Wells narrowly beat Silvio Leonard in an era when the electronic timers didn't go down into the thousandths of a second.\n\n\"I thought I had (him) cleared,\" Thompson said. \"But I wasn't sure. It was so close.\"\n\nLyles became the first American to win the marquee event in Olympic track since Justin Gatlin in 2004.\n\nThe 9.784 also marks a personal best for Lyles, who has been promising to add his own brand of excitement to track and certainly delivered this time.\n\nHe will be a favorite later this week in the 200 meters -- his better race -- and will try to join Usain Bolt as the latest runner to win both Olympic sprints.\n\nFor perspective, the blink of an eye takes, on average, .1 second, which was 20 times longer than the gap between first and second in this one.\n\nWhat was the difference? Maybe Lyles' closing speed and his lean into the line.\n\nHe and Thompson had two of the three slowest bursts from the blocks, and Thompson had what sufficed for a \"lead\" at the halfway point. The photo finish actually shows Kerley's orange shoe well in front of the line. But it's the chest breaking the barrier that counts, and Lyles beat everyone by a sliver.\n\nIt would take more than a mere 9.7(84) seconds to decide who would supplant Marcell Jacobs as the next Olympic champion.\n\nLyles patted Thompson on the shoulder while the wait grew -- from 10, to 20, then nearly 30 seconds. When the American learned he'd added this to the 100 meters he won at world championships last year, he pulled off his name tag and raised it to the sky, then brought his hands to his side and pointed at the camera.\n\n\"America, I told you I got this!\" he yelled into the camera.\n\nYaroslava Mahuchikh won Olympic gold in the high jump for her war-torn country of Ukraine and, as a bonus, had company. Her teammate Iryna Gerashchenko won the bronze and the teammates hopped, skipped and jumped around the track parading their blue-and-yellow flags in a heartfelt celebration.\n\nMahuchikh needed fewer tries to clear the winning height of 2 meters than Australia's Nicola Olyslagers, and so, added the sport's biggest prize of all -- Olympic gold -- to her world championship and world record.\n\nThe best rivalry in track will culminate Tuesday when reigning world champion Josh Kerr of Britain takes on defending Olympic champion Jakob Ingebrigtsen of Norway.\n\nThey squared off in Sunday's semifinal, too, and Ingebrigtsen edged out the Brit, looking over to him twice as they surged down the homestretch, to win a race that felt like it meant more than it should have in 3:32.38.\n\n\"They should be expecting one of the most vicious and hardest 1,500s the sport's seen in a very long time,\" Kerr said.\n\n\"Depends who you ask, maybe,\" he said. \"I mean, racing is what you want it to be.\"", "source": {"uri": "boston.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Boston"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@boston.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": true}], {"uri": "8259350790", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "03:17:05", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T03:17:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T03:16:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "http://theatlantavoice.com/noah-lyles-wins-gold-100m-race/", "title": "Noah Lyles takes the Olympic gold in the 100-meter dash by the slimmest of margins", "body": "Saint-Denis, France (CNN) -- An American is once again the world's fastest man.\n\nNoah Lyles earned that title and the gold medal in the men's 100-meter dash by the slimmest of margins - just five-thousandths of a second - on Sunday night outside Paris, exploding down the track at the Stade de France and leaning in to cross the finish line ahead of favorite Kishane Thompson of Jamaica.\n\nThe victory ends a 20-year Olympic drought in the event for the USA, when Justin Gatlin won the 100-meter race in Athens. It also cements Lyles as the premier American superstar in this sport as the charismatic 27-year-old sprinter had already been one of the top faces of track and field with his blazing speed and viral moments.\n\nThompson, who was the betting favorite in the race, took the silver medal and American Fred Kerley took home the bronze.\n\nIt was a sterling version of the signature Olympic race. Taking place on the same night as the women's high jump final and the men's hammer throw final, along with qualifying heats in multiple other races, the showpiece event didn't begin until all those other competitions were done for the day.\n\nWhen the time came, the lights went out in the Stade de France just as the sun had nearly set. And then it lit back up as wristbands on the 80,000 spectators in the stadium began to flash, creating another one of the dazzling light shows that these Paris Olympics are becoming known for.\n\nEach competitor received an introduction, but Lyles took it like no other, bounding nearly halfway down the track to hype up the crowd and let off a little emotion. Lyles has gone viral in the past for such pre-race moves like pulling out Yu-Gi-Oh! cards before key races, but this time it was only his energy on display.\n\nWhen all the competitors had entered the track, they stood waiting for what felt like an eternity as dramatic music played throughout the stadium.\n\nEventually, the music stopped and the competitors settled into the starting blocks. The stadium fell completely silent - tens of thousands and all one could hear was the wind - before the horn sounded. A mighty roar cut the tension as the sprinters hung together in a tight pack through the first 50 meters of the race.\n\nThere was some separation in the back half of the less-than-10-second contest - the first 100-meter Olympic final in which running a 10-second qualifying heat would not guarantee passage to the final race and the first where every competitor ran sub-10 seconds with a legal wind, according to World Athletics - but not nearly enough for it to be clear who won when the runners crossed the finish line.\n\nThe pack of panting sprinters gathered at the northeastern bend in the track, doubled over catching their breath while they stared up at the big screen, waiting for results. For a while, it only read \"Photo,\" indicating a photo finish.\n\nAnd then the update came through: Lyles had done it.\n\nHe took off again, bounding around the track in ecstasy.\n\nThat photo finish makes it one of the most incredible and dramatic 100-meter races in Olympic history.\n\nThe final times - Lyles finishing in 9.784 seconds, Thompson in 9.789 - tell the story neatly. But it's not the whole tale, given Lyles' qualifying rounds over the last two days.\n\nThe American finished second in both the first round and the semifinal qualifiers, seeming to do just enough to get to the final race but being underwhelming enough for fans to wonder if all of Lyles' bravado was going to be overmatched on this biggest of stages.\n\nLyles said afterward that he was convinced Thompson had beat him to the line.\n\n\"It was a crazy moment because, like I said, I did think that because Kishane had that and I was like, 'Man, I really, you know, have to swallow my pride,' which I don't have a problem doing because respect deserves respect,\" he said.\n\nBut when his name popped up on the board first, he knew he'd earned the right to celebrate a bit.\n\n\"I was like, I didn't do this against a slow field. I did this against the best of the best on the biggest stage with the biggest pressure. And seeing the names, I was like, 'Oh my gosh, there it is.'\"\n\nThompson, meanwhile, crushed the competition in each of his races, simply on cruise control until he reached the final. His nation's long history of sprinting success and his own cool demeanor appeared to be enough wind at his back to get him across the finish line first.\n\nThompson put the defeat on himself, telling reporters that he didn't trust himself enough.\n\n\"I really beat myself today in that I didn't trust myself and my speed to bring myself to the line in first place,\" he said, giving kudos to Lyles and the rest of the field for pushing him.\n\nThe American champion is hoping Sunday night's result is just the start of a historic Games - and he won't have a lot of time to rest on his laurels.\n\nLyles' signature race - this was his first time running the 100m at the Olympics - is the 200-meters and qualification for that distance begins on Monday morning.\n\nHe's also aiming to add a pair of relay medals on his neck - the men's 4\u00d7100-meter relay and possibly the 4\u00d7400-meter relay, if he's chosen for the team.\n\nLyles' confidence after the race for the rest of the Olympics is - not surprisingly - sky-high.\n\n\"I'll just leave it there, I'll be winning,\" he said.\n\n\"None of them are winning,\" he added of the 200-meter field. \"When I come off the turn, they will be depressed.\"", "source": {"uri": "theatlantavoice.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Atlanta Voice | Atlanta GA News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8259112972", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "21:27:24", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T21:27:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T21:26:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.irishtimes.com/sport/athletics/2024/08/04/noah-lyles-takes-mens-100m-gold-by-narrowest-margin-in-dramatic-olympic-final/", "title": "Noah Lyles takes men's 100m gold by narrowest margin in dramatic Olympic final", "body": "American earns victory by five thousandths of a second from Jamaica's Kishane Thompson, with Fred Kerley in third\n\nAn extraordinary men's 100m final came down to a photo finish and five thousandths of a second. That was the margin between the American Noah Lyles and the Jamaican Kishane Thompson, who both crossed the line in 9.79sec. After a long wait, and plenty of racing hearts, Lyles was declared the winner.\n\nAnother American, Fred Kerley, took bronze in 9.81, with the South African Akani Simbine fourth.\n\nWhen Lyles won the world 200m title in 2022 he set his sights on a daring new goal: becoming a global star and influencer. It sounded like a preposterous dream. But then he won three gold medals at the 2023 world championships in Budapest. And, with the Netflix cameras and boom mics in tow, he also emerged as the co-star of the docu-series Sprint. Now, after this, everything is on the table for him.\n\nLyles had been last after 15 metres, his start less explosive than his main rivals. But over the last few metres he closed on Thompson in front of him, before getting the dip on the line.\n\nWhen Netflix made Sprint, which has brought the adrenalised thrills of the 100m to an entirely new audience, it never even bothered to speak to either Thompson or Oblique Seville. Instead, most of its focus was directed at those with a star spangled banner on their vest, including Lyles and Kerley.\n\n[ Olympics: Complete day-by-day guide to the Irish athletes in action in ParisOpens in new window ]\n\nIt meant that when the sprinters were introduced to the crowd of 75,000 at the Stade de France with a dazzling show and the soundtrack of Kavinsky, Lyles and Kerley were given the biggest cheers.\n\nAs they were introduced, Thompson roared like the king of the jungle, while Kerley put his fingers to his lips. Lyles, meanwhile, bounded halfway down the track, hollering in excitement\n\n.\n\nNormally the sprinters do not have to wait long to start after that. Instead, they were kept an age standing on the blocks, as the crowd clapped and the music played. Perhaps that explained why they all seemed to run tight, and the times were less quick than had been expected.\n\nIf the race had been 99 metres, Thompson would have been celebrating, but fast-finishing Lyles kept his form superbly and timed his dip expertly to add Olympic gold to his world title.\n\nHe ripped his bib name from his shirt and held it aloft, announcing himself, as he had always promised, as the fastest man in the world.\n\n\"It's the one I wanted, it's the hard battle, it's the amazing opponents,\" said Lyles, the first American Olympic 100m champion since Justin Gatlin in 2004.\n\n\"Everybody came prepared for the fight and I wanted to prove that I'm the man among all of them, I'm the wolf among wolves.\"\n\nAkani Simbini of South Africa was fourth, making it a remarkable six fourth or fifth finishes in global championships, albeit with the consolation of a national record of 9.83.\n\nDefending champion Lamont Marcell Jacobs of Italy, heavily strapped, finished fifth in 9.85, and such was the quality of the race that even eighth-placed Oblique Seville of Jamaica still clocked 9.91 seconds.\n\nIt was the first time that eight men have broken 10 He didn't win! Jamaica won that gold \ud83c\uddef\ud83c\uddf2. This race needs to be reviewed!\"\n\n\"Thompson got Robbed . . . There's NO way Lyles won that one !!\"\n\nDespite the murmurs, Lyles' head dip at the line stands as a textbook example of the technical precision needed to win at the highest level of athletics.\n\nEarlier, Legit.ng reported that Noah Lyles has inspired his fans with a message of resilience and belief after winning Gold at the Paris Olympics with a finish time of 9.784 seconds.\n\nThe American sprinter beat Jamaica's Kishane Thompson on the line after both athletes clocked similar times in a tension-packed 100 meters final.\n\nLyles, the newly crowned 100-meter champion, took to social media not to boast but to inspire. {"uri": "8260036604", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "11:59:59", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T11:59:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T11:58:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.newsweek.com/noah-lyles-100m-olympics-data-how-win-1934533", "title": "How Noah Lyles won 100m Olympic title, according to data", "body": "New data has revealed exactly how American sprinter Noah Lyles was able to snatch victory by the narrowest of margins after a dramatic photo-finish at the Olympics on Sunday.\n\nThe 27-year-old athlete's gold-winning performance in the 100m race was even more remarkable given his poor start, which saw him trailing in last place before he managed to recover and storm ahead at the Stade de France.\n\nBut the finish line was so closely contested that the runners faced an agonizing wait as officials scrutinized footage of the final seconds, and Lyles himself told Kishane Thompson, 23, that he believed the Jamaican had won. He was wrong; Lyles had taken gold by just five thousandths of a second.\n\nLyles is known for his relatively weak starts, and his gold-winning race was no exception. In fact, the American's start was the joint slowest; he shared a 0.178 reaction time with Botswana's Letsile Tebogo. When told that statistic after the race by a journalist, Lyles said: \"Slowest reaction time -- that's crazy! I thought I was a little better than that but that goes to prove that reaction time does not win races.\"\n\nThe slow start looked as if it had destroyed his chances, and he was still trailing in last place some 40 meters in.\n\nBut expert analysis of the race reveals how Lyles managed to pick up speed as the finish line approached.\n\nTwo-time Olympian Ashton Eaton, a mechanical engineer who won gold twice in the decathlon but now works in research and development at Nike, shared a string of data on the race. Posting on X (formerly Twitter), Eaton revealed how researchers were able to work out the runners' exact speeds using the precise location of cameras filming the race and time-stamped footage.\n\nThe analysis revealed that Lyles was in third place after 60m, but -- crucially -- he was now running his fastest at 43.5 km/h (27.02 mph). At that point, Thompson was in first place, but was running at 43.1 km/h (26.7 mph).\n\nLyles' top speed during the race was higher than any other runner (43.6 km/h or 27.09 mph), which allowed him to reach the front of the pack alongside Thompson, whose own top speed was 43.3 km/h (26.9 mph).\n\nThe two men stood together as they anxiously watched the screen immediately after the end of the race. \"Come on man!\" Thompson roared with impatience as he waited for the big screen to display the official results. Lyles told Thompson at one point: \"I think you've got the Olympics, big dog.\"\n\nHowever, the images showed that although Thompson's foot had hit the line first, Lyles' torso was marginally ahead -- and that's what counts.\n\nLyles' winning time was 9.784 seconds, while Thompson had clocked 9.789 seconds (a difference of just 0.005 seconds). The bronze medal was taken by another American, Fred Kerley, who finished in 9.81 seconds.\n\nAfter the results were announced, a stunned but delighted Lyles took off for a run around the track clutching the Stars and Stripes. Speaking to reporters afterward, he said of Thompson: \"He was in lane four, I was in lane seven, so I couldn't really see what was happening. I continued to run like I would win it. Something told me: 'I need to lean.' It is that type of race. It was crazy.\" He added: \"I am going around as the Olympic champion; I have that title as the world's fastest man. This has been years in the making.\"\n\nThompson was magnanimous in accepting second place and insisted the gold should not be shared, despite the closeness of the race was and given he was actually the first person to touch the finish line.\n\n\"I think the sport is too competitive, no offense to any other sport,\" he said. \"It's too competitive for us to share a gold medal.\"", "source": Lyles edged out Jamaica's Kishane Thompson in one of the closest Olympic 100m finishes, with just five thousandths of a second separating them. Both runners recorded a time of 9.79 seconds, but Lyles' exact time was 9.784, compared to Thompson's 9.789.\n\nNoah Lyles was crowned the fastest man on the planet after a stunning photo finish awarded him the gold medal in the 100m sprint at the Paris Olympics. In one of the closest 100m races in Olympic history, Lyles narrowly edged out Kishane Thompson for the gold by five-thousandths of a second, with both athletes recording a time of 9.79 seconds. Fred Kerley secured the bronze medal, finishing with a time of 9.81 seconds.\n\nALSO ON ABP Live | Yusuf Dikec's Daughter Reveals Tips She Gave Turkish Shooter Ahead Of Olympics 2024 Silver Medal Win\n\nNoah Lyles becomes the first American sprinter to win an Olympic gold medal in the prestigious men's 100m race since the 2004 Athens Olympics. The last American to achieve this feat was Justin Gatlin.\n\nLyles previously won bronze in the 200-metre at the Tokyo 2020 Olympics and is now aiming for more success in the 200-metre and 4\u00d7100-metre relay events in Paris. His victory in the 100-metre sprint adds to his achievements from the 2023 World Athletics Championships, where he won gold in the 100-metre, 200-metre, and 4\u00d7100-metre relay.\n\nUsain Bolt, celebrated for his eight Olympic gold medals and world records in the 100m and 200m, remains unbeaten with a 9.63-second Olympic 100m record and a 9.58-second world record. Noah Lyles, who won the 100m in 9.79 seconds at the Paris Olympics, aims to match Bolt's feat by winning both the 100m and 200m. {"uri": "8259060734", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "20:17:07", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T20:17:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T20:16:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.amny.com/sports/olympics-noah-lyles-100m-8-4-24/", "title": "Olympics 2024: Noah Lyles win 100m gold to take fastest man crown, ends 20-year American drought | amNewYork", "body": "Paris 2024 Olympics - Athletics - Men's 100m Final - Stade de France, Saint-Denis, France - August 04, 2024. Gold medallist Noah Lyles of United States celebrates after the men's 100m final. REUTERS/Sarah Meyssonnier\n\nNoah Lyles talked the talk, walked the walk, and ran the race.\n\nThe 27-year-old Gainesville, FL native is the Olympic champion at the men's 100m dash at the 2024 Paris Games, ending a 20-year-old American drought in the event in a photo finish.\n\nLyles, the 2023 world champion, defeated Jamaica's Kishane Thompsom -- widely regarded as the favorite for this race -- by the slimmest of margins of 0.005 seconds (five-one-thousandths). Justin Gatlin was the last American to win gold in this race at the 2004 Games in Athens.\n\nThe finish was so close that it was Thompson who initially believed that he won the race. It was not until a short review and a tense wait that Lyles and the world learned that he was a champion when it showed the American's torso breaking over the finish line first.\n\nHis official time of 9.784 seconds was a personal best while Thompson's debut at a major competition yielded a time of 9.789 seconds.\n\nThompson's silver ensures that Jamaica's wait for a first gold since Usain Bolt's retirement continues while Fred Kerley -- a silver medalist at the Tokyo Games three years ago -- took bronze to put two Americans on the podium. Kerley's time of 9.81 seconds was a season-best for him and just two-one-hundredths of a second back of the top two.\n\nLyles did not win either of his qualifying races in Paris but remained as confident as ever.\n\n\"It wasn't tougher. I was more expecting that they would just fall in line and they didn't,\" Lyles said leading up to the race. \"They took it as 'I got one shot and I'm going to take it.' And to be honest, I should have expected that knowing that this is the Olympics. But this is my first time in an Olympic 100. I didn't. That's on me and I won't let that happen again.\"\n\nSouth Africa's Akani Simbine finished just one-hundredth of a second behind Kerley for bronze while the defending Olympic 100m champion, Italy's Lamont Marcell Jacobs, finished fifth with a 9.85-second sprint.\n\nA third American in the field, Kenny Bednarek, finished seventh.", "source": {"uri": "amny.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8259608152", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "07:18:52", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T07:18:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T07:17:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://ca.sports.yahoo.com/news/the-inspiration-behind-noah-lyles-100-meter-gold-medal-run-at-the-2024-olympics-015647214.html", "title": "The inspiration behind Noah Lyles' 100-meter gold medal run at the 2024 Olympics", "body": "PARIS -- Noah Lyles didn't hesitate when asked what inspired his epic victory in Sunday night's impossibly close, impossibly dramatic Olympic men's 100 meters final.\n\nThe newly crowned world's fastest man rummaged in a bag and retrieved the Tokyo bronze medal that he packed before leaving for Paris last month.\n\n\"I was fueled as soon as I saw this in my hands,\" Lyles said, holding the bronze medal aloft.\n\nTo Lyles, the medal is not a prize that he earned but a symbol of the lowest moment of his track and field career. He brought it with him to the Stade de France the past few days because the sight of it instantly motivates him.\n\nLyles won his first career Olympic gold medal in a photo finish on Sunday night, coming from behind to overtake Jamaica's Kishane Thompson and edge him by five-thousandths of a second. He is the first American to capture first place in the men's 100 since Justin Gatlin did it 20 years ago.\n\nThat victory could be the beginning of a transformative week for Lyles in Paris if all goes according to plan. He is a heavy favorite to win gold in the 200 this week and he is the most obvious choice to run the anchor leg in the men's 4x100-meter relay. Lyles might even talk his way into running a leg of the men's 4x400-meter relay and seizing the rare chance to win a fourth gold medal in the same Olympics.\n\nFor Lyles, the path to this moment of glory began three years ago. He doesn't achieve gold in Paris if he weren't humbled by settling for bronze in Tokyo.\n\nDuring the buildup to the Tokyo Olympics, Lyles was not in a good head space. The depression that he had dealt with when bullied as a kid had returned, fueled by the isolation of the COVID-19 pandemic, the murder of George Floyd and uncertainty surrounding when or if the postponed Tokyo Olympics would ever happen.\n\nThe mental health issues affected his performance.Lyles finished a distant seventh in the 100 final at the 2021 U.S. Olympic Trials. He only qualified for Tokyo in his signature 200.\n\nWhen Lyles arrived in Tokyo to find empty stadiums, strict COVID protocols and minimal support from family or friends, his mental health further deteriorated. Standing on the starting line, staring at nothing but empty seats before the men's 200 final, track's ultimate showman remembers thinking, \"This is not fun. This is not it.\"\n\nLyles, then 24 and already the best 200-meter runner in the world, finished third in the 200 that day, then just his second career loss at that distance as a professional. He uncharacteristically couldn't hold a slim lead as he rounded the curve and let Canada's Andre De Grasse and fellow American Kenny Bednarek overtake him.\n\nWhen Lyles spoke to reporters that night, he called his bronze medal \"boring.\" He sobbed as he talked about his own mental health struggles, about antidepressants causing him to gain weight, about having to cycle off that medication to prepare for Olympic Trials.\n\nLyles returned home saying to himself, \"I've got to change. I've got to evolve.\" Recommitting to therapy, he says, is what made the biggest difference for him. Therapy helped him overcome his crippling fears of returning to the track, to convert the disappointment of Tokyo into fuel for future success and to lay out a psychological game plan for race days.\n\nWhereas before he felt pressure to live up to other people's expectations or anxious before big races, now Lyles says he tries to frame it as if he is \"extremely curious as to what is going to happen.\"\n\n\"That's how me and my therapist phrase it,\" he said, smiling. \"I'm curious what I'm going to do. How am I going to pull this off?\"\n\nThe change that Lyles wanted to see didn't take years or even months. It took weeks. Only a month after the Tokyo Olympics, Lyles ran a world-leading time in the 200 at the Prefontaine Classic. He followed that up in 2022 by eclipsing Michael Johnson's American record in the 200 and last year by pulling off the rare sprint treble at World Championships last year.\n\nWhen another Olympic year arrived, Lyles this time has been ready to seize the moment. The motivation that he has needed is his unwanted Tokyo keepsake.\n\n\"I'll be like, 'Yeah, I think I'm doing enough,\" Lyles said earlier this summer. \"Then I turn around and look at the medal -- 'All right, back to work.'\"", "source": {"uri": "ca.sports.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo Sports Canada"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": Back then, Britain's Allan Wells narrowly beat Silvio Leonard in an era when timing didn't go down into the thousandths of a second.\n\nLyles is the first American to win the celebrated race since Justin Gatlin in 2004.\n\nAnd 9.784 also marks a personal best for Lyles, who has been promising to add his own brand of excitement to track and certainly delivered this time.\n\nHe will be a favorite later this week in the 200 meters -- his better race -- and will try to join Usain Bolt as the latest runner to win both Olympic sprints.\n\n___\n\nTHIS IS A BREAKING NEWS UPDATE. AP's earlier story follows below.\n\nNoah Lyles finished behind Jamaica's Oblique Seville in the semifinal of the Olympic 100 meters Sunday but still advanced for a rematch in the gold-medal race later in the evening.\n\nSeville is now 2-0 this season against Lyles after finishing in 9.81 seconds, good for a .02-second margin over the American champion.\n\nSeville got off to a stronger start than Lyles, and the American made up ground over the last 40 meters but couldn't completely close the gap. Lyles also lost his opening-round heat -- to Britain's Louie Hinchliffe on Saturday. Hinchliffe finished third in the semifinal and did not advance.\n\nJoining Lyles in the eight-man final will be Jamaica's Kishane Thompson, who won his semifinal in 9.80 seconds, the fastest time in the three semifinal. Thompson also has the world's best time this year at 9.77; he and Seville are trying to put Jamaica back on top of the Olympic podium for the first time since Usain Bolt retired after the 2016 Games.\n\nDefending champion Marcell Jacobs of Italy finished third in the second semifinal and advanced because his 9.92 was the best among sprinters who didn't automatically qualify by finishing in the top two in their heats.\n\nAlso in the final will be Americans Kenny Bednarek and Fred Kerley, Botswana's Letsile Tebogo and South Africa's Akani Simbine.\n\nOther gold medals on the line Sunday {"uri": "8259159998", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "22:35:43", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T22:35:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T22:35:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.thehindu.com/sport/olympics/lyles-wins-olympic-100m-gold-in-closest-finish-in-modern-history/article68486313.ece", "title": "Lyles wins Olympic 100m gold in closest finish in modern history", "body": "World champion Noah Lyles roared to victory in 9.79sec to claim gold in a dramatic men's Olympic 100m final in Paris on Sunday.\n\nLyles won in the closest Olympic 100m finish in modern history as just five thousandths of a second separated him from Jamaica's Kishane Thompson.\n\nBoth were given the rounded-up time of 9.79sec but the American's name carried the all-important (.784) to Thompson's (.789.)\n\nIt made Lyles the first American, male or female, to win the event since Justin Gatlin took gold in the 2004 Athens Games.\n\n\"It's the one I wanted,\" said Lyles, whose winning time was a personal best. \"It's the hard battle, it's the amazing opponents.\n\n\"Everybody's healthy, everybody came prepared for the fight and I wanted to prove that I'm the man amongst all of them. I'm the wolf amongst wolves.\"\n\nLyles' victory was only confirmed after a photo-finish.\n\nThe American said of the wait for the final results: \"I went up to Kishane and I was like, 'I'm going to be honest, bro, I think you had that one'.\n\n\"And I was fully prepared to see his name pop up and to see my name pop up, I'm like goodness gracious. I'm incredible.\"\n\nLyles added: \"It's been a rollercoaster, ups and downs.\n\n\"I'm usually a guy who likes to come out blazing in all my rounds, especially in the 200m. But the 100m, it's my first time here on the Olympic stage.\"\n\nNot 'fresh enough'\n\nThe relatively unknown Thompson, the fastest man this year with a best of 9.77sec, said he hadn't been \"fresh enough\" over the final 30 metres.\n\n\"I couldn't really see Lyles, I wasn't sure,\" 23-year-old Thompson said of the photo-finish. \"It was that close.\n\n\"I'm going to take it and move forward from here,\" he said. \"Everybody loves a winner so I would have loved to win today, but I loved the competition overall.\"\n\nLyles' U.S. teammate Fred Kerley took bronze in 9.81sec, just one-hundredth ahead of South African Akani Simbine, who timed 9.82sec.\n\n\"I don't feel any frustration because I'm facing the best in the world,\" said Kerley, the 2022 world champion and Olympic silver medallist over 100m three years ago at the Tokyo Games.\n\n\"At the end of the day, not many people can say they came to the Olympic Games,\" Kerley said. \"Whoever came off the best is the best. It's my second time around and I'm going off with a medal.\"\n\nIn an astonishing race, defending champion Marcell Jacobs of Italy was fifth in 9.85sec, Botswana's Letsile Tebogo sixth in 9.86sec, American Kenny Bednarek seventh in 9.88sec and Jamaican Oblique Seville eighth in 9.91sec.\n\nStarting in lane seven, outside Seville and inside Tebogo, Lyles got off to an average start but was soon into his stride pattern.\n\nHead tucked down through to the 40-metre mark, the American opened up, but the whole field pushed him all the way.\n\nAs Lyles dipped for the line with Thompson charging alongside him, the crowd erupted and a photo-finish was called before Lyles was confirmed as gold medallist.\n\nTense buildup\n\nThere was an electric pre-race atmosphere in a 69,000-capacity Stade de France, a light show and booming music keeping the crowd entertained as the sprinters adjusted their starting blocks.\n\nThe lights then went off and the sprinters leaving the track to remake their entrance like prize fighters in a colosseum, with each sprinter individually introduced behind an image of their name above their flag.\n\nThompson roared, hands clenched in fists as his head rolled back. Kerley patted his heart.\n\nLyles bounded out like a kangaroo, bouncing 20 metres down the track. Jacobs was the definition of cool, raising both arms and calmly walking to his blocks.\n\nThen came the moment where the sprinters set, at the starter's beck and call.\n\nThe wait seemed interminable. The music continued, the crowd clapped in unison, then the sprinters stood in their lanes, rocking from foot to foot and the tension was palpable, while the only sound was that of a helicopter whirring overhead.\n\nThe shot was fired and the field moved as if one up the purple track to the dramatic denouement.\n\nThe photo-finish officials examined the evidence and Lyles walked away with gold to bury the demons of the Tokyo Olympics three years ago where he harvested a mere 200m bronze.\n\nAsked whether he was confident of doubling up in the 200m, an event in which he is a three-time world champion, Lyles was in no doubt.\n\n\"100 percent,\" he said. \"That's my better event and now that I've got a new PR in the 100, I'm ready to take it to the 200.\"\n\nRead Comments", "source": {"uri": "8259081340", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "20:45:53", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T20:45:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T20:44:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/noah-lyles-wins-dramatic-olympic-203559069.html", "title": "Noah Lyles wins dramatic Olympic 100m final in photo finish from Kishane Thompson", "body": "World champion, Olympic champion. Noah Lyles talked an awful lot of talk in the build-up to Paris 2024, but tonight he backed up the bluster with blistering speed on the Stade de France track, surging past the field to pip them all on the line. There can be no argument now. \"What's the title of Olympic champion?\" Lyles said, referring to \"the fastest man on the planet\" tag that goes with gold. \"Amen.\"\n\nIt doesn't matter that he didn't get near the world record he said he'd break, finishing in 9.79. It doesn't matter that the winning margin was only five thousandths of a second, a time too miniscule to comprehend. Jamaica's Kishane Thompson had been burdened with the title of heir to Usain Bolt after running the fastest time this year, and he led for 99m of this race. But Lyles is a fighter and he dug in, hauling himself alongside Thompson as they crossed the line.\n\nThompson roared in celebration but his face dropped when the giant screen displayed \"photo finish\" by his name. They stared up from purgatory, waiting for the verdict. Lyles paced with his hands on his head. Then it came, and Lyles was off again, one moment ripping the number from his chest and raising it to the gods, the next streaking across the hammer field with the stars and stripes flapping in the wind.\n\nThompson was awarded silver as Lyles' US teammate Fred Kerley took bronze. Lyles admitted afterwards that he thought he was too late.\n\n\"I went to Kishane, I said, 'I'll be honest, I think you had that one'. I was prepared to see his name pop up. I saw my name pop up and I said, 'Goodness gracious, I'm incredible'. It's the one I wanted. It's the hard battle, the amazing opponents, everybody was healthy and came to fight. "https://media.zenfs.com/en/the_independent_577/6d4b0000d53c0ff8f50040ce94e237d4", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9790103", "eventUri": "eng-9790103", "location": null, "extractedDates": {"uri": "8259299745", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "02:10:06", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T02:10:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T02:08:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://cbs58.com/news/noah-lyles-takes-the-olympic-gold-in-the-100-meter-dash-by-the-slimmest-of-margins", "title": "Noah Lyles takes the Olympic gold in the 100-meter dash by the slimmest of margins", "body": "Saint-Denis, France (CNN) -- An American is once again the world's fastest man.\n\nNoah Lyles earned that title and the gold medal in the men's 100-meter dash by the slimmest of margins - just five-thousandths of a second - on Sunday night outside Paris, exploding down the track at the Stade de France and leaning in to cross the finish line ahead of favorite Kishane Thompson of Jamaica.\n\nThe victory ends a 20-year Olympic drought in the event for the USA, when Justin Gatlin won the 100-meter race in Athens. It also cements Lyles as the premier American superstar in this sport as the charismatic 27-year-old sprinter had already been one of the top faces of track and field with his blazing speed and viral moments.\n\nThompson, who was the betting favorite in the race, took the silver medal and American Fred Kerley took home the bronze.\n\nIt was a sterling version of the signature Olympic race. Taking place on the same night as the women's high jump final and the men's hammer throw final, along with qualifying heats in multiple other races, the showpiece event didn't begin until all those other competitions were done for the day.\n\nWhen the time came, the lights went out in the Stade de France just as the sun had nearly set. And then it lit back up as wristbands on the 80,000 spectators in the stadium began to flash, creating another one of the dazzling light shows that these Paris Olympics are becoming known for.\n\nEach competitor received an introduction, but Lyles took it like no other, bounding nearly halfway down the track to hype up the crowd and let off a little emotion. Lyles has gone viral in the past for such pre-race moves like pulling out Yu-Gi-Oh! cards before key races, but this time it was only his energy on display.\n\nWhen all the competitors had entered the track, they stood waiting for what felt like an eternity as dramatic music played throughout the stadium.\n\nEventually, the music stopped and the competitors settled into the starting blocks. The stadium fell completely silent - tens of thousands and all one could hear was the wind - before the horn sounded. A mighty roar cut the tension as the sprinters hung together in a tight pack through the first 50 meters of the race.\n\nThere was some separation in the back half of the less-than-10-second contest - the first 100-meter Olympic final in which running a 10-second qualifying heat would not guarantee passage to the final race and the first where every competitor ran sub-10 seconds with a legal wind, according to World Athletics - but not nearly enough for it to be clear who won when the runners crossed the finish line.\n\nThe pack of panting sprinters gathered at the northeastern bend in the track, doubled over catching their breath while they stared up at the big screen, waiting for results. For a while, it only read \"Photo,\" indicating a photo finish.\n\nAnd then the update came through: Lyles had done it.\n\nHe took off again, bounding around the track in ecstasy.\n\nThat photo finish makes it one of the most incredible and dramatic 100-meter races in Olympic history.\n\nThe final times - Lyles finishing in 9.784 seconds, Thompson in 9.789 - tell the story neatly. But it's not the whole tale, given Lyles' qualifying rounds over the last two days.\n\nThe American finished second in both the first round and the semifinal qualifiers, seeming to do just enough to get to the final race but being underwhelming enough for fans to wonder if all of Lyles' bravado was going to be overmatched on this biggest of stages.\n\nLyles said afterward that he was convinced Thompson had beat him to the line.\n\n\"It was a crazy moment because, like I said, I did think that because Kishane had that and I was like, 'Man, I really, you know, have to swallow my pride,' which I don't have a problem doing because respect deserves respect,\" he said.\n\nBut when his name popped up on the board first, he knew he'd earned the right to celebrate a bit.\n\n\"I was like, I didn't do this against a slow field. I did this against the best of the best on the biggest stage with the biggest pressure. And seeing the names, I was like, 'Oh my gosh, there it is.'\"\n\nThompson, meanwhile, crushed the competition in each of his races, simply on cruise control until he reached the final. His nation's long history of sprinting success and his own cool demeanor appeared to be enough wind at his back to get him across the finish line first.\n\nThompson put the defeat on himself, telling reporters that he didn't trust himself enough.\n\n\"I really beat myself today in that I didn't trust myself and my speed to bring myself to the line in first place,\" he said, giving kudos to Lyles and the rest of the field for pushing him.\n\nThe American champion is hoping Sunday night's result is just the start of a historic Games - and he won't have a lot of time to rest on his laurels.\n\nLyles' signature race - this was his first time running the 100m at the Olympics - is the 200-meters and qualification for that distance begins on Monday morning.\n\nHe's also aiming to add a pair of relay medals on his neck - the men's 4x100-meter relay and possibly the 4x400-meter relay, if he's chosen for the team.\n\nLyles' confidence after the race for the rest of the Olympics is - not surprisingly - sky-high.\n\n\"I'll just leave it there, I'll be winning,\" he said.\n\n\"None of them are winning,\" he added of the 200-meter field. \"When I come off the turn, they will be depressed.\"\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. {"uri": "2024-08-443937273", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "23:48:02", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T23:48:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T22:53:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/sports/national_sports/kishane-thompson-relishes-silver-after-being-on-wrong-end-of-olympic-100-meter-photo-finish/article_df850132-2bcf-5e6a-a59e-46e3ba09dbd9.html", "title": "Kishane Thompson relishes silver after being on wrong end of Olympic 100-meter photo finish", "body": "Oblique Seville, of Jamaica, Akani Simbine, of South Africa, Kishane Thompson, of Jamaica, and Fred Kerley, of the United States, react as they cross the finish line in the men's 100 meters final at the 2024 Summer Olympics, Sunday, Aug. 4, 2024, in Saint-Denis, France. Noah Lyles, of the United States, won, Thompson was second and Kerley third.\n\nSAINT-DENIS, France (AP) -- Kishane Thompson let out a scream after crossing the finish line that was fitting of an Olympic 100-meter champion. Because, for a brief moment, he thought maybe he was.\n\nBy the slimmest of margins, Thompson was beaten out for gold on a perfectly timed lean from American Noah Lyles on Sunday night. Their times of 9.79 seconds needed to be calculated farther out to determine the winner -- with Lyles winning 9.784 to 9.789. Thompson was five-thousandths of a second away from joining the company of fellow Jamaican Usain Bolt as an Olympic champion.\n\n\"I'm a bit disappointed,\" Thompson said. \"But I am happy at the same time. I am going to take it as what it is and move forward from here.\"\n\nSomeone asked Thompson soon after if he thought the gold medal could be shared, since it was that close of race. It would be a nod to the high jumpers at the Tokyo Games in 2021, when Gianmarco Tamberi of Italy and Mutaz Barshim of Qatar agreed to split the gold medal.\n\nSomehow, Thompson didn't think Lyles would go for the idea.\n\n\"I think the sport is too competitive, no offense to any other sport,\" the 23-year-old Thompson said. \"It's too competitive for us to share a gold medal.\"\n\nThe race was barely over and Thompson was already replaying the little things that could've made a big difference. Maybe more of a lean. Maybe a bit more patience to let his speed propel him to the finish line.\n\n\"I know that Jamaica would have wanted me to get the gold,\" he said. \"Everybody loves winners.\"\n\nThompson was in Lane 4 in the final and Lyles in Lane 7. He couldn't see Lyles out that far so he wasn't sure precisely where he stood right after the finish. Thompson knew it was close and immediately glanced at the scoreboard for an answer.\n\nHe waited. They all waited.\n\nLyles gave him a glimmer of hope, though.\n\n\"I did think Thompson had it at the end,\" Lyles said. \"I even said, 'Bro, I think you got that one big dog. And then my name popped up, and I'm like, 'Oh my gosh, I'm amazing.'\"\n\nThompson became the first Jamaican to be on the podium in the men's Olympic 100 since Bolt's run of three straight titles in 2008, '12 and '16.\n\n\"My body language will not show it because I am not an expressive guy, but I am glad,\" Thompson said. \"I'm super grateful.\"\n\nThompson entered the race with the fastest time of the season and was viewed as the biggest threat to Lyles. It came down to the wire with all eight sprinters separated by a margin of .12 seconds -- and even closer for gold and silver.\n\n\"That close,\" Thompson said. \"It was that close.\"\n\nAP Summer {"uri": "8259083175", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "20:52:39", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T20:52:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T20:46:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/noah-lyles-wins-dramatic-olympic-203559069.html", "title": "'I'm incredible': Noah Lyles backs up fighting talk with gold in dramatic Olympic 100m final", "body": "World champion, Olympic champion. Noah Lyles talked an awful lot of talk in the build-up to Paris 2024, but tonight he backed up the bluster with blistering speed on the Stade de France track, surging past the field to pip them all on the line. There can be no argument now. \"What's the title of Olympic champion?\" Lyles said, referring to \"the fastest man on the planet\" tag that goes with gold. \"Amen.\"\n\nIt doesn't matter that he didn't get near the world record he said he'd break, finishing in 9.79. It doesn't matter that the winning margin was only five thousandths of a second, a time too miniscule to comprehend. Jamaica's Kishane Thompson had been burdened with the title of heir to Usain Bolt after running the fastest time this year, and he led for 99m of this race. But Lyles fought back from dead last at 40m to be alongside Thompson as they crossed the line.\n\nThompson roared in celebration but his face dropped when the giant screen displayed \"photo finish\" by his name. They stared up from purgatory, waiting for the verdict. Lyles paced with his hands on his head. Then it came, and Lyles was off again, one moment ripping the number from his chest and raising it to the gods, the next streaking across the hammer field with the stars and stripes flapping in the wind.\n\nThompson was awarded silver as Lyles' US teammate Fred Kerley took bronze. Lyles admitted afterwards that he thought he was too late.\n\n\"I went to Kishane, I said, 'I'll be honest, I think you had that one'. I was prepared to see his name pop up. I saw my name pop up and I said, 'Goodness gracious, I'm incredible'. It's the one I wanted. It's the hard battle, the amazing opponents, everybody was healthy and came to fight. I'm the wolf among wolves.\"\n\nThompson hoped to be the first Jamaican man since Bolt to win a global 100m title.\n\n\"I'm a bit disappointed but I'm super happy and grateful at the same time,\" he said, \"I've just got to take it as it is and move forward from here.\n\n\"I wasn't patient enough with my speed and myself, I should have let my speed bring me to the line. I've learned from it. I couldn't see Noah, but I think he could see me and said, 'hey, Kishane, I thought you got it'. But I wasn't sure, he was too far to my right, so I wasn't sure. This is my closest race. {"uri": "2024-08-443881408", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "21:15:43", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T21:15:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T21:13:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://eu.freep.com/story/sports/olympics/2024/08/04/olympic-track-live-results/74665582007/", "title": "Olympic track live updates: Noah Lyles is World's Fastest Man in 100 meters photo finish", "body": "After a disappointing performance in 2021, a fire was lit under Noah Lyles to become the fastest man in the world. He just needs to improve by 1%.\n\nSAINT-DENIS, France -- Noah Lyles is the fastest man in the world.\n\nThe U.S. sprinter won the 100 at the Paris Olympics. Lyles crossed the finish line with a gold-medal winning time of 9.79 in a photo finish to win track and field's marquee sprint event.\n\nKishane Thompson ran a 9.79 to finish second and Fred Kerley came in third, posting a time of 9.81 to get bronze.\n\nThe runners had to wait for photo review moments after the race and didn't know who won seconds after the race.\n\nBut the moment belonged to Lyles inside a packed house at Stade de France. Lyles is the first American sprinter to win an Olympic gold medal in the men's 100 since Justin Gatlin won gold at the 2004 Athens Games.\n\n\"It's the one I wanted, it's the hard battle, it's the amazing opponents,\" Lyles said after the race. \"Everybody came prepared for the fight and I wanted to prove that I'm the man among all of them, I'm the wolf among wolves.\"\n\nLyles came into the Olympics confident. He ran a personal-best 9.81 at last month. He told USA TODAY Sports that he wanted to win multiple Olympic gold medals. He's well on his way to achieving his goal.\n\nThe 100 victory earned Lyles his first ever Olympic gold medal. He received a bronze in the 200 at the Tokyo Olympics. He's also a six-time world champion gold medalist, but Sunday's Olympic gold medal in the 100 might be the crowning achievement of his career thus far.\n\n\u27a4 Get Olympics updates in your texts! Join USA TODAY Sports' WhatsApp Channel\n\n\u27a4 The USA TODAY app gets you to the heart of the news -- fast. Download for award-winning coverage, crosswords, audio storytelling, the eNewspaper and more.\n\nWhen does Noah Lyles run next?\n\nLyles will start his pursuit of 200-meter gold Monday with round 1 heats. He's in the sixth heat with Jamaica's Bryan Levell and Canada's Andre De Grasse, the defending 200-meter champion from Tokyo. De Grasse did not qualify for the 100 final. The first heat starts at 7:55 p.m. Monday in Paris (1:55 p.m. ET). The top three in each heat advance to the semifinals, which are Wednesday.\n\nKeisha Caine Bishop on Noah Lyles' dreams of turning pro\n\nNoah Lyles' mother knew her sons' dream of becoming professional track stars when they were still teenagers.\n\n\"In 10th grade they wanted to go professional out of high school and I was like are you crazy,\" Keisha Caine Bishop, the mother of Noah and Josephus, told USA TODAY Sports this summer.\n\nIn July 2016 when Noah was 19 years old, he and his younger brother, Josephus, 18 at the time, turned professional and signed a contract with Adidas instead of competing collegiately for the University of Florida.\n\n\"I had to go back and apologize,\" Caine Bishop said. \"I realized that's not fair to kill somebody's dream, especially if they are willing to do the work, and they were willing to do the work.\"\n\nNoah and Josephus have been running professionally since. Josephus isn't on the Olympic team in Paris but ran the 100 and 200 at Olympic trials. - Tyler Dragon\n\nNBC broadcaster incorrectly calls 100 meters race winner\n\nIf you thought Noah Lyles missed out on the gold medal in the 100-meter dash, you weren't the only one.\n\nNBC broadcaster Leigh Diffey was into the moment like the rest of the audience taking in the 100 meters, but he seemed a bit more decisive with his call than what the eye told. As the sprinters crossed the line, the cameras panned to Jamaican sprinter Kishane Thompson and Diffey declared Thompson the winner, not Lyles.\n\n\"Jamaica's gonna do it, Kishane Thompson is a gold medalist, on debut,\" Diffey declared, before going silent.\n\nThe competitors were all huddled waiting for photo evidence of the finish. When the photo did come in, it was Lyles who was the winner of the race, by just thousandths of a second over Thompson.\n\nLyles' victory secures the USA's first gold medal in the 100 meter in 20 years, and solidifies his standing as the fastest man in the world. - Joseph Rivera\n\nAccording to World Athletics, it's the first time in history that eight men have broken 10 seconds in a wind-legal race.\n\nUSA's Juliette Whittaker makes it through to 800 final\n\nJuliette Whittaker will be the only American woman in the 800-meter final after squeaking through the semifinals Sunday night.\n\nWhittaker, 20, nabbed the third and final 800-meter spot on Team USA at the Olympic trials but is now the only one of them left. Allie Wilson did not make it out of the first round, and Nia Akins fell short in the semifinals.\n\nAfter making the final and running a personal best of 1 minute, 57.76 seconds, Whittaker said she feels like she's playing with house money now.\n\n\"I think I'm just so excited now just to see what I can do tomorrow, without any expectation,\" she said. \"Even if I get last in the final, I will be overjoyed just to make it that far. So yeah, I'm just excited.\" - Tom Schad\n\n3 Americans qualify for men's 1500-meter final\n\nThere will be plenty of red, white and blue in the men's 1500-meter final.\n\nAll three Americans left in the field qualified for the final, with Yared Nuguse and Hobbs Kessler finishing first and second in one of the two semifinals to advance. Both ran under 3 minutes, 32 seconds.\n\nCole Hocker also cruised into the final after placing third in his semi and spending most of the race shadowing two of the medal favorites: Jacob Ingebrigsten of Norway and Josh Kerr of Great Britain.\n\n\"That was just the very last bit of confidence that I needed, heading into the final,\" said Hocker, who ran collegiately at Oregon. - Tom Schad\n\nUSA's Vashti Cunningham finishes fifth in women's high jump\n\nSAINT-DENIS, France - Team USA women's high jumper Vashti Cunningham missed out on a medal for the third consecutive Olympics Sunday. Still, despite a troubling back injury this season, she recorded her highest Olympic finish ever (fifth place). The daughter of former Philadelphia Eagles quarterback Randall Cunningham cleared the bar at 1.86, 1.91 and 1.95 meters, but failed on three attempts to clear 1.98 to fall out of medal contention.\n\nThe gold medal went to Ukrainian Yaroslava Mahuchikh, who cleared 2.0 meters in fewer attempts than silver medalist Nicola Olyslagers of Australia. Ukrainian Iryna Gerashchenko and Australia's Eleanor Patterson tied for the bronze.\n\nCunningham narrowly qualified for the Paris Olympics, but entered ranked No. 7 in the world. She recorded finishes of 13th at the Rio Games in 2016 and sixth at the Tokyo Games in 2021.\n\n\"I felt good about my performance. I was happy when I made the bar and when I missed the bar, I knew what I was doing wrong,\" Cunningham said. \"I just need to go back to the drawing board and work on a few things.\"\n\nAsked if she's committed to making a run at the 2028 Games in Los Angeles, Cunningham said, \"Absolutely. I'm only going to be 30 years old, guys.\" - Chase Goodbread\n\nWeather forecast for 100 final\n\nThere is no rain in the forecast for the men's 100 final. It's expected to be slightly cloudy and 71 degrees at the start of the race. The women's sprinters in Saturday's 100 final had to deal with rainy conditions.\n\nAll three American sprinters advance to 100 final\n\nNoah Lyles, Fred Kerley and Kenny Bednarek all advanced to the 100 showdown Sunday night. Lyles and Kerley placed second in their respective heats. Bednarek qualified on time.\n\nJamaica's Kishane Thompson (9.80) and Oblique Seville (9.81) have the top times entering the final.\n\nJamaica's Kishane Thompson won his third and final heat at 9.80 in what was a quick semifinal. Fred Kerley placed second at 9.84 to get the second automatic qualifying spot.\n\nNoah Lyles second in heat, qualifies for 100 final\n\nSAINT-DENIS, France -- Noah Lyles is going to have to make some adjustments ahead of the 100 final.\n\nLyles placed second his first semifinal heat, running a 9.83. Jamaica's Oblique Seville won the heat and looked at Lyles as he crossed the finish line in a personal-best time of 9.81.\n\nLyles lost to Great Britain's Louie Hinchliffe in the opening round. But all that matters is he qualified for Sunday's final.\n\nThe top two from each heat plus the next two fastest times advance to the final.\n\nHow many events is Noah Lyles going to run at Paris Olympics?\n\nNoah Lyles is slated to run the 100, 200 and 4x100 relay.\n\nQuincy Hall, Michael Norman, Christopher Bailey advance to 400 semis\n\nSAINT-DENIS, France -- All three Team USA runners advanced in the men's 400.\n\nChristopher Bailey took second in the first heat of the men's 400 to move on to the semifinal. Heat No. 1 also featured Great Britian's Matthew Hudson-Smith who has the fastest time in the world this year (43.74). Hudson-Smith won the first heat timing at 44.78.\n\nMichael Norman ran a fast 44.10 to win the second heat.\n\nQuincy Hall, the U.S. Olympic track and field trials gold medalist, sped by Australia's Reece Holder down the home stretch and crossed the line with a first-place time of 44.28 in the fourth heat.\n\nThe top three in each heat automatically advanced to Tuesday's semifinal round. Norman qualified to the semifinal with the fastest time.\n\nWhat time does Noah Lyles run the 100 semifinals?\n\nThe semifinal in the 100 is at 2:05 p.m. ET. Lyles is in the first heat and will run in lane No. 4.\n\nJamaica's Kishane Thompson is the fastest man in the world this year with a world-leading time of 9.77. Thompson eased up in the opening round in Paris and still ran a 10.00 to finish first in his heat. Thompson's Jamaican teammate, Oblique Seville, has defeated Lyles before and can make the podium.\n\nLyles' American teammates, Kenny Bednarek and Fred Kerley, are threats to reach the podium. Bednarek and Kerley both ran 9.97 to advance to the semis.\n\nThe defending Olympic champ, Marcell Jacobs of Italy, can't be counted out, either.\n\nWhat is world record in 100?\n\nThe world record in the 100 is 9.58 set by Jamaica's Usain Bolt in 2009.\n\nWhat is Olympic record in the 100?\n\nUsain Bolt ran 9.63 to win a gold medal and set the Olympic record at the 2012 London Games.\n\nLast time American won gold medal in men's 100 at Olympics\n\nJustin Gatlin was the last American male to win an Olympic gold medal in the 100. Gatlin won gold at the 2004 Athens Games. Team USA's best medal in the 100 since then has been silver medals won at the 2016 Olympics (Gatlin) and 2020 Games (Fred Kerley).", "source": {"uri": "freep.com", "dataType": "news", "title": Because, for a brief moment, he thought maybe he was.\n\nBy the slimmest of margins, Thompson was beaten out for gold on a perfectly timed lean from American Noah Lyles on Sunday night.\n\nTheir times of 9.79 seconds needed to be calculated farther out to determine the winner - with Lyles winning 9.784 to 9.789. Thompson was five-thousandths of a second away from joining the company of fellow Jamaican Usain Bolt as an Olympic champion.\n\n'I'm a bit disappointed,' Thompson said. 'But I am happy at the same time. I am going to take it as what it is and move forward from here.'\n\nSomeone asked Thompson soon after if he thought the gold medal could be shared, since it was that close of race. It would be a nod to the high jumpers at the Tokyo Games in 2021, when Gianmarco Tamberi of Italy and Mutaz Barshim of Qatar agreed to split the gold medal.\n\nKishane Thompson admitted disappointment after losing out in the men's 100m final\n\nAmerican Noah Lyles pipped Thompson by five-thousandths of a second to win the gold\n\nYour browser does not support iframes.\n\nSomehow, Thompson didn't think Lyles would go for the idea.\n\n'I think the sport is too competitive, no offense to any other sport,' the 23-year-old Thompson said. 'It's too competitive for us to share a gold medal.'\n\nThe race was barely over and Thompson was already replaying the little things that could've made a big difference. Maybe more of a lean. Maybe a bit more patience to let his speed propel him to the finish line.\n\n'I know that Jamaica would have wanted me to get the gold,' he said. 'Everybody loves winners.'\n\nThompson was in Lane 4 in the final and Lyles in Lane 7. He couldn't see Lyles out that far so he wasn't sure precisely where he stood right after the finish. Thompson knew it was close and immediately glanced at the scoreboard for an answer.\n\nHe waited. They all waited.\n\nA photo finish was needed to separate both athletes - with Lyles clinching the win after leaning\n\nLyles believed Thompson had initially done enough before his name appeared on the screens\n\nYour browser does not support iframes.\n\nLyles gave him a glimmer of hope, though.\n\n'I did think Thompson had it at the end,' Lyles said. 'I even said, \"Bro, I think you got that one big dog\". And then my name popped up, and I'm like, \"Oh my gosh, I'm amazing\".'\n\nThompson became the first Jamaican to be on the podium in the men's Olympic 100m since Bolt's run of three straight titles in 2008, '12 and '16.\n\n'My body language will not show it because I am not an expressive guy, but I am glad,' Thompson said. 'I'm super grateful.'\n\nThompson entered the race with the fastest time of the season and was viewed as the biggest threat to Lyles. {"uri": "8259371545", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "03:43:47", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T03:43:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T03:42:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://nypost.com/2024/08/04/sports/noah-lyles-delivers-inspirational-message-after-olympic-gold/", "title": "Noah Lyles delivers inspirational message about what he's overcome to...", "body": "American track and field star Noah Lyles had a message for everyone after becoming the world's fastest man on Sunday, winning the gold medal in the 100-meters at the 2024 Paris Olympics.\n\nLyles took to social media to implore his fans not to let the things they feel are obstacles in their life to define them.\n\n\"I have Asthma, allergies, dyslexia, ADD, anxiety, and Depression,\" he wrote on X Sunday night. \"But I will tell you that what you have does not define what you can become.\n\n\"Why Not You!\"\n\nLyles defeated Jamaica's Kishane Thompson by .005 seconds, with the official time coming in at 9.784 seconds and the American needing to lean as he crossed the finish line in what became a photo finish.\n\n\"We were waiting for the names to pop up, and I'm going to be honest, I came over [to Thompson] and I was like: 'I think you got that one, big dawg!'\" Lyles told reporters. \"Something said I need to lean, and I was like, 'I'm going to lean,' because it's that type of race.\"\n\nLyles became the first American to win Olympic gold in the race since 2004 when Justin Gatlin was victorious, and he'll have another chance at gold on Wednesday if he can reach the 200-meter finals.\n\nAmerican Fred Kerley took home the bronze medal in the event.\n\n\"To be honest, I just believe in myself,\" Lyles said, according to FloTrack. \"I've done worse and I've run faster 60s.
