{"uri": "2024-08-443933920", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "23:38:05", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T23:38:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T23:33:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.thenewstribune.com/sports/olympics/article290745894.html", "title": "Noah Lyles Crowned World's Fastest Man: 'It Feels Good to Back It Up'", "body": "SAINT-DENIS, France - Late Sunday, 20 minutes before a track superstar turned into an icon, Keisha Caine Bishop walked the outer ring at Stade de France with her daughter. They were pretty much alone. The sun kept dropping, nearby horizons turning purple and orange and a darker yellow, a hue that looked a lot like ...\n\nGold.\n\nShe wasn't exactly nervous. And she wasn't exactly calm.\n\nHer son, Noah Lyles-the bombastic, shoe-painting, anime-watching, LEGO-building sprinter-needed to prove that embracing every single zany slice of his ever-more public personality had made him faster.\n\n\"I just want to get this going,\" she said, smiling, in a way that indicated she knew more than she wanted to say out loud.\n\nJust before Lyles left for Paris, other confidants weren't making any predictions, but one did tell Lyles one thing: He held the thumb and pointer finger on his right hand no more than half an inch apart. A sliver maybe. The end of a pen cap. A popsicle stick, laid flat. The 100-meter final, the confidant predicted, would be that close-specifically, the physical non-distance between first place and second.\n\nLyles, 27, nearly tied the 100-meter final on Sunday. He came as close as one can in his sport to running exactly the same time as another sprinter. Five-thousandths of a single second separated the gold and silver medal winners. That's 0.005 seconds. Google: what can happen in 0.005 seconds? The primary and prevalent answer is ... nothing. At least that can be perceived.\n\nIn winning the 100-meter dash, Lyles secured his first-but not likely his last-Olympic gold medal.\n\n\"It feels good,\" he said, \"to back it up.\"\n\nA lifetime unfolded between the walk onto the track and the photo finish. It began with an extraordinary Olympic prelude. The inside of the stadium all but pulsated. A deejay, clad in a black leather jacket, wearing sunglasses at night, spun deep house. As the bright stadium bulbs went completely dark, without warning, the lights along the upper ring flashed white and purple, in sync with the beats. The crowd gasped. Spotlights scanned from one side to the other, while tiny lights sparkled throughout the stands, thanks to wristbands fans were given at the gates. The thumping bass elevated, slowly at first, then faster, faster and faster, until the whole stadium felt like a bubble of anticipation about to pop.\n\nOne-by-one, the men's 100-meter finalists made their way onto the track. Here they were, in Paris, in an Olympic final, in their sport's premier race. Kishane Thompson, a Jamaican among the favorites, leaned back in the entrance tunnel, before slowly raising both arms, tilting his head back and roaring like a lion. The camera strung above the purple track dropped and elevated, slinging left and right, before settling on the obvious suspect: Lyles.\n\nHe didn't saunter onto the track. Nor did he swagger in. He ran. Not sprinting, but not slowly. He didn't stop at the starting blocks, like everybody else. He cruised about 15 meters beyond the others.\n\nLyles never stopped moving, like he had bottled every ounce of energy and online hatred and unrealized ambition but could no longer hold it in. His feet bounced on the purple track-purple, his favorite color-springing up, then down, as if guided by a trampoline underfoot.\n\nFred Kerley, another American finalist, entered the stadium right then. He held a finger to his lips, as if to say, quiet down. Perhaps that gesture was meant for Lyles, whose general nature had grated on his competition, especially over the last six months.\n\nLyles screamed. He beat his chest with both hands. Energy seemed to rise from his body, like steam rising from a whistling kettle. He saluted, then appeared to repeat the same three words, over and over. It looked like he was saying: thank you, God.\n\nThe crowd began to clap. The introductions dragged on for minutes that unspooled like hours. The competitors-the world's fastest men-stepped in place, swayed, danced, waiting for the signal. The last Olympic 100-meter champion, Lamont Marcell Jacobs of Italy, stood still with his eyes closed.\n\nAt 9:53 p.m. local time, the sprinters leaned their bodies forward and placed their spikes into the starting blocks. The stadium dropped into near silence. The loudest sound came from the helicopters hanging overhead.\n\nAnticipation isn't the right word. The general feeling landed around start this damn thing already. The gun sounded. And off they went.\n\nFor the first few meters, Lyles sprinted from the back of the pack-perhaps, even, in last place. But that didn't last long. He caught them, all of them, these strong, powerful, human locomotives, each churning as fast as humanly possible toward the same line down the track.\n\nFor a second, it appeared that Kerley had won. Then it appeared that Lyles did. Then Thompson. Those three names flashed across the video screens, in that order. Everyone stood around the finish line.\n\nLyles approached Thompson at one point. \"Hey, man,\" Lyles told him, \"I think you got it.\"\n\nIt didn't take long for officials to come back with the results. Lyles surely must have never been happier to be dead wrong. Those same three names flashed on those same screens, only this time, in a different order: Lyles-Thompson-Kerley. The men's 100-meter final gold, silver and bronze medalists, respectively.\n\nIn the video analysis Olympic officials distributed after the race, Lyles was last, even at the 30-meter mark. He did not lead at any other point. In Lane 7, he didn't have time to look left, at Thompson in Lane 4, or Kerley in Lane 3. He told himself the obvious, in fractions of critical seconds. I need to lean. So that's what Lyles did. He leaned. They all did. Photographs from the finish line make the runners look like their necks are being bent forward by a gale-force wind.\n\nHis winning time, 9.79 seconds, matched Ben Johnson's steroid-aided world record in 1988, the one that didn't stand. Lyles began to alternately gallop and jog and walk around the track. He pumped his fists. He unleashed screams. He held his race bib, the one that read LYLES in black letters, and jumped a barrier to celebrate with Keisha and other relatives.\n\nLyles showed up as Noah on Sunday. Last month, Keisha said that the biggest difference she saw in her son from Tokyo-where he won bronze in the 200 meters-and Paris, was a fuller embrace of just how different he was. He came to a better understanding of self, which led him to a better understanding of his sport.\n\nBefore Paris, former sprinter Michael Johnson said that of all America's promising young superstars, Lyles had the best chance to vault to a new level of stardom with his results. \"But he has to do it in Paris, at the Olympics, and more than once,\" Johnson added.\n\nSunday marked an ideal start, for the six-time world champion and the now two-time Olympic medalist, who found himself and found his speed. Now, he can continue to chase one of his sport's rarest achievements in Paris. It's not a lock. But it's not that far away, either. Lyles didn't lose one 200-meter race over the 2022 and '23 seasons.\n\nBefore Sunday's final, Lyles wasn't nervous-same as Keisha on her walk. He thought back to a regular topic he had been exploring with his therapist. To not view pressure as a problem, to understand the notion that wanting something doesn't always equate to being able to automatically deliver it.\n\n\"I was extremely curious to see what was gonna happen,\" he said. \"I came in third fastest [in the semis.] This [was] not going to be easy. That's how we phrase it. I'm curious what I'm gonna do. How am I going to pull this off?\"\n\nHis therapist, Lyles said, told him to let go in those moments, to relax and be himself. Turns out, to achieve the rarest kind of greatness, and to lift his sport to the same heights he's headed toward, that was all he ever needed.\n\nThis article was originally published on www.si.com as Noah Lyles Crowned World's Fastest Man: 'It Feels Good to Back It Up'.", "source": {"uri": "thenewstribune.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The News Tribune"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8259089838", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "20:58:28", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T20:58:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T20:56:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.kob.com/news/us-and-world-news/noah-lyles-wins-olympic-100-by-five-thousandths-of-a-second-among-closest-finishes-in-games-history/", "title": "Noah Lyles wins Olympic 100 by five-thousandths of a second, among closest finishes in Games history", "body": "SAINT-DENIS, France (AP) -- Noah Lyles won the Olympic 100 meters by .005 seconds Sunday, waiting some 30 seconds after the finish of one of the closest sprints in history to find out he'd beaten Kishane Thompson of Jamaica.\n\nThe word \"Photo\" popped up on the scoreboard next to the names of Lyles, Thompson and five others after they crossed the line. Lyles paced the track with his hands draped over his head. Finally, the numbers came up. Lyles won in 9.784 seconds to edge out the Jamaican by five-thousandths of a tick of the clock.\n\nAmerica's Fred Kerley came in third at 9.81. The top seven all finished within .09 of each other.\n\nThis was the closest 1-2 finish in the 100 since at least Moscow in 1980 -- or maybe even ever. Back then, Britain's Allan Wells narrowly beat Silvio Leonard in an era when the electronic timers didn't go down into the thousandths of a second.\n\nThank goodness they do now.\n\n\"I thought I had (him) cleared,\" Thompson said. \"But I wasn't sure. It was so close.\"\n\nLyles became the first American to win the marquee event in Olympic track since Justin Gatlin in 2004.\n\nThe 9.784 also marks a personal best for Lyles, who has been promising to add his own brand of excitement to track and certainly delivered this time.\n\nHe will be a favorite later this week in the 200 meters -- his better race -- and will try to join Usain Bolt as the latest runner to win both Olympic sprints.\n\nFor perspective, the blink of an eye takes, on average, .1 second, which was 20 times longer than the gap between first and second in this one.\n\nWhat was the difference? Maybe Lyles' closing speed and his lean into the line.\n\nHe and Thompson had two of the three slowest bursts from the blocks, and Thompson had what sufficed for a \"lead\" at the halfway point. The photo finish actually shows Kerley's orange shoe well in front of the line. But it's the chest breaking the barrier that counts, and Lyles beat everyone by a sliver.\n\nIt would take more than a mere 9.7(84) seconds to decide who would supplant Marcell Jacobs as the next Olympic champion.\n\nLyles patted Thompson on the shoulder while the wait grew -- from 10, to 20, then nearly 30 seconds. When the American learned he'd added this to the 100 meters he won at world championships last year, he pulled off his name tag and raised it to the sky, then brought his hands to his side and pointed at the camera.\n\n\"America, I told you I got this!\" he yelled into the camera.\n\nYaroslava Mahuchikh won Olympic gold in the high jump for her war-torn country of Ukraine and, as a bonus, had company. Her teammate Iryna Gerashchenko won the bronze and the teammates hopped, skipped and jumped around the track parading their blue-and-yellow flags in a heartfelt celebration.\n\nMahuchikh needed fewer tries to clear the winning height of 2 meters than Australia's Nicola Olyslagers, and so, added the sport's biggest prize of all -- Olympic gold -- to her world championship and world record.\n\nKerr vs Ingebrigtsen is a go for heated men's 1,500\n\nThe best rivalry in track will culminate Tuesday when reigning world champion Josh Kerr of Britain takes on defending Olympic champion Jakob Ingebrigtsen of Norway.\n\nThey squared off in Sunday's semifinal, too, and Ingebrigtsen edged out the Brit, looking over to him twice as they surged down the homestretch, to win a race that felt like it meant more than it should have in 3:32.38.\n\n\"They should be expecting one of the most vicious and hardest 1,500s the sport's seen in a very long time,\" Kerr said.\n\nDid Ingebrigtsen agree?\n\n\"Depends who you ask, maybe,\" he said. \"I mean, racing is what you want it to be.\"\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"uri": "2024-08-443930221", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "23:27:01", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T23:27:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T23:21:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://www.washingtonpost.com/sports/olympics/2024/08/04/noah-lyles-100-meters-gold-medal-paris-olympics/", "title": "Column | In a fraction of a blink, Noah Lyles becomes an Olympic legend", "body": "Sorry, a summary is not available for this article at this time. Please try again later.\n\nSAINT-DENIS, France -- The 100 meters at the Olympics takes a blink. Cross the finish line as the eyelid closes, and you're a legend. Wait till the eyelid opens, and you're an afterthought. What a way to determine legacies.\n\nSunday night, when eight sprinters crossed the finish line at Stade de France -- all seemingly on that same down blink -- legacies couldn't be determined by the naked eye. Chests heaving, nearly the entirety of the field looked at the scoreboard, yearning for answers. Aside seven of their names sat a single word in allcaps: PHOTO.\n\nPoll the nearly 80,000 people who packed the place who won, and it might have been an even split. Cameras had to do the work. As the sprinters mingled to try to unfray their nerves, American Noah Lyles approached Jamaican Kishane Thompson.\n\n\"Bro,\" Lyles told Thompson. \"I think you got that one, big dog.\"\n\nSkip to end of carousel\n\nGet the latest updates on the 2024 Olympics\n\n(Washington Post illustration)\n\nTrack all the Paris Olympic medal counts country by country, and see the breakdown of medals by U.S. athletes. Get live updates from Paris and keep up with the latest by signing up for The Sports Moment: Olympics Edition.\n\nEnd of carousel\n\nThe first runner -- it looked to be Thompson or Lyles, but who's to say? -- crossed the line in 9.79 seconds. The last finished in 9.91. It took 28 seconds -- nearly three times as long as the race -- to show the result.\n\n\"I was not sure,\" Thompson said. \"It was that close.\"\n\nWhen the scoreboard finally revealed whose life would change irrecoverably, Lyles's name popped to the top. His time registered on the scoreboard as the same as Thompson's: 9.79 seconds. Digital photography determined the difference needed another decimal place: Lyles crossed in 9.784 seconds, Thompson in 9.789.\n\nDo the math. That's five thousandths of a second between gold and silver. American Fred Kerley crossed in 9.81 seconds. It was good only for bronze.\n\nWhatever the margin, there was the moment Lyles saw his name. He is full of brashness and bravado. The magnitude of the accomplishment was almost knee-buckling.\n\n\"I'ma be honest: I wasn't ready to see it,\" Lyles said. \"And that's the first time I've ever said that in my head. Like, I wasn't ready to see it.\"\n\nNo matter that he had prepared for so many of his 27 years to see just that: gold medal, Olympic champion, world's fastest human. A dozen years ago as a teenager, he watched the London Olympics from his Alexandria, Va., home. He saw Jamaican icon Usain Bolt win gold in both the 100 and 200 meters. He boldly wanted -- rather, he boldly decided -- to do the same.\n\n\"It feels good to back it up,\" Lyles said.\n\nHold on. He's only halfway there. But what a half.\n\nThe Paris Olympics already had been thrilling. The final week began with an event that will be hard to dislodge from the best of the competition, a race that was nothing short of historic. The 100 always has been -- and should always be -- a marquee event at the Olympics. After something of a lull in recent years, Sunday night restored that status.\n\nWhat is a more basic judge of human athletic capability than who can cover a short distance in the least amount of time? Sprinting invites preening and showmanship, trash-talking and intimidation. The race lasts 10 seconds. The show is much longer.\n\nBolt, as much as any figure in history, leaned into it all, casting himself as a distinct character. He set the world record at the 2008 Beijing Olympics, all but prancing to the finish line, inviting the world to marvel at his superiority. He won again in London and four years later in Rio, too. He seemed untouchable -- not just when he ran, but for the sprinters chasing his ghost.\n\nSo in the years since Bolt's retirement in 2017, no one has stepped in -- or, rather, no one has strutted forward -- and seized the Alpha Male role on the men's side. Maybe that changed Sunday night, both because of how the race played out and who won it.\n\nPart of Lyles's initial reaction to winning gold by five-thousandths of a second was, \"Dang, I'm amazing.\" He meant it, and he was unafraid to say so. That's a champion sprinter playing the role.\n\nWhen the field was introduced for the evening's final event, each sprinter put his stamp on the moment. Thompson, whose 9.77-second victory at the Jamaican trials was the fastest time of the year, let out a roar from his thick, 6-foot-1 frame.\n\nBy comparison, that was mundane. Lyles, running from Lane 7, was introduced next-to-last. With a sunglass-wearing, leather-jacketed DJ thumping heavy bass lines through the stadium, Lyles bounded and leaped into the arena, bouncing almost 30 yards down the track.\n\nLyles had arrived. The show could start.\n\n\"Noah Lyles is Noah Lyles,\" said Lance Brauman, Lyles's longtime coach. \"He needs to do what he does. He's not your normal guy, so you can't treat him like a normal guy. You got to let him do the things he does to get excited.\"\n\nThompson, the betting favorite, ran from Lane 4, three spots to Lyles's left. But there was danger everywhere. Oblique Seville of Jamaica came out of the semifinals with a 9.81, the third-fastest time in the world this year -- matching Lyles's personal best. Kerley lurked.\n\n\"We started the season, a lot of people were saying it's going to be a slow year in the 100,\" Lyles said. \"Well, it wasn't no slow year in the 100!\"\n\nWhen the gun went off, Lyles's reaction time matched the slowest in the field. But 30 meters into the race, he had reestablished himself.\n\n\"I was like, 'Okay, we're in the mix,'\" Brauman said. \" ... At 80 [meters], I was like, 'Holy cow, he's right there.'\"\n\nImagine working day after day, week after week -- over years -- to have your fate determined by an amount of time and space that's not perceptible to the human eye. That was Noah Lyles -- that was the entire 100-meter field -- on Sunday night at the Paris Olympics. Consider this, too: Seville finished eighth in 9.91 seconds. Never had an entire field, unaided by wind, finished the 100 in less than 10 seconds.\n\n\"Beside Usain Bolt, nobody has run faster in an Olympic race than what they just did today,\" Baumann said. \"And that will go down as the closest final in the history of the Olympic Games. Put that into context. That means something to me.\"\n\nplayPlay now\n\nNaN min\n\nFollow on\n\nPodcast episode\n\nSpotify\n\nApple\n\nGoogle\n\nAmazon\n\nIt should mean something to every human who watched it. Boundaries are being pushed. Three years ago, Noah Lyles left Tokyo -- an Olympics for which he did not qualify in the 100 -- crushed by the fact he won only bronze in the 200.\n\nSunday, his life changed because he was five thousandths of a second faster than another man. He ripped off the bib bearing his name and held it to the crowd. LYLES, it blared.\n\n\"Here I am: First Olympics in the 100, now the Olympic champion,\" Lyles said. \"And you know, having that title not just at world championships, but at the Olympics -- of the world's fastest man.\"\n\nBy a mile or a millisecond, that's the title he earned. No one can take that from him. No one can take a remarkable night from anyone who saw it, 9.784 seconds that somehow could fill hours -- rather, years -- of conversation.", "source": {"uri": "washingtonpost.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8259633487", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "07:37:32", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T07:37:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T07:36:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://www.nwaonline.com/news/2024/aug/05/photo-determines-lyles-narrow-win/", "title": "Photo determines Lyles' narrow win", "body": "SAINT-DENIS, France -- Noah Lyles won the Olympic 100 meters by .005 seconds Sunday, waiting some 30 seconds after the finish of one of the closest sprints in history to find out he'd beaten Kishane Thompson of Jamaica.\n\nThe word \"Photo\" popped up on the scoreboard next to the names of Lyles, Thompson and five others after they crossed the line.\n\nLyles paced the track with his hands draped over his head. Finally, the numbers came up. Lyles won in 9.784 seconds to edge out the Jamaican by five-thousandths of a tick of the clock.\n\nLyles said he thought he had given the win away by dipping at the line too soon, so he went up to Thompson and told him, \"Bro, I think you got that one.\"\n\n\"But then my name popped up and I'm like 'Oh my gosh, amazing!' \"\n\nAmerica's Fred Kerley came in third at 9.81.\n\n\"That's probably one of the most beautiful races I've been in,\" he said.\n\nThe top seven all finished within .09 of each other.\n\nThis was the closest 1-2 finish in the 100 since at least Moscow in 1980 -- or maybe even ever. Back then, Britain's Allan Wells narrowly beat Silvio Leonard in an era when the electronic timers didn't go down into the thousandths of a second. The same was true in 1932, when Eddie Tolan won the Olympics' first ever photo finish.\n\nThank goodness they do now.\n\n\"I thought I had (him) cleared,\" Thompson said. \"But I wasn't sure. It was so close.\"\n\nLyles became the first American to win the marquee event in Olympic track since Justin Gatlin in 2004.\n\nThe 9.784 also marks a personal best for Lyles, who has been promising to add his own brand of excitement to track and certainly delivered this time.\n\nHe will be a favorite later this week in the 200 meters -- his better race -- and will try to join Usain Bolt as the latest runner to win both Olympic sprints.\n\nFor perspective, the blink of an eye takes, on average, .1 second, which was 20 times longer than the gap between first and second in this one.\n\nWhat was the difference? Maybe Lyles' closing speed and that lean into the line that he thought was mistimed.\n\nHe and Thompson had two of the three slowest bursts from the blocks, and Thompson had what sufficed for a \"lead\" at the halfway point. The photo finish actually shows Kerley's orange shoe well in front of everything at the finish line. But it's the chest breaking the barrier that counts, and Lyles beat everyone by a sliver.\n\nWhen the American learned he had added the Olympic title to the 100 meters he won at world championships last year, he pulled off his name tag and raised it to the sky, then brought his hands to his side and pointed at the camera.\n\n\"America, I told you I got this!\" he yelled into the camera.\n\nYes, he's the World's Fastest Man. Just not by a lot.\n\nNoah Lyles, of the United States, celebrates as he wins the men's 100-meter final at the 2024 Summer Olympics, Sunday, Aug. 4, 2024, in Saint-Denis, France. Photographs: Reuters\n\nIt was the closest-ever 100 metres final in the history of the Olympic Games as Noah Lyles won by five thousandths of a second in a sensational finish to give the United States the title of fastest man in the world for the first time in 20 years in Paris on Sunday.\n\nJamaican Kishane Thompson led for most of the race and clocked the same time -- 9.79 seconds -- as Lyles who won by five thousandths of a second in a photo finish after timing his dip to cross the line to perfection.\n\nLyles admitted he thought Thompson, who came into the final as the fastest man this year, had beaten him.\n\nIt was the first time eight men have broken 10 seconds in a wind-legal 100 metres race.\n\nIf the race had been 99 metres, Thompson would have been celebrating a fourth Jamaican men's 100m win in five Olympics, but fast-finishing Lyles kept his form superbly and timed his dip expertly to add Olympic gold to his world title.\n\nAmerican Fred Kerley took the bronze in 9.81 and Akani Simbini of South Africa was fourth, while defending champion Lamont Marcell Jacobs of Italy, heavily strapped, finished fifth in 9.85 and Letsile Tebogo of Botswana also set a national record with 9.86 in sixth.\n\nSuch was the quality of the race, that eighth-placed Oblique Seville of Jamaica clocked 9.91 seconds.\n\n'I did not think I won, I didn't think I dipped at the right time, too early,' Lyles said after the race. 'I even went up to Kishane while we were waiting and said \"I think you got that one.\" But then my name popped up and I thought \"Oh my gosh, I'm amazing\".'\n\n'I wasn't patient enough with myself to let my speed bring me at the line, in the position that I know I could have gone to, but I have learned from it,' Thompson said.\n\nAsked if he thought the pair should share the medal, rhe Jamaican runner said: 'I think the sport is too competitive, no offence to any other sport. Lyles is an American sprinter looking toward multiple events and medals at the Paris Olympics. At the 2020 Tokyo Olympics, Lyles won a bronze medal in the men's 200-meter. / Jasper Colt / USA TODAY NETWORK\n\nNBA great Magic Johnson was among the first to congratulate sprinter Noah Lyles for winning the 100 meters at the Olympics Sunday.\n\nLyles became the first American to win the event since Justin Gatlin in 2004 in Athens. Lyles won a photo finish with a winning time of 9.79. He edged Kishane Thompson and Fred Kerley.\n\nJohnson, a Hall of Famer, wasted little time to celebrate the victory. He immediately took to social media.\n\nHere's what Johnson posted on X: \"We're all on the yacht cheering for Noah Lyles winning the Men's 100M race and remaining the fastest man in the world! It's the first time in 20 years that the US brings home the gold in the Men's 100! Wow - what an exciting race!!\"\n\nFormer Miami Heat guard Dwyane Wade also joined the celebration. He used it as opportunity to silence those who criticize males for wearing nail polish. Wade is also part of the nail-painting fraternity.\n\n\"And he got his nails painted Say something,\" Wade wrote on X.\n\nLyles is now in the same class with Johnson and Wade. Johnson won a gold medal with the Dream Team in 1992 while Wade was part of the Redeem Team in 2008. This is Lyles' first gold medal. He won bronze in the 200 meters in Tokyo.\n\nHis victory came after finishing second in the earlier heat.\n\nShandel Richardson is the publisher of Back In The Day Hoops. {"uri": "8259088800", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "20:58:27", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T20:58:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T20:55:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://www.idahostatejournal.com/2024olympics/noah-lyles-wins-olympic-100-by-five-thousandths-of-a-second-among-closest-finishes-in/article_bed3f0b3-0f4b-51e9-a9ae-4179ec281ade.html", "title": "Noah Lyles wins Olympic 100 by five-thousandths of a second, among closest finishes in Games history", "body": "SAINT-DENIS, France (AP) -- Noah Lyles won the Olympic 100 meters by .005 seconds Sunday, waiting some 30 seconds after the finish of one of the closest sprints in history to find out he'd beaten Kishane Thompson of Jamaica.\n\nThe word \"Photo\" popped up on the scoreboard next to the names of Lyles, Thompson and five others after they crossed the line. Lyles paced the track with his hands draped over his head. Finally, the numbers came up. Lyles won in 9.784 seconds to edge out the Jamaican by five-thousandths of a tick of the clock.\n\nAmerica's Fred Kerley came in third at 9.81. The top seven all finished within .09 of each other.\n\nThis was the closest 1-2 finish in the 100 since at least Moscow in 1980 -- or maybe even ever. Back then, Britain's Allan Wells narrowly beat Silvio Leonard in an era when the electronic timers didn't go down into the thousandths of a second.\n\nThank goodness they do now.\n\n\"I thought I had (him) cleared,\" Thompson said. \"But I wasn't sure. It was so close.\"\n\nLyles became the first American to win the marquee event in Olympic track since Justin Gatlin in 2004.\n\nThe 9.784 also marks a personal best for Lyles, who has been promising to add his own brand of excitement to track and certainly delivered this time.\n\nHe will be a favorite later this week in the 200 meters -- his better race -- and will try to join Usain Bolt as the latest runner to win both Olympic sprints.\n\nFor perspective, the blink of an eye takes, on average, .1 second, which was 20 times longer than the gap between first and second in this one.\n\nWhat was the difference? Maybe Lyles' closing speed and his lean into the line.\n\nHe and Thompson had two of the three slowest bursts from the blocks, and Thompson had what sufficed for a \"lead\" at the halfway point. The photo finish actually shows Kerley's orange shoe well in front of the line. But it's the chest breaking the barrier that counts, and Lyles beat everyone by a sliver.\n\nIt would take more than a mere 9.7(84) seconds to decide who would supplant Marcell Jacobs as the next Olympic champion.\n\nLyles patted Thompson on the shoulder while the wait grew -- from 10, to 20, then nearly 30 seconds. When the American learned he'd added this to the 100 meters he won at world championships last year, he pulled off his name tag and raised it to the sky, then brought his hands to his side and pointed at the camera.\n\n\"America, I told you I got this!\" he yelled into the camera.\n\nYes, he's the World's Fastest Man. Just not by a lot.\n\nGold (and bronze) for Ukrainian high jumpers\n\nYaroslava Mahuchikh won Olympic gold in the high jump for her war-torn country of Ukraine and, as a bonus, had company. Her teammate Iryna Gerashchenko won the bronze and the teammates hopped, skipped and jumped around the track parading their blue-and-yellow flags in a heartfelt celebration.\n\nMahuchikh needed fewer tries to clear the winning height of 2 meters than Australia's Nicola Olyslagers, and so, added the sport's biggest prize of all -- Olympic gold -- to her world championship and world record.\n\nKerr vs Ingebrigtsen is a go for heated men's 1,500\n\nThe best rivalry in track will culminate Tuesday when reigning world champion Josh Kerr of Britain takes on defending Olympic champion Jakob Ingebrigtsen of Norway.\n\nThey squared off in Sunday's semifinal, too, and Ingebrigtsen edged out the Brit, looking over to him twice as they surged down the homestretch, to win a race that felt like it meant more than it should have in 3:32.38.\n\n\"They should be expecting one of the most vicious and hardest 1,500s the sport's seen in a very long time,\" Kerr said.\n\nDid Ingebrigtsen agree?\n\n\"Depends who you ask, maybe,\" he said. \"I mean, racing is what you want it to be.\"\n\nAP Summer Olympics: https://apnews.com/hub/2024-paris-olympic-games", "source": {"uri": The race didn't just live up to expectations, it blew them out of the water with maybe the closest finish you will ever see.\n\nAmerican Noah Lyles took home gold by five thousands of a second over silver medalist Kishane Thompson of Jamaica. Fred Kerley of the United States came in bronze. Lyles and Thompson each posted an official time of 9.79 seconds. The difference was too minuscule to even notice in real time.\n\nThe announcer immediately declared Thompson the winner, but got it wrong. This is one of the most thrilling races you will ever see. Watch the full men's 100-meter sprint at the 2024 Paris Olympics here:\n\nThe announcers explained that the race is determined by whose torso/clavicle crosses the line first. Here's a look at the finish line.\n\nIt really was that close.\n\nHere are the official times. Lyles won by 0.005. Lyles had previously taken home bronze in the 200-meter dash at the 2021 Tokyo Olympics.\n\nThe difference between Olympic gold and finishing outside of the podium was 0.03 seconds. It was only .12 seconds first and last. What a race.\n\nIs this the closest race in Olympics history? It might be. Back in 1932, American Eddie Tolan beat teammate Ralph Metcalfe in a photo finish when both runners had times of 10.38.\n\nLyles and Thompson now go down in history with their own photo finish. {"uri": "8259082194", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "20:45:47", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T20:45:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T20:45:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/olympics/noah-lyles-olympics-100m-final-result-b2591068.html", "title": "'I'm incredible': Noah Lyles backs up fighting talk in dramatic Olympic 100m final", "body": "Our mission is to deliver unbiased, fact-based reporting that holds power to account and exposes the truth.\n\nWhether $5 or $50, every contribution counts.\n\nSupport us to deliver journalism without an agenda.\n\nWorld champion, Olympic champion. Noah Lyles talked an awful lot of talk in the build-up to Paris 2024, but tonight he backed up the bluster with blistering speed on the Stade de France track, surging past the field to pip them all on the line. There can be no argument now. \"What's the title of Olympic champion?\" Lyles said, referring to \"the fastest man on the planet\" tag that goes with gold. \"Amen.\"\n\nIt doesn't matter that he didn't get near the world record he said he'd break, finishing in 9.79. It doesn't matter that the winning margin was only five thousandths of a second, a time too miniscule to comprehend. Jamaica's Kishane Thompson had been burdened with the title of heir to Usain Bolt after running the fastest time this year, and he led for 99m of this race. But Lyles is a fighter and he dug in, hauling himself alongside Thompson as they crossed the line.\n\nThompson roared in celebration but his face dropped when the giant screen displayed \"photo finish\" by his name. They stared up from purgatory, waiting for the verdict. Lyles paced with his hands on his head. Then it came, and Lyles was off again, one moment ripping the number from his chest and raising it to the gods, the next streaking across the hammer field with the stars and stripes flapping in the wind.\n\nThompson was awarded silver as Lyles' US teammate Fred Kerley took bronze. Lyles admitted afterwards that he thought he was too late.\n\n\"I went to Kishane, I said, 'I'll be honest, I think you had that one'. I was prepared to see his name pop up. I saw my name pop up and I said, 'Goodness gracious, I'm incredible'. It's the one I wanted. It's the hard battle, the amazing opponents, everybody was healthy and came to fight. I'm the wolf among wolves.\"\n\nThompson hoped to be the first Jamaican man since Bolt to win a global 100m title.\n\n\"I'm a bit disappointed but I'm super happy and grateful at the same time,\" he said, \"I've just got to take it as it is and move forward from here.\n\n\"I wasn't patient enough with my speed and myself, I should have let my speed bring me to the line. I've learned from it. I couldn't see Noah, but I think he could see me and said, 'hey, Kishane, I thought you got it'. But I wasn't sure, he was too far to my right, so I wasn't sure. This is my closest race. Olympic 100m champion since 2004 | Honolulu Star-Advertiser", "body": "Noah Lyles of the United States celebrates after winning gold.\n\nPARIS >> After all the talk and all the hype, Noah Lyles delivered when it mattered most when he won a superlative Olympic 100-meter final by five-thousandths of a second on Sunday to give the United States the title for the first time in 20 years.\n\nIn one of the most competitive finals of all time, there was a blanket finish, with the stadium scoreboard initially flashing a photo finish for the first seven athletes.\n\nIt then confirmed Lyles as the winner in a personal best 9.79 seconds, the same time as Jamaica's Kishane Thompson, but ahead by a fraction.\n\nIf the race had been 99 meters Thompson would have been celebrating, but fast-finishing Lyles kept his form superbly and timed his dip expertly to add Olympic gold to his world title.\n\nHe ripped his bib name from his shirt and held it aloft, announcing himself, as he had always promised, as the fastest man in the world.\n\n\"It's the one I wanted, it's the hard battle, it's the amazing opponents,\" said Lyles, the first American Olympic 100m champion since Justin Gatlin in 2004.\n\n\"Everybody came prepared for the fight and I wanted to prove that I'm the man among all of them, I'm the wolf among wolves.\"\n\nCompatriot Fred Kerley took bronze in 9.81 and Akani Simbini of South Africa was fourth, making it a remarkable six-fourth or fifth finish in global championships, albeit with the consolation of a national record of 9.83.\n\nDefending champion Lamont Marcell Jacobs of Italy, heavily strapped, finished fifth in 9.85 and, such was the quality of the race, that eighth-placed Oblique Seville of Jamaica still clocked 9.91 seconds.\n\nIt was the {"uri": "8259109062", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "21:26:55", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T21:26:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T21:20:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://kion546.com/news/2024/08/04/noah-lyles-wins-olympic-100-by-five-thousandths-of-a-second-among-closest-finishes-in-games-history/", "title": "Noah Lyles wins Olympic 100 by five-thousandths of a second, among closest finishes in Games history - KION546", "body": "SAINT-DENIS, France (AP) -- Noah Lyles won the Olympic 100 meters by .005 seconds Sunday, waiting some 30 seconds after the finish of one of the closest sprints in history to find out he'd beaten Kishane Thompson of Jamaica.\n\nThe word \"Photo\" popped up on the scoreboard next to the names of Lyles, Thompson and five others after they crossed the line.\n\nLyles paced the track with his hands draped over his head. Finally, the numbers came up. Lyles won in 9.784 seconds to edge out the Jamaican by five-thousandths of a tick of the clock.\n\nLyles said he thought he had given the win away by dipping at the line too soon, so he went up to Thompson and told him, \"Bro, I think you got that one.\"\n\n\"But then my name popped up and I'm like 'Oh my gosh, amazing!'\"\n\nAmerica's Fred Kerley came in third at 9.81.\n\n\"That's probably one of the most beautiful races I've been in,\" he said.\n\nThe top seven all finished within .09 of each other.\n\nThis was the closest 1-2 finish in the 100 since at least Moscow in 1980 -- or maybe even ever. Back then, Britain's Allan Wells narrowly beat Silvio Leonard in an era when the electronic timers didn't go down into the thousandths of a second. The same was true in 1932, when Eddie Tolan won the Olympics' first ever photo finish.\n\nThank goodness they do now.\n\n\"I thought I had (him) cleared,\" Thompson said. \"But I wasn't sure. It was so close.\"\n\nLyles became the first American to win the marquee event in Olympic track since Justin Gatlin in 2004.\n\nThe 9.784 also marks a personal best for Lyles, who has been promising to add his own brand of excitement to track and certainly delivered this time.\n\nHe will be a favorite later this week in the 200 meters -- his better race -- and will try to join Usain Bolt as the latest runner to win both Olympic sprints.\n\nFor perspective, the blink of an eye takes, on average, .1 second, which was 20 times longer than the gap between first and second in this one.\n\nWhat was the difference? Maybe Lyles' closing speed and that lean into the line that he thought was mistimed.\n\nHe and Thompson had two of the three slowest bursts from the blocks, and Thompson had what sufficed for a \"lead\" at the halfway point. The photo finish actually shows Kerley's orange shoe well in front of everything at the finish line. But it's the chest breaking the barrier that counts, and Lyles beat everyone by a sliver.\n\nWhen the American learned he had added the Olympic title to the 100 meters he won at world championships last year, he pulled off his name tag and raised it to the sky, then brought his hands to his side and pointed at the camera.\n\n\"America, I told you I got this!\" he yelled into the camera.\n\nYaroslava Mahuchikh won Olympic gold in the high jump for her war-torn country of Ukraine and, as a bonus, had company. Her teammate Iryna Gerashchenko won the bronze and the teammates hopped, skipped and jumped around the track parading their blue-and-yellow flags in a heartfelt celebration.\n\nMahuchikh needed fewer tries to clear the winning height of 2 meters than Australia's Nicola Olyslagers, and so, added the sport's biggest prize of all -- Olympic gold -- to her world championship and world record.\n\nKerr vs Ingebrigtsen is a go for heated men's 1,500\n\nThe best rivalry in track will culminate Tuesday when reigning world champion Josh Kerr of Britain takes on defending Olympic champion Jakob Ingebrigtsen of Norway.\n\nThey squared off in Sunday's semifinal, too, and Ingebrigtsen edged out the Brit, looking over to him twice as they surged down the homestretch, to win a race that felt like it meant more than it should have in 3:32.38.\n\n\"They should be expecting one of the most vicious and hardest 1,500s the sport's seen in a very long time,\" Kerr said.\n\nDid Ingebrigtsen agree?\n\n\"Depends who you ask, maybe,\" he said. \"I mean, racing is what you want it to be.\"", "source": {"uri": "kion546.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KION546"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-08-443898957", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "22:02:42", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T22:02:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T21:33:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://eu.usatoday.com/story/sports/olympics/2024/08/04/noah-lyles-2024-paris-olympics/74667304007/", "title": "Head bone connected to the clavicle bone and then a gold medal for sprinter Noah Lyles", "body": "The nine-time Olympic gold medalist shares his thoughts on the perception of track and field and the importance of mental health.\n\nFive one thousandths of a second, or -- if measuring by body parts -- a clavicle: that was the margin of victory for American sprinter Noah Lyles in the men's 100-meter photo finish sprint Sunday.\n\nOfficially, both Lyles and Jamaican sprinter Kishane Thompson finished with the time of 9.79 seconds, though the tight margin prompted the results to be confirmed by photo finish, with Lyles (9.784) just slightly edging out Thompson (9.789) for the gold medal and the title of the fastest man in the world.\n\nLyles' victory ended a 20-year drought for the U.S. atop the podium at the men's 100-meter dash, as he became the first American to win gold in the event since Justin Gatlin did so at the 2004 Athens Olympics.\n\nHere's everything to know about the rules governing track and field finishes at the 2024 Paris Olympics:\n\nWhat is the official rule for track and field finishes at the Olympics?\n\nJust after the men's 100-meter race concluded, NBC's Mike Tirico gave a brief explanation of how track and field race winners are determined. In his explanation, Tirico said that Olympic races determine a victor when any part of the leading runner's torso crosses the vertical plane of the finish line.\n\nUSA Track & Field, the governing body that oversees Team USA's international track and field competitions, has similar language published in its 2024 USATF Competition Rules.\n\nOn page 67 of the document, under Rule 163 (which concerns running competitions), the first point states: \"Competitors shall be placed at the finish line in the order in which any part of their bodies (i.e., the 'torso,' as distinguished from the head, neck, arms, hands, legs, or feet) reaches the finish line.\"\n\nThe sports governing body World Athletics also has similar language in its technical rulebook for track and field competitions.\n\nWhat did the Noah Lyles 100-meter photo finish look like?\n\nOmega, the official provider of photo finish images at the 2024 Paris Olympics, shared the image of Lyles' victory at the men's 100-meter sprint. The image clearly shows Lyles extending his body forward, with his torso -- namely, his shoulder and clavicle -- crossing the line before anyone else's.\n\nHow did Noah Lyles win gold in the 100-meter sprint?\n\nLyles, known for being a strong finisher in his races, had to rely on just that, lunging forward to just beat out Kishane Thompson. Lyles had to make ground in the second half of the race after Thompson and other sprinters raced out from the blocks to take early leads.\n\nMen's 100m final results", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-08-444094068", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "05:25:30", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T05:25:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T05:08:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://gephardtdaily.com/sports/noah-lyles-becomes-first-american-champion-in-100m-in-20-years/", "title": "Noah Lyles becomes first American champion in 100M in 20 years", "body": "Aug. 4 (UPI) -- Noah Lyles flung his body forward at the finish line to beat Jamaican Kishane Thompson by .005 of a second, becoming the first U.S. Olympic champion in the men's 100 meters in 20 years Sunday in Saint-Denis.\n\nLyles clocked a personal-best time of 9.784 in the storied event, which results in the moniker of \"World's Fastest Man\" for its winner at every Olympics.\n\nThompson, who finished in 9.789, earned a silver medal. Team USA's Fred Kerley finished in 9.81 seconds to win a bronze medal, while American Kenneth Bednarek (9.88) placed seventh.\n\nLyles appeared slow out of the blocks but gained on Thompson over the final 50 meters. He then willed his upper body forward just before the finish line, beating his Jamaican foe by the narrowest of margins.\n\n\"America, I told you,\" Lyles said into the NBC cameras after he was officially announced as the winner. \"I got this.\"\n\nWith his photo-finish, Lyles became the first American man to win the Olympic event since Justin Gatlin in 2004.\n\nLyles, who won a bronze medal in the 200-meter sprint at Tokyo 2020, is now halfway finished with his goal of becoming the 10th man in history to win the Olympic double -- capturing gold medals in the 100 meters and 200 meters.\n\nJamaican Usain Bolt won both events in 2008 to become the first man to achieve the double since American Carl Lewis in 1984. Olympic icon Jesse Owens also accomplished the feat in 1936.\n\nNo other Americans won medals in track and field events Sunday at Stade de France. Ukraine's Yaroslava Mahuchikh won gold in the women's high jump. Canada's Ethan Katzberg won gold in the men's hammer throw.\n\nLyles' gold medal marked the second won by an American in athletics so far in Paris. Ryan Crouser earned the first by winning the men's shot put final Saturday at Stade de France.\n\nQualifying for the men's 200-meter final will be held Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday in Saint-Denis. The final will be at 12:30 p.m. MDT Thursday at Stade de France. {"uri": "8259883056", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "10:23:07", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T10:23:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T10:21:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/olympics/noah-lyles-100m-final-olympics-b2591292.html", "title": "From last to Olympic 100m gold, how Noah Lyles won greatest final ever", "body": "{{ #verifyErrors }}{{ message }}{{ /verifyErrors }}{{ ^verifyErrors }}Something went wrong. Please try again later{{ /verifyErrors }}\n\nBy the time Noah Lyles started the Olympic 100m final, he was already last. Lyles took 0.0178 sec to react to the gun and begin his race. That might sound quick but in a sport measured in thousandths of a second, he had just given up 0.07 to one his biggest rivals, fellow American Fred Kerley.\n\nThe man Lyles most feared, Jamaica's Kishane Thompson, was just as sluggish, reacting in 0.0176. Yet Thompson is the fastest man this year for a reason. He is a 100m specialist with power and a long stride, and he emerged from his drive phase at 30m with the lead.\n\nBy contrast, and despite being the 100m world champion, Lyles is a 200m runner by trade. His strength is in his top speed but he takes a little while to get there, and his slow start has sometimes been an Achilles heel. At 30m he was dead last, eighth out of eight.\n\nCrucially, though, Lyles was now travelling towards the finish line quicker than anyone else. Between 50m and 60m he made a rapid, stunning climb from eighth to third as he reached his peak speed of the race, 43.6km/hr (27.1mph).\n\nAt this point, the leader Thompson (43.2km/hr) and second-place Kerley (43.1km/hr) had already hit their top speed and they were fighting to maintain it. Thompson, running in his first Olympic final, was clearly tensing up, grimacing and straining for the line.\n\n\"I wasn't patient enough with myself to let my speed bring me to the line in the position that I know I could have gone to,\" Thompson later admitted. \"But I have learned from it.\"\n\nThis is where Lyles came into his element. His speed endurance is his strength, which is why he is such a successful 200m sprinter. He is also an experienced campaigner, having run in Olympic and world finals with memories of both success and failure to call upon. Lyles stayed calm and composed, holding his smooth running style all the way to the line.\n\n\"To be honest, I was like, if I'm running 9.83 in the semi-finals I'm going to be hard to beat,\" he said. \"I called my therapist and she was like, 'you need to let go, you need to let it flow', I was like, 'alright, I'm going to trust you'.\"\n\nHe still had one last job to do. The photo finish shows how Lyles body is leaning forwards, head dragging the torso through the line with the legs trailing behind. If Lyles' lean is around 60 degrees from the track, Thompson's is more like 75.\n\nTechnically, Thompson's right hallux was the first body part to complete this Olympic final. But finish lines only recognise the chest. Lyles won gold by five thousandths of a second, quicker than the time it takes to blink.\n\n\"I did think [Thompson] had it at the end,\" Lyles admitted. \"I went up to him while we were waiting, and said \"I think you've got that, good going', and then my name popped up and I'm like 'oh my gosh, I'm amazing'.\"\n\nHe had overcome not only seven rival finalists but the weight of American expectation, delivering Olympic men's 100m gold for the first time in 20 years, since Justin Gatlin in Athens.\n\n\"I had so many commercials going around and so many people, like Snoop Dog is out here, saying that I'm going to be the one. I'm not going to say it's not pressure, it's definitely pressure. Saying that the moment is not bigger than me, that the moment was meant for me, constantly saying that it's going to be the thing I need.\"\n\nIt was a moment that encapsulated Lyles: drama, entertainment, sheer theatre. Michael Johnson called it the greatest 100m final he had ever seen. \"We had this amazing race where you could throw a blanket over the finishing line,\" said the American sprint legend. \"We didn't even know who won for a few minutes.\"", "source": {"uri": "independent.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Independent"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8259233704", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "00:33:37", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T00:33:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T00:30:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.dimsumdaily.hk/noah-lyles-clinches-dramatic-100m-victory-at-paris-olympics-by-five-thousandths-of-a-second/", "title": "Noah Lyles clinches dramatic 100m victory at Paris Olympics by five-thousandths of a second - Dimsum Daily", "body": "5th August 2024 - (Paris) In a heart-stopping finale at the Paris 2024 Olympics, American sprinter Noah Lyles claimed the title of the World's Fastest Man by the slimmest of margins. On a warm Sunday evening in Saint-Denis, Lyles edged out Jamaica's Kishane Thompson by a mere five-thousandths of a second in the men's 100-meter final, a victory that underscored the razor-thin line between glory and second place.\n\nThe race, which concluded in a photo finish, saw Lyles clock a personal best of 9.784 seconds, just fractionally ahead of Thompson's 9.789 seconds. This marked the closest 1-2 finish in the 100 meters since electronic timing was introduced, and possibly the closest ever in Olympic history.\n\nAs the athletes crossed the finish line, the scoreboard hesitated, displaying \"Photo\" next to the names of the contenders. The tension was palpable as both sprinters and the crowd awaited the verdict. Lyles, who had been visibly anxious, finally saw his name flash as the winner, prompting him to tear off his name tag and brandish it towards the sky in triumph.\n\nThis victory is not just about the gold medal for Lyles but represents a pivotal moment in his career. After settling for bronze in the 200 meters at the Tokyo Games, a result that left him profoundly dissatisfied, Lyles redirected his focus towards the 100 meters. His dedication to improving every facet of his sprinting, from starts to mental fortitude, paid significant dividends in Paris.\n\nLyles' win also marks a historical milestone, making him the first American to clinch the marquee sprint title at the Olympics since Justin Gatlin in 2004. His achievement has reignited excitement around track and field in the U.S., reminiscent of the era dominated by legends like Carl Lewis and Edwin Moses.\n\nThe race itself was a masterpiece of competitive sprinting, with the first four finishers separated by less than 0.03 seconds, and the top seven within 0.09 seconds. America's Fred Kerley, who came in third with a time of 9.81 seconds, described it as \"probably one of the most beautiful races I've been in.\"\n\nAside from the sheer competitive nature of the race, the psychological warfare was equally gripping. Thompson, known for his explosive starts, let out a primal scream during the introductions, a tactic often employed by Lyles in major races. This psychological interplay added another layer of drama to the proceedings, with Lyles momentarily thrown but quickly regaining his composure.", "source": {"uri": "dimsumdaily.hk", "dataType": {"uri": "2024-08-443895115", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "21:51:16", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T21:51:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T17:44:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://www.ntd.com/noah-lyles-wins-olympic-100-by-5-thousandths-of-a-second_1008940.html?utm_source=dlvr.it&utm_medium=twitter", "title": "Noah Lyles Wins Olympic 100 by 5-thousandths of a Second", "body": "SAINT-DENIS, France -- Noah Lyles won the Olympic 100 meters by .005 seconds Sunday, waiting some 30 seconds after the finish of one of the closest sprints in history to find out he'd beaten Kishane Thompson of Jamaica.\n\nThe word \"Photo\" popped up on the scoreboard next to the names of Lyles, Thompson and five others after they crossed the line.\n\nLyles paced the track with his hands draped over his head. Finally, the numbers came up. Lyles won in 9.784 seconds to edge out the Jamaican by five-thousandths of a tick of the clock.\n\nLyles said he thought he had given the win away by dipping at the line too soon, so he went up to Thompson and told him, \"Bro, I think you got that one.\"\n\n\"But then my name popped up and I'm like 'Oh my gosh, amazing!'\"\n\nAmerica's Fred Kerley came in third at 9.81.\n\n\"That's probably one of the most beautiful races I've been in,\" he said.\n\nThe top seven all finished within .09 of each other.\n\nThis was the closest 1-2 finish in the 100 since at least Moscow in 1980 -- or maybe even ever. Back then, Britain's Allan Wells narrowly beat Silvio Leonard in an era when the electronic timers didn't go down into the thousandths of a second. The same was true in 1932, when Eddie Tolan won the Olympics' first ever photo finish.\n\nThank goodness they do now.\n\n\"I thought I had [him] cleared,\" Thompson said. \"But I wasn't sure. It was so close.\"\n\nLyles became the first American to win the marquee event in Olympic track since Justin Gatlin in 2004.\n\nThe 9.784 also marks a personal best for Lyles, who has been promising to add his own brand of excitement to track and certainly delivered this time.\n\nHe will be a favorite later this week in the 200 meters -- his better race -- and will try to join Usain Bolt as the latest runner to win both Olympic sprints.\n\nFor perspective, the blink of an eye takes, on average, .1 second, which was 20 times longer than the gap between first and second in this one.\n\nWhat was the difference? Maybe Lyles' closing speed and that lean into the line that he thought was mistimed.\n\nHe and Thompson had two of the three slowest bursts from the blocks, and Thompson had what sufficed for a \"lead\" at the halfway point. The photo finish actually shows Kerley's orange shoe well in front of everything at the finish line. But it's the chest breaking the barrier that counts, and Lyles beat everyone by a sliver.\n\nWhen the American learned he had added the Olympic title to the 100 meters he won at world championships last year, he pulled off his name tag and raised it to the sky, then brought his hands to his side and pointed at the camera.\n\n\"America, I told you I got this!\" he yelled into the camera.\n\nYaroslava Mahuchikh won Olympic gold in the high jump for her war-torn country of Ukraine and, as a bonus, had company. Her teammate Iryna Gerashchenko won the bronze and the teammates hopped, skipped and jumped around the track parading their blue-and-yellow flags in a heartfelt celebration.\n\nMahuchikh needed fewer tries to clear the winning height of 2 meters than Australia's Nicola Olyslagers, and so, added the sport's biggest prize of all -- Olympic gold -- to her world championship and world record.\n\nKerr vs Ingebrigtsen Is a Go for Heated Men's 1,500\n\nThe best rivalry in track will culminate Tuesday when reigning world champion Josh Kerr of Britain takes on defending Olympic champion Jakob Ingebrigtsen of Norway.\n\nThey squared off in Sunday's semifinal, too, and Ingebrigtsen edged out the Brit, looking over to him twice as they surged down the homestretch, to win a race that felt like it meant more than it should have in 3:32.38.\n\n\"They should be expecting one of the most vicious and hardest 1,500s the sport's seen in a very long time,\" Kerr said.\n\nDid Ingebrigtsen agree?\n\n\"Depends who you ask, maybe,\" he said. \"I mean, racing is what you want it to be.\"", "source": {"uri": "ntd.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NTD"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": The U.S. track & field athlete, who secured a bronze last Olympics in the 200m, won gold in the 100m on Sunday in Paris. He set a personal best of 9.79, beating the silver medalist Kishane Thompson by just five thousandths of a second. His teammate, Fred Kerley, secured bronze with a 9.81.\n\nLyles overcame a subpar reaction time, the worst of the field (0.178). There was an extended pre-race portion as it is one of the most anticipated events of the Games. Lyles appeared to be motioning for the theatrics to speed up before the athletes took their marks.\n\nHis personal best in the event before the final was a 9.81, which he posted at the London Athletics Meet in July. At team trials, he posted a 9.83 before the Olympics in late June.\n\nLyles ran a 10.04 in his quarterfinal heat, sandwiched between Louie Hinchliffe (Great Britain) who put up a 9.98 and Shaun Maswanganyi (South Africa) who put up a 10.06. He admitted after that heat that he was a little stunned by how much his fellow competitors brought their A-game.\n\n\"That's my first lesson in underestimating the power of the Olympics. When somebody's on the line, they're going to give it their all or nothing. But now I don't have to hold back. I'm ready to go.\"\n\nIn his semifinal heat, Lyles secured one of the two automatic-in slots in his heat with a 9.83, second in his heat to Oblique Seville (Jamaica), who put up a 9.81. Of the eight runners that qualified, two (Seville and Kishane Thompson, also of Jamaica) put up better quarterfinal times than him.\n\nLyles is not done at the Paris games. {"uri": "8259108210", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "21:26:11", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T21:26:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T21:18:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://www.postandcourier.com/arena/cfb-nfl/noah-lyles-tragic-old-post-warning-oblique-seville-before-olympics-resurfaces/article_ca4410d8-189e-5d6a-b08f-55023e702a37.html", "title": "Noah Lyles' Tragic Old Post Warning Oblique Seville Before Olympics Resurfaces", "body": "U.S. sprinter Noah Lyles went viral for an old post he made warning Jamaican rival Oblique Seville before the Paris Olympics.\n\nLyles and Seville were neck-and-neck during Sunday's 100m semifinals at the Stade de France in Paris. The former recorded a time of 9.81, which matched Lyles' all-time personal best.\n\nSeville beat Lyles by 0.02 seconds, but both still men qualified for a spot in the 100m final. British sprinter Louie Hinchliffe, who bested Lyles in Round 1 of the men's 100m, finished third and missed the cutoff.\n\nPhotos of the thrilling finish showed Lyles staring down Seville as both men crossed the finish line. The moment has since turned Lyles into a trending topic.\n\nThe Lyles-Seville beef isn't completely fresh. Fans have unearthed Lyles' warning against Seville from just weeks ago.\n\nIn June, Seville also bested Lyles during the 100m in the Racers Grand Prix held in Kingston, Jamaica. The hometown sprinter had stared down Lyles at the finish line as they crossed the finish line.\n\nThe U.S. star later posted the photo and issued a warning against Seville that doesn't exactly look flattering moments after the semifinal happened.\n\n\"Oh yah... I'll remember this! See you in Paris,\" Lyles captioned the post while tagging Seville.\n\nLyles may have been trying to recreate the moment against Seville on the Olympic stage but again ended up behind the Jamaican.\n\nAfter placing second to Hinchliffe in the 1st round earlier this week, Lyles issued a similar warning to the rest of the field.\n\nBut Lyles ultimately got the last laugh. The U.S. sprinter bounced back with a blazing 9.79 finish in the final to win the Olympic gold medal. {"uri": "8259872914", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "10:16:16", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T10:16:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T10:15:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://thesportsrush.com/olympics-news-track-and-field-news-aint-no-money-in-spikes-noah-lyles-comes-clean-on-future-goals-post-100m-gold-at-the-paris-olympics/", "title": "\"Ain't No Money In Spikes\": Noah Lyles Comes Clean On Future Goals Post 100m Gold At The Paris Olympics", "body": "Aug 4, 2024; Paris Saint-Denis, France; Noah Lyles (USA) celebrates after winning the men\u00eds 100m final during the Paris 2024 Olympic Summer Games at Stade de France. Mandatory Credit: Yukihito Taguchi-USA TODAY Sports\n\nNoah Lyles finally reached the summit he missed in Tokyo, winning the men's 100m Olympic gold medal. In a stacked field, the American sprinter took home the win in a photo finish with Kishane Thompson.\n\nSpeaking at the post-event press conference, the 27-year-old looked ahead at his possible future and shared his goals. Wanting to join the list of some of the most elite athletes across the globe and in history, Lyles has his eyes on launching his own sneakers.\n\nHe explained that the spiked shoes that runners wear, were of no interest to him, as there wasn't much money in them. Thus, his focus remained on sneakers.\n\n\"I want my own shoe....I want a sneaker, there ain't no money in spikes.\"\n\nReferring to the great Michael Johnson, Lyles claimed how he \"didn't have his own sneaker\"- such has been the history of American sprinters. Talking about the number of medals they bring in from various competitions, Lyles felt the American sprinters go unnoticed in terms of their brand image.\n\nThus, the Gainesville native hopes to become the first American sprinter to have a sneaker named after him. And given his latest accomplishment, he has good reason. Noah Lyles's journey to the Olympics, however, has not been without its challenges.\n\nThe Tokyo Olympics in 2021 ended in heartbreak for the 27-year-old as he had to settle for bronze. Ever since then, only one goal stood in front of his eyes, and that was to become the Olympic champion. But a 6-foot hurdle by the name of Kishane Thompson stood in the way.\n\nIn the build-up for the Paris Olympics, Thompson was the fastest man of 2024 and was the favorite to win the gold. But Lyles was having none of it. Showing shaky form in the heats and the semi-finals, the 27-year-old gathered himself when it mattered most.\n\nRunning neck and neck, both Lyles and Thompson crossed the finish line at exactly 9.79 seconds. spectacular finish to successfully begin his bid for a potential four golds at these Games.\n\nThe United States' former world champion Fred Kerley took bronze in 9.81, edging out South Africa's Akani Simbine for the podium.\n\nAfter a lengthy wait behind the start line to a backdrop of dramatic music in a frenzied atmosphere at Stade de France, all eight finalists finished within 0.12 seconds of Lyles in a remarkable race.\n\nSuch was the standard of the final - which Great Britain's Zharnel Hughes and Louie Hinchliffe failed to reach - Italy's reigning champion Lamont Marcell Jacobs was run {"uri": "8259123033", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "21:42:08", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T21:42:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T21:40:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://www.nbcnews.com/sports/olympics/noah-lyles-worlds-fastest-man-thanks-part-torso-rcna165089", "title": "Noah Lyles is the world's fastest man  --  thanks in part to his torso", "body": "Team USA's Noah Lyles took the gold in the men's 100-meter final at the Paris Olympics -- by five thousandths of a second.\n\nLyles, who won Sunday with a time of 9.784 seconds, came out just barely ahead of Jamaica's Kishane Thompson (who ran in 9.789) and USA's Fred Kerley (whose time was 9.81).\n\nThe race was so close that even the commentators nearly called the wrong winner before the photo finish, which showed Lyles being the first to lean over the finish line even as others managed to step over it before him.\n\nIt raises the question: Which part of the body must cross the finish line first to earn the win?\n\nAccording to Olympic rules and regulations, the first athlete whose torso reaches the closest edge of the finish line is the winner. This means the trunk of the body is what counts, as opposed to the head, limbs or feet.\n\nThis is what earned Lyles the gold and the title of world's fastest man despite some viewers online noting that several other athletes' shoes reached the finish line first.", "source": {"uri": "nbcnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NBC News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8259267008", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "01:23:07", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T01:23:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T01:22:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://www.pehalnews.in/latest/american-noah-lyles-secures-mens-100m-gold-medal-at-paris-olympics-2024/4978/", "title": "American Noah Lyles Secures Men's 100m Gold Medal at Paris Olympics 2024 - Pehal News", "body": "Champion Noah Lyles thundered to triumph in 9.79 seconds to seize the top prize in a thrilling men's Olympic 100m final in Paris on Sunday. Lyles became the initial American, man or woman, to capture the title since Justin Gatlin emerged victorious in the 2004 Athens Games. In a close finish, Jamaica's Kishane Thompson secured the silver medal, just five-thousandths of a second behind Lyles. Lyles' US compatriot Fred Kerley claimed the bronze in 9.81 seconds, narrowly edging out South African Akani Simbine, who clocked in at 9.82 seconds. Defending champion Marcell Jacobs of Italy finished fifth in 9.85 seconds, while Botswana's Letsile Tebogo came in sixth with a time of 9.86 seconds. American Kenny Bednarek finished seventh in 9.88 seconds, with Jamaican Oblique Seville rounding out the race in eighth place with a time of 9.91 seconds.\n\nCommencing in lane seven, on the outside of Seville and inside Tebogo, Lyles started off with an average beginning but quickly found his rhythm.\n\nWith his head down through the first 40 meters, the American sprinter then accelerated, with the entire field pushing him to the limit.\n\nAs Lyles crossed the finish line with Thompson hot on his heels, the crowd erupted and a close finish was declared before Lyles was officially declared the gold medalist.\n\nThe pre-race atmosphere was electric in the 69,000-seat Stade de France, with a dazzling light show and pulsating bass-heavy music keeping the spectators entertained as the sprinters made their final preparations at the starting blocks.\n\nAfter the lights were dimmed, the sprinters left the track to re-enter like gladiators in a colosseum.\n\nIntroduced individually over the speakers, each sprinter was presented with an image of their name alongside their country's flag.\n\nThompson let out a roar, clenching his fists as he threw his head back. Kerley tapped his chest.\n\nLyles bounded out like a kangaroo, bouncing 20 meters down the track. Jacobs remained composed, raising both arms and calmly walking to his blocks.\n\nAnd then came the moment where the sprinters settled, ready at the starter's command.\n\nThe wait felt endless. The music played on, the crowd clapped in unison as if urging the starter to begin, and the sprinters stood in their lanes, shifting their weight from foot to foot, the tension palpable.\n\nThe cameras scanned the field once more, and then it was time, with the only sound being the whirring of a helicopter's blades overhead.\n\nThe signal was given and the competitors surged forward as one on the purple track.\n\nThe officials at the photo-finish examined the evidence, and Lyles walked away with the gold medal, putting to rest the disappointments of the Tokyo Games where he had only managed to secure a bronze in the 200m event.", "source": {"uri": "pehalnews.in", "dataType": "news", "title": "Pehal News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-08-443866832", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "20:43:51", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T20:43:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T20:11:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://www.france24.com/en/live-news/20240804-american-noah-lyles-wins-men-s-olympic-100m-gold", "title": "Lyles wins Olympic 100m gold in closest finish in modern history", "body": "Paris (AFP) - World champion Noah Lyles roared to victory in 9.79sec to claim gold in a dramatic men's Olympic 100m final in Paris on Sunday.\n\nLyles won in the closest Olympic 100m finish in modern history -- just five thousandths of a second separated him from Jamaica's Kishane Thompson who clocked the same time of 9.79sec.\n\nIt made Lyles the first American, male or female, to win the event since Justin Gatlin took gold in the 2004 Athens Games.\n\n\"It's the one I wanted,\" said Lyles. \"It's the hard battle, it's the amazing opponents.\n\n\"Everybody's healthy, everybody came prepared for the fight and I wanted to prove that I'm the man amongst all of them. I'm the wolf amongst wolves.\"\n\nLyles' victory was only confirmed after a photo-finish.\n\nThe American said of the wait for the final results: \"I went up to Kishane and I was like, 'I'm going to be honest, bro, I think you had that one'.\n\n\"And I was fully prepared to see his name pop up and to see my name pop up, I'm like goodness gracious. I'm incredible.\"\n\nLyles' US teammate Fred Kerley took bronze in 9.81sec, just one-hundredth ahead of South African Akani Simbine, who timed 9.82sec.\n\nIn an astonishing race, defending champion Marcell Jacobs of Italy was fifth in 9.85sec, Botswana's Letsile Tebogo sixth in 9.86sec, American Kenny Bednarek seventh in 9.88sec and Jamaican Oblique Seville eighth in 9.91sec.\n\nStarting in lane seven, outside Seville and inside Tebogo, Lyles got off to an average start but was soon into his stride pattern.\n\nHead tucked down through to the 40-metre mark, the American opened up, but the whole field pushed him all the way.\n\nAs Lyles dipped for the line with Thompson charging alongside him, the crowd erupted and a photo-finish was called before Lyles was confirmed as gold medallist.\n\nThere was an electric pre-race atmosphere in a 69,000-capacity Stade de France, a light show and booming music keeping the crowd entertained as the sprinters made the final adjustments to their starting blocks.\n\nTense buildup\n\nThe lights were then shut off, the sprinters leaving the track to remake their entrance like prize fighters in a colosseum.\n\nEach sprinter was individually introduced behind an image of their name above their flag.\n\nThompson roared, hands clenched in fists as his head rolled back. Kerley patted his heart.\n\nLyles bounded out like a kangaroo, bouncing 20 metres down the track. Jacobs was the definition of cool, raising both arms and calmly walking to his blocks.\n\nThen came the moment where the sprinters set, at the starter's beck and call.\n\nThe wait seemed interminable. The music continued, the crowd clapped in unison as if to hurry the starter, then the sprinters stood in their lanes, rocking from foot to foot and the tension was palpable.\n\nThe cameras panned one more and then it was time, the only sound that of a helicopter's wings whirring overhead.\n\nThe shot was fired and the field moved as if one up the purple track.\n\nThe photo-finish officials examined the evidence and Lyles walked away with gold to bury the demons of the Tokyo Olympics three years ago where he harvested a mere 200m bronze.\n\nAsked whether he was confident of doubling up in the 200m, an event in which he is a three-time world champion, Lyles was in no doubt.\n\n\"100 percent,\" he said. \"That's my better event and now that I've got a new PR in the 100, I'm ready to {"uri": "8259975315", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "11:20:02", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T11:20:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T11:19:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://gulfnews.com/sport/olympics/sprint-king-noah-lyles-confident-of-olympic-treble-in-paris-1.103739810", "title": "Sprint king Noah Lyles confident of Olympic treble in Paris", "body": "Paris: Newly minted Olympic 100m champion Noah Lyles has his sights on triple gold at the Paris Games.\n\nLyles came out on top of a thrilling race at the Stade de France Sunday that ended in a photo-finish to open his golden account.\n\nThe American was awarded victory over Jamaican Kishane Thompson by just five-thousandths of a second in the closest finish in modern Olympic history.\n\nLyles won three golds at last year's world championships in Budapest and the 27-year-old said he was eyeing a repeat in the French capital.\n\n\"I'm pretty confident, I can't lie,\" said Lyles.\n\nHe is seeking to emulate Usain Bolt, the last sprinter to achieve the treble.\n\nThe Jamaican legend did it at the 2016 Rio Games, having also done it four years previously in London.\n\n\"Kenny (Bednarek) definitely put up a fast time (in the 200m) at trials and that definitely woke me up -- and I was very proud of him.\n\n\"He's definitely not going to take how he did here in the 100m lying down. He's going to say 'I'm going after it in the 200m' because he knows he can go after it.\"\n\nBut Lyles had a message for any pretenders to the crown in the 200m, an event in which he is reigning three-time world champion.\n\n\"I'll be winning!\" he said. \"None of them is winning. When I come off the turn, They will be depressed.\"\n\nLyles' winning time in the 100m was a personal best, but he'd known something was cooking after timing 9.83 sec in the semi-finals.\n\n\"When I saw that, I know I'm going to be difficult to beat, I'm about to set a personal record,\" he said.\n\n\"I called my therapist and she was like, 'you need to let go, you need to let it flow', and I was like, 'alright I'm going to trust you'.\"\n\nMental health\n\nThe therapy certainly worked and set Lyles up perfectly for a tilt at a treble, with the 4x100m relay to follow the 200m, round one of which is on Monday.\n\nLyles came away from the Covid-delayed Tokyo Games with just a bronze in the 200m, something he said left him with burning in his chest.\n\nBut he was adamant that he had changed in the three years since then.\n\n\"Oh gosh, this is definitely a different Noah, 100 per cent,\" said Lyles, who has openly talked about his struggles with mental health and depression in recent years.\n\n\"I'm definitely not depressed. Don't get me wrong, I'm definitely feeling normal stress. I definitely feel the moment. It's a lot to deal with.\n\n\"I think back to Tokyo when I messed up handling the rounds. From then on, I was like, 'I'm never going to do that again.
