{"uri": "8259709437", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "08:30:30", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T08:30:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T08:29:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://www.ladbible.com/news/sport/olympics-2024-paris-noah-lyle-kishane-thompson-mens-100m-123694-20240805", "title": "Noah Lyles' 10-word message to Jamaican rival Kishane Thompson during photo finish wait after 100m Olympics final", "body": "Noah Lyles and Kishane Thompson were separated by five-thousandths of a second in the men's 100m at the Paris Olympics\n\nUS sprinter Noah Lyles stormed to victory in the Men's 100m final at the Paris Olympics last night, but he only beat out Jamaican rival Kishane Thompson by the skin of his teeth.\n\nThe 27-year-old, from Florida, came out on top by an extremely slim margin, as only 0.005 seconds set the pair apart.\n\nThe highly-anticipated race culminated in a photo finish, as the American was neck and neck with Thompson for the final 10 metres - while the rest of the runners weren't too far behind them either.\n\nDespite getting off to a slow start, Lyles set a new personal best with his incredible time of just 9.784 to win gold, while his Jamaican counterpart, 23, came in with a time of 9.789.\n\nAmerican sprinter Fred Kerley took home the bronze medal with a time of 9.81.\n\nBut for viewers watching at home - and the athletes themselves - it was hard to tell who had come out on top at first.\n\nIt's not enough for a sprinter just to stretch their leg over the finish line, as it's the first person to get their torso across it which counts, so both Lyles and Thompson weren't too sure who had managed to secure the narrow victory.\n\nThe two track and field stars were seen uttering a few words to one another as they intently looked up at the screens in the Olympic stadium while waiting for the official results to flash up.\n\nAnd if you were wishing you could be a fly on the wall for that tense conversation, you're in luck - as Lyles has explained what he said to his opponent while they waited to find out which one of them had triumphed.\n\nSpeaking to Jamaican broadcaster SportsMax TV after his extraordinary win, the American revealed what was running through his mind while sprinting along the track, as well as the details of his chat with Thompson.\n\nLyles said: \"It was a very close race.\n\n\"I'm glad I had Oblique Seville next to me because I was like, 'Yo, I need someone to put that pressure on me early'.\n\n\"And then after I passed him I saw Kishane out there I was like, 'Just do what I do, hit my top-end speed, let it work'.\n\n\"To be honest, I didn't know if I had it,\" the six-time world champion said.\n\n\"I leaned, but I didn't know I had it. Me and Kishane were at the end waiting for our names to come up and I came back and I said, 'I'll be honest, man, I think you got that one'.\n\nThe athlete added: \"But my name came up and I was like, 'Oh my gosh, I'm amazing'.\"\n\nSo rather than slinging trash talk at one another, it was actually more of a mutual pat on the back.\n\nLyles - who qualified in lane seven with the third fastest time in the semis, 9.83, and with the second fastest personal best out of the final runners, which was 9.81 - said he somewhat manifested his win in the Men's 100m.\n\nHe added: \"I've waited a long time, I've seen Jamaicans dominate the 100m and 200m for so long and I remember growing up saying, 'When it's my turn, I'm going to make sure that the US is on top'.\n\n\"And here it is, here's my time, my journey, my moment, it's such a beautiful thing to see.\"\n\nThe gold medallist will now battle it out in the Men's 200m as well as the 4x100m relay this week - which could see him follow in the Both sprinters clocked an identical time of 9.79 seconds, with Lyles setting a new personal best in the process.\n\nThe race unfolded dramatically at Stade de France, with Thompson leading for the majority of the distance. However, Lyles demonstrated his exceptional finishing power, surging past his rivals in the latter half of the race to claim victory by the narrowest of margins.\n\nThis triumph marks the beginning of Lyles' ambitious campaign at the Paris Olympics, where he aims to win up to four gold medals. The American sprinter's victory in the 100m event sets a strong foundation for his subsequent competitions.\n\nFred Kerley, another American and former world champion, secured the bronze medal with a time of 9.81 seconds. South Africa's Akani Simbine narrowly missed out on a podium finish, coming in fourth place.\n\nThe men's 100m final lived up to its reputation as one of the most anticipated events of the Olympic Games, delivering a spectacle of speed and competitiveness that captivated spectators at the stadium and viewers worldwide. {"uri": "8259068280", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "20:27:10", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T20:27:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T20:26:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://bleacherreport.com/articles/10130774-noah-lyles-celebrated-by-fans-after-photo-finish-win-in-mens-100m-at-2024-olympics", "title": "Noah Lyles Celebrated by Fans After Photo Finish Win in Men's 100M at 2024 Olympics", "body": "Noah Lyles talked the talk leading up to the men's 100m final at the Paris Olympics on Sunday. And then he walked the walk.\n\nWell, more accurately, he ran very, very fast and won the gold medal by probably the narrowest margin you'll ever see in the event.\n\nNyles posted a personal best of 9.79, besting Kishane Thompson by 0.005 seconds. It doesn't get much closer than that.\n\n\"America, I told you,\" Lyles yelled into the camera after the results were made official.\n\nAmerican Fred Kerley took bronze, posting a time of 9.81 seconds. Marcell Jacobs, who won gold at the 2020 Tokyo Games, placed fifth.\n\nSunday's race was incredibly tight, to the point that it was unclear who won at all. But once Lyles was crowned, social media was whipped into a frenzy:\n\nLyles, who got off to a slow start in Sunday's final and didn't even finish first in his opening heat on Saturday, admitted that he underestimated the field heading into the event.\n\n\"These boys said they ain't coming to play,\" he told reporters. \"And I guess that's my first lesson in underestimating the power of an Olympics. When somebody's on the line, they say they're going to give it their all or nothing. The plan was first. But it didn't happen. Second is fine. We'll make sure from here on out it's first.\"\n\nHe also finished second in his semifinals run on Sunday, leading to some doubt as to whether gold was in his future. {"uri": "8259062111", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "20:18:37", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T20:18:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T20:17:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://www.on3.com/pro/news/photo-finish-reveals-noah-lyles-won-100-meter-dash-by-thinnest-of-margins/", "title": "Photo finish reveals Noah Lyles won 100-meter dash by thinnest of margins", "body": "In a finish for the ages in the 100-meter dash, America's Noah Lyles narrowly edged out Jamaica's Kishane Thompson by five-thousandths of a second to take the gold medal.\n\nIt was as much of a photo finish as there's been in the Olympics in years. And even with the photo it's somewhat hard to determine the winner at the finish.\n\nCheck out how close it was below.\n\nThe finish was so close that Lyles and Thompson spent an agonizingly long few seconds simply looking up at the scoreboard with their hands on their head after the race, waiting for the winner to be announced.\n\nWhen Lyles learned he had won, he reacted jubilantly, bouncing up and down the track, taking his pinned USA label from the front of his jersey and holding it up to the crowd. He then turned to the camera and yelled, \"America, I told you!\"\n\nNoah Lyles posted a 9.78-second time in the event to take home the gold.\n\nHe needed every bit of it, too. That was something he might not necessarily have factored in when he initially arrived in Paris, perhaps just a touch overconfident.\n\nLyles ran a 10.04 second time in qualifying, watching some finish ahead of him. He remarked afterward that he was surprised by the level of competition.\n\n\"These boys said they ain't coming to play,\" Lyles said, via ESPN. \"And I guess that's my first lesson in underestimating the power of an Olympics. When somebody's on the line, they say they're going to give it their all or nothing.\n\n\"The plan was first. But it didn't happen. Second is fine. We'll make sure from here on out it's first ... Now I don't have to hold back.\"\n\nNoah Lyles certainly held nothing back in the final of the 100-meter dash, running a blazing time to secure the gold medal. Now he'll get the chance to add to his tally by taking the 200-meter dash, an event he also had circled coming into Paris.\n\nLyles was the reigning 100-meter dash World Champion and took home a bronze medal in the 200-meter dash during the 2020 Tokyo Olympics. He eventually won a title at the World Championships in that event in 2022 and 2023, in addition to the 100-meter dash.", "source": {"uri": "on3.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "On3"}, "authors": "https://on3static.com/uploads/dev/assets/cms/2024/08/04150515/LylesNoah_240804_001_LangJames_USAT.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9790103", "eventUri": "eng-9790103", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.1764705882352942, "wgt": 168, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8259202894", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "23:44:39", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T23:44:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T23:42:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://www.si.com/olympics/noah-lyles-crowned-worlds-fastest-man-paris-olympics-100-meters-gold-medal", "title": "Noah Lyles Crowned World's Fastest Man: 'It Feels Good to Back It Up'", "body": "SAINT-DENIS, France -- Late Sunday, 20 minutes before a track superstar turned into an icon, Keisha Caine Bishop walked the outer ring at Stade de France with her daughter. They were pretty much alone. The sun kept dropping, nearby horizons turning purple and orange and a darker yellow, a hue that looked a lot like ...\n\nGold.\n\nShe wasn't exactly nervous. And she wasn't exactly calm.\n\nHer son, Noah Lyles -- the bombastic, shoe-painting, anime-watching, LEGO-building sprinter -- needed to prove that embracing every single zany slice of his ever-more public personality had made him faster.\n\n\"I just want to get this going,\" she said, smiling, in a way that indicated she knew more than she wanted to say out loud.\n\nJust before he left for Paris, Lyles's biomechanist Ralph Mann told him one thing: He held the thumb and pointer finger on his right hand no more than half an inch apart. A sliver maybe. The end of a pen cap. A popsicle stick, laid flat. The 100-meter final, Mann predicted, would be that close -- specifically, the physical non-distance between first place and second.\n\nLyles, 27, nearly tied the 100-meter final on Sunday. He came as close as one can in his sport to running exactly the same time as another sprinter. Five-thousandths of a single second separated the gold and silver medal winners. That's 0.005 seconds. Google: what can happen in 0.005 seconds? The primary and prevalent answer is ... nothing. At least that can be perceived.\n\nIn winning the 100-meter dash, Lyles secured his first -- but not likely his last -- Olympic gold medal.\n\n\"It feels good,\" he said, \"to back it up.\"\n\nA lifetime unfolded between the walk onto the track and the photo finish. It began with an extraordinary Olympic prelude. The inside of the stadium all but pulsated. A deejay, clad in a black leather jacket, wearing sunglasses at night, spun deep house. As the bright stadium bulbs went completely dark, without warning, the lights along the upper ring flashed white and purple, in sync with the beats. The crowd gasped. Spotlights scanned from one side to the other, while tiny lights sparkled throughout the stands, thanks to wristbands fans were given at the gates. The thumping bass elevated, slowly at first, then faster, faster and faster, until the whole stadium felt like a bubble of anticipation about to pop.\n\nOne-by-one, the men's 100-meter finalists made their way onto the track. Here they were, in Paris, in an Olympic final, in their sport's premier race. Jamaica's Kishane Thompson, a favorite with the world's fastest time this year, leaned back in the entrance tunnel, before slowly raising both arms, tilting his head back and roaring like a lion. The camera strung above the purple track dropped and elevated, slinging left and right, before settling on the obvious suspect: Lyles.\n\nHe didn't saunter onto the track. Nor did he swagger in. He ran. Not sprinting, but not slowly. He didn't stop at the starting blocks, like everybody else. He cruised about 15 meters beyond the others.\n\nLyles never stopped moving, like he had bottled every ounce of energy and online hatred and unrealized ambition but could no longer hold it in. His feet bounced on the purple track -- purple, his favorite color -- springing up, then down, as if guided by a trampoline underfoot.\n\nFred Kerley, another American finalist, entered the stadium right then. He held a finger to his lips, as if to say, quiet down. Perhaps that gesture was meant for Lyles, whose general nature had grated on his competition, especially over the last six months.\n\nLyles screamed. He beat his chest with both hands. Energy seemed to rise from his body, like steam rising from a whistling kettle. He saluted, then appeared to repeat the same three words, over and over. It looked like he was saying: thank you, God.\n\nThe crowd began to clap. The introductions dragged on for minutes that unspooled like hours. The competitors -- the world's fastest men -- stepped in place, swayed, danced, waiting for the signal. The defending Olympic 100-meter champion, Lamont Marcell Jacobs of Italy, stood still with his eyes closed.\n\nAt 9:53 p.m. local time, the sprinters leaned their bodies forward and placed their spikes into the starting blocks. The stadium dropped into near silence. The loudest sound came from the helicopters hanging overhead.\n\nAnticipation isn't the right word. The general feeling landed around start this damn thing already. The gun sounded. And off they went.\n\nFor the first few meters, Lyles sprinted from the back of the pack -- perhaps, even, in last place. But that didn't last long. He caught them, all of them, these strong, powerful, human locomotives, each churning as fast as humanly possible toward the same line down the track.\n\nFor a second, it appeared that Kerley had won. Then it appeared that Lyles did. Then Thompson. Those three names flashed across the video screens, in that order. Everyone stood around the finish line.\n\nLyles approached Thompson at one point. \"Hey, man,\" Lyles told him, \"I think you got it.\"\n\nIt didn't take long for officials to come back with the results. Lyles surely must have never been happier to be dead wrong. Those same three names flashed on those same screens, only this time, in a different order: Lyles-Thompson-Kerley. The men's 100-meter final gold, silver and bronze medalists, respectively.\n\nIn the video analysis Olympic officials distributed after the race, Lyles was last, even at the 30-meter mark. He did not lead at any other point. In Lane 7, he didn't have time to look left, at Thompson in Lane 4, or Kerley in Lane 3. He told himself the obvious, in fractions of critical seconds. I need to lean. So that's what Lyles did. He leaned. They all did. Photographs from the finish line make the runners look like their necks are being bent forward by a gale-force wind.\n\nHis winning time, 9.79 seconds, matched Ben Johnson's steroid-aided world record in 1988, the one that didn't stand. He is the first male U.S. sprinter to win the race since Justin Gatlin in 2004. Lyles began to alternately gallop and jog and walk around the track. He pumped his fists. He unleashed screams. He held his race bib, the one that read LYLES in black letters, and jumped a barrier to celebrate with Keisha and other relatives.\n\nLyles showed up as Noah on Sunday. Last month, Keisha said that the biggest difference she saw in her son from Tokyo -- where he won bronze in the 200 meters -- and Paris, was a fuller embrace of just how different he was. He came to a better understanding of self, which led him to a better understanding of his sport.\n\nBefore Paris, former sprinter Michael Johnson said that of all America's promising young superstars, Lyles had the best chance to vault to a new level of stardom with his results. \"But he has to do it in Paris, at the Olympics, and more than once,\" Johnson added.\n\nSunday marked an ideal start, for the six-time world champion and the now two-time Olympic medalist, who found himself and found his speed. Now, he can continue to chase one of his sport's rarest achievements in Paris -- the sprint double. It's not a lock. But it's not that far away, either. Lyles didn't lose one 200-meter race over the 2022 and '23 seasons.\n\nBefore Sunday's final, Lyles wasn't nervous -- same as Keisha on her walk. He thought back to a regular topic he had been exploring with his therapist. To not view pressure as a problem, to understand the notion that wanting something doesn't always equate to being able to automatically deliver it.\n\n\"I was extremely curious to see what was gonna happen,\" he said. \"I came in third fastest [in the semis.] This [was] not going to be easy. That's how we phrase it. I'm curious what I'm gonna do. How am I going to pull this off?\"\n\nHis therapist, Lyles said, told him to let go in those moments, to relax and be himself. Turns out, to achieve the rarest kind of greatness, and to lift his sport to the same heights he's headed toward, that was all he ever needed.", "source": {"uri": "si.com", "dataType": "news", I'm going to handle this correctly and practice over the years'. It's accumulated to this point. You only need one. As long as that's the last one, that's all that matters,\" he said.\n\nThe gold made Lyles the first American, male or female, to win the event since Justin Gatlin claimed the gold in 2004, while luckless Kishane Thompson of Jamaica, who had appeared slightly ahead of Lyles at the race's halfway point, took silver with 0.005 seconds behind.\n\n\"It's been a rollercoaster, ups and downs. I'm usually a guy who likes to come out blazing in all my rounds, especially in the 200m. But the 100m, it's my first time here on the Olympic stage,\" Lyles noted.\n\nThompson said he was super grateful and he came out here and finished injury free, \"I think you guys know my past issues with injuries, so I am a bit disappointed. But I am happy at the same time. Lyles ended up losing the semifinal after staring down Seville right before they crossed the finish line.\n\nLyles' showboating got the better of him in the preliminary race as he ended up finishing second behind Seville. Lyles clocked in with a final time of 9.83, which was just 0.02 seconds behind Seville's time.\n\nLyles himself admitted that he committed a near-fatal error in the preliminary race -- one that he vowed to learn from.\n\n\"These are like the hardest fought medals I've ever had to do,\" Lyles said after winning gold in the final race. \"I came out here in the first round and I underestimated it. His mother's reaction to the victory resulted in a moment as special as her son's triumph.\n\nMORE: Updated standings of track and field medal winners at Paris Games\n\nWhile celebrations continued and awe from the event set in among all in attendance, Lyles made his way to his mother in the stands, with whom he shared a special moment. There's no questioning the pride his mother felt at that moment.\n\nAs Lyles and his mother shared an embrace, she reaffirmed the moment's gravity by telling Lyles \"You did it!\" as the two were moved to tears of joy. {"uri": "8259171857", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "22:54:34", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T22:54:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T22:52:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "url": "https://www.on3.com/pro/news/kyle-busch-shouts-out-noah-lyles-after-dramatic-100-meters-gold-medal-win-this-aged-well/", "title": "Kyle Busch shouts out Noah Lyles after dramatic 100M gold medal win: 'This aged well'", "body": "Kyle Busch made it clear he was rooting for Noah Lyles in Sunday's 100-meter final at the 2024 Summer Olympics, and the American sprinter did not disappoint.\n\nLyles posted a personal-best 9.784-second time, outlasting Jamaica's Kishane Thompson by 0.005 seconds to win his first career gold medal. \"From one guy who knows speed to another,\" the two-time NASCAR Cup Series champion gave Lyles a shoutout on X following his dramatic victory at Stade de France.\n\n\"Seems this aged well!! Great race @LylesNoah,\" Busch tweeted.\n\nLyles, the 27-year-old, Gainesville, Florida, born sprinter, is the first American to win gold in the 100-meter final since Justin Gatlin in 2004. He claimed bronze in the 200-meter final in the 2020 Summer Games in Tokyo and will seek to top his performance in that event this coming Wednesday.\n\nWhile Lyles will soon turn his attention to the 200-meter final, he's relishing in his run for gold in the 100-meter final, officially becoming the \"World's Fastest Man.\"\n\n\"We were waiting for the names to pop up, and I'm going to be honest, I came over [to Thompson] and I was like: 'I think you got that one, big dawg,'\" Lyles said, via Coley Harvey of ESPN. \"Something said I need to lean, and I was like, 'I'm going to lean,' because it's that type of race.\"\n\nFellow Americans Fred Kerley and Kenny Bednarek took part in the 100-meter final, Kerley taking bronze. Bednarek, meanwhile, sprinted his way to a seventh-place finish. While the competition will be steep in the 200-meter final, the confident Lyles isn't concerned.\n\nHe sees a second gold medal in his future.\n\n\"[Kerley] is definitely not going to take how he did here in the 100-meter lying down... [But] that man ain't winning,\" Lyles said. \"None of them is winning. {"uri": "8259199884", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "23:38:31", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T23:38:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T23:37:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "url": "https://www.usmagazine.com/celebrity-news/news/noah-lyles-wins-mens-100m-gold-in-photo-finish-at-paris-olympics/", "title": "USA's Noah Lyles Wins Mens 100m Gold in Photo-Finish", "body": "It would be fair to say that American track star Noah Lyles has reached the pinnacle of his sport - if he hadn't spent months setting an even higher goal for himself.\n\nThe sprinter took home the gold in the men's 100m, a first for the Florida native, at the 2024 Paris Summer Olympics. Lyles' win was the closest on record, as he beat his nearest competitor (Jamaica's Kishane Thompson) by five-thousandths of a second (.005). The most recent comparable race to this year's photo-finish came in Moscow 1980, well before times were recorded to such a granular level. Great Britain's Allan Wells and Cuba's Silvio Sarria both notched a time of 10.25 seconds, with Wells taking the gold.\n\n\"I did think Thompson had it at the end,\" Lyles shared with reporters, about the close finish. \"I went up to him when we were waiting and I said, 'I think you got that one, big dog.' And then my name popped up and I'm like, 'Oh my gosh, I'm amazing.'\n\nLyles' win is the first time an American has taken the top prize in the race in 20 years, with the years between Justin Gatlin's 2004 Athens win and the present filled by the indomitable run of Jamaica's Usain Bolt. It's that retired superstar who the press-savvy Lyles sees as his biggest competition, as he's frequently boasted that his goal is to top the string of records set by the world's fastest man.\n\nBoth Bolt's Olympic and world records in the 100m were safe on Sunday. Bolt set his Olympic record in 2012 with a time of 9.63, more than a tenth of a second faster than Lyles' winning time of 9.79 (his personal best). Bolt's world record is even more distant, a staggeringly fast sprint of 9.58 seconds that he set in 2009.\n\nLyles specializes in the 200m race, which is still to come on Tuesday. Bolt also holds the record for that competition. A gold in Lyles' preferred event would make him the first man to take both medals since Bolt in 2016. He would be the first American to win both races since Carl Lewis in 1984.\n\nBolt, for his part, thinks that Lyles may one day break his record. He told Citius Mag in March that the runner needed to work on some parts of his technique, but stopped short of drawing a road map on how to take down his record.\n\n\"I think if he corrects a few things -- I won't say -- he could get better,\" he said. \"The possibility is there... {"uri": "8259077101", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "20:39:55", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T20:39:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T20:38:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "url": "https://www.postandcourier.com/aikenstandard/sports/noah-lyles-wins-olympic-100-by-five-thousandths-of-a-second-among-closest-finishes-in/article_d03bb972-5679-58b6-b9d6-28228275f8d2.html", "title": "Noah Lyles wins Olympic 100 by five-thousandths of a second, among closest finishes in Games history", "body": "SAINT-DENIS, France -- Noah Lyles won the Olympic 100 meters by .005 seconds Sunday, waiting some 30 seconds after the finish of an excruciatingly close sprint to find out he'd beaten Kishane Thompson of Jamaica.\n\nThe word \"Photo\" popped up on the scoreboard after Lyles and Thompson dashed to the line. Lyles paced the track with his hands draped over his head. Finally, the numbers came up. Lyles won in 9.784 seconds to edge out the Jamaican by five-thousandths of a tick of the clock.\n\nAmerica's Fred Kerley came in third at 9.81. The top seven all finished within .09 of each other.\n\nThis was the closest 1-2 finish in the 100 since at least Moscow in 1980 -- or maybe even ever. Back then, Britain's Allan Wells narrowly beat Silvio Leonard in an era when the electronic timers didn't go down into the thousandths of a second.\n\nThank goodness they do now.\n\nLyles became the first American to win the marquee event in Olympic track since Justin Gatlin in 2004.\n\nToday's Top Headlines Third Lulu's Car Wash opens in Aiken Traffic delays anticipated as resurfacing begins on Aiken's Whiskey Road One person dead following fatal hit-and-run in Barnwell County Aiken-trained Post Time runs third in Whitney Stakes ARTS AND HUMANITIES: A lost Carolina novel is found New facility for Children's Place almost complete SC's Tax Free Weekend begins today. Here's what you need to know before shopping. Guest column: Biden administration should protect S.C.s prescription drug access Aiken funeral home owner, former employee arraigned on federal bank fraud charges What could be achieved with a renewed Penny Sales Tax? Corey Murphy shares insights with community leaders\n\nThe 9.784 also marks a personal best for Lyles, who has been promising to add his own brand of excitement to track and certainly delivered this time.\n\nHe will be a favorite later this week in the 200 meters -- his better race -- and will try to join Usain Bolt as the latest runner to win both Olympic sprints.\n\nFor perspective, the blink of an eye takes, on average, .1 second, which was 20 times longer than the gap between first and second in this one.\n\nWhat was the difference? Maybe Lyles' closing speed and his lean into the line. He and Thompson had two of the three slowest bursts from the blocks, and Thompson had what sufficed for a \"lead\" at the halfway point.\n\nBut this would take more than 10 seconds to decide. When Lyles learned he'd won it, he pulled off his name tag and raised it to the sky, then brought his hands to his side and pointed at the camera.\n\nYes, he's the World's Fastest Man. 2024", "body": "Paris: World champion Noah Lyles roared to victory in 9.79 seconds to claim gold in a dramatic men's Olympic 100m final in Paris on Sunday.\n\nLyles became the first American, male or female, to win the event since Justin Gatlin won in the 2004 Athens Games.\n\nIn a photo-finish, Jamaica's Kishane Thompson claimed silver, just five-thousandths of a second off Lyles' pace.\n\nLyles' US teammate Fred Kerley took bronze in 9.81s, just one-hundredth ahead of South African Akani Simbine, who timed 9.82s.\n\nDefending champion Marcell Jacobs of Italy was fifth in 9.85s, Botswana's Letsile Tebogo sixth in 9.86s, American Kenny Bednarek seventh in 9.88s and Jamaican Oblique Seville eighth in 9.91s in an astonishing race.\n\nStarting in lane seven, outside Seville and inside Tebogo, Lyles got off to an average start but was soon into his stride pattern.\n\nHead tucked down through to the 40-metre mark, the American opened up, but the whole field pushed him all the way.\n\nAs Lyles dipped for the line with Thompson charging alongside him, the crowd erupted and a photo-finish was called before Lyles was confirmed as gold medallist.\n\nThere was an electric pre-race atmosphere in a 69,000-capacity Stade de France, a light show and booming bass-heavy music keeping the crowd entertained as the sprinters made the final adjustments to their starting blocks.\n\nThe lights were then shut off, the sprinters leaving the track to remake their entrance like prize fighters in a colosseum.\n\nCalled out over the tannoy, each sprinter was individually introduced behind an image of their name above their flag.\n\nThompson roared, hands clenched in fists as his head rolled back. Kerley patted his heart.\n\nLyles bounded out like a kangaroo, bouncing 20 metres down the track. Jacobs was the definition of cool, raising both arms and calmly walking to his blocks.\n\nThen came the moment where the sprinters set, at the starter's beck and call.\n\nThe wait seemed interminable. The music continued, the crowd clapped in unison as if to hurry the starter, then the sprinters stood in their lanes, rocking from foot to foot and the tension was palpable.\n\nThe cameras panned one more and then it was time, the only sound that of a helicopter's wings whirring overhead.\n\nThe shot was fired and the field moved as if one up the purple track.\n\nThe photo-finish officials When I crossed the line, I went up to him and said, 'Hey, man, I think you got that one'.\n\n\"When it came out, I thought, 'Oh my gosh, I am amazing'.\"\n\nThe 27-year-old beat out rival Jamaican Kishane Thompson (9.789) and fellow American Fred Kerley (9.81).\n\nThe race was the first time in Olympic history all 100m runners had qualified for the final in under 10 seconds.\n\nLyles' path to victory had been anything but easy as the Florida-born sprinter bypassed the traditional US college athlete route to turn professional.\n\nThe American had spent the leadup to the Olympics working on his technique and practicing his infamously poor start with coach Lance Brauman.\n\nWhen the starting gun fired, his 0.178 reaction time set him off the blocks in last place as he torched his way down the straight.\n\nHis speed saved him as he gradually fought his way back among the pack by 50m and threw himself over the line to overtake Thompson by a hair's breadth.\n\nWhile Thompson actually broke the line first with his foot, it was the American whose chest first passed the finishing line - the body part which determines the victor.\n\nThe victory makes Lyles the first United States Olympic champion in 20 years - since Justin Gatlin won at Athens in 2004.\n\nLyles has set himself the goal of winning gold in the 100m, 200m and 4x100m relay after achieving the trifecta at the World Message After Gold-Medal Win News", "body": "Noah Lyles, the 27-year-old sprinter, made history by becoming the first American to win gold in the men's 100-meter since 2004. In a nail-biting photo finish victory, Lyles won by five-thousandths of a second, securing his first Olympic gold medal. Known for his vibrant personality and emotional nature, Lyles has always been one to back up his words with actions. Prior to the opening ceremony, he boldly wrote \"ICON\" on his nails, setting the stage for his remarkable performance.\n\nDespite his outward confidence, Lyles has faced his fair share of struggles, including asthma, allergies, dyslexia, ADD, anxiety, and depression. In a powerful message of inspiration, he shared on social media, \"What you have does not define what you can become. Why Not You!\" This message resonates with anyone facing challenges and serves as a reminder of the power of perseverance and determination.\n\nClocking in at 9.79784 seconds, Lyles set a personal best with his gold-winning sprint. Even with the slowest reaction time and initially being in last place at the 40-meter mark, he defied the odds to claim victory. His triumphant performance added to the impressive tally of five gold medals won by Americans on that memorable day.\n\nLooking ahead, Lyles is setting his sights on the 200-meter race, with a dream goal of breaking Usain Bolt's world record of 19.19 seconds. Track legend Carl Lewis emphasized the importance of Lyles' success for the sport, stating that track and field thrive when there is a dominant champion to rally behind. With Lyles' potential to elevate the sport and capture the hearts of fans worldwide, his journey is one to watch and support.\n\nAs fans eagerly anticipate Lyles' future races and achievements, his story serves as a beacon of hope and inspiration for all. In a world where adversity is common, his words \"Why Not You!\" echo as a reminder to dream big, work hard, and never let obstacles define your potential. {"uri": "2024-08-444347538", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "09:50:22", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T09:50:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T09:37:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/other-sports/athletics/inside-mens-100m-olympic-final-33394875", "title": "Inside men's 100m final including photo finish, words exchanged and huge speeds", "body": "Noah Lyles had a slow start and was seventh at the half way stage - before storming to the finish\n\nThe 100m final is as tense as any event at the Olympics but few will come close to the dramatic finish fans were treated to at the 2024 Games.\n\nPundits were left claiming this was the greatest 100m event in history after all eight contestants finished within 0.12 seconds of the gold medal - which was secured by American runneer Noah Lyles, winning in 9.79 and holding off Jamaica's Kishane Thompson following a stunning photo finish.\n\nLyles and Thompson both faced an agonising wait before the former discovered he was the winner, claiming his first gold medal by five hundredths of a second - having claimed a bronze in the 200m in the Tokyo Games four years ago\n\nAfter an incredible turn of events with records broken, words exchanged and plenty of questions, Mirror Sport takes a look at the biggest talking points of an amazing 100m race.\n\nWhat is a photo finish?\n\nA photo finish happens in a race when more than one competitor crosses the finish line at almost the same time, with officials traditionally using a 'photo' or video footage to determine who the winner is.\n\nDuring especially tight finishes, that will include checking to see who has edged ahead and analysing which body part hit the finish line first.\n\nIn Lyles' case, technology was used with red lines breaking down the photo finish - similar to VAR in football - that shows the American's chest was the first body part across the line. While Thompson's foot appears to have crossed the line first, it is the torso - which includes the chest, abdomen, pelvis and back, that is primarily measured for the 100m.\n\nOfficials at the games are believed to use a \"slit video\" system that scans the finish line 2,000 times per second, showing an accurate image of when each athlete crossed the line.\n\nPhoto finishes are very common in horse racing, when multiple horses race towards the finish line, with one often winning \"by a nose\" in those cases, while they can also be seen in any other type of race, including motorsports and cycling.\n\nWhat was said between Lyles and Thompson?\n\nLyles and Thompson were seen deep in conversation after the race as both competitors faced a wait to determine who was taking the gold medal.\n\nThe American has now shed light on what was said between the pair - revealing he actually thought his Jamaican rival had beaten him.\n\n\"After I passed [Seville] I saw Kishane out there I was like just do what I do, hit my top-end speed, let it work,\" Lyles told SportsMax TV (via Metro) \"To be honest, I didn't know if I had it. I leaned but I didn't know I had it.\n\n\"Me and Kishane were at the end waiting for our names to come up and I came back and I said, 'I'll be honest man, I think you got that one'. But my name came up and I was like, 'Oh my gosh, I'm amazing.'\"\n\n\"I've waited a long time, I've seen Jamaicans dominate the 100m and 200m for so long and I remember growing up saying, 'when it's my turn I'm going to make sure that the US is on top'. And here it is, here's my time, my journey, my moment, it's such a beautiful thing to see.\"\n\nHow the lead changed during the race\n\nLyles didn't look remotely close to winning this race in the early stages, having the slowest reaction time of any sprinter with 0.178 - level with Letslie Tebogo - while Fred Kerley has the quickest with 0.108.\n\nHowever, Kerley could only claim bronze with a time of 9.81, while Lyles enjoyed a lightning chase to race past his rivals - despite being in last place after 40 metres of the race and being seventh at the halfway stage - before charging towards the finish line.\n\nHe had the quickest top speed of any runner in the race - 43.6km/h - which appears to have been crucial in him edging this race by the smallest of margins.\n\nWhat records were broken?\n\nSuch was the close nature of the 100m finish, world records were broken - but not for the men finishing in the podium places.\n\nAkani Simbine, Lamont Marcell Jacobs, Tebogo, Kenny Bednarek and Oblique Seville all registered the fastest times for those finishing between fourth and eighth in a 100m race, with times of 9.82, 9.85, 9.86, 9.88 and 9.91 respectively.\n\nLyles' time was impressive but still not quite enough to claim the world record for fastest time in the men's race - held by Usain Bolt (9.58).\n\nThis article contains affiliate links, we will receive a commission on any sales we generate from it. {"uri": "2024-08-443882213", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "21:18:56", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T21:18:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T20:50:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://www.capitalfm.co.ke/sports/2024/08/04/lyles-wins-sensational-100m-gold-by-just-0-005-seconds/", "title": "Lyles wins sensational 100m gold by just 0.005 seconds", "body": "PARIS, France, August 4 - American Noah Lyles won the Olympic men's 100m title by five-thousandths of a second from Jamaica's Kishane Thompson in a dramatic photo finish at Paris 2024.\n\nShowman Lyles overhauled his rivals in the second half of the race to triumph by the finest of margins in a personal best 9.79 seconds.\n\nThat was the same time as Olympic debutant Thompson, who led for most of the race, but Lyles produced a spectacular finish to successfully begin his bid for a potential four golds at these Games.\n\nThe United States' former world champion Fred Kerley took bronze in 9.81, edging out South Africa's Akani Simbine for the podium.\n\nAfter a lengthy wait behind the start line to a backdrop of dramatic music in a frenzied atmosphere at Stade de France, all eight finalists finished within 0.12 seconds of Lyles in a remarkable race.\n\nSuch was the standard of the final - which Great Britain's Zharnel Hughes and Louie Hinchliffe failed to reach - Italy's reigning champion Lamont Marcell Jacobs was run out of the medals and another Jamaican rising star, Oblique Seville, finished last in 9.91.\n\nIn the end it was Lyles, an athlete who thrives on the sport's grandest stages and who won three golds at last year's World Championships, who sprinted away in celebration once the official result appeared on the big screen.\n\nThe 27-year-old repeatedly rang the victory bell by the side of the track after establishing himself at the pinnacle of the sport, before he targets further success in the 200m and relay events.\n\nLyles continues to deliver on big ambitions\n\nLyles has remained outspoken and unflinching in his belief that he has the on-track ability and off-track aura to replace Usain Bolt as the new superstar of men's athletics.\n\nThe American has talked the talk but he continues to back it up when it matters most.\n\nLyles last year became the first man since Bolt in 2015 to win a 100m and 200m world double, before completing a golden treble in the 4x100m relay.\n\nLyles claimed in the build-up to the Paris Games that he will look to add the 4x400m to that haul in the French capital, and he hinted at his form when running a 100m personal best at the London Diamond League last month.\n\nBut repeating such success on these stages, under intense pressure - much of it self-imposed - is another thing entirely.\n\nHe has now become the first American to win an Olympic 100m title for 20 years, since Justin Gatlin in 2004, to assert himself as the dominant male sprinter of the current generation.\n\nA three-time reigning world 200m champion, he will now look to maintain his grip on the sport's major titles in that event, which starts on Monday.\n\nShould he do so, he will move a step closer to sporting immortality in his pursuit of a historic four golds at these Games.\n\nGB's Hinchliffe and Hughes come up short\n\nHinchliffe's fairytale rise from obscurity less than three months ago to an Olympic 100m debut was already a stunning achievement in its own right.\n\nBut the 22-year-old and his coach Carl Lewis both said their goal was to make the final in Paris. When the Briton beat Lyles in a statement introduction in his heat on Saturday that appeared a realistic target.\n\nEven Lewis, with his vast experience as both a nine-time Olympic champion and coach at the University of Houston for the past decade, has been surprised by the remarkable rate of Hinchliffe's progress during their 12-month partnership.\n\nUnfortunately the final proved a step too far, with Hinchliffe run out of the non-automatic qualifying spots after finishing third behind Seville and Lyles in his semi-final.\n\n\"It's obviously not the result I wanted but I can't be too hard on myself,\" Hinchliffe, already the sixth-fastest British man in history, told BBC Sport.\n\n\"I'll definitely use this experience and I'll learn from my mistakes, so it is back to the drawing board and we'll work on it and come back stronger next year.\"\n\nIt also was not to be for Hughes, who could not set up the opportunity to replicate the breakthrough first global medal he achieved last year - or for Olympic redemption following his false start in the Tokyo final three years ago.\n\nThe 29-year-old has not been able to hit the same heights of a 2023 season in which he broke two long-standing British records over 100m and 200m, after this campaign was disrupted by a hamstring injury.\n\n\"Obviously I'm disappointed but I know where I am coming from. This is my third 100m. Not making any excuses. Today just wasn't my day,\" Hughes, who will also contest the 200m, said.\n\n\"To try to get through the rounds of the Olympics after injuring my hamstring with a grade two tear last month wasn't that easy, but I dug deep to give myself a chance and that's what I came here to do.\"", "source": {"uri": "capitalfm.co.ke", "dataType": "news", "title": "Capital FM Kenya"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8259526220", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "06:15:02", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T06:15:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T06:14:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://sportstar.thehindu.com/olympics/paris-2024/news/paris-olympics-2024-kishane-thompson-relishes-silver-after-narrow-100m-photo-finish/article68487289.ece", "title": "Paris Olympics 2024: Kishane Thompson relishes silver after being on wrong end of 100-meter photo finish", "body": "Kishane Thompson let out a scream after crossing the finish line that was fitting of an Olympic 100-meter champion. Because, for a brief moment, he thought maybe he was.\n\nBy the slimmest of margins, Thompson was beaten out for gold on a perfectly timed lean from American Noah Lyles on Sunday night. Their times of 9.79 seconds needed to be calculated farther out to determine the winner -- with Lyles winning 9.784 to 9.789. Thompson was five-thousandths of a second away from joining the company of fellow Jamaican Usain Bolt as an Olympic champion.\n\n\"I'm a bit disappointed,\" Thompson said. \"But I am happy at the same time. I am going to take it as what it is and move forward from here.\"\n\nSomeone asked Thompson soon after if he thought the gold medal could be shared, since it was that close of race. It would be a nod to the high jumpers at the Tokyo Games in 2021, when Gianmarco Tamberi of Italy and Mutaz Barshim of Qatar agreed to split the gold medal.\n\nSomehow, Thompson didn't think Lyles would go for the idea.\n\n\"I think the sport is too competitive, no offense to any other sport,\" the 23-year-old Thompson said. \"It's too competitive for us to share a gold medal.\"\n\nALSO READ | Lyles wants US athletics to cash in on 100m triumph\n\nThe race was barely over and Thompson was already replaying the little things that could've made a big difference. Maybe more of a lean. Maybe a bit more patience to let his speed propel him to the finish line.\n\n\"I know that Jamaica would have wanted me to get the gold,\" he said. \"Everybody loves winners.\"\n\nThompson was in Lane 4 in the final and Lyles in Lane 7. He couldn't see Lyles out that far so he wasn't sure precisely where he stood right after the finish. Thompson knew it was close and immediately glanced at the scoreboard for an answer.\n\nHe waited. They all waited.\n\nLyles gave him a glimmer of hope, though.\n\n\"I did think Thompson had it at the end,\" Lyles said. \"I even said, 'Bro, I think you got that one big dog. And then my name popped up, and I'm like, 'Oh my gosh, I'm amazing.'\"\n\nThompson became the first Jamaican to be on the podium in the men's Olympic 100 since Bolt's run of three straight titles in 2008, '12 and '16.\n\n\"My body language will not show it because I am not an expressive guy, but I am glad,\" Thompson said. \"I'm super grateful.\"\n\nThompson entered the race with the fastest time of the season and was viewed as the biggest threat to Lyles. It came down to the wire with all eight sprinters separated by a margin of .12 seconds -- and even closer for gold and silver.\n\n\"That close,\" Thompson said. \"It was that close.\"\n\nLatest on {"uri": "8259154457", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "22:26:49", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T22:26:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T22:25:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "url": "https://bdnews24.com/sport/187b39cfe972", "title": "Showman Lyles wins 100m gold by five thousandths of a second", "body": "Paris 2024 Olympics - Athletics - Men's 100m Final - Stade de France, Saint-Denis, France - Aug 04, 2024. Noah Lyles of United States celebrates after winning gold. REUTERS/Dylan Martinez\n\nAfter all the talk and all the hype, Noah Lyles duly delivered when it mattered most when he won a superlative Olympic 100 metres final by five thousandths of a second on Sunday to give the United States the title for the first time in 20 years.\n\nIn the most competitive final of all time, there was a blanket finish, with the stadium scoreboard initially flashing a photo to separate the first seven athletes and Lyles believing he had lost.\n\nHe was then confirmed him as the winner in a personal best 9.79 seconds, the same time as Jamaica's Kishane Thompson, but ahead by the width of a vest.\n\nIf the race had been 99 metres Thompson would have been celebrating a fourth Jamaican win in five Olympics, but fast-finishing Lyles kept his form superbly and timed his dip expertly to add Olympic gold to his world title.\n\nHe ripped his bib name from his shirt and held it aloft with his red, white and blue varnished fingernails, announcing himself, as he had always promised he would be, as the fastest man in the world.\n\n\"It's the one I wanted, it's the hard battle, it's the amazing opponents,\" said Lyles, the first American Olympic 100m champion since Justin Gatlin in 2004.\n\n\"Everybody came prepared for the fight and I wanted to prove that I'm the man among all of them, I'm the wolf among wolves.\"\n\nIt was the first time eight men have broken 10 seconds in a wind-legal 100 metres race.\n\nTHOMPSON DISAPPOINTED\n\n\"I am a bit disappointed, but I am happy at the same time,\" Thompson said. \"I wasn't patient enough with myself to let my speed bring me at the line, in the position that I know I could have gone to, but I have learnt from it.\"\n\n\"I know that Jamaica would have wanted me to get the gold, everybody love winners. I would have loved to win today, but big up to the whole field.\"\n\nAmerican Fred Kerley took bronze in 9.81 and Akani Simbini of South Africa was fourth, making it a remarkable six fourth or fifth-placed finishes in global championships, albeit with the consolation of a national record of 9.83.\n\nDefending champion Lamont Marcell Jacobs of Italy, heavily strapped, finished fifth in 9.85 and Letsile Tebogo of Botswana also set a national record with 9.86 in sixth place.\n\nSuch was the quality of the race, that eighth-placed Oblique Seville of Jamaica still clocked 9.91 seconds.\n\nSeville had finished ahead of Lyles in 9.81 in the semi-final when the American looked to be at full stretch.\n\nHowever, the biggest showman in the sport and the star of the runaway success Netflix SPRINT series, has become a serious championship operator over the shorter distance, having won three 200m world titles and bronze over that distance at the last Olympics.\n\n\"I think back to Tokyo when I messed up handling the rounds. From then on, I was like, 'I'm never going to do that again. I'm going to handle this correctly and practice over the years',\" he said. \"It's accumulated to this point.\"\n\nLyles, 27, is targeting a possible four golds in Paris, in the 100m, his favourite 200m, the 4x100m relay and, possibly, the 4x400m relay.\n\nThat would emulate illustrious compatriots Jesse Owens and Carl Lewis, who achieved the feat at a single Games but with long jump instead of the longer relay.\n\nFormer world champion Kerly ran an excellent race to add bronze to his Tokyo silver medal.\n\n\"That was a great race and anyone could have won it,\" he said. \"I feel that I executed as best as I could. I came here for the gold and nothing else but, hey, everybody came here for the same thing and only one can win. Whoever came off the best, is the best.\"", "source": {"uri": "bdnews24.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "bdnews24.com"}, "authors": [{"uri": "bdnews24_com@bdnews24.com", "name": "Bdnews24 Com", Lyles, featured in the Netflix Sprint documentary, feels he deserves a personalized shoe after adding the Olympic title to his three World Athletics Championship titles from Budapest last year.\n\n\"I want my own shoe - my own trainer,\" said Lyles, who is sponsored by Adidas. \"There's no money in spikes. Even Michael Johnson didn't have his own sneaker. Considering the medals we win and the recognition we get, it's crazy this hasn't happened.\"\n\nAmong the fans at the Stade de France was American rapper Snoop Dogg, whom Lyles jokingly challenged to a race. \"As the Olympic champion, I hold the title of the world's fastest man. This has been years in the making,\" he said.\n\nAfter the race, Lyles admitted he initially thought he had lost in the photo-finish. \"We were waiting for the results, and I honestly told Kishane, 'I think you've got this, big dog.' He was in lane 4, and I was in lane 7, so I couldn't see clearly. I was ready to see his name pop up, but when I saw mine, I thought, 'Goodness gracious, I'm incredible.' This is the one I wanted. Everyone was prepared for the fight, and I wanted to prove that I'm the best among them all. I'm the wolf among wolves.\"\n\nLyles is set to compete in the men's 200m heats on Monday and is confident about winning gold, potentially challenging Usain Bolt's world record. \"I am very confident,\" he said. \"Kenny Bednarek's fast time in the trials woke me up. {"uri": "8259343744", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "03:09:50", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T03:09:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T03:08:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "url": "https://www.chinadailyasia.com/hk/article/589845", "title": "Olympics: Noah Lyles wins 100m gold by five thousandths of a second", "body": "PARIS - After all the talk and all the hype, Noah Lyles duly delivered when it mattered most by winning the closest-ever Olympic 100 meters final by five thousandths of a second on Sunday to give the United States the title for the first time in 20 years.\n\nIn a blanket finish Lyles believed he had left it too late to catch the powerful Kishane Thompson, but the giant screen confirmed him as the winner in a personal best 9.79 seconds, the same time as the Jamaican, but ahead by the width of a vest.\n\nIf the race had been 99 meters, Thompson would have been celebrating a fourth Jamaican men's 100m win in five Olympics, but fast-finishing Lyles kept his form superbly and timed his dip expertly to add Olympic gold to his world title.\n\nHe ripped his name bib from his shirt and held it aloft with his red, white and blue varnished fingernails, announcing himself, as he had always promised he would be, as the fastest man in the world.\n\n\"It's the one I wanted, it's the hard battle, it's the amazing opponents,\" said Lyles, the first American male Olympic 100m champion since Justin Gatlin in 2004.\n\n\"I didn't do this against a slow field - I did this against the best of the best, on the biggest stage, with the biggest pressure.\"\n\nHe was right about that, as it was the first time eight men have broken 10 seconds in a wind-legal 100 meters race.\n\nAmerican Fred Kerley took bronze in 9.81 and Akani Simbini of South Africa was fourth, making it a remarkable six fourth or fifth-placed finishes in global championships, albeit with the consolation of a national record time of 9.83.\n\nALSO READ: Olympics Day 9: Chinese swimmers surge up, Djokovic completes trophy collection\n\nDefending champion Lamont Marcell Jacobs of Italy, heavily strapped, finished fifth in 9.85 and Letsile Tebogo of Botswana also set a national record with 9.86 in sixth.\n\nSuch was the quality of the race, that eighth-placed Oblique Seville of Jamaica clocked 9.91 seconds.\n\n\"I did not think I won, I didn't think I dipped at the right time, too early,\" Lyles said. \"I even went up to Kishane while we were waiting and said 'I think you got that one.' But then my name popped up and I thought 'oh my gosh, I'm amazing'.\"\n\nThompson disappointed\n\nThompson arrived in Paris as the fastest man in the world this year (9.77) and was the quickest of the semi-finalists on Sunday with 9.80.\n\n\"I am a bit disappointed, but I am happy at the same time,\" he said. \"I wasn't patient enough with myself to let my speed bring me at the line in the position that I know I could have gone to.\"\n\nFormer world champion Kerley also ran an excellent race to add bronze to his Tokyo silver.\n\n\"That was a great race and anyone could have won it,\" he said.\n\n\"I feel that I executed as best as I could. I came here for the gold and nothing else but, hey, everybody came here for the same thing and only one can win. Whoever came off the best, is the best.\"\n\nSeville had finished ahead of Lyles in the semi-final when the American looked to be at full stretch.\n\nHowever, the biggest showman in the sport and the star of the runaway success Netflix SPRINT series, has become a serious championship operator over the shorter distance, having won three 200m world titles and 200m bronze at the last Olympics.\n\n\"I think back to Tokyo when I messed up handling the rounds. From then on, I was like, 'I'm never going to do that again. I'm going to handle this correctly and practice over the years',\" he said, adding that he felt rattled after the semi and called one of his therapists for advice.\n\nREAD MORE: Simone Biles wins her 3rd gold at Paris Olympics\n\nLyles, 27, is targeting a possible four golds in Paris, in the 100m, his favorite 200m, the 4x100m relay and, possibly, the 4x400m relay.\n\nThat would emulate illustrious compatriots Jesse Owens and Carl Lewis, who achieved the feat at a single Games but with long jump instead of the longer relay.", "source": {"uri": "chinadailyasia.com", "dataType": {"uri": "2024-08-443926538", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "23:13:13", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T23:13:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T22:53:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "url": "https://www.goskagit.com/2024olympics/kishane-thompson-relishes-silver-after-being-on-wrong-end-of-olympic-100-meter-photo-finish/article_839bd1ae-b02a-5c42-bbe4-dc9cd0bf920b.html", "title": "Kishane Thompson relishes silver after being on wrong end of Olympic 100-meter photo finish", "body": "Oblique Seville, of Jamaica, Akani Simbine, of South Africa, Kishane Thompson, of Jamaica, and Fred Kerley, of the United States, react as they cross the finish line in the men's 100 meters final at the 2024 Summer Olympics, Sunday, Aug. 4, 2024, in Saint-Denis, France. Noah Lyles, of the United States, won, Thompson was second and Kerley third.\n\nSAINT-DENIS, France (AP) -- Kishane Thompson let out a scream after crossing the finish line that was fitting of an Olympic 100-meter champion. Because, for a brief moment, he thought maybe he was.\n\nBy the slimmest of margins, Thompson was beaten out for gold on a perfectly timed lean from American Noah Lyles on Sunday night. Their times of 9.79 seconds needed to be calculated farther out to determine the winner -- with Lyles winning 9.784 to 9.789. {"uri": "8259396642", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "04:10:46", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T04:10:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T04:09:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "url": "https://www.thestandard.com.hk/breaking-news/section/6/219084/Noah-Lyles-wins-100m-gold-by-five-thousandths-of-a-second", "title": "Noah Lyles wins 100m gold by five thousandths of a second", "body": "After all the talk and all the hype, Noah Lyles duly delivered when it mattered most by winning the closest-ever Olympic 100 meters final by five thousandths of a second on Sunday to give the United States the title for the first time in 20 years.\n\nIn a blanket finish Lyles believed he had left it too late to catch the powerful Kishane Thompson, but the giant screen confirmed him as the winner in a personal best 9.79 seconds, the same time as the Jamaican, but ahead by the width of a vest.\n\nIf the race had been 99 meters, Thompson would have been celebrating a fourth Jamaican men's 100m win in five Olympics, but fast-finishing Lyles kept his form superbly and timed his dip expertly to add Olympic gold to his world title.\n\nHe ripped his name bib from his shirt and held it aloft with his red, white and blue varnished fingernails, announcing himself, as he had always promised he would be, as the fastest man in the world.\n\n\"It's the one I wanted, it's the hard battle, it's the amazing opponents,\" said Lyles, the first American male Olympic 100m champion since Justin Gatlin in 2004.\n\n\"I didn't do this against a slow field - I did this against the best of the best, on the biggest stage, with the biggest pressure.\"\n\nHe was right about that, as it was the first time eight men have broken 10 seconds in a wind-legal 100 meters race.\n\nAmerican Fred Kerley took bronze in 9.81 and Akani Simbini of South Africa was fourth, making it a remarkable six fourth or fifth-placed finishes in global championships, albeit with the consolation of a national record time of 9.83.\n\nDefending champion Lamont Marcell Jacobs of Italy, heavily strapped, finished fifth in 9.85 and Letsile Tebogo of Botswana also set a national record with 9.86 in sixth.\n\nSuch was the quality of the race, that eighth-placed Oblique Seville of Jamaica clocked 9.91 seconds.\n\n\"I did not think I won, I didn't think I dipped at the right time, too early,\" Lyles said. \"I even went up to Kishane while we were waiting and said 'I think you got that one.' But then my name popped up and I thought 'oh my gosh, I'm amazing'.\"\n\nThompson arrived in Paris as the fastest man in the world this year (9.77) and was the quickest of the semi-finalists on Sunday with 9.80.\n\n\"I am a bit disappointed, but I am happy at the same time,\" he said. \"I wasn't patient enough with myself to let my speed bring me at the line in the position that I know I could have gone to.\"\n\nFormer world champion Kerley also ran an excellent race to add bronze to his Tokyo silver.\n\n\"That was a great race and anyone could have won it,\" he said.\n\n\"I feel that I executed as best as I could. I came here for the gold and nothing else but, hey, everybody came here for the same thing and only one can win. Whoever came off the best, is the best.\"\n\nSeville had finished ahead of Lyles in the semi-final when the American looked to be at full stretch.\n\nHowever, the biggest showman in the sport and the star of the runaway success Netflix SPRINT series, has become a serious championship operator over the shorter distance, having won three 200m world titles and 200m bronze at the last Olympics.\n\n\"I think back to Tokyo when I messed up handling the rounds. From then on, I was like, 'I'm never going to do that again. I'm going to handle this correctly and practice over the years',\" he said, adding that he felt rattled after the semi and called one of his therapists for advice.\n\nLyles, 27, is targeting a possible four golds in Paris, in the 100m, his favorite 200m, the 4x100m relay and, possibly, the 4x400m relay.\n\nThat would emulate illustrious compatriots Jesse Owens and Carl Lewis, who achieved {"uri": "8259172486", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "23:02:01", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T23:02:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T22:53:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://www.news-gazette.com/kishane-thompson-relishes-silver-after-being-on-wrong-end-of-olympic-100-meter-photo-finish/article_a612ffce-2908-577c-81aa-bf97b36251df.html", "title": "Kishane Thompson relishes silver after being on wrong end of Olympic 100-meter photo finish", "body": "SAINT-DENIS, France (AP) -- Kishane Thompson let out a scream after crossing the finish line that was fitting of an Olympic 100-meter champion. Because, for a brief moment, he thought maybe he was.\n\nBy the slimmest of margins, Thompson was beaten out for gold on a perfectly timed lean from American Noah Lyles. Their times of 9.79 seconds needed to be calculated farther out to determine the winner -- with Lyles winning 9.784 to 9.789. Thompson was five-thousandths of a second away from joining the company of fellow Jamaican Usain Bolt as an Olympic champion.\n\n\"I'm a bit disappointed,\" Thompson said. \"But I am happy at the same time. I am going to take it as what it is and move forward from here.\"\n\nSomeone asked Thompson soon after if he thought the gold medal could be shared, since it was that close of race. It would be a nod to the high jumpers at the Tokyo Games in 2021, when Gianmarco Tamberi of Italy and Mutaz Barshim of Qatar agreed to split the gold medal.\n\nSomehow, Thompson didn't think Lyles would go for the idea.\n\n\"I think the sport is too competitive, no offense to any other sport,\" the 23-year-old Thompson said. \"It's too competitive for us to share a gold medal.\"\n\nThe race was barely over and Thompson was already replaying the little things that could've made a big difference. Maybe more of a lean. Maybe a bit more patience to let his speed propel him to the finish line.\n\n\"I know that Jamaica would have wanted me to get the gold,\" he said. \"Everybody loves winners.\"\n\nThompson was in Lane 4 in the final and Lyles in Lane 7. He couldn't see Lyles out that far so he wasn't sure precisely where he stood right after the finish. Thompson knew it was close and immediately glanced at the scoreboard for an answer.\n\nHe waited. They all waited.\n\nLyles gave him a glimmer of hope, though.\n\n\"I did think Thompson had it at the end,\" Lyles said. \"I even said, 'Bro, I think you got that one big dog. And then my name popped up, and I'm like, 'Oh my gosh, I'm amazing.'\"\n\nThompson became the first Jamaican to be on the podium in the men's Olympic 100 since Bolt's run of three straight titles in 2008, '12 and '16.\n\n\"My body language will not show it because I am not an expressive guy, but I am glad,\" Thompson said. \"I'm super grateful.\"\n\nThompson entered the race with the fastest time of the season and was viewed as the biggest threat to Lyles. It came down to the wire with all eight sprinters separated by a margin of .12 seconds -- and even closer for gold and silver.\n\n\"That close,\" Thompson said. \"It was that close.\"\n\nAP Summer Lyles also lost his opening-round heat -- to Britain's Louie Hinchliffe on Saturday. Hinchliffe finished third in the semifinal and did not advance.\n\nJoining Lyles in the eight-man final will be Jamaica's Kishane Thompson, who won his semifinal in 9.80 seconds, the fastest time in the three semifinal. Games.\n\nDefending champion Marcell Jacobs of Italy finished third in the second semifinal and advanced because his 9.92 was the best among sprinters who didn't automatically qualify by finishing in {"uri": "8259931115", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "10:52:36", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T10:52:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T10:51:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://www.lifestyleasia.com/hk/entertainment/noah-lyles-100m-gold-medal-dodges-nba-firestorm-paris-2024-olympics-news-info/", "title": "Noah Lyles wins 100m Gold by a hair, dodges NBA firestorm at Paris 2024 Olympics", "body": "In a spectacular display of speed and determination, Team USA's Noah Lyles captured the Gold medal in the men's 100m final at the Paris 2024 Olympics.\n\nWith a time of 9.79 seconds, Lyles narrowly edged out Jamaica's Kishane Thompson by just 0.005 seconds, marking the 100m event as one of the most thrilling finishes in Olympic history.\n\nThe 100m final at the 2024 Paris Olympics in Stade de France was an electrifying affair, enhanced by a pre-race light show and dramatic music. All eight competitors finished within 0.12 seconds of each other, making it the fastest race of all time with a legal wind. Michael Johnson, a four-time Olympic champion, called it \"absolutely\" the best 100m final he had ever seen.\n\nLyles' slow start saw him trailing in the early stages, but his incredible top-end speed propelled him from last place at 40 meters to a victorious finish. His top speed of 43.6 km/h at 60 meters was unmatched, allowing him to clinch the gold with his final stride.\n\nLyles' victory not only ended a 20-year drought for the United States in the blue riband event but also silenced critics following his controversial remarks about the NBA's use of the term \"world champions.\" The comments ignited backlash from NBA stars, including Kevin Durant and Devin Booker.\n\nDespite the uproar, Lyles remained focused and delivered a performance that justified his brash confidence. His success in Paris followed a dominant showing at the World Championships in Budapest, where he won gold in the 100m, 200m, and 4x100m relay.\n\nAt 27, Lyles is positioning himself as the heir to Usain Bolt's throne, not just with his performances on the track but also with his off-track charisma. His contract renewal with Adidas -- described as the biggest since Bolt's with Puma -- and his starring role in the Netflix docuseries Sprint underscore his growing influence in athletics.\n\nLyles has openly discussed his struggles with mental health, including depression and the pressures of fame. Yet, he thrives under scrutiny, often performing better with more eyes on him. His ability to handle pressure was evident as he navigated the longest preliminaries in Olympic history and emerged victorious in the final.\n\nWith one gold medal secured, Lyles is now aiming for more. After the 100m at the Olympics, he will compete in his signature 200m event on August 6, where he is a three-time defending world champion. He also plans to add the 4x100m and possibly the 4x400m relay to his medal tally.\n\nReflecting on his journey and aspirations, Lyles said, \"Usain Bolt has done it and him saying to me that he sees what I am doing and he respects it, it is amazing. I am the guy who wants to move past being track-famous. I want people to see me on the track, but in GQ and my docu-series, and realize I'm a cool guy too.\"\n\nAs the Olympic champion and the new \"World's Fastest Man,\" Noah Lyles continues to build his legacy, both on and off the track, aiming to elevate the sport of athletics to new heights.", "source": {"uri": "lifestyleasia.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Lifestyle Asia HK"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8260080363", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "12:26:34", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T12:26:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T12:24:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://www.latestly.com/agency-news/sports-news-after-winning-olympic-thriller-by-a-whisker-noah-lyles-looks-for-an-encore-in-his-favorite-event-6165626.html", "title": "Sports News | After Winning Olympic Thriller by a Whisker, Noah Lyles Looks for an Encore in His Favorite Event | LatestLY", "body": "Get latest articles and stories on Sports at LatestLY. Saint- All the overhead shots and race replays tell the same story. Noah Lyles only led one time during his Olympic 100-meter sprint for the ages: at the finish line.\n\nSaint-Denis (France(), Aug 5 (AP) All the overhead shots and race replays tell the same story. Noah Lyles only led one time during his Olympic 100-meter sprint for the ages: at the finish line.\n\nThere's a good argument that the rest of his stay at these Paris Games won't be anywhere near as nip-and-tuck.\n\nAlso Read | Washington Sundar, Gus Atkinson, Charlie Cassell Shortlisted for ICC Men's Player of the Month Award for July 2024.\n\nWith the Olympics still abuzz over his .005-second victory in the 100, Lyles didn't have much time to rest before moving to his next event. He is a heavy favorite in the 200 meters, his better race, and a race he has not lost since the Olympic final in Tokyo three years ago, where he finished third. Opening heats for the 200 were set for Monday night.\n\nLyles' willingness -- make that, desire -- to be the front man for a sport that yearns for new fans feels like a game-changer to Seb Coe, the World Athletics president who called Sunday's race \"if not perfect, about as close to perfect as you can get.\"\n\nAlso Read | Paris Olympics 2024: Kiran Pahal Finishes Seventh In Her 400 M Round 1 Qualification Heat, Will Run in Repechage for Spot in Semifinals.\n\n\"If I'm wearing a promoter's hat, then him winning last night was important, because he's now creating a narrative that's heading us back into Usain Bolt territory,\" Coe said. \"That's hugely important.\"\n\nLyles not shy about what he wants from all thisIn a typically candid and engaging post-race news conference, Lyles made no secret that he is in this to promote his sport, but also wants more.\n\nHe has been a front man for the popular Netflix documentary \"SPRINT,\" and has brought a sense of fashion back to the track, making \"walk-ins\" a thing and bedazzling his hair with white pearls on race day.\n\nNow, he's got a message for his shoe sponsor, Adidas.\n\n\"I want my own shoe,\" he said. \"I want my own trainer. I'm dead serious. I want a sneaker. There ain't no money in spikes, there's money in sneakers. I feel like for how many medals we bring back and the notoriety we get, the fact that hasn't happened, that's crazy for me. I feel like that needs to happen.\"\n\nWhat could slow down Lyles in his quest for Olympic sprint glory?The 100 was the biggest hurdle for Lyles to overcome. It is not his best race, and it's the one he took up shortly after Tokyo with the goal of becoming more than a mere sprinter, but a larger-than-life personality, both on and off the track.\n\nLyles also figures to feature prominently in the men's 4x100 relay but that's anything but a gimme.\n\nRiddled with poor work with the baton, a lack of consistent training habits, a doping positive and the constant spectre of trying to beat Bolt, the U.S. has not won, and kept, a single Olympic medal in this event since 2004. It hasn't captured gold since 2000.\n\nHe'll have challengers in the 200 meters, but he's hard to beatThe relay is a bigger threat to Lyles' quest to win three gold medals, the way Bolt did in all three of his appearances, than the 200 meters.\n\nLyles figures to get his biggest challenge in the 200 from Kenny Bednarek, who finished ahead of Lyles in Tokyo and, more recently, pushed him at a fast Olympic trails that Lyles won in 19.53.\n\nBotswana's Letsile Tobogo, American Erryion Knighton and defending champion Andre De Grasse are also in the mix. One interesting wager would be whether Lyles has more of a chance of losing the race or lowering his American record of 19.31. Bolt's world record is 19.19. {"uri": "8259194295", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "23:28:03", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T23:28:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T23:27:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://heavy.com/sports/olympics/nbc-announcer-botched-call-noah-lyles-100m/", "title": "NBC Announcer's Botched Call on Noah Lyles' 100m Victory Turns Heads", "body": "Noah Lyles won a thrilling 100m race at the Paris Olympics -- though fans watching on the NBC broadcast may have taken a few moments to realize it.\n\nAnnouncer Leigh Diffey and NBC analysts mistakenly declared Jamaica and sprinter Kishane Thompson the winner in what turned out to be a photo finish.\n\n\"Jamaica's gonna do it,\" Diffey shouted at the race's conclusion. \"Kishane Thompson is a gold medalist.\"\n\nThe camera then remained on Thompson as he and Lyles met on the track and strained to watch for the official results. Judges would declare Lyles the winner, leading to a belated correction from the broadcast crew and giving the mistaken call some viral attention.\n\nThe incorrect call from NBC drew some strong pushback from fans, including some who said the missed call marred what was otherwise a historically close race. Lyles earned the victory with a career-best time of 9.794 seconds, putting him just 0.005 seconds ahead of Thompson for the gold medal.\n\n\"What a race. And quite possibly the worst call in history by Leigh Diffey,\" one person shared on X. \"Declared the wrong winner on a photo finish, then extended silence while Lyles celebrated. Brutal\"\n\nOthers suggested Diffey should have shown more restraint on what was obvious to be an incredibly close finish, spoiling the way history will see the race.\n\n\"I like Leigh Diffey a lot, but he really blew this call, why didn't he wait, or say, photo finish? Declaring Thompson the winner immediately makes this footage unusable,\" another person posted on X.\n\nThe race was so close that Lyles admitted afterward even he thought Thompson had crossed the finish line first.\n\n\"We were waiting for the names to pop up, and I'm going to be honest, I came over [to Thompson] and I was like: 'I think you got that one, big dawg!'\" Lyles told reporters after the race, via ESPN. \"Something said I need to lean, and I was like, 'I'm going to lean,' because it's that type of race.\"\n\nBut Lyles added that he was prepared for a close race, having trained with the knowledge that he may need any edge he can find.\n\n\"What's crazy is my [biomechanist] Ralph Mann, before I left for Paris, he's like, 'This is how close first and second is going to be away from each other,'\" Lyles said as he held up a tiny bit of space between his thumb and forefinger. \"I can't believe how right he was.\"\n\nLyles was trailing Thompson for much of the race, making a move in the final 10 meters and leaning forward as the two reached the finish line together. Though Thompson's foot actually crossed the finish line first, races are determined when a sprinter's torso crosses the finish line, and Lyles' lean earned him the gold medal.\n\nAfter the race, Thompson said he was \"grateful\" for the experience but still felt disappointment.\n\n\"I'm going to be disappointed, but I'm super happy and grateful at the same time,\" Thompson said. \"I just got
