{"uri": "8259293231", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "02:01:21", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T02:01:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T01:59:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://www.channelnewsasia.com/sport/showman-noah-lyles-wins-100m-gold-five-thousandths-second-4526276", "title": "Showman Noah Lyles wins 100m gold by five thousandths of a second", "body": "PARIS: After all the talk and all the hype, Noah Lyles duly delivered when it mattered most by winning the closest-ever Olympic 100 metres final by five-thousandths of a second on Sunday (Aug 4) to give the United States the title for the first time in 20 years.\n\nIn a blanket finish Lyles believed he had left it too late to catch the powerful Kishane Thompson, but the giant screen confirmed him as the winner in a personal best 9.79s, the same time as the Jamaican, but ahead by the width of a vest.\n\nIf the race had been 99m, Thompson would have been celebrating a fourth Jamaican men's 100m win in five Olympics, but fast-finishing Lyles kept his form superbly and timed his dip expertly to add Olympic gold to his world title.\n\nHe ripped his name bib from his shirt and held it aloft with his red, white and blue varnished fingernails, announcing himself, as he had always promised he would be, as the fastest man in the world.\n\n\"It's the one I wanted, it's the hard battle, it's the amazing opponents,\" said Lyles, the first American male Olympic 100m champion since Justin Gatlin in 2004.\n\n\"I didn't do this against a slow field - I did this against the best of the best, on the biggest stage, with the biggest pressure.\"\n\nHe was right about that, as it was the first time eight men have broken 10 seconds in a wind-legal 100m race.\n\nAmerican Fred Kerley took bronze in 9.81 and Akani Simbini of South Africa was fourth, making it a remarkable six fourth or fifth-placed finishes in global championships, albeit with the consolation of a national record time of 9.83.\n\nDefending champion Lamont Marcell Jacobs of Italy, heavily strapped, finished fifth in 9.85 and Letsile Tebogo of Botswana also set a national record with 9.86 in sixth.\n\nSuch was the quality of the race, that eighth-placed Oblique Seville of Jamaica clocked 9.91 seconds.\n\n\"I did not think I won, I didn't think I dipped at the right time, too early,\" Lyles said. \"I even went up to Kishane while we were waiting and said 'I think you got that one.' But then my name popped up and I thought 'oh my gosh, I'm amazing'.\"\n\nThompson arrived in Paris as the fastest man in the world this year (9.77) and was the quickest of the semi-finalists on Sunday with 9.80.\n\n\"I am a bit disappointed, but I am happy at the same time,\" he said. \"I wasn't patient enough with myself to let my speed bring me at the line in the position that I know I could have gone to.\"\n\nFormer world champion Kerley also ran an excellent race to add bronze to his Tokyo silver.\n\n\"That was a great race and anyone could have won it,\" he said.\n\n\"I feel that I executed as best as I could. I came here for the gold and nothing else but, hey, everybody came here for the same thing and only one can win. Whoever came off the best, is the best.\"\n\nSeville had finished ahead of Lyles in the semi-final when the American looked to be at full stretch.\n\nHowever, the biggest showman in the sport and the star of the runaway success Netflix SPRINT series, has become a serious championship operator over the shorter distance, having won three 200m world titles and 200m bronze at the last Olympics.\n\n\"I think back to Tokyo when I messed up handling the rounds. From then on, I was like, 'I'm never going to do that again. I'm going to handle this correctly and practise over the years',\" he said, adding that he felt rattled after the semi and called one of his therapists for advice.\n\nLyles, 27, is targeting a possible four golds in Paris, in the 100m, his favourite 200m, the 4x100m relay and, possibly, the 4x400m relay.\n\nThat would emulate illustrious compatriots Jesse Owens and Carl Lewis, who achieved the feat at a single Games but with long jump instead of the longer relay.", "source": {"uri": "channelnewsasia.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "CNA"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8259435140", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "04:54:59", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T04:54:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T04:50:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://www.latestly.com/agency-news/sports-news-kishane-thompson-relishes-silver-after-being-on-wrong-end-of-olympic-100-meter-photo-finish-6164078.html", "title": "Sports News | Kishane Thompson Relishes Silver After Being on Wrong End of Olympic 100-meter Photo Finish | LatestLY", "body": "Get latest articles and stories on Sports at LatestLY. Saint- Kishane Thompson let out a scream after crossing the finish line that was fitting of an Olympic 100-meter champion. Because, for a brief moment, he thought maybe he was.\n\nSaint-Denis (France), Aug 5 (AP) Kishane Thompson let out a scream after crossing the finish line that was fitting of an Olympic 100-meter champion. Because, for a brief moment, he thought maybe he was.\n\nBy the slimmest of margins, Thompson was beaten out for gold on a perfectly timed lean from American Noah Lyles on Sunday night. Their times of 9.79 seconds needed to be calculated farther out to determine the winner -- with Lyles winning 9.784 to 9.789. Thompson was five-thousandths of a second away from joining the company of fellow Jamaican Usain Bolt as an Olympic champion.\n\nAlso Read | Paris Olympics 2024: Noah Lyles Takes Away Gold Medal by Whisker in Men's 100-Meter Final.\n\n\"I'm a bit disappointed,\" Thompson said. \"But I am happy at the same time. I am going to take it as what it is and move forward from here.\"\n\nSomeone asked Thompson soon after if he thought the gold medal could be shared, since it was that close of race. It would be a nod to the high jumpers at the Tokyo Games in 2021, when Gianmarco Tamberi of Italy and Mutaz Barshim of Qatar agreed to split the gold medal.\n\nAlso Read | Paris Olympics 2024: India To Take On Germany in Semifinals of Men's Hockey.\n\nSomehow, Thompson didn't think Lyles would go for the idea.\n\n\"I think the sport is too competitive, no offense to any other sport,\" the 23-year-old Thompson said. \"It's too competitive for us to share a gold medal.\"\n\nThe race was barely over and Thompson was already replaying the little things that could've made a big difference. Maybe more of a lean. Maybe a bit more patience to let his speed propel him to the finish line.\n\n\"I know that Jamaica would have wanted me to get the gold,\" he said. \"Everybody loves winners.\"\n\nThompson was in Lane 4 in the final and Lyles in Lane 7. He couldn't see Lyles out that far so he wasn't sure precisely where he stood right after the finish. Thompson knew it was close and immediately glanced at the scoreboard for an answer.\n\n\"I did think Thompson had it at the end,\" Lyles said. \"I even said, 'Bro, I think you got that one big dog. And then my name popped up, and I'm like, 'Oh my gosh, I'm amazing.'\"\n\nThompson became the first Jamaican to be on the podium in the men's Olympic 100 since Bolt's run of three straight titles in 2008, '12 and '16.\n\n\"My body language will not show it because I am not an expressive guy, but I am glad,\" Thompson said. \"I'm super grateful.\"\n\nThompson entered the race with the fastest time of the season and was viewed as the biggest threat to Lyles. It came down to the wire with all eight sprinters separated by a margin of .12 seconds -- and even closer for gold and silver.\n\n\"That close,\" Thompson said. \"It was that close.\" (AP)", "source": {"uri": "8259070698", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "20:30:50", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T20:30:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T20:29:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://dnyuz.com/2024/08/04/usa-sprinter-noah-lyles-wins-first-olympic-gold-in-epic-mens-100m-final/", "title": "USA sprinter Noah Lyles wins first Olympic gold in epic men's 100M final", "body": "After dominating the world championships last year, Noah Lyles finally has his Olympic gold medal.\n\nAfter talking the talk for quite some time, the Gainesville, Fla., native is now walking the walk, as he won the men's 100-meter final on Sunday in Paris.\n\nLyles crossed the finish line in 9.79784 seconds, a personal best, and winning by five-thousandths of a second.\n\nA long photo finish review was necessary to officially crown Lyles champion, as he looked on intently alongside Jamaican Kishane Thompson.\n\nLyles is the first American to win the event at the Olympics since Justin Gatlin did so in 2004. It's the fifth gold medal won by Americans on Sunday (golfer Scottie Scheffler, cyclist Kristen Faulkner, swimmer Bobby Finke, and the women's 4\u00d7100 medley relay team).\n\nThe 27-year-old ran a 9.83 in the semifinal, automatically qualifying by finishing second in that race. He caught some flack on Saturday for finishing in second place in a heat, saying that his \"plan\" was to finish in first from there on out. That didn't happen - but it'll all be forgotten about now, as he finished first when it mattered most.\n\nOf course, some will argue he brought the hate upon himself when he quipped that NBA champions do not have the right to call themselves world champions. That comment alone has caused him to be hated by American sports fans just as much, maybe more, than he is loved by them. But, perhaps this victory can change the tide.\n\nLyles will now turn his focus on the 200m (he's said his \"dream goal\" is to break Usain Bolt's world record of 19.19) and the 4x100m relay. It remains up in the air about whether he will be part of the 4x400m relay, but he was a part of the silver-medal winning team at this year's world indoor championships.\n\nIn an interview with Fox News Digital back in March, Lyles said a friend told him, \"'Forget three, you need to go after four. Do something no one's ever done.'\"\n\n\"When you want to talk about being the greatest, that's what you have to achieve. So, I announced that that is a goal of mine to complete; why not do it on the biggest stage, the Olympics?\" Lyles said of a potential fourth Olympic event.\n\n\"I think track does better when we do have a superstar. That's why I think if Noah were to win, he would elevate the sport as well. As opposed to saying 'I wonder who's going to win,' people want to say 'I want him' or 'I don't want him.' They want to root for someone, or root against someone. I think it creates more intensity when you have someone that dominates, and that's been throughout history. . . . {"uri": "8259146387", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "22:14:42", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T22:14:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T22:13:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://www.nbcnewyork.com/paris-2024-summer-olympics/when-to-watch-noah-lyles-compete-mens-200m-final-paris-olympics/5669355/", "title": "Here's when to watch Noah Lyles compete next in the men's 200m race", "body": "Lyles is looking to become the first man to win both the 100m and 200m events in the same Olympics since Carl Lewis in 1984\n\nTeam USA's Noah Lyles, the new official \"World's Fastest Man\" after winning gold in the men's 100m race is seeking another win in the 200m, which would make him the first American man to win both those events in the same Olympics since Carl Lewis.\n\nLyles just beat out Jamaica's Kishane Thompson in the men's 100m final on Sunday to win the gold.\n\nNext up is the 200m men's race starting Monday, Aug. 5. Lyles is racing in the sixth heat in the first round, which starts at 1:55 p.m. ET. Assuming Lyles moves on, he'll race in the semifinals on Wednesday, Aug. 7 at 2:02 p.m. ET.\n\nThe men's 200m final is scheduled for Thursday, Aug. 8 at 2:30 p.m. ET.\n\nLyles personal-best time in the men's 200m is 19.31 and his best this season is 19.53. He won the bronze medal in the men's 200m in Tokyo in 2020. He's a favorite to win the gold but will have tough competition. Lyles is the three-time reigning world-champion in the 200m.\n\nThe last American man to win the men's 200m was Shawn Crawford in 2004. Lyles would be in good company to win both the 100m and 200m at the same Olympics. The last man to do it was Usain Bolt in 2016 in Rio.\n\nUsain Bolt holds the world record in the men's 200m with a time of 19.19 set in 2009. Bolt also hold the Olympic record in the men's 200m with a time of 19.30 set in 2008.\n\nThe men's 200m final is scheduled for Thursday, Aug. 8 at 2:30 p.m. ET from the Stade de France in Paris.\n\nRound one of the men's 200m features six heats. The top three in each heat will move onto the semifinals.\n\nAthletes who didn't qualify from round 1 will have a chance to qualify in the repechage round the next day. The repechage round will feature four heats. The top athlete in each heat will move onto the semifinals along with the athletes with the fastest two times who have not qualified yet.\n\nThere are three semifinal heats for the men's 200m with eight athletes in each. 100m gold drought in historic final", "body": "Noah Lyles delivered when it mattered most on Sunday night when he won a sensational Paris 2024 Olympics men's 100 metres final by five thousandths of a second to give the United States of America the title for the first time in 20 years.\n\nThe last time USA won men's 100m gold was at Athens 2004 through Justin Gatlin, and the hyperactive Lyles got them back the title in one of the greatest sprint races of all time in Paris.\n\nIn the most competitive final ever, there was a blanket finish, with the stadium scoreboard initially flashing a photo to separate the first seven athletes and Lyles believing he had lost.\n\nHe was then confirmed as the winner in a personal best 9.79 seconds, the same time as Jamaica's Kishane Thompson, but ahead by the width of a vest.\n\nThe fast-finishing Lyles trailed for most of the race but kept his form superbly and timed his dip expertly to add Olympic gold to his world title.\n\nHe ripped his bib name from his shirt and held it aloft with his red, white and blue varnished fingernails, announcing himself, as he had always promised he would be, as the fastest man in the world.\n\n\"It's the one I wanted, it's the hard battle, it's the amazing opponents,\" said Lyles.\n\n\"Everybody came prepared for the fight and I wanted to prove that I'm the man among all of them, I'm the wolf among wolves.\"\n\nIt was the first time eight men have broken 10 seconds in a wind-legal 100 metres race.\n\n\"I am a bit disappointed, but I am happy at the same time,\" said Thompson, the fastest man in the world this year. \"I wasn't patient enough with myself to let my speed bring me at the line, in the position that I know I could have gone to, but I have learnt from it.\"\n\nAnother United States of America athlete, Fred Kerley, clinched bronze in 9.81s, while South Africa's Akani Simbine just missed out on a medal, finishing fourth in a new national record of 9.82s.\n\nThe final was the {"uri": "8259729849", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "08:44:41", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T08:44:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T08:43:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://talksport.com/olympics/1818451/noah-lyles-usain-bolt-united-states-nba-gold-paris/", "title": "New 100m king Lyles represents USA with a 'heavy heart' and annoyed NBA stars", "body": "After winning eight Olympic golds from 2008 to 2016, Usain Bolt's retirement in 2017 left a noticeable vacuum in men's sprinting.\n\nNo one has yet come close to matching his achievements, but it looks like there is finally an heir apparent -- Noah Lyles.\n\nThe sprinting sensation has already won 100m gold at the Paris 2024 Olympic Games and hopes to win the trio alongside the 200m and 4x100m.\n\nThe last time a male athlete won all three of these events at the Olympics was Bolt in 2016, making clear just why there is so much excitement surrounding 27-year-old Lyles.\n\nBorn in Florida in 1997, Lyles switched from gymnastics to track and field when he was 12 years old. Despite his young age, it quickly became clear he had immense sprinting talent, and the teenager went on to win a 200m gold medal at the 2014 Youth Olympic Games in Nanjing.\n\nIn 2016, Lyles and his younger brother Josephus decided to forgo college to become professional athletes. He just missed out on selection for the US team heading to the Olympic Games in Rio, but now, 10 years on from winning a gold medal at the Youth Olympic Games, Lyles is aiming to imitate Bolt in Paris.\n\nIt won't be the first time Lyles competes at the Olympic Games. He raced at Tokyo 2020, and after earning 200m and 4x100m world titles for the first time in 2019, was considered a favourite for gold in the Japanese capital. But he was unable to make his mark, settling for a bronze medal in the 200m.\n\nLyles has raised his game since then. He clinched another 200m world title in 2022, before sweeping the 100m, 200m and 4x100m at the 2023 World Athletics Championships to rightly earn the title of the fastest man in the world right now.\n\nHis best time across 200m is 19.31 seconds, surpassing the previous American record of 19.32 -- set by Michael Johnson since 1996. The time makes Lyles the fastest 200m runner in history, behind only Bolt and Yohan Blake.\n\nLyles then went on to win the 100m final in Paris by 0.0005 of a second in a time of 9.79 seconds.\n\nLyles often appears to wear the red, white and blue of the Star-Spangled Banner with pride, but he revealed to Fox News that he often has mixed feelings about representing his home.\n\n\"It's a bittersweet moment,\" he explained. \"I'm American, and I truly believe that we are the best in the world, especially when it comes to sports. We have definitely been proving that dominance. And it feels good to add on to that collection that the US is the best.\n\n\"But at the same time, it's with a heavy heart, because being black in America, there's a lot to deal with. I'm not going to go into everything, but it's not easy. It's hard to love the country that sometimes doesn't love you back.\n\n\"At the same time, you always want to put your best foot forward. So, it's a little contradicting, it's with a heavy heart, but it still makes you feel extremely proud because you are an American.\"\n\nLyles also annoyed a number of his country's basketball stars last year after hitting out at the tendency to describe the winners of the NBA Finals as world champions.\n\nHe made the comments during a press conference after his third gold medal at the 2023 World Athletics Championships, having been asked about the state of track and field as a sport.\n\n\"You know what hurts me the most is that I have to watch the NBA Finals and they have 'world champion' on their head,\" Lyles said.\n\n\"World champion of what? The United States? Don't get me wrong. I love the US -- at times -- but that ain't the world. That is not the world. We are the world.\n\n\"We have almost every country out here fighting, thriving, putting on their flag to show that they are represented. There ain't no flags in the NBA. We gotta do more. We gotta be presented to the world.\"\n\nPhoenix Suns star Kevin Durant, who earned an Olympic gold medal in the men's basketball tournament at Tokyo 2020, was among the NBA players to respond, posting on social media: \"Somebody help this brother.\"\n\nWhile he may have riled up some of his compatriots, they certainly won't mind if he returns to the US this summer with three Olympic gold medals around his neck.\n\nBut Lyles is not just aiming to make a mark on the track. Self-described as an artist and rapper, he is also passionate about music, fashion and video games. Lyles has previously spoken about his desire to revolutionise athletics through his other interests.\n\n\"I want to show people how far they can really go,\" he told Olympics.com. \"I don't want them to stop at medals. Yes, medals are nice, they get your attention. That should be the first stopping point, that should be the first check off the box.\n\n\"After you go to medals, now you go to moving outside of the sport. After you're outside of the sport, we go and reinvent ourselves.\"\n\nBolt was often rightly credited with transforming athletics into an exciting and engaging sport -- Lyles now has the chance to follow in his footsteps and continue the evolution at the Paris 2024 Olympic Games.", "source": {"uri": "talksport.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "talkSPORT"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8259859032", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "10:07:55", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T10:07:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T10:07:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://talksport.com/olympics/1946319/noah-lyles-paris-2024-olympics-usain-bolt-100m-200m-gold/", "title": "Noah Lyles stops 20-year USA Olympics rot and on course to become new Usain Bolt", "body": "Forget Joe Biden and Donald Trump - is Noah Lyles the man who can make America great again?\n\nDespite being viewed as a powerhouse in men's sprinting, it's actually been two decades since the United States earned a men's sprinting gold medal at the Olympic Games.\n\nJustin Gatlin and Fred Kerley have come close in the 100m, while Shawn Crawford and Kenneth Bednarek have taken silver medals from the 200m, but a place at the top of the podium has eluded all of them.\n\nThat wait ended on Sunday night as Lyles took home 100m gold, a sprinter whose talent, charisma, and determination have drawn comparisons to the legendary Usain Bolt.\n\nThe United States has a storied history in track and field, particularly in sprinting.\n\nNames like Jesse Owens, Carl Lewis and Michael Johnson are etched into the annals of Olympic history, each from a period when American sprinters were nearly unbeatable.\n\nBut the last time an American man stood atop the podium after an Olympic 100m or 200m final was at Athens 2004. Gatlin claimed gold in the 100m, while Crawford triumphed over the longer distance.\n\nAfter that, Bolt completely dominated men's sprinting, winning both the 100m and 200m at three successive Olympic Games.\n\nThe Jamaicans record-shattering performances and irrepressible personality transformed him into a global icon, leaving little room for American sprinters to shine.\n\nLyles has proved to be the solution to this problem, already winning one gold medal with the 200m and 4x100m to come.\n\nThe 27-year-old, who is the reigning world champion across both distances, became a professional athlete in 2016.\n\nAfter earning 200m and 4x100m world titles for the first time in 2019, Lyles finished with a bronze medal in the 200m at the Tokyo 2020 Olympics.\n\nHe was disappointed with missing out on the gold medal in the Japanese capital, but he bounced back almost immediately. Another 200m world title came in 2022, before Lyles swept the 100m, 200m and 4x100m at the 2023 World Athletics Championships.\n\nThe track and field star has stepped up another level this year, setting a 9.83 seconds to win the 100m at the US Olympic trials and qualify for Paris 2024.\n\nLyles has looked equally dominant in the 200m. He ran an event record of 19.53 seconds at the US Olympic trials, consigning Bednarek to second place.\n\nHe then ran an even faster time in the 100m final, winning the race in 9.79 seconds.\n\nBolt's dominance in the 100m and 200m, combined with his charismatic showmanship, set a benchmark that is extraordinarily high.\n\nBut Lyles has shown that he possesses similar qualities. He has a vibrant personality and a genuine love for entertaining the crowd, for example.\n\n\"Being able to run with passion, and a smile on your face, and turning a race into something for everybody to enjoy, that's what I consider running with soul,\" Lyles said in a recent interview with Time Magazine.\n\n\"It just means that I'm happy. I love to do what I do. And that's a dangerous guy.\"\n\nLyles has been showing off his personality during the US Olympic trials, bringing out a Yu-Gi-Oh card and showing it to the camera before every race. He has previously spoken of his love of anime, as well as music, fashion and video games.\n\nBut it is on the track where Lyles truly shines. His blend of explosive speed and technical proficiency makes him a formidable competitor.\n\nThe Olympics in Paris is a crucial juncture in Lyles' career. With Bolt retired, men's sprinting is now wide open, and Lyles has grabbed his chance to become his heir.\n\nThe pressure is immense. Not only is Lyles vying for personal glory, but he also carried the hopes of a nation starved of sprinting success. A gold medal in the French capital could also symbolise the resurgence of American sprinting.\n\nLyles has the opportunity to follow in Bolt's footsteps and be a transformative figure in athletics. While this is an enormous task, Lyles believes he could be even more influential than Bolt, particularly in the US.\n\n\"That's my plan,\" he told Time Magazine. \"I have the personality, I have the speed, I have the showmanship. I have the marketing mindset. I'm willing to be uncomfortable.\"", "source": {"uri": "talksport.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "talkSPORT"}, "authors": [{"uri": "nancy_gillen@talksport.com", "name": "Nancy Gillen", "type": {"uri": "8259179964", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "23:08:27", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T23:08:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T23:06:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "url": "https://apnews.com/article/2024-olympics-100-meter-d0cb0022258aeb502be102003b94818b", "title": "Kishane Thompson relishes silver after being on wrong end of Olympic 100-meter photo finish", "body": "SAINT-DENIS, France (AP) -- Kishane Thompson let out a scream after crossing the finish line that was fitting of an Olympic 100-meter champion. Because, for a brief moment, he thought maybe he was.\n\nBy the slimmest of margins, Thompson was beaten out for gold on a perfectly timed lean from American Noah Lyles on Sunday night. Their times of 9.79 seconds needed to be calculated farther out to determine the winner -- with Lyles winning 9.784 to 9.789. Thompson was five-thousandths of a second away from joining the company of fellow Jamaican Usain Bolt as an Olympic champion.\n\n\"I'm a bit disappointed,\" Thompson said. \"But I am happy at the same time. I am going to take it as what it is and move forward from here.\"\n\nSomeone asked Thompson soon after if he thought the gold medal could be shared, since it was that close of race. It would be a nod to the high jumpers at the Tokyo Games in 2021, when Gianmarco Tamberi of Italy and Mutaz Barshim of Qatar agreed to split the gold medal.\n\nSomehow, Thompson didn't think Lyles would go for the idea.\n\n\"I think the sport is too competitive, no offense to any other sport,\" the 23-year-old Thompson said. \"It's too competitive for us to share a gold medal.\"\n\nThe race was barely over and Thompson was already replaying the little things that could've made a big difference. Maybe more of a lean. Maybe a bit more patience to let his speed propel him to the finish line.\n\n\"I know that Jamaica would have wanted me to get the gold,\" he said. \"Everybody loves winners.\"\n\nThompson was in Lane 4 in the final and Lyles in Lane 7. He couldn't see Lyles out that far so he wasn't sure precisely where he stood right after the finish. Thompson knew it was close and immediately glanced at the scoreboard for an answer.\n\n\"I did think Thompson had it at the end,\" Lyles said. \"I even said, 'Bro, I think you got that one big dog. And then my name popped up, and I'm like, 'Oh my gosh, I'm amazing.'\"\n\nThompson became the first Jamaican to be on the podium in the men's Olympic 100 since Bolt's run of three straight titles in 2008, '12 and '16.\n\n\"My body language will not show it because I am not an expressive guy, but I am glad,\" Thompson said. \"I'm super grateful.\"\n\nThompson entered the race with the fastest time of the season and was viewed as the biggest threat to Lyles. It came down to the wire with all eight sprinters separated by a margin of .12 seconds -- and even closer for gold and silver.", "source": {"uri": "apnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "AP {"uri": "8259286088", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "01:50:38", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T01:50:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T01:49:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "url": "https://www.bangkokpost.com/sports/2841677/showman-lyles-wins-100m-gold-by-five-thousandths-of-a-second", "title": "Showman Lyles wins 100m gold by five thousandths of a second", "body": "PARIS: After all the talk and all the hype, Noah Lyles duly delivered when it mattered most by winning the closest-ever Olympic 100 metres final by five thousandths of a second on Sunday to give the United States the title for the first time in 20 years.\n\nIn a blanket finish Lyles believed he had left it too late to catch the powerful Kishane Thompson, but the giant screen confirmed him as the winner in a personal best 9.79 seconds, the same time as the Jamaican, but ahead by the width of a vest.\n\nIf the race had been 99 metres, Thompson would have been celebrating a fourth Jamaican men's 100m win in five Olympics, but fast-finishing Lyles kept his form superbly and timed his dip expertly to add Olympic gold to his world title.\n\nHe ripped his name bib from his shirt and held it aloft with his red, white and blue varnished fingernails, announcing himself, as he had always promised he would be, as the fastest man in the world.\n\n\"It's the one I wanted, it's the hard battle, it's the amazing opponents,\" said Lyles, the first American male Olympic 100m champion since Justin Gatlin in 2004.\n\n\"I didn't do this against a slow field - I did this against the best of the best, on the biggest stage, with the biggest pressure.\"\n\nHe was right about that, as it was the first time eight men have broken 10 seconds in a wind-legal 100 metres race.\n\nAmerican Fred Kerley took bronze in 9.81 and Akani Simbini of South Africa was fourth, making it a remarkable six fourth or fifth-placed finishes in global championships, albeit with the consolation of a national record time of 9.83.\n\nDefending champion Lamont Marcell Jacobs of Italy, heavily strapped, finished fifth in 9.85 and Letsile Tebogo of Botswana also set a national record with 9.86 in sixth.\n\nSuch was the quality of the race, that eighth-placed Oblique Seville of Jamaica clocked 9.91 seconds.\n\n\"I did not think I won, I didn't think I dipped at the right time, too early,\" Lyles said. \"I even went up to Kishane while we were waiting and said 'I think you got that one.' But then my name popped up and I thought 'oh my gosh, I'm amazing'.\"\n\nTHOMPSON DISAPPOINTED\n\nThompson arrived in Paris as the fastest man in the world this year (9.77) and was the quickest of the semi-finalists on Sunday with 9.80.\n\n\"I am a bit disappointed, but I am happy at the same time,\" he said. \"I wasn't patient enough with myself to let my speed bring me at the line in the position that I know I could have gone to.\"\n\nFormer world champion Kerley also ran an excellent race to add bronze to his Tokyo silver.\n\n\"That was a great race and anyone could have won it,\" he said.\n\n\"I feel that I executed as best as I could. I came here for the gold and nothing else but, hey, everybody came here for the same thing and only one can win. Whoever came off the best, is the best.\"\n\nSeville had finished ahead of Lyles in the semi-final when the American looked to be at full stretch.\n\nHowever, the biggest showman in the sport and the star of the runaway success Netflix SPRINT series, has become a serious championship operator over the shorter distance, having won three 200m world titles and 200m bronze at the last Olympics.\n\n\"I think back to Tokyo when I messed up handling the rounds. From then on, I was like, 'I'm never going to do that again. I'm going to handle this correctly and practise over the years',\" he said, adding that he felt rattled after the semi and called one of his therapists for advice.\n\nLyles, 27, is targeting a possible four golds in Paris, in the 100m, his favourite 200m, the 4x100m relay and, possibly, the 4x400m relay.\n\nThat would emulate illustrious compatriots Jesse Owens and Carl Lewis, who achieved the feat at a single Games but with long jump instead of the longer relay.", "source": {"uri": "bangkokpost.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Bangkok Post"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-08-443881030", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "21:14:24", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T21:14:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T17:40:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "url": "https://wcfcourier.com/photo-finish/article_3c85059f-fe1a-5598-925c-a8c401b211a1.html", "title": "PHOTO FINISH", "body": "Noah Lyles, of the United States, celebrates after winning the men's 100-meter final.\n\nEDDIE PELLS Associated Press\n\nSAINT-DENIS, France -- Noah Lyles won the Olympic 100 meters by .005 seconds Sunday, waiting some 30 seconds after the finish of one of the closest sprints in history to find out he'd beaten Kishane Thompson of Jamaica.\n\nThe word \"Photo\" popped up on the scoreboard next to the names of Lyles, Thompson and five others after they crossed the line. Lyles paced the track with his hands draped over his head. Finally, the numbers came up. Lyles won in 9.784 seconds to edge out the Jamaican by five-thousandths of a tick of the clock.\n\nAmerica's Fred Kerley came in third at 9.81. The top seven all finished within .09 of each other.\n\nThis was the closest 1-2 finish in the 100 since at least Moscow in 1980 -- or maybe even ever. Back then, Britain's Allan Wells narrowly beat Silvio Leonard in an era when the electronic timers didn't go down into the thousandths of a second.\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nTimeline: Deere has cut 2,700 jobs in 10 months in Iowa and Illinois West Lake Okoboji home sells for state record $9.5M Bremer Avenue bridge in Waverly to be demolished, closed for a year starting Thursday Helicopter crashed near Nashua after striking powerlines, killing pilot UPDATE: Man charged with TC damage said he was 'blackout drunk' Waterloo man arrested following short chase Waterloo residents have more than 1,000 signatures on petition to put high school plan on the ballot Autistic man accused of breaking into co-worker's home to plant letter, smear boyfriend Man charged with breaking into home to steal wiring for scrap UAW releases statement on John Deere layoffs, says cuts 'kill good American jobs' Pablo's Mexican Grill marking 20 years on Main Street in downtown Cedar Falls Waterloo school board approves $165 million plan to to merge high schools by 2028-29 Oelwein man arrested for gun after found passed out in garage John Deere idled more than 300 workers in Quad Cities on Wednesday, bringing last week's total to 489 Allen Hospital among nation's top performing hospitals for treatment of heart attack\n\nThank goodness they do now.\n\n\"I thought I had (him) cleared,\" Thompson said. \"But I wasn't sure. It was so close.\"\n\nLyles became the first American to win the marquee event in Olympic track since Justin Gatlin in 2004.\n\nThe 9.784 also marks a personal best for Lyles, who has been promising to add his own brand of excitement to track and certainly delivered this time.\n\nHe will be a favorite later this week in the 200 meters -- his better race -- and will try to join Usain Bolt as the latest runner to win both Olympic sprints.\n\nFor perspective, the blink of an eye takes, on average, .1 second, which was 20 times longer than the gap between first and second in this one.\n\nWhat was the difference? Maybe Lyles' closing speed and his lean into the line.\n\nHe and Thompson had two of the three slowest bursts from the blocks, and Thompson had what sufficed for a \"lead\" at the halfway point. The photo finish actually shows Kerley's orange shoe well in front of the line. But it's the chest breaking the barrier that counts, and Lyles beat everyone by a sliver.\n\nIt would take more than a mere 9.7(84) seconds to decide who would supplant Marcell Jacobs as the next Olympic champion.\n\nLyles patted Thompson on the shoulder while the wait grew -- from 10, to 20, then nearly 30 seconds. When the American learned he'd added this to the 100 meters he won at world championships last year, he pulled off his name tag and raised it to the sky, then brought his hands to his side and pointed at the camera.\n\n\"America, I told you I got this!\" he yelled into the camera.\n\nYes, he's the World's Fastest Man. Just not by a lot.\n\nGold (and bronze) for Ukrainian high jumpers\n\nYaroslava Mahuchikh won Olympic gold in the high jump for her war-torn country of Ukraine and, as a bonus, had company. Her teammate Iryna Gerashchenko won the bronze and the teammates hopped, skipped and jumped around the track parading their blue-and-yellow flags in a heartfelt celebration.\n\nMahuchikh needed fewer tries to clear the winning height of 2 meters than Australia's Nicola Olyslagers, and so, added the sport's biggest prize of all -- Olympic gold -- to her world championship and world record.\n\nKerr vs Ingebrigtsen is a go for heated men's 1,500\n\nThe best rivalry in track will culminate Tuesday when reigning world champion Josh Kerr of Britain takes on defending Olympic champion Jakob Ingebrigtsen of Norway.\n\nThey squared off in Sunday's semifinal, too, and Ingebrigtsen edged out the Brit, looking over to him twice as they surged down the homestretch, to win a race that felt like it meant more than it should have in 3:32.38.\n\n\"They should be expecting one of the most vicious and hardest 1,500s the sport's seen in a very long time,\" Kerr said.\n\nDid Ingebrigtsen agree?\n\n\"Depends who you ask, maybe,\" he said. \"I mean, racing is what you want it to be.\"\n\nLove\n\n0\n\nFunny\n\n0\n\nWow\n\n0\n\nSad\n\n0\n\nAngry\n\n0\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local {"uri": "8260079488", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "12:25:32", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T12:25:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T12:24:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "url": "https://www.the-star.co.ke/sports/athletics/2024-08-05-how-lyles-torso-decided-greatest-olympics-100m-final/", "title": "How Lyles' torso decided greatest Olympics 100m final", "body": "Thompson, the fastest man in the world this year with a best time of 9.77, maintained a lead from 30 metres into the race, to 10 metres from the finish line.\n\nIt was the finest margins which determined the outcome, as Lyles covered the distance between 80-90 metres in 0.84 and the final 10 metres in 0.86 - compared to 0.85 and 0.87 for Thompson.\n\n\"I did think [Thompson] had it at the end. I went up to him while we were waiting, and said 'I think you've got that, good going', and then my name popped up and I'm like 'oh my gosh, I'm amazing',\" Lyles said.\n\n\"I'm going to be honest, I wasn't ready to see it and that's the first time I've ever said that. I wasn't ready to see it.\"\n\nReflecting on narrowly missing out on gold, 23-year-old Thompson said: \"I wasn't patient enough with myself to let my speed bring me at the line, in the position that I know I could have gone to, but I have learned from it.\"\n\nThe drama at the head of the race inspired world records behind it.\n\nThe finishing times for Akani Simbine, Lamont Marcell Jacobs, Tebogo, Kenny Bednarek and Seville were all records for fourth to eighth place finishers in a 100m race.\n\nSouth Africa's Simbine ran a personal best for fourth and said: \"Missing the medal by 0.01, it's actually really crazy, but yeah, I'm pretty happy.\"\n\nLyles building legacy with each global gold\n\nLyles has long positioned himself as the heir to Usain Bolt's throne, combining on-track performances with off-track flair in his bid to establish himself as the new superstar of men's athletics.\n\nNot afraid to raise expectations through his own comments, Lyles has spoken about his desire to break the long-standing 100m and 200m records set by Jamaica's eight-time Olympic champion Bolt, who retired in 2017.\n\nThe American also claimed he will target four golds in Paris by adding the men's 4x400m relay to his schedule after winning the world 100m, 200m and 4x100m title in Budapest 12 months ago.\n\nLyles will next pursue the Olympic 200m title as a three-time defending world champion in the event, although he had to settle for bronze on his Games debut in Tokyo three years ago.\n\n\"Lyles had a bad Tokyo and since then he's really been looking for big moments,\" said Johnson.\n\n\"He wants to be a global superstar. He talks about Usain Bolt and the type of person he was. He's talked about his sport and voiced his frustration about how it doesn't give you that platform.\"\n\nIt is 16 years since Bolt strolled to the first of his three Olympic 100m golds in Beijing, showboating as he crossed the line but still clocking a world record 9.69 - which he improved to the still-standing mark of 9.58 in 2009.\n\nLyles is yet to get close to that time, running under 9.80 for the first time to win on Sunday night, while his 200m best of 19.31 also trails Bolt's best (19.19).\n\nBut, like Bolt, Lyles stars on the sport's grandest stages and he continues to amass global golds at a considerable rate.\n\n\"Noah Lyles is able to back it up,\" Olympic heptathlon champion Denise Lewis said on BBC TV.\n\n\"He has been amplifying the need for people to take this sport more seriously, deliver and respect the athletes for what they deliver, which is sensational entertainment every single time.\n\n\"To do this here, with the amphitheatre of the lights, the drama, everything, is just brilliant.\"\n\nJohnson added: \"He is here to create a legacy and he has put the first stamp down on that legacy by taking this title in such imperious fashion.\"", "source": {"uri": "2024-08-443908428", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "22:23:18", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T22:23:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T22:05:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "url": "https://theeagle.com/sports/college/aggiesports/track_and_field/photo-finish-in-paris-olympics/article_e6f85fa2-52a8-11ef-b0e2-5ff774c40768.html", "title": "Aggie Kerley settles for bronze in a 100-meter dash for the ages", "body": "STAFF & WIRE REPORT\n\nSAINT-DENIS, France -- Former Texas A&M All-American Fred Kerley settled for third place in in the 100-meter dash one of the closest sprints in Olympic history Sunday the State de France.\n\nTeam USA's Noah Lyles won Olympic gold by .005 seconds Sunday. He had to wait some 30 seconds after the finish of one to find out he'd beaten Kishane Thompson of Jamaica. Lyles won in 9.784 seconds to edge out the Jamaican by five-thousandths of a tick of the clock. Team USA's Kerley claimed bronze in 9.81. It was his second Olympic medal. He grabbed silver at the 2020 Tokyo Olympics.\n\nThe word \"Photo\" popped up on the scoreboard next to the names of Lyles, Thompson and five others after they crossed the line. Lyles paced the track with his hands draped over his head. Finally, the numbers came up.\n\nLyles said he thought he had given the win away by dipping at the line too soon, so he went up to Thompson and told him, \"Bro, I think you got that one.\"\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nCorps of Cadets announces march-in schedule for Texas A&M football season Texas A&M student claims dorm mold caused adverse health effects Texas A&M announces 2024 class of distinguished alumni Krispy Kreme owner arrested for arson Teen victim identified in College Station homicide KBTX anchor Heather Kovar arrested for assault Activist protests against CPS system at Brazos County Courthouse Stephen F. That's probably one of the most beautiful races I've been in.\"\n\nThe top seven all finished within .09 of each other.\n\nThis was the closest 1-2 finish in the 100 since at least Moscow in 1980 -- or maybe even ever. Back then, Britain's Allan Wells narrowly beat Silvio Leonard in an era when the electronic timers didn't go down into the thousandths of a second. The same was true in 1932, when Eddie Tolan won the Olympics' first ever photo finish.\n\nThank goodness they do now.\n\n\"I thought I had [him] cleared,\" Thompson said. \"But I wasn't sure. It was so close.\"\n\nLyles became the first American to win the marquee event in Olympic track since Justin Gatlin in 2004.\n\nThe 9.784 also marks a personal best for Lyles, who has been promising to add his own brand of excitement to track and certainly delivered this time.\n\nHe will be a favorite later this week in the 200 meters -- his better race -- and will try to join Usain Bolt as the latest runner to win both Olympic sprints.\n\nFor perspective, the blink of an eye takes on average, .1 second, which was 20 times longer than the gap between first and second in this one.\n\nWhat was the difference? Maybe Lyles' closing speed and that lean into the line that he thought was mistimed.\n\nHe and Thompson had two of the three slowest bursts from the blocks, and Thompson had what sufficed for a \"lead\" at the halfway point. The photo finish shows Kerley's orange shoe well in front of everything at the finish line. But it's the chest breaking the barrier that counts, and Lyles beat everyone by a sliver.\n\nWhen the American learned he had added the Olympic title to the 100 meters he won at world championships last year, he pulled off his name tag and raised it to the sky, then brought his hands to his side and pointed at the camera.\n\n\"America, I told you I got this!\" he yelled into the camera.\n\nYes, he's the World's Fastest Man. {"uri": "8259122427", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "21:43:17", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T21:43:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T21:39:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/head-bone-connected-clavicle-bone-213040220.html", "title": "Head bone connected to the clavicle bone and then a gold medal for sprinter Noah Lyles", "body": "Five one thousandths of a second, or -- if measuring by body parts -- a clavicle: that was the margin of victory for American sprinter Noah Lyles in the men's 100-meter photo finish sprint Sunday.\n\nOfficially, both Lyles and Jamaican sprinter Kishane Thompson finished with the time of 9.79 seconds, though the tight margin prompted the results to be confirmed by photo finish, with Lyles (9.784) just slightly edging out Thompson (9.789) for the gold medal and the title of the fastest man in the world.\n\nLyles' victory ended a 20-year drought for the U.S. atop the podium at the men's 100-meter dash, as he became the first American to win gold in the event since Justin Gatlin did so at the 2004 Athens Olympics.\n\nHere's everything to know about the rules governing track and field finishes at the 2024 Paris Olympics:\n\nJust after the men's 100-meter race concluded, NBC's Mike Tirico gave a brief explanation of how track and field race winners are determined. In his explanation, Tirico said that Olympic races determine a victor when any part of the leading runner's torso crosses the vertical plane of the finish line.\n\nUSA Track & Field, the governing body that oversees Team USA's international track and field competitions, has similar language published in its 2024 USATF Competition Rules.\n\nOn page 67 of the document, under Rule 163 (which concerns running competitions), the first point states: \"Competitors shall be placed at the finish line in the order in which any part of their bodies (i.e., the 'torso,' as distinguished from the head, neck, arms, hands, legs, or feet) reaches the finish line.\"\n\nThe sports governing body World Athletics also has similar language in its technical rulebook for track and field competitions.\n\nOmega, the official provider of photo finish images at the 2024 Paris Olympics, shared the image of Lyles' victory at the men's 100-meter sprint. The image clearly shows Lyles extending his body forward, with his torso -- namely, his shoulder and clavicle -- crossing the line before anyone else's.\n\nLyles, known for being a strong finisher in his races, had to rely on just that, lunging forward to just beat out Kishane Thompson. Lyles had to make ground in the second half of the race after Thompson and other sprinters raced out from the blocks to take early leads.\n\nFirst-, second- and third-place finishes win the gold, silver and bronze, respectively.", "source": {"uri": "sports.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo Sports"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Photo_finish", {"uri": "8259112158", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "21:25:48", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T21:25:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T21:25:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://www.sportingnews.com/us/olympics/news/noah-lyles-photo-finish-olympics-tiebreaker-100-meter-gold/1d3c2bbe414ac873c00fb8bd", "title": "Noah Lyles' photo finish, explained: How Olympics tiebreaker rules gave USA first 100m gold medal since 2004", "body": "Nothing came easy for Noah Lyles in the men's 100-meter, despite his blazing speed.\n\nLyles underwhelmed in the first round, vowing never to underestimate his competitors again, and he followed it up by narrowly finishing behind Oblique Seville in his semifinal heat. When it came time to prove he was the fastest man in the world, it took considerably longer than his time of 9.78 seconds for Lyles to find out if he completed his mission.\n\nLyles and Jamaica's Kishane Thompson had to wait out the results of a photo finish that would determine two different legacies. The finish was so close, in fact, that the NBC broadcast initially labeled Thompson the winner. It was Lyles who ultimately got to celebrate a gold medal, allowing him to share an emotional moment with his mother.\n\nMORE MEN'S 100M: Lyles' mom's reaction | Last US man to win 100m gold\n\nWhile the wait was only a few additional seconds, there's no doubt it felt arduously long for both sprinters.\n\nHere's a look at the Olympic men's 100-meter photo finish and the tiebreaker rule that gave Lyles the edge.\n\nMORE: Explaining the Noah Lyles-NBA controversy\n\nLyles won the 100-meter final by .005 seconds. That's five-thousandths of a second, as both he and Thompson posted a time of 9.79 when rounded off.\n\nThompson's foot definitively crossed the finish line first, which might be one reason why the broadcast appeared to believe he was the winner. The foot isn't what matters, though. Lyles' torso crossed before Thompson's torso, and it took a close examination of the finish to determine that the American star had the edge.\n\nBelow is the official photo from the photo finish.\n\nThe Olympics uses imaging with Fully Automatic Timing to determine the winner. The camera takes continuous, narrow images of the finish line, allowing those in charge to see exactly when a runner crosses for the first time.\n\nThe winner was hard enough to determine in slow motion. In real time, it was virtually impossible to know who had the edge in those final couple of seconds.\n\nLyles hit a top speed of 27.1 mph during the race, ahead of Thompson's 26.8. That surge allowed him to catch up with Thompson just in time to lurch ahead for the victory despite trailing nearly the entire way.\n\nWhat a year it is for the photo finish, as the Kentucky Derby required a photo finish on the same weekend a NASCAR race required a photo finish in May. Those photo finishes are a bit simpler, though: who (or what) crossed the line first? In the case of the 100-meter, it's a question of which torso crossed first.\n\nHere are more details on how the winner was determined.\n\nMORE: When does Noah Lyles race next?\n\nThe 100-meter final went to a photo finish, but there wasn't necessarily a tiebreaker applied to determine the winner. In this case, it was determined that Lyles did cross the finish line just before Thompson did -- and it wasn't his feet that crossed first.\n\nA runner's finish is determined by the moment their torso crosses the finish line. The feet are not what get a runner over the finish line, just like a runner can't stick out their arm in hopes it crosses the finish line before the other competitors.\n\nThe head doesn't count, either, but you will almost always see sprinters stick out their heads when approaching the finish line because moving the head forward naturally moves the top of the torso forward. As soon as the torso crosses, the job is done.", "source": {"uri": "sportingnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Sporting News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": After finishing with bronze in Tokyo three years ago, Lyles redeemed himself in an absurd photo finish comeback to win his first-ever gold medal.\n\nIf you ask NBC's production for Lyles' big finish, they're gonna want the whole moment back. Unfortunately, that's not how it works.\n\nAs Lyles and Jamaica's Kishane Thompson crossed the finish line at virtually the same time, it was clear that it was way too close to call by the naked eye. In fact, as a result, the prudent move for the broadcast should've been to cast doubt on the outcome until photos and official times confirmed the victor while offering up some measure of clarity in the transitional period.\n\nInstead, NBC's Leigh Diffey and his analysts stuck with Jamaica and Thompson, ran with that as the clear answer, said nothing for an awkward amount of time, and then had to correct to Lyles being the rightful winner by the blink of an eye (five-thousandths of a second).\n\nOof, all of that could've been avoided with more patience and tact:\n\nAh, well, at least Lyles got the deserved gold. {"uri": "8259140926", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "22:07:48", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T22:07:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T22:06:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://roanoke.com/sports/college/other/virginia-tech-hokies/lyles-wins-100-hocker-and-gourley-make-1-500-final/article_5f9d4442-52a7-11ef-920d-431fa868700c.html", "title": "Lyles wins 100, Hocker and Gourley make 1,500 final", "body": "Wire and Staff Reports\n\nSAINT-DENIS, France -- Noah Lyles won the Olympic 100 meters by .005 seconds Sunday, waiting some 30 seconds after the finish of one of the closest sprints in history to find out he'd beaten Kishane Thompson of Jamaica.\n\nIn other track action Sunday, Blacksburg resident Cole Hocker and former Virginia Tech standout Neil Gourley advanced to Tuesday's final of the men's 1,500 meters.\n\nThe word \"Photo\" popped up on the scoreboard next to the names of Lyles, Thompson and five others after they crossed the line in the 100.\n\nLyles, 27, paced the track with his hands draped over his head. Finally, the numbers came up. Lyles won in 9.784 seconds to edge out Thompson by five-thousandths of a tick of the clock.\n\nLyles said he thought he had given the win away by dipping at the line too soon, so he went up to Thompson and told him, \"Bro, I think you got that one.\"\n\n\"But then my name popped up and I'm like 'Oh my gosh, amazing!'\" said Lyles, who was a high school track star in Virginia when he ran for T.C. Williams High School (now known as Alexandria City High).\n\nAmerica's Fred Kerley came in third at 9.81.\n\n\"That's probably one of the most beautiful races I've been in,\" he said.\n\nThe top seven all finished within .09 of each other.\n\nThis was the closest 1-2 finish in the 100 since at least Moscow in 1980 -- or maybe even ever. Back then, Britain's Allan Wells narrowly beat Silvio Leonard in an era when the electronic timers didn't go down into the thousandths of a second. The same was true in 1932, when Eddie Tolan won the Olympics' first ever photo finish.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | Omny Studio\n\n\"I thought I had (him) cleared,\" Thompson said. \"But I wasn't sure. It was so close.\"\n\nLyles became the first American to win the marquee event in Olympic track since Justin Gatlin in 2004.\n\nThe 9.784 also marks a personal best for Lyles, who has been promising to add his own brand of excitement to track and certainly delivered this time.\n\nHe will be a favorite later this week in the 200 meters -- his better race -- and will try to join Usain Bolt as the latest runner to win both Olympic sprints.\n\nLyles and Thompson had two of the three slowest bursts from the blocks, and Thompson had what sufficed for a \"lead\" at the halfway point. The photo finish actually shows Kerley's orange shoe well in front of everything at the finish line. But it's the chest breaking the barrier that counts, and Lyles beat everyone by a sliver.\n\nWhen the American learned he had added the Olympic title to the 100 meters he won at world championships last year, he pulled off his name tag and raised it to the sky, then brought his hands to his side and pointed at the camera.\n\n\"America, I told you I got this!\" he yelled into the camera.\n\nAlso Sunday, Hocker and Gourley did well in the 1,500 semifinals.\n\nHocker, a former University of Oregon star who has trained at Virginia Tech since November, finished third in his 12-man semifinal heat with a time of 3:32.54. The top six runners in each heat advanced to Tuesday's final.\n\nGourley, running for Great Britain, finished third in the other semifinal heat with a time of 3:32.11.\n\nGourley, a Scotland native, was third overall. Hocker, a Pennsylvania native running in his second Olympics, was 10th overall.\n\nAs a senior, Gourley ran the anchor leg for the Tech distance medley relay team that won gold at the 2018 NCAA indoor championships.\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user {"uri": "8259075289", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "20:36:45", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T20:36:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T20:36:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://www.ft.com/content/d4899a82-ad98-481b-b8a3-b7346a377c72", "title": "Noah Lyles wins men's 100-metre final by razor-thin margin", "body": "Noah Lyles of the US won the men's 100-metre final at the Paris Olympics in a razor-thin photo finish over Jamaican Kishane Thompson, becoming the first American to claim the title in 20 years.\n\nInside a packed Stade de France on Sunday night, Lyles crossed the finish in a personal best 9.784 seconds to Thompson's 9.789. Fred Kerley, also of the US and the silver medallist at the Tokyo Olympics, finished third in 9.81. Marcel Jacobs, defending champion, finished fifth. It was the first time in history that eight men broke 10 seconds in a wind-legal race.\n\nLong considered one of the marquee events of the entire Olympic Games, the 100-metre final has catapulted winners to instant global fame. From 2008 through 2016, the event was dominated by reigning world record holder Usain Bolt of Jamaica, and while no sprinter has run within a tenth of a second of his fastest time of 9.58, Lyles has been positioning himself for years to inherit the position as the face of global sprinting.\n\nAs a recent star of the Netflix series Sprint, Lyles, 27, developed elaborate narratives around himself through each season, including one in the early part of this year by bringing a secretive metal briefcase to each meet, promising to reveal its contents at the US Olympic trials in June. The briefcase contained his running kit.\n\nTechnically superior at the 200 metres, in which his personal best of 19.31 is the third-best all-time, Lyles joked in the series that the 200 metres is his \"wife\", while the 100 metres is his \"mistress\". He will also contest the longer event in Paris, where the first heats begin on Monday.\n\nAs the favorite in the 200 metres, Lyles could become the first man since Bolt in 2016 to complete the 100 and 200 double at the games.\n\nThompson, 23, became a late favourite for a medal in Paris after running 9.77 seconds at the Jamaican championships in June, the fastest time in the world this year. He was the top-ranked runner after Sunday evening's semi-finals, in which he qualified with 9.80.\n\nSunday night's podium reshuffles the ongoing sprint rivalry between the Jamaicans and Americans after Jacobs, 29, became the shock winner in Tokyo. Since then, the Italian has struggled with injury and inconsistency, failing to make the 100-metre final in the 2022 and 2023 world championships.\n\nLyles' victory came a night after the US had to settle for silver and gold in the women's 100-metre final, with St Lucia's Julien Alfred winning gold -- her country's first Olympic medal.\n\nThe last American to win the men's Olympic 100 metres was {"uri": "8259181003", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "23:09:32", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T23:09:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T23:07:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://www.nzherald.co.nz/sport/olympics/olympics-2024-noah-lyles-did-not-break-the-line-first-but-won-100m-gold-here-is-how-he-did-it/5IO6DS3WBFERFFA3A6LX474A6Q/", "title": "Olympics 2024: Noah Lyles did not break the line first but won 100m gold - here is how he did it - NZ Herald", "body": "Lyles, predictably, had made the most eye-catching of arrivals, sprinting down as far as the 40m line when he was announced into the stadium. Plenty of people watching wondered if he should conserve some energy but, clearly wanting to be the showman that the men's 100m has lacked ever since Usain Bolt, he continued his high-energy antics.\n\nThe wait between the athletes arriving out on the track and the actual start of the race felt interminable. Lengthy introductions, booming music, a spectacular light show, darkness and then a longer than anticipated wait for the bulbs inside the Stade de France to reach optimal brightness. That was before even the eight athletes had been called to their blocks before the silence that accompanied the starter's orders.\n\nWith Lyles's rivals having warmed themselves up with such vigour and precision on a separate track just outside the Stade de France, there was a theory that the wait might have particularly affected the two Jamaican sprinters, Oblique Seville and Thompson. They had looked capable of running so much faster in the heats and, while nerves may also have been a factor, they looked tight by comparison.\n\nLyles has never been a fast starter and, true to form, his reaction time from when the gun sounded and his feet actually left the blocks was the joint slowest in the entire field at 0.178sec. Thompson was crucially not much faster, ensuring that Fred Kerley, who was largely unfancied for gold, took an instant lead.\n\nSprinters then vary greatly in how long they keep their heads down but this next part of the race was excellent for Thompson who, by 30m, had taken the lead and was moving faster than anyone at 40.6km per hour. Lyles, who was now just touching that same speed, had taken much longer to get there and was actually still last out of all eight runners even at 30m.\n\nLyles had made the unexpected decision earlier this year to turn up at the World Indoor Championships and take on Christian Coleman, the best 60m runner in history over the distance. He could not win, but it was a critical decision for what would follow here in Paris. Knowing that he was the fastest finisher, Lyles desperately wanted to shorten the moment between the start of the race and when he was upright out of the 'drive phase' and ready to launch into full flight.\n\nThis transition was not instantly noticeable during the race, with Lyles still trailing Thompson at 40m but making crucial inroads into the rest of the field. By halfway, he had reached 43.5kph - almost his top speed during the race - which is quicker than anyone else managed through the full 100m. It meant that he had moved from eighth to third between 30m and 60m. This meant that it was now simply a question of holding his form and hoping that there would be enough track to complete his surge through the field.\n\nLyles had reached overdrive by 60m, peaking at 43.6kpm in the 10m to 70m, which is at the moment when those 100m specialists in front of him were starting to struggle to hold their form and just faltering into the final metres. What Lyles did then brilliantly here, however, was to maintain his concentration, keep relaxed and not allow the desperation that he would have felt at still not quite hitting the front to impact his running. He calls the 200m \"his wife\" and the 100m \"his mistress\" and knew that he just needed to stay faithful to his old instincts that had been honed from years of running over the longer sprint.\n\nIt was a masterful display of nerve and mind over matter just as much as pure physical speed or power. Yes, it was something that he had practised endlessly with his coach but to actually deliver it in front of a watching world was extraordinary.\n\nFew people are more sure of themselves than Lyles, but even he suspected that Thompson had won following a blanket finish. Incredibly, the scoreboard said that seven of the finalists were in the photo-finish and there was an agonising 20 seconds while they all just stopped and looked up at the big screen. The only finishing time that had been recorded was that of Seville, who was eighth, despite looking so dominant in beating Lyles in their semi-final.\n\nAnd then the result flashed up, Lyles's eyes almost popped out of his head to confirm that, by an almost unimaginably fine margin, he was the Olympic champion.\n\nThe difference between Lyles (9.784) and Thompson (9.789) was a ludicrously microscopic five-thousandths of a second. The subsequent overhead photo showed that Thompson's foot had actually crossed the line first but Lyles's superior lean into the finish line had sealed it for him.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8259975374", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "11:19:26", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T11:19:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T11:19:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://www.foxsports.com.au/olympics/this-is-so-stupid-confusing-pic-sparks-furore-over-100m-final/news-story/5a54153c7fb85e1210103feece99e218", "title": "'This is so stupid': Confusing pic sparks furore over 100m final", "body": "You're not the only one confused by the photo that has the world talking after the closest, most insane, finish in the 100m sprint the Olympics has ever seen.\n\nWorld champion Noah Lyles roared to victory in 9.79 seconds on Monday morning (AEST) and there were just five one thousandths of a second separating him and silver medallist Kishane Thompson of Jamaica.\n\nThe world was forced to wait for several agonising moments before the technology showed the American's name on the top of the timesheet -- 9.784sec to Thompson's 9.789sec.\n\nAerial and side on photos, however, appeared to suggest Thompson was the first to cross the line -- thanks to his white track shoes -- with American bronze medallist Fred Kerley also crossing ahead of Lyles with his snazzy orange kicks.\n\nIt's left plenty asking why on Earth is Lyles celebrating his new title as the world's fastest man?\n\nAthletics results are measured by the first torso that crosses the line.\n\nAccording to Olympic rules, a runner is considered to have finished a race when part of their body from the clavicle down crosses the finish line -- something always considered to be the fairest measurement because of the different strides and leg lengths of runners.\n\nSo what separated Lyles and Thompson was the American's torso lunge to the line, while Thompson's dip was just slightly concave.\n\nBut his line-breaking right boot left plenty of Olympics fans convinced the Jamaican was robbed.\n\nThat doesn't in any way detract from the widely-held view it was one of the best races in the history of the Games -- the very first time that all runners went under 10 seconds (not including wind assisted races).\n\nThere were just 0.03 seconds between Lyles and the fourth-placed runner, Akani Simbine from South Africa.\n\nIt says a lot about how close the result was that a journalist asked the medallist if they should share the gold medal if measured at the same time to within hundredths of a second.\n\nThe other question, that keeps coming up is how did Lyles pull it off when he was so slow out of the blocks -- his reaction time of 0.178 seconds was the equal slowest.\n\nIt was only in the final 10m that Lyles edged in front.\n\nHe came home like a freight train, but looking across from lane seven over to Thompson in lane three it was easy to see why he thought Thompson had won.\n\n\"We were waiting for the names to pop up. I told him, 'I think you got that one'. I couldn't really see what was going on over there,\" he said as the world waited for the winner to be announced.\n\n\"I just had to keep running like I was going to win it. Something told me 'you need to lean'. This is how close first and second is going to be.\n\n\"It was a crazy moment. I did think that Kishane had that. I was like, 'I'm going to have to swallow my pride', which I don't have a problem doing.\n\n\"Everybody on the field came out knowing they could win this race. That's the mindset we have to have. Iron sharpens iron.\n\n\"I saw my name and was like, 'I didn't do this against a slow crowd, I did this against the best of the best, on the biggest stage with the biggest pressure'.\"\n\nLyles' whole career may boil down to that famous lunge for the line, but he says it's not something he has ever focused on.\n\n\"I would say I have a decent history with dipping at the line. Throughout my high-school career and stuff like that, a lot of races have come down to dips. I've been able to win.\"\n\nBriefly, ever so briefly, Thompson thought the glory could be his.\n\n\"I couldn't see him, but I thought he was seeing me,\" Thompson said of Lyles.\n\n\"He said, 'Hey Kishane I thought you got it,' and I said, 'I am not sure'.\n\n\"This is the closest medal.\"\n\nIt was almost cruel for Thompson to be asked if the medal should be shared between them.\n\n\"I think the sport is too competitive, no offence to any other sport. It's too competitive for us to share a gold medal.\" he said.\n\n\"I'm feeling very good, honestly. My body language will not show it because I am not an expressive guy, but I am glad.\n\n\"I know that Jamaica would have wanted me to get the gold, everybody love winners. I would have loved to win today, but big up to the whole field.\"\n\nIn an astonishing race, defending champion Marcell Jacobs of Italy was fifth in 9.85sec, Botswana's Letsile Tebogo sixth in 9.86sec, American Kenny Bednarek seventh in 9.88sec and Jamaican Oblique Seville eighth in 9.91sec.\n\nMost of them will also be running in the 200m -- and the world will be desperately hoping to see something as special as the 100m was on Monday morning.", "source": {"uri": "foxsports.com.au", "dataType": "news", "title": "Fox Sports"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8259895375", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "10:29:34", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T10:29:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T10:28:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://www.ladbible.com/news/sport/olympics-2024-how-noah-lyles-won-gold-947972-20240805", "title": "How Noah Lyles won 100m gold despite Jamaican rival's foot crossing line first in race", "body": "Last night's (4 August) men's 100m final certainly felt like one of the best track and field events in Olympic history.\n\nThe eight finalists endured an agonising delay to the start of their race after a failed track invasion from a spectator just moments before it was due to begin, which meant that emotions were already running high by time the athletes were able to take their starting position.\n\nThings weren't looking good for Team USA's Noah Lyles in the first seconds, with the American languishing in last place with just under half of the race gone.\n\nHowever the final moments of the race would see Lyles have a massive reverse of fortunes, with the athlete powering past all other competitors to snag gold with just 0.05 seconds to spare.\n\nJamaica's Kishane Thompson was right behind him in second, while defending Tokyo 2020 champion Lamont Marcell Jacobs found himself all the way back in fifth.\n\nThe final was also the fastest race of all time, with all eight athletes crossing the finish line in under 10 seconds.\n\nThe final moments of the race were so close that it was almost impossible to tell who'd won from our TV screens at home. If anything, it appeared that Thompson had gotten his foot further over the finish line.\n\nSo how did Lyles win Olympic gold?\n\nIt's true that Thompson's foot crossed the finish line before Lyles, however the winner is decided by whose chest first crosses the line - with Lyles' leaning ever so slightly further forward being just enough to seal the deal.\n\nAs per The Telegraph, his final time was recorded at 9.79784 while Thompson had a time of 9.79789, with the microscopic five thousandths of a second being the only thing to separate gold and silver.\n\nTruly phenomenal stuff.\n\nThe race was even declared the greatest ever final by four-time Olympic champion Michael Johnson, who said it was 'absolutely' the best he'd ever seen.\n\n\"The final lived up to the hype,\" he said in a post-race interview with the BBC. \"Going through the rounds it looked like a foregone conclusion that Kishane Thompson would win as he was the one who came in as the fastest man in the world.\n\n\"We Lyles also lost his opening-round heat -- to Britain's Louie Hinchliffe on Saturday. Hinchliffe finished third in the semifinal and did not advance.\n\nJoining Lyles in the eight-man final will be Jamaica's Kishane Thompson, who won his semifinal in 9.80 seconds, the fastest time in the three semifinal. Thompson also has the world's best time this year at 9.77; he and Seville are trying to put Jamaica back on top of the Olympic podium for the first time since Usain Bolt retired after the 2016 Games.\n\nDefending champion Marcell Jacobs of Italy finished third in the second semifinal and advanced because his 9.92 was the best among sprinters who didn't automatically qualify by finishing in the top two in their heats.\n\nAlso in the final will be Americans Kenny Bednarek and Fred Kerley, Botswana's Letsile Tebogo and South Africa's Akani Simbine.\n\nOther gold medals on the line Sunday night at the Stade de France are in men's hammer throw and women's high jump, where Yaroslava Mahuchikh tries to bring Olympic gold to her war-torn home country of Ukraine.\n\nCopyright \u00a9 2024 The Associated Press. {"uri": "8259084558", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "20:49:34", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T20:49:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T20:48:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://www.news18.com/olympics/paris-2024-noah-lyles-reigns-supreme-to-claim-mens-100m-sprint-gold-kishane-thompson-second-8990129.html", "title": "Paris 2024: Noah Lyles Reigns Supreme to Claim Men's 100m Sprint Gold, Kishane Thompson Second - News18", "body": "American sprinter Lyles earned the yellow metal with a timing of 9.79sec in the final of the 100m dash as he pipped out Jamaican Kishane Thompson, who finished second. Fred Kerley came in third with a time of 9.81sec.\n\nWorld champion Noah Lyles roared to victory in 9.79sec to claim the men's Olympic 100m gold in Paris on Sunday.\n\nLyles became the first American, male or female, to win the event since Justin Gatlin won in the 2004 Athens Games.\n\nIn a photo-finish, Jamaica's Kishane Thompson claimed silver, just five-thousandths of a second off Lyles' pace.\n\nLyles' US teammate Fred Kerley took bronze in 9.81sec, just one-hundredth ahead of South African Akani Simbine, who timed 9.82sec.\n\nDefending champion Marcell Jacobs of Italy was fifth in 9.85sec, Botswana's Letsile Tebogo sixth in 9.86sec, American Kenny Bednarek seventh in 9.88sec and Jamaican Oblique Seville eighth in 9.91sec in an astonishing race.\n\nStarting in lane seven, outside Seville and inside Tebogo, Lyles got off to an average start but was soon into his stride pattern.\n\nHead tucked down through to the 40-metre mark, the American opened up, but the whole field pushed him all the way.\n\nAs Lyles dipped for the line with Thompson charging alongside him, the crowd erupted and a photo-finish was called before Lyles was confirmed as gold medallist.\n\nThere was an electric pre-race atmosphere in a 69,000-capacity Stade de France, a light show and booming bass-heavy music keeping the crowd entertained as the sprinters made the final adjustments to their starting blocks.\n\nThe lights were then shut off, the sprinters leaving the track to remake their entrance like prize fighters in a colosseum.\n\nCalled out over the tannoy, each sprinter was individually introduced behind an image of their name above their flag.\n\nThompson roared, hands clenched in fists as his head rolled back. Kerley patted his heart.\n\nLyles bounded out like a kangaroo, bouncing 20 metres down the track. Jacobs was the definition of cool, raising both arms and calmly walking to his blocks.\n\nThen came the moment where the sprinters set, at the starter's beck and call.\n\nThe wait seemed interminable. The music continued, the crowd clapped in unison as if to hurry the starter, then the sprinters stood in their lanes, rocking from foot to foot and the tension was palpable.\n\nThe cameras panned one more and then it was time, the only sound that of a helicopter's wings whirring overhead.\n\nThe shot was fired and the field moved as if one up the purple track.\n\nThe photo-finish officials examined the evidence and Lyles walked away with gold to bury the demons of the Tokyo Games where he harvested a mere 200m bronze.", "source": {"uri": "news18.com", "dataType": "news", "title":
