"eng-9790103", "eventUri": "eng-9790103", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.2, "wgt": 160, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8259149766", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "22:20:48", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T22:20:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T22:18:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://ca.sports.yahoo.com/news/noah-lyles-walks-walk-become-221028399.html", "title": "Noah Lyles walks the walk to become undisputed king of men's sprinting", "body": "Perhaps the greatest tribute you can pay to Noah Lyles is that he really is as good as he says he is. First comes the vision. Then comes the pledge, almost as if he is trying to speak the vision into reality. Finally the delivery, the nuts and screws of cashing the cheques his words have already written for him. And in about the time it takes you to read this paragraph, he becomes the Olympic 100m champion.\n\nThe new undisputed king of men's sprinting is a kind of tortured genius, a manga and anime fan who likes painting his nails and his skateboards, who mentioned his therapist in his press conference, who understands better than most that the glory and the despair are basically two halves of a whole. Perhaps nothing captures this better than a final won by five-thousandths of a second, the breathtakingly cruel difference between Lyles and Kishane Thompson of Jamaica.\n\nRelated: USA's Noah Lyles: manga geek, alpha male and very, very fast\n\nIt was one hell of a fight, which is just as well because there is nothing Lyles likes better. In a sport of pure air and clean straight lines, perhaps the simplest sport of all, Lyles thrives on the thrust of conflict, the fast-twitch muscles of competition and confrontation, the salt of his haters' tears and the salt of his own. Often it is said of athletes that the first yard is in their head. With Lyles, it is more accurate to say that the first yard is in his mouth.\n\nHe has, for example, insisted all season on calling himself the \"fastest man in the world\" even though Thompson has run what remains the fastest time this year; who calls out pretty much the entire NFL and NBA for having the temerity to call themselves world champions. Who described himself before the last Games as the three-time Olympic gold medallist and made it his phone screensaver, shortly before leaving Tokyo with a grand total of one bronze medal.\n\nWhat changed? Perhaps we discovered this a few seconds into the final. He had already been edged out by Oblique Seville of Jamaica in the semi-final and Louie Hinchliffe of Great Britain in his first-round heat.\n\nWhatever aura he still possessed from his clean sweep at the world championships in Budapest 12 months ago, let's just say it wasn't entirely evident 40 metres into the race, with Lyles dead last and Thompson ominously taking to the front.\n\nThompson is 23 and yet, until this still-warm Paris evening, remained something of an unknown quantity. A product of the famous MVP club in Kingston, his coach Stephen Francis has made a very conspicuous show of holding him back, keeping his talent under wraps like a Formula One prototype. After running 9.92sec in the heats of last year's national championships, Francis withdrew him before the final. At other times, he has ordered Thompson to ease up after 60 metres which - in hindsight - might not have been the greatest idea.\n\nBecause at around 50m, the point at which Thompson is usually springing the knees high and opening out into his devastating drive phase, something began to malfunction. His head began to sway from side to side, the arms hanging a little loosely. In the biggest race of his life, in his first major championship, in a moment of stress few of us can imagine, Thompson was wobbling.\n\nAnd perhaps this, ultimately, is where those five-thousandths of a second can be found. Lyles has seen things. He has known the pain of defeat, the numbness of depression, the sting of rejection, even humiliation, and come out the other side. More importantly, this is a technique tweaked and honed in miniaturised detail with his coach Lance Brauman, a mindset forged in long and often difficult therapy sessions.\n\nThe arm strokes were perfectly clean, the head in absolute stillness, and his mind presumably in a similar state. Lyles ate up those final few metres, and then the final few centimetres, some deep competitive urge that simply would not allow him to be beaten. A pregnant pause. The eyes of the world on a little blue screen. Then the verdict. A scream from Lyles, followed by a tear down the back straight, chased by dozens of photographers, the biggest athletic mismatch of the night.\n\nRelated: Yaroslava Mahuchikh rises to occasion to secure high jump gold for Ukraine\n\nWhat happens next is anyone's guess. Men's 100m champions from Jesse Owens to Usain Bolt have always been required to represent something larger than themselves, to be not just a champion but a figurehead, a polestar, a physical ideal and a relentless personal brand upon which tickets, hospitality packages and household items can reliably be sold.\n\nThis was a task too far for the defending champion Marcell Jacobs. Perhaps it came a little soon for Thompson too, an athlete still discovering the outer limits of himself, and who will have learned so much.\n\nFor Lyles, on the other hand, this is the role he always dreamed for himself. Through the tainted and confusing post-Bolt years, the brief interregnums of Justin Gatlin and Kerley, Jacobs and Christian Coleman, athletics has been searching - not without a certain internal contradiction - for a successor to its freakish once-in-a-generation sprinting god.\n\nAnd as the achievement began to dawn on him, Lyles began to slow a little. He stopped leaping and gurning for the cameras. He looked up at the stands and for a few seconds he fell completely silent, with all the solemnity of a man who has kept a sacred promise.", "source": {"uri": "ca.sports.yahoo.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8260010201", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "11:41:57", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T11:41:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T11:40:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://apnews.com/article/olympics-lyles-sprint-f7e98b358efe838a2eb2d1912690cae9", "title": "After winning Olympic thriller by a whisker, Noah Lyles looks for an encore in his favorite event", "body": "SAINT-DENIS, France (AP) -- All the overhead shots and race replays tell the same story. Noah Lyles only led one time during his Olympic 100-meter sprint for the ages: at the finish line.\n\nThere's a good argument that the rest of his stay at these Paris Games won't be anywhere near as nip-and-tuck.\n\nWith the Olympics still abuzz over his .005-second victory in the 100, Lyles didn't have much time to rest before moving to his next event. He is a heavy favorite in the 200 meters, his better race, and a race he has not lost since the Olympic final in Tokyo three years ago, where he finished third. Opening heats for the 200 were set for Monday night.\n\nLyles' willingness -- make that, desire -- to be the front man for a sport that yearns for new fans feels like a game-changer to Seb Coe, the World Athletics president who called Sunday's race \"if not perfect, about as close to perfect as you can get.\"\n\n\"If I'm wearing a promoter's hat, then him winning last night was important, because he's now creating a narrative that's heading us back into Usain Bolt territory,\" Coe said. \"That's hugely important.\"\n\nIn a typically candid and engaging post-race news conference, Lyles made no secret that he is in this to promote his sport, but also wants more.\n\nHe has been a front man for the popular Netflix documentary \"SPRINT,\" and has brought a sense of fashion back to the track, making \"walk-ins\" a thing and bedazzling his hair with white pearls on race day.\n\nNow, he's got a message for his shoe sponsor, Adidas.\n\n\"I want my own shoe,\" he said. \"I want my own trainer. I'm dead serious. I want a sneaker. There ain't no money in spikes, there's money in sneakers. I feel like for how many medals we bring back and the notoriety we get, the fact that hasn't happened, that's crazy for me. I feel like that needs to happen.\"\n\nThe 100 was the biggest hurdle for Lyles to overcome. It is not his best race, and it's the one he took up shortly after Tokyo with the goal of becoming more than a mere sprinter, but a larger-than-life personality, both on and off the track.\n\nLyles also figures to feature prominently in the men's 4x100 relay but that's anything but a gimme.\n\nRiddled with poor work with the baton, a lack of consistent training habits, a doping positive and the constant spectre of trying to beat Bolt, the U.S. has not won, and kept, a single Olympic medal in this event since 2004. It hasn't captured gold since 2000.\n\nThe relay is a bigger threat to Lyles' quest to win three gold medals, the way Bolt did in all three of his appearances, than the 200 meters.\n\nLyles figures to get his biggest challenge in the 200 from Kenny Bednarek, who finished ahead of Lyles in Tokyo and, more recently, pushed him at a fast Olympic trails that Lyles won in 19.53.\n\nBotswana's Letsile Tobogo, American Erryion Knighton and defending champion Andre De Grasse are also in the mix. One interesting wager would be whether Lyles has more of a chance of losing the race or lowering his American record of 19.31. In 14 of the past 30, the nation has multiple medalists.\n\nJesse Owens, Carls Lewis, and now Noah Lyles are just a few names to win gold. Lyles is the latest winner of the 100-meter dash, breaking the country's 20-year drought of having a gold medalist in the race.\n\nHis victory at the 2024 Paris Olympics was a literal photo finish (see above), coming by just five thousandths of a second as he edged out Jamaica's Kishane Thompson. Before Lyles brought the gold back to the United States, here's who won the last U.S. gold medal in the 100-meter dash.\n\nMORE: Noah Lyles, Fred Kerley win gold, bronze in 100-meter dash at 2024 Paris Olympics\n\nThe United States has a long history of success in the men's 100-meter dash, having won gold 16 times prior to the 2024 Paris Olympics.\n\nThat said, the nation has been starved for a gold in said race since 2004 at the Athens Games. Justin Gatlin won the last USA men's 100-meter gold medal prior to the 2024 Summer Games.\n\nBEST U.S. OLYMPIANS\n\nTop 33 rankings | Simone Biles | Katie Ledecky | Jesse Owens\n\nLyles breaks the streak, giving the U.S. its 17th gold medal in the history of this race.\n\nUsain Bolt was a major reason why the United States remained without any gold medals over the past 20 years. The Jamaican sprinter won three straight gold medals from 2008-2016. He still owns the world record with a 9.58 finish in the world championships in 2009.\n\nMORE MEN'S 100M: Photo finish explainer | Lyles' mom's reaction\n\nThe United States medaled in each year since 2004, but nobody could quite catch Bolt. Walter Dix placed third in 2008, Gatlin earned third and second in 2012 and 2016, respectively, and Fred Kerley, who claimed the bronze this year, finished second in 2020.\n\nLyles' victory was a {"uri": "8259075544", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "20:38:10", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T20:38:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T20:36:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/other-sports/athletics/paris-olympics-100m-noah-lyles-33393775", "title": "Noah Lyles profiled after Olympics star is crowned new fastest man in the world", "body": "Noah Lyles has won the men's 100m final at the Paris Olympics with a time of 9.79 to become the new fastest man in the world.\n\nJamaica's Kishane Thompson won the silver medal, narrowly losing to Lyles by just five thousandths of a second, while Fred Kerley claimed bronze with a time of 9.81. Lyles was absolutely delighted with his triumph, with the American claiming his second Olympic medal after winning bronze in the 200m in Tokyo.\n\nLyles is the reigning world champion, having claimed gold in Budapest last year, and his triumph was documented in Netflix's 'SPRINT' series which has helped him become a huge name in the world of athletics.\n\nThe 27-year-old also won the 200m and was part of the victorious US 4x100m relay at the World Championships, the first man to complete the sprint treble since Usain Bolt, and he raised some eyebrows ahead of the Olympics by claiming he is \"ready to transcend the sport\".\n\n\"You have to have the mindset of a god to be able to think every time that you're going to win the race,\" Lyles said. \"Belief. That is what you have to have. I don't believe in idols. I believe in myself. My mentality is extremely strong. And if it's not, I'll train it to be.\n\n\"I'm ready to transcend the sport. The medals come first because without them, who's going to pay attention to you? Once you have the medals, then you get the times, and more and more people gain interest.\n\n\"Then you've got the whole floor. We have to push the narrative of track and field. We have to do more; we have to be presented to the world.\" Lyles will also be eyeing gold in the 200m, with his personal best time of 19.31 making him the third-fastest competitor of all-time.\n\nLyles' father Kevin is a former sprinter who won gold in the 4x400m relay at the 1995 World Championships, while his mother Keisha was also a standout track and field athlete at college. Younger brother Josephus is also a sprinter who turned professional alongside Noah in 2016 after the pair signed with Adidas.\n\nLyles began competing in track and field at the age of 12, having initially been a gymnast as a child, with the American inspired to make the switch alongside his brother after watching the 2012 Olympics in London.\n\nReflecting on the race, four-time Olympic gold medallist Michael Johnson told the BBC : \"The best 100m final I have seen bar none. It was so open, there were so many great athletes. It lived up to it, we had this amazing race where you could throw a blanket over the finishing line.\"\n\nOlympic silver medallist Steve Cram added: \"Lyles didn't even have a medal 10m out. He didn't have a hope of winning. He came fast, he came hard, and in the end, by the smallest of margins, he has taken the Olympic title. Beaten in the heats, beaten in the semi-final, but he's won the one that mattered most.\"\n\nFollow all the action on day 9 of the Paris Olympics with Mirror Sport's live blog\n\nJoin our new WhatsApp community and receive your daily dose of Mirror Football content. He came out with all the confidence and swagger of a gold medalist, and after a somewhat shaky set of qualification races, got himself to the final. In the end, we got a photo finish.\n\nAnother photo came out after the race, shared by the World Athletics social media, that tells an awesome story.\n\nJust look how awesome this eight-frame edit is:\n\nIt's eight frames of the race, from the start to the finish, and it shows just how close the race was. Every glance down the various lanes tells a different story. Each horizontal look at the eight race stages it captures tells another. The most obvious story, of course, is Lyles, who came from behind after the worst reaction-time start in the race.\n\nThe best and worst were separated by 0.12 seconds, and Lyles and the silver medalist, Kishane Thompson, were separated by .005 seconds.\n\nLyles was in last place at the 40 meter mark, and just seventh by the time the race got to the halfway point. He jumped up to third by the 60-meter mark and second at the 90-meter mark. He did not lead until the 100th meter, the end of the race. {"uri": "8259499742", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "05:53:03", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T05:53:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T05:51:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/magazines/panache/olympic-100-meter-champ-noah-lyles-has-asthma-depression-dyslexia-check-his-powerful-message-for-you/articleshow/112278359.cms", "title": "Olympic 100-meter champ Noah Lyles has asthma, depression, dyslexia... Check his powerful message for you", "body": "United States sprinter Noah Lyles cemented his reputation as the fastest man in the world by clinching the gold medal in the 100-meter sprint at the 2024 Paris Olympics. His victory marked the first time a U.S. man has won this event since Justin Gatlin's triumph in 2004. Lyles edged out Jamaica's Kishane Thompson in a thrilling photo finish, with Lyles clocking a time of 9.784 seconds, just five thousandths of a second ahead of Thompson's 9.789 seconds. This win secured Lyles his first Olympic gold medal and his second Olympic medal overall.\n\nWhat makes Lyles' achievement even more remarkable is his battle with asthma, a condition that could have hindered his ability to compete at such a high level. Asthma affects the airways in the lungs, making breathing difficult, which is particularly challenging for an elite athlete.\n\nAfter his victory, Lyles took to social media to reflect on his journey and the obstacles he has overcome. \"I have Asthma, allergies, dyslexia, ADD, anxiety, and depression,\" Lyles shared on X (formerly known as Twitter). \"But I will tell you that what you have does not define what you can become. Why Not You!\"\n\nLyles has dealt with asthma since childhood, a condition that once led to him being homeschooled. \"Asthma definitely affects kind of everything I do in terms of health, physical fitness, and sometimes even emotional well-being,\" Lyles told CNN in 2020. \"If you're emotionally fatigued, that can bring your immune system down.\"\n\nTo manage his condition, Lyles takes several precautions, including washing his hands frequently, taking vitamin C, and drinking warm water with lemon. He also emphasizes the importance of maintaining high spirits to keep his immune system strong.\n\nLyles' journey with asthma began at a young age, leading to frequent hospital visits due to severe asthma attacks and a weakened immune system. \"From about three to four, all the way to about seven years old, I was dealing with asthma and asthma attacks seriously, like in the hospital maybe every third night; coughing fits, constantly sick because my immune system was weak,\" Lyles recalled.\n\nA tonsillectomy, a change in diet, and the unwavering support of his mother eventually allowed Lyles to attend public school, where he faced additional challenges such as ADD and dyslexia. \"Around second grade, I was diagnosed with ADD and dyslexia, which made standardized testing and even simple tasks like spelling tests extremely difficult,\" Lyles said.\n\nDespite these hurdles, Lyles has proven that with determination and resilience, one can overcome significant obstacles. Jon Rahm (+135) and Tommy Fleetwood (+150) were the favorites to win Gold as of 10:30 a.m. ET after the final round got underway early Sunday morning.\n\nOther notable events scheduled for Sunday include a handful of medal races on the final day of Olympic swimming:\n\nBelow are the odds for the headline event of the day, where Lyles will look to upset the favorite, Kishane Thompson of Jamaica.\n\nThe semifinals of the 100m are scheduled for 2:05 p.m. ET, followed by the final at 3:50 p.m. ET.\n\nThe odds indicate that this will come down to either Thompson or Lyles. The 23-year-old Thompson and Lyles, 27, are two of the biggest names competing in these Olympics.\n\nLyles won the 100m, 200m and 4x100m relay last year at the 2023 World Athletics Championships.\n\nBut he finished second in his qualifying 100m heat on Saturday with a time of 10.04 seconds. He'll need a much better showing on Sunday to medal, much less take home Gold. Lyles will also run in the 200m on Thursday, an event in which he's heavily favored to win Gold.\n\nMen's 100m final best bet: For Sunday, the best bet, based on Lyles' underwhelming showing on {"uri": "8259151558", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "22:21:45", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T22:21:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T22:20:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://www.theguardian.com/sport/article/2024/aug/04/noah-lyles-walks-the-walk-to-become-undisputed-king-of-mens-sprinting", "title": "Noah Lyles walks the walk to become undisputed king of men's sprinting", "body": "The maverick American sprinter delivered on his fighting talk to win battle with Kishane Thompson in 100m final\n\nPerhaps the greatest tribute you can pay to Noah Lyles is that he really is as good as he says he is. First comes the vision. Then comes the pledge, almost as if he is trying to speak the vision into reality. Finally the delivery, the nuts and screws of cashing the cheques his words have already written for him. And in about the time it takes you to read this paragraph, he becomes the Olympic 100m champion.\n\nThe new undisputed king of men's sprinting is a kind of tortured genius, a manga and anime fan who likes painting his nails and his skateboards, who mentioned his therapist in his press conference, who understands better than most that the glory and the despair are basically two halves of a whole. Perhaps nothing captures this better than a final won by five-thousandths of a second, the breathtakingly cruel difference between Lyles and Kishane Thompson of Jamaica.\n\nIt was one hell of a fight, which is just as well because there is nothing Lyles likes better. In a sport of pure air and clean straight lines, perhaps the simplest sport of all, Lyles thrives on the thrust of conflict, the fast-twitch muscles of competition and confrontation, the salt of his haters' tears and the salt of his own. Often it is said of athletes that the first yard is in their head. With Lyles, it is more accurate to say that the first yard is in his mouth.\n\nHe has, for example, insisted all season on calling himself the \"fastest man in the world\" even though Thompson has run what remains the fastest time this year; who calls out pretty much the entire NFL and NBA for having the temerity to call themselves world champions. Who described himself before the last Games as the three-time Olympic gold medallist and made it his phone screensaver, shortly before leaving Tokyo with a grand total of one bronze medal.\n\nWhat changed? Perhaps we discovered this a few seconds into the final. He had already been edged out by Oblique Seville of Jamaica in the semi-final and Louie Hinchliffe of Great Britain in his first-round heat.\n\nWhatever aura he still possessed from his clean sweep at the world championships in Budapest 12 months ago, let's just say it wasn't entirely evident 40 metres into the race, with Lyles dead last and Thompson ominously taking to the front.\n\nThompson is 23 and yet, until this still-warm Paris evening, remained something of an unknown quantity. A product of the famous MVP club in Kingston, his coach Stephen Francis has made a very conspicuous show of holding him back, keeping his talent under wraps like a Formula One prototype. After running 9.92sec in the heats of last year's national championships, Francis withdrew him before the final. At other times, he has ordered Thompson to ease up after 60 metres which - in hindsight - might not have been the greatest idea.\n\nBecause at around 50m, the point at which Thompson is usually springing the knees high and opening out into his devastating drive phase, something began to malfunction. His head began to sway from side to side, the arms hanging a little loosely. In the biggest race of his life, in his first major championship, in a moment of stress few of us can imagine, Thompson was wobbling.\n\nAnd perhaps this, ultimately, is where those five-thousandths of a second can be found. Lyles has seen things. He has known the pain of defeat, the numbness of depression, the sting of rejection, even humiliation, and come out the other side. More importantly, this is a technique tweaked and honed in miniaturised detail with his coach Lance Brauman, a mindset forged in long and often difficult therapy sessions.\n\nThe arm strokes were perfectly clean, the head in absolute stillness, and his mind presumably in a similar state. Lyles ate up those final few metres, and then the final few centimetres, some deep competitive urge that simply would not allow him to be beaten. A pregnant pause. The eyes of the world on a little blue screen. Then the verdict. A scream from Lyles, followed by a tear down the back straight, chased by dozens of photographers, the biggest athletic mismatch of the night.\n\nWhat happens next is anyone's guess. Men's 100m champions from Jesse Owens to Usain Bolt have always been required to represent something larger than themselves, to be not just a champion but a figurehead, a polestar, a physical ideal and a relentless personal brand upon which tickets, hospitality packages and household items can reliably be sold.\n\nThis was a task too far for the defending champion Marcell Jacobs. Perhaps it came a little soon for Thompson too, an athlete still discovering the outer limits of himself, and who will have learned so much.\n\nFor Lyles, on the other hand, this is the role he always dreamed for himself. Through the tainted and confusing post-Bolt years, the brief interregnums of Justin Gatlin and Kerley, Jacobs and Christian Coleman, athletics has been searching - not without a certain internal contradiction - for a successor to its freakish once-in-a-generation sprinting god.\n\nAnd as the achievement began to dawn on him, Lyles began to slow a little. He stopped leaping and gurning for the cameras. He looked up at the stands and for a few seconds he fell completely silent, with all the solemnity of a man who has kept a sacred promise.", "source": {"uri": "theguardian.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8259096633", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "21:06:01", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T21:06:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T21:05:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://heraldcourier.com/photo-finish/article_9b9d9639-7461-56e9-93c3-dee89f9de994.html", "title": "PHOTO FINISH", "body": "Noah Lyles, of the United States, celebrates after winning the men's 100-meter final.\n\nEDDIE PELLS Associated Press\n\nSAINT-DENIS, France -- Noah Lyles won the Olympic 100 meters by .005 seconds Sunday, waiting some 30 seconds after the finish of one of the closest sprints in history to find out he'd beaten Kishane Thompson of Jamaica.\n\nThe word \"Photo\" popped up on the scoreboard next to the names of Lyles, Thompson and five others after they crossed the line. Lyles paced the track with his hands draped over his head. Finally, the numbers came up. Lyles won in 9.784 seconds to edge out the Jamaican by five-thousandths of a tick of the clock.\n\nAmerica's Fred Kerley came in third at 9.81. The top seven all finished within .09 of each other.\n\nThis was the closest 1-2 finish in the 100 since at least Moscow in 1980 -- or maybe even ever. Back then, Britain's Allan Wells narrowly beat Silvio Leonard in an era when the electronic timers didn't go down into the thousandths of a second.\n\nPeople are also reading... OLYMPICS: Johnson City-born Brody Malone helps U.S. get bronze in men's gymnastics team competition VHSL PRESEASON FOOTBALL PRIMER: Plenty of storylines as prep football begins in Virginia Antiques showcased at Virginia Highlands Festival HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL: Not yet 30, Norris achieves goal as Lebanon head coach The Big Tri City Fair looks to bring fun and entertainment PREP BASKETBALL: Field released for The Classic at Tennessee High HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL: Trust and obey; Former Sullivan East star now playing for the Hilltoppers HIGH SCHOOL BASKETBALL: Hart steps down at Honaker, not seeing commitment in offseason Badcock Furniture closing all its retail locations PRO GOLF: Runner-up for Connor Creasy (Abingdon) in PGA Americas Tour tourney in Ottawa HIGH SCHOOL NOTEBOOK: Wise Central's Emmah McAmis on Under Armour national title team; Some transfers and new coaching hires as well LOCAL MOTORSPORTS: Chilhowie racer knows the Bristol Motor Speedway experience Platter & Pour working to open State Street location Harshbarger defeats Lundberg in heated state senate race MLB: Evan Carter's back injury among Rangers concerns\n\nThank goodness they do now.\n\n\"I thought I had (him) cleared,\" Thompson said. \"But I wasn't sure. It was so close.\"\n\nLyles became the first American to win the marquee event in Olympic track since Justin Gatlin in 2004.\n\nThe 9.784 also marks a personal best for Lyles, who has been promising to add his own brand of excitement to track and certainly delivered this time.\n\nHe will be a favorite later this week in the 200 meters -- his better race -- and will try to join Usain Bolt as the latest runner to win both Olympic sprints.\n\nFor perspective, the blink of an eye takes, on average, .1 second, which was 20 times longer than the gap between first and second in this one.\n\nWhat was the difference? Maybe Lyles' closing speed and his lean into the line.\n\nHe and Thompson had two of the three slowest bursts from the blocks, and Thompson had what sufficed for a \"lead\" at the halfway point. The photo finish actually shows Kerley's orange shoe well in front of the line. But it's the chest breaking the barrier that counts, and Lyles beat everyone by a sliver.\n\nIt would take more than a mere 9.7(84) seconds to decide who would supplant Marcell Jacobs as the next Olympic champion.\n\nLyles patted Thompson on the shoulder while the wait grew -- from 10, to 20, then nearly 30 seconds. When the American learned he'd added this to the 100 meters he won at world championships last year, he pulled off his name tag and raised it to the sky, then brought his hands to his side and pointed at the camera.\n\n\"America, I told you I got this!\" he yelled into the camera.\n\nYes, he's the World's Fastest Man. Just not by a lot.\n\nGold (and bronze) for Ukrainian high jumpers\n\nYaroslava Mahuchikh won Olympic gold in the high jump for her war-torn country of Ukraine and, as a bonus, had company. Her teammate Iryna Gerashchenko won the bronze and the teammates hopped, skipped and jumped around the track parading their blue-and-yellow flags in a heartfelt celebration.\n\nMahuchikh needed fewer tries to clear the winning height of 2 meters than Australia's Nicola Olyslagers, and so, added the sport's biggest prize of all -- Olympic gold -- to her world championship and world record.\n\nKerr vs Ingebrigtsen is a go for heated men's 1,500\n\nThe best rivalry in track will culminate Tuesday when reigning world champion Josh Kerr of Britain takes on defending Olympic champion Jakob Ingebrigtsen of Norway.\n\nThey squared off in Sunday's semifinal, too, and Ingebrigtsen edged out the Brit, looking over to him twice as they surged down the homestretch, to win a race that felt like it meant more than it should have in 3:32.38.\n\n\"They should be expecting one of the most vicious and hardest 1,500s the sport's seen in a very long time,\" Kerr said.\n\nDid Ingebrigtsen agree?\n\n\"Depends who you ask, maybe,\" he said. \"I mean, racing is what you want it to be.\"\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9790103", "eventUri": "eng-9790103", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.2156862745098038, "wgt": 158, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "2024-08-444037846", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "03:53:49", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T03:53:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T01:30:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://www.timesfreepress.com/news/2024/aug/04/paris-olympics-roundup-american-sprinter-noah/", "title": "Paris Olympics roundup: American sprinter Noah Lyles wins historically close men's 100", "body": "SAINT-DENIS, France -- Noah Lyles paced on the far end of the track, hands folded over the top of his head, wistfully looking up at a scoreboard that would, sooner or later, flash an answer he's been seeking over three sweat-soaked years.\n\nWas all that toil since the last Olympics -- all the work on the practice track and in the weight room in the name of finding a centimeter here or a millisecond there -- really going to be worth all the trouble?\n\nTen seconds passed, then 20, nearly 30. And last, the answer popped up.\n\nYes, Lyles is the 100-meter champion at the Paris Olympics. The world's fastest man.\n\nJust not by very much.\n\nThe American showman edged Jamaica's Kishane Thompson on Sunday by five-thousandths of a second -- that's .005 of one tick of the clock -- in a race for the ages.\n\nThe final tally in this one: Lyles 9.784 seconds for gold, Thompson 9.789 second for silver.\n\nThe new champion, a 27-year-old from Florida, said that before he left for Paris, a member of his support team ensured him this race would be a squeaker.\n\n\"He said, 'This is how close first and second are going to be,'\" Lyles said as he pinched his thumb and his forefinger together so they were almost touching. \"I can't believe how right he was.\"\n\nFor perspective, the blink of an eye takes, on average, .1 second. That was 20 times longer than the gap between first and second.\n\nIt was so close, that when the sprinters crossed the line and the word \"Photo\" popped up next to the names of Lyles, Thompson and five others in the eight-man field, Lyles walked over to the 23-year-old Jamaican and said, \"I think you got the Olympics, dog.\"\n\nThompson, who raced three lanes to the left of Lyles and had no clue where he was on the track, wasn't convinced.\n\n\"I was, 'Wow, I'm not even sure, because it was that close,'\" the Jamaican said.\n\nTime would tell. It always does. When Lyles' name came up first, he snatched his name tag off the front of his bib and held it to the sky. Moments later, he shouted at the TV camera: \"America, I told you I got this!\"\n\nThe first four racers were separated by less than .03. The top seven all finished within .09 of each other.\n\nFred Kerley, another U.S. runner, came in third at 9.81.\n\n\"That's probably one of the most beautiful races I've been in,\" the bronze medalist said.\n\nIn the photo finish, Kerley's orange shoe crossed the line before anyone, or anything -- but it's the chest breaking the barrier that counts. Lyles' chest crossed first in he closest 1-2 finish in the 100 since at least the 1980 Moscow Games -- or maybe even ever.\n\nBack then, Great Britain's Allan Wells narrowly beat Cuba's Silvio Leonard in an era when the electronic timers didn't go into the thousandths of a second. The same was true in 1932, when Eddie Tolan won the Olympics' first photo finish.\n\nThe 9.784 marked a personal best for Lyles and made him the first American champion in the marquee men's race at the Olympics since Justin Gatlin in 2004.\n\nAP photo by David J. Phillip / U.S. sprinter Noah Lyles, in lane seven, wins the men's 100-meter final at the Paris Olympics on Sunday in Saint-Denis, France.\n\nOut of the pool\n\nNANTERRE, France -- The final night of swimming at the Paris Games stirred a wide range of emotions for an American team that no longer rules the world in the pool.\n\nA world record from Bobby Finke. Elation.\n\nA historic loss that reignited gripes about Chinese doping. Stunning.\n\nFinally, another world record for the women's 4x100-meter medley relay team to edge rival Australia for the top spot in the gold-medal table. Whew!\n\n\"Just an awesome way to cap off the meet,\" said Lilly King of the winning relay team, who joined her teammates in strolling around the deck holding up the stars and stripes as the crowd filed out of La Defense Arena.\n\nFinke set the standard in the men's 1,500 freestyle -- he touched in 14 minutes, 30.67 seconds to break the record of 14.31.02 set by China's Sun Yang at the 2012 London Games -- before the American women closed a thrilling nine days of swimming in style.\n\nThe U.S. finished with eight gold medals to top Australia, which won seven events. Still, it was the lowest victory total for the Americans in the pool since the 1988 Seoul Games, when they were beaten by a doping-tainted East German program.\n\nThis time, American swimmers finished with 28 medals overall, two shy of their total three years ago at the Tokyo Games. In all, 13 countries won at least one gold and 19 teams made the medal podium.\n\nAfter a bevy of disappointing performances by some of its biggest names, the U.S. team was very much aware of its gold battle with the Aussies.\n\n\"I knew Bobby had tied it up,\" King said. \"Bobby's swim was electric. That was amazing. He definitely got my energy going for the relay. I was pumped to hopefully assert that lead and get the gold.\"\n\nThat's just what she did.\n\nKing made up for a disappointing showing in individual events at her third and final Olympics by powering to the lead on the breaststroke segment. Then it was Gretchen Walsh and Torri Huske bringing it home in 3:49.63 to break the record of 3:50.40 set by the U.S. at the 2019 world championship meet.\n\nRegan Smith led off in the backstroke leg, earning a relay gold for the second night in a row after starting her Olympic career with five silvers and a bronze.\n\nAustralia (3:53.11) won silver and China (3:53.23) took bronze.\n\nChina stunningly won gold in the men's 4x100 medley relay with a time of 3:27.46, ending the American run of dominance that stretched back to the introduction of that event at the 1960 Rome Games. The Americans were left with the silver in 3:28.01, with France taking bronze in 3:28.38.\n\nThe only time the U.S. didn't win gold in the event was in 1980, when it boycotted the Moscow Games.\n\nThe winning team in Paris included Qin Haiyang and Sun Jiajun, both among the nearly two dozen swimmers who tested positive for a banned substance before the Tokyo Games but were allowed to compete. The result stirred more hard feelings from other nations that feel the Chinese might have gotten away with cheating.\n\nAP photo by Brynn Anderson / Lilly King swims the breaststroke for the U.S. in the women's 4x100-meter medley relay final at the Paris Olympics on Sunday in Nanterre, France.\n\nSame as always\n\nThe Americans continued their domination in women's basketball as they chase an eighth consecutive gold medal. The United States beat Germany 87-68 to extend its record winning streak to 58 consecutive games dating to the 1992 Barcelona Olympics. The team clinched the top seed in its pool as it moves into the quarterfinals.\n\nLee's latest prize\n\nAmerican gymnast Sunisa Lee picked up her third medal in Paris and the sixth of her Olympic career by grabbing bronze in the uneven bars, exactly where she finished in Tokyo three years ago. Lee was part of the gold-winning U.S. team Tuesday and two days later added a bronze in the all-around individual competition.", "source": {"uri": "timesfreepress.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "2024-08-444037716", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "03:53:31", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T03:53:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T03:10:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://weeklyvoice.com/paris-olympics-noah-lyles-clinches-thrilling-100m-title-by-0-005-seconds/", "title": "Paris Olympics: Noah Lyles clinches thrilling 100m title by 0.005 seconds", "body": "Paris, Aug 5 (VOICE) American sprinter Noah Lyles secured the Olympic men's 100m title, narrowly edging out Jamaica's Kishane Thompson by a mere 0.005 seconds at the Paris 2024 Games.Lyles surged past his rivals in the final metres, clocking a personal best of 9.79 seconds.\n\nThompson, making his Olympic debut, led for most of the race but could not hold off the charging Lyles, who showcased his trademark showmanship and finishing speed. Both athletes recorded the same official time, but Lyles was declared the winner.\n\nThe competition was fierce, with former world champion Fred Kerley of the United States securing bronze in 9.81 seconds, narrowly beating South Africa's Akani Simbine to the podium. The final was marked by an extraordinary level of performance, as all eight finalists finished within 0.12 seconds of Lyles.\n\nThe race proved to be a disappointment for Italy's reigning Olympic champion Lamont Marcell Jacobs, who failed to medal, and for another Jamaican rising star, Oblique Seville, who finished last despite a respectable time of 9.91 seconds.\n\nNotably, Great Britain's Zharnel Hughes and Louie Hinchliffe did not make it to the final, highlighting the high level of competition.", "source": {"uri": "weeklyvoice.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Weekly Voice"}, {"uri": "8259068005", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "20:28:14", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T20:28:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T20:25:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://www.thejournal.ie/noah-lyles-100m-olympics-paris-2-6455343-Aug2024/", "title": "American Noah Lyles wins men's Olympic 100m gold", "body": "WORLD CHAMPION NOAH Lyles roared to victory in 9.79 seconds to claim gold in a dramatic men's Olympic 100m final in Paris on Sunday.\n\nLyles became the first American, male or female, to win the event since Justin Gatlin won in the 2004 Athens Games.\n\nIn a photo-finish, Jamaica's Kishane Thompson claimed silver, just five-thousandths of a second off Lyles' pace.\n\nLyles' US teammate Fred Kerley took bronze in 9.81 seconds, just one-hundredth ahead of South African Akani Simbine, who timed 9.82 seconds.\n\nDefending champion Marcell Jacobs of Italy was fifth in 9.85 seconds, Botswana's Letsile Tebogo sixth in 9.86 seconds, American Kenny Bednarek seventh in 9.88 seconds and Jamaican Oblique Seville eighth in 9.91 seconds in an astonishing race.\n\nStarting in lane seven, outside Seville and inside Tebogo, Lyles got off to an average start but was soon into his stride pattern.\n\nHead tucked down through to the 40-metre mark, the American opened up, but the whole field pushed him all the way.\n\nAs Lyles dipped for the line with Thompson charging alongside him, the crowd erupted and a photo-finish was called before Lyles was confirmed as gold medallist.\n\nThere was an electric pre-race atmosphere in a 69,000-capacity Stade de France, a light show and booming bass-heavy music keeping the crowd entertained as the sprinters made the final adjustments to their starting blocks.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThe lights were then shut off, the sprinters leaving the track to remake their entrance like prize fighters in a colosseum.\n\nCalled out over the tannoy, each sprinter was individually introduced behind an image of their name above their flag.\n\nThompson roared, hands clenched in fists as his head rolled back. Kerley patted his heart.\n\nLyles bounded out like a kangaroo, bouncing 20 metres down the track. Jacobs was the definition of cool, raising both arms and calmly walking to his blocks.\n\nThen came the moment where the sprinters set, at the starter's beck and call.\n\nThe wait seemed interminable. The music continued, the crowd clapped in unison as if to hurry the starter, then the sprinters stood in their lanes, rocking from foot to foot and the tension was palpable.\n\nThe cameras panned one more and then it was time, the only sound that of a helicopter's wings whirring overhead.\n\nThe shot was fired and the field moved as if one up the purple track.\n\nThe photo-finish officials examined the evidence and Lyles walked away with gold to bury the demons of the Tokyo Games where he harvested a mere 200m bronze.\n\n- \u00a9 AFP 2024\n\nWritten by AFP and originally published on The 42 whose award-winning team produces original content that you won't find anywhere else: on GAA, League of Ireland, women's sport and boxing, as well as our game-changing rugby coverage, all with an Irish eye. {"uri": "2024-08-443903434", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "22:10:33", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T22:10:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T21:52:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://www.aol.co.uk/olympic-100-metres-champion-noah-215203702.html", "title": "Olympic 100 metres champion Noah Lyles feared photo finish had gone against him", "body": "Olympic 100 metres champion Noah Lyles feared photo finish had gone against him\n\nRachel Steinberg, PA, Paris\n\n4 August 2024 at 11:52 pm\n\nNewly-crowned Olympic champion Noah Lyles revealed he thought Jamaica's Kishane Thompson had beaten him to 100 metres gold following their photo finish in Paris.\n\nEvery occupant of the 80,000-seat Stade de France seemed to inhale at once before a roar erupted as the 27-year-old American's name appeared first on the screen, then announced to the stadium as the victor by just five thousandths of a second, a winning time of 9.79.784 seconds.\n\nThe 27-year-old rang the victory bell hard, fait accompli after setting out to settle the \"fastest man\" debate once and for all in France.\n\nLyles, whose US team-mate Fred Kerley took bronze, said: \"I knew that when the time came, for me to be able to say 'this is the final, this is where I need to put it together' I was going to do it.\n\n\"I did think (Thompson) had it at the end. I went up to him after, while we were waiting, and I even said 'I think you've got that, good going,' and then my name popped up and I'm like 'oh my gosh, I'm amazing'.\n\n\"I'm going to be honest, I wasn't ready to see it (his name) and that's the first time I've ever said that. I wasn't ready to see it.\n\n\"He was quite a few lanes down, he was in four, I was in seven so it was hard for me to picture where we were.\"\n\nThe American world 100m and 200m champion's triumph comes three summers after he entered the postponed Tokyo 2020 Olympics as the 200m favourite and world champion - but only claimed bronze.\n\nAfterwards, he opened up about a lifelong battle with depression and the challenges of balancing the benefits of antidepressant medication with side effects that led to weight gain and affected his ability to perform - ultimately electing to wean off the treatment before those Games.\n\nEarlier this week, he acknowledged he performs better in front of a full house, remembering the moment on the start line in Tokyo when he would usually say to himself \"it's showtime\", but instead found himself thinking \"this is not it. This is not fun. This is not cool. This is not what I wanted.\"\n\nLyles had no such trouble in Paris, where he thumped his chest at the start line and pumped up the electrified crowd, clearly revelling in the occasion, before they fell so quiet at the start of the race that it was possible to hear a plane passing overhead.\n\nThen the man whose weakness is often said to be his starts got off to the joint slowest, an 0.178 reaction time alongside Botswana's Letsile Tebogo.\n\nLyles, only learning that fact from a journalist, said: \"Slowest reaction time - that's crazy! I thought I was a little better than that but that goes to prove that reaction time does not win races.\"\n\nHe entered these Olympics with the third-fastest time at 100m this year behind Thompson's world-leading 9.77 and Kenyan Ferdinand Omanyala's 9.79, and as a result found himself in a position of needing to back up his signature bravado on Sunday night.\n\nThompson qualified fastest of the semi-finalists in 9.80, his compatriot Seville Oblique just behind him in a personal-best 9.81 and Lyles two hundredths of a second behind.\n\nOblique was the only man who did not have to wait for his place to be confirmed - the last-placed man in 9.91.\n\nLyles is in Paris with a point to prove, embroiled in a debate before the Games about who was currently fastest man on the planet - not that he ever had any doubts.\n\nThe Floridian - who is looking to do the double in the 200 metres - emphatically reiterated his answer, this time with his feet instead of his rhetoric.\n\nGreat Britain's Louie Hinchliffe (left) and USA's Noah Lyles during the men's 100 metres semi-finals (Martin Rickett/PA).\n\nEarlier, Team GB sprinters Louie Hinchliffe and Zharnel Hughes saw their bid for Olympic 100m gold come to and end in the semi-finals.\n\nHinchliffe said: \"It was a good experience, not the result that I wanted. Definitely a lot to learn. I haven't seen the race back.\n\n\"I am disappointed. The time is OK but it's where I finished in the race. I will come back stronger next year. I will not regress. It's my first year on the scene. There is a lot more to come.\n\n\"Definitely, definitely LA, I will be there (in the final). Next year as well. There are a lot of world championships between then and now. There is a lot of time.\n\nHughes has another chance to try for a first Olympic medal when the men's 200m heats begin on Monday.\n\nHe said: \"I am a fighter. I am very determined and that's why I wanted to give it a go. I got the training in but the races is what I needed to get me race sharp.\"", "source": {"uri": "aol.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo News"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8259087582", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "20:55:00", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T20:55:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T20:53:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://pantagraph.com/photo-finish/article_85ca37d0-18d3-5037-860a-4a0a5443d067.html", "title": "PHOTO FINISH", "body": "Noah Lyles, of the United States, celebrates after winning the men's 100-meter final.\n\nEDDIE PELLS Associated Press\n\nSAINT-DENIS, France -- Noah Lyles won the Olympic 100 meters by .005 seconds Sunday, waiting some 30 seconds after the finish of one of the closest sprints in history to find out he'd beaten Kishane Thompson of Jamaica.\n\nThe word \"Photo\" popped up on the scoreboard next to the names of Lyles, Thompson and five others after they crossed the line. Lyles paced the track with his hands draped over his head. Finally, the numbers came up. Lyles won in 9.784 seconds to edge out the Jamaican by five-thousandths of a tick of the clock.\n\nAmerica's Fred Kerley came in third at 9.81. The top seven all finished within .09 of each other.\n\nThis was the closest 1-2 finish in the 100 since at least Moscow in 1980 -- or maybe even ever. Back then, Britain's Allan Wells narrowly beat Silvio Leonard in an era when the electronic timers didn't go down into the thousandths of a second.\n\nPeople are also reading... J.B. Pritzker's odds of becoming Kamala Harris' running mate? Record of deputy who killed Sonya Massey should have raised flags, experts say Kamala Harris' little-known childhood connection to Central Illinois Funerals pending for Aug. 1 Flick Fact: The former Central Illinoisan now all over page 1?\n\nThank goodness they do now.\n\n\"I thought I had (him) cleared,\" Thompson said. \"But I wasn't sure. It was so close.\"\n\nLyles became the first American to win the marquee event in Olympic track since Justin Gatlin in 2004.\n\nThe 9.784 also marks a personal best for Lyles, who has been promising to add his own brand of excitement to track and certainly delivered this time.\n\nHe will be a favorite later this week in the 200 meters -- his better race -- and will try to join Usain Bolt as the latest runner to win both Olympic sprints.\n\nFor perspective, the blink of an eye takes, on average, .1 second, which was 20 times longer than the gap between first and second in this one.\n\nWhat was the difference? Maybe Lyles' closing speed and his lean into the line.\n\nHe and Thompson had two of the three slowest bursts from the blocks, and Thompson had what sufficed for a \"lead\" at the halfway point. The photo finish actually shows Kerley's orange shoe well in front of the line. But it's the chest breaking the barrier that counts, and Lyles beat everyone by a sliver.\n\nIt would take more than a mere 9.7(84) seconds to decide who would supplant Marcell Jacobs as the next Olympic champion.\n\nLyles patted Thompson on the shoulder while the wait grew -- from 10, to 20, then nearly 30 seconds. When the American learned he'd added this to the 100 meters he won at world championships last year, he pulled off his name tag and raised it to the sky, then brought his hands to his side and pointed at the camera.\n\n\"America, I told you I got this!\" he yelled into the camera.\n\nYes, he's the World's Fastest Man. Just not by a lot.\n\nGold (and bronze) for Ukrainian high jumpers\n\nYaroslava Mahuchikh won Olympic gold in the high jump for her war-torn country of Ukraine and, as a bonus, had company. Her teammate Iryna Gerashchenko won the bronze and the teammates hopped, skipped and jumped around the track parading their blue-and-yellow flags in a heartfelt celebration.\n\nMahuchikh needed fewer tries to clear the winning height of 2 meters than Australia's Nicola Olyslagers, and so, added the sport's biggest prize of all -- Olympic gold -- to her world championship and world record.\n\nKerr vs Ingebrigtsen is a go for heated men's 1,500\n\nThe best rivalry in track will culminate Tuesday when reigning world champion Josh Kerr of Britain takes on defending Olympic champion Jakob Ingebrigtsen of Norway.\n\nThey squared off in Sunday's semifinal, too, and Ingebrigtsen edged out the Brit, looking over to him twice as they surged down the homestretch, to win a race that felt like it meant more than it should have in 3:32.38.\n\n\"They should be expecting one of the most vicious and hardest 1,500s the sport's seen in a very long time,\" Kerr said.\n\nDid Ingebrigtsen agree?\n\n\"Depends who you ask, maybe,\" he said. \"I mean, racing is what you want it to be.\"\n\nLove 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your time and was widely expected to challenge Lyles on Sunday night on the purple tracks of Stade de France.\n\nHowever, the 23-year-old agonisingly missed out on the gold by a mere five-thousandths of a second.\n\nThe race was so tight that even the commentators almost miscalled the winner before the photo finish revealed Lyles as the victor in one of the greatest races in Olympic history.\n\nThe deciding factor was Lyles' precise lean at the line, with his torso crossing just ahead of Thompson's.\n\nAccording to Olympic regulations, the first athlete whose torso reaches the closest edge of the finish line is declared the winner.\n\nThis rule focuses on the trunk of the body, excluding the head, limbs, or feet.\n\nThis technicality secured Lyles the gold and the title of the world's fastest man, despite some online observers noting that other athletes' shoes seemed to cross the line first.\n\nThe close finish sparked discussions about the possibility of sharing the gold medal between the athletes involved in the photo finish, particularly Lyles and Thompson.\n\nWhen asked about this idea, Thompson provided a firm and unequivocal response, maintaining his stance on the matter.\n\n\"No disrespect to other sports, but I think our sport is too competitive for a medal to be shared,\" he said, as quoted by Fentuo Tahiru Fentuo.\n\nYEN.com.gh also reported that the close In a photo finish for the 100m gold medal, Lyles pipped Jamaican sprinter Kishane Thomas to clinch the title.\n\nLyles became the first American in 20 years to win 100m gold medal. The last American to win this crown was Justin Gatlin in the 2004 Athens Olympics and Maurice Greene in the 2000 Sydney Olympics.\n\nItaly's Marcell Jacobs was the previous 100m champion at the 2020 Tokyo Olympics in an event which was dominated by Jamaica's Usain Bolt from 2008 Beijing Olympics to 2016 Rio Olympics.\n\nFred Kerley won the bronze as the United States put two sprinters on the podium. Lyles ran a career best 9.784 seconds to earn the gold and will seek a sweep later this week in the 200 meters, much like Bolt achieved in the past. Thompson's silver is his first Olympic medal and Kerley took bronze in 9.81 seconds.\n\nIt was the closest 100-meter since at least Moscow in 1980 -- or maybe even ever. Back then, Britain's Allan Wells narrowly beat Silvio Leonard in an era when timing didn't go down into the thousandths of a second.\n\nLyles will be a favorite later this week in the 200 meters -- his better race -- and will try to join Usain Bolt as the latest runner to win both Olympic sprints. Defending champion Marcell Jacobs of Italy made the final but did not win a medal.\n\nMeanwhile, Jamaican sprinter Shericka Jackson pulled out of the women's 200 meters and will not race for an individual medal in Paris. While the broadcast never cut to the players in the stadium, some fans did spot them. They got to witness Lyles getting the win for the USA, securing the gold medal in the sprint.\n\nOne X user did point out that at the end of the race, when Lyles had secured the gold medal, Joel Embiid could be seen walking out of the stands, presumably to leave the stadium.\n\nLyles has been quite the controversial figure in basketball discourse over the last year or so. Lyles famously called out the NBA for calling their winners 'world champions', claiming that a winner of a national league cannot be considered world champions if they haven't defeated any international teams in the process.\n\nSeveral players responded to Lyles' comments, including Kevin Durant, Devin Booker, and Damian Lillard. Tyrese Haliburton actually went on to explain why the NBA calls winners 'world champions', as the NBA is the best basketball league in the world by some distance, and houses some of the best players all over the world.\n\nHowever, some players, like Giannis Antetokounmpo, actually agreed with what Lyles had to say. Despite the backlash, Lyles stood firm in his belief, especially as a track runner who competes on the world stage on a regular basis.\n\nThere is merit to both sides of this argument. In theory, Lyles is right because the NBA is a national league - the 'N' in NBA does stand for national, after all. But at the same time, the NBA is far and away the best league in the world, and the best team in the NBA can be considered world champions because they are the best team in the best league.\n\nNoah Lyles Is Public Enemy No.1 For Basketball Fans\n\nNoah Lyles made himself an enemy of ardent NBA fans with his comments, People were not happy with what he had to say about the league, and how dismissive he was about the 'world champions' title. While some of the discourse has been excessive, Lyles hasn't exactly warmed himself to fans.\n\nLyles even trolled Team USA last year, after their disastrous performance at the FIBA World Cup, where they finished fourth in the tournament after losses to Germany and Canada. It is clear that even after he made those comments, Lyles feels a type of way about the distinction of 'world champions'.\n\nUSA Basketball has a chance to get one-up Lyles in the Olympics, as they look to secure the gold medal for their country. After a perfect run so far, going 3-0 in their group-stage games, Team USA will face Brazil in the quarter-finals of the tournament.\n\nA win in that game sends them to the semi-finals, where they will play the winner of Serbia vs. Australia. Team USA will be confident about their chances against either team, as they defeated both teams in their showcase games in the lead-up to the Olympics, and even beat Serbia in their group stage opener.\n\nRelated: Team USA Spending $15 Million On 700 Rooms At Secret Luxury Hotel Outside Of Olympic Village\n\nThank you for being a valued reader of Fadeaway World. {"uri": "8259127455", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "21:48:40", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T21:48:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T21:47:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.615686297416687, "url": "https://www.stabroeknews.com/2024/08/04/sports/showman-lyles-wins-100m-gold-by-five-thousandths-of-a-second/", "title": "Showman Lyles wins 100m gold by five thousandths of a second - Stabroek News", "body": "PARIS, (Reuters) - After all the talk and all the hype, Noah Lyles duly delivered when it mattered most when he won a superlative Olympic 100 metres final by five thousandths of a second today to give the United States the title for the first time in 20 years.\n\nIn the most competitive final of all time, there was a blanket finish, with the stadium scoreboard initially flashing a photo to separate the first seven athletes and Lyles believing he had lost.\n\nHe was then confirmed him as the winner in a personal best 9.79 seconds, the same time as Jamaica's Kishane Thompson, but ahead by the width of a vest.\n\nIf the race had been 99 metres Thompson would have been celebrating a fourth Jamaican win in five Olympics, but fast-finishing Lyles kept his form superbly and timed his dip expertly to add Olympic gold to his world title.\n\nHe ripped his bib name from his shirt and held it aloft with his red, white and blue varnished fingernails, announcing himself, as he had always promised he would be, as the fastest man in the world.\n\n\"It's the one I wanted, it's the hard battle, it's the amazing opponents,\" said Lyles, the first American Olympic 100m champion since Justin Gatlin in 2004.\n\n\"Everybody came prepared for the fight and I wanted to prove that I'm the man among all of them, I'm the wolf among wolves.\"\n\nIt was the first time eight men have broken 10 seconds in a wind-legal 100 metres race.\n\n\"I am a bit disappointed, but I am happy at the same time,\" Thompson said. \"I wasn't patient enough with myself to let my speed bring me at the line, in the position that I know I could have gone to, but I have learnt from it.\"\n\n\"I know that Jamaica would have wanted me to get the gold, everybody love winners. I would have loved to win today, but big up to the whole field.\"\n\nAmerican Fred Kerley took bronze in 9.81 and Akani Simbini of South Africa was fourth, making it a remarkable six fourth or fifth-placed finishes in global championships, albeit with the consolation of a national record of 9.83.\n\nDefending champion Lamont Marcell Jacobs of Italy, heavily strapped, finished fifth in 9.85 and Letsile Tebogo of Botswana also set a national record with 9.86 in sixth place.\n\nSuch was the quality of the race, that eighth-placed Oblique Seville of Jamaica still clocked 9.91 seconds.\n\nSeville had finished ahead of Lyles in 9.81 in the semi-final when the American looked to be at full stretch.\n\nHowever, the biggest showman in the sport and the star of the runaway success Netflix SPRINT series, has become a serious championship operator over the shorter distance, having won three 200m world titles and bronze over that distance at the last Olympics.\n\n\"I think back to Tokyo when I messed up handling the rounds. From then on, I was like, 'I'm never going to do that again. I'm going to handle this correctly and practice over the years',\" he said. \"It's accumulated to this point.\"\n\nLyles, 27, is targeting a possible four golds in Paris, in the 100m, his favourite 200m, the 4x100m relay and, possibly, the 4x400m relay.\n\nThat would emulate illustrious compatriots Jesse Owens and Carl Lewis, who achieved the feat at a single Games but with long jump instead of the longer relay.\n\nFormer world champion Kerly ran an excellent race to add bronze to his Tokyo silver medal.\n\n\"That was a great race and anyone could have won it,\" he said. \"I feel that I executed as best as I could. I came here for the gold and nothing else but, hey, everybody came here for the same thing and only one can win. final photo deceiving world", "body": "World champion Noah Lyles roared to victory in 9.79 seconds on Monday morning (AEST) and there were just five one thousandths of a second separating him and silver medallist Kishane Thompson of Jamaica.\n\nThe world was forced to wait for several agonising moments before the technology showed the American's name on the top of the timesheet -- 9.784sec to Thompson's 9.789sec.\n\nAerial and side on photos, however, appeared to suggest Thompson was the first to cross the line -- thanks to his white track shoes -- with American bronze medallist Fred Kerley also crossing ahead of Lyles with his snazzy orange kicks.\n\nIt's left plenty asking why on Earth is Lyles celebrating his new title as the world's fastest man?\n\nThe answer is of course simple.\n\nAthletics results are measured by the first torso that crosses the line.\n\nAccording to Olympic rules, a runner is considered to have finished a race when part of their body from the clavicle down crosses the finish line -- something always considered to be the fairest measurement because of the different strides and leg lengths of runners.\n\nSo what separated Lyles and Thompson was the American's torso lunge to the line, while Thompson's dip was just slightly concave.\n\nBut his line-breaking right boot left plenty of Olympics fans convinced the Jamaican was robbed.\n\nThat doesn't in any way detract from the widely-held view it was one of the best races in the history of the Games -- the very first time that all runners went under 10 seconds (not including wind assisted races).\n\nThere were just 0.03 seconds between Lyles and the fourth-placed runner, Akani Simbine from South Africa.\n\nIt says a lot about how close the result was that a journalist asked the medallist if they should share the gold medal if measured at the same time to within hundredths of a second.\n\nThe other question, that keeps coming up is how did Lyles pull it off when he was so slow out of the blocks -- his reaction time of 0.178 seconds was the equal slowest.\n\nIt was only in the final 10m that Lyles edged in front.\n\nPhotos show he had a lot of work to do at the 70m mark.\n\nHe came home like a freight train, but looking across from lane seven over to Thompson in lane three it was easy to see why he thought Thompson had won.\n\n\"We were waiting for the names to pop up. I told him, 'I think you got that one'. I couldn't really see what was going on over there,\" he said as the world waited for the winner to be announced.\n\n\"I just had to keep running like I was going to win it. Something told me 'you need to lean'. This is how close first and second is going to be.\n\n\"It was a crazy moment. I did think that Kishane had that. I was like, 'I'm going to have to swallow my pride', which I don't have a problem doing.\n\n\"Everybody on the field came out knowing they could win this race. That's the mindset we have to have. Iron sharpens iron.\n\n\"I saw my name and was like, 'I didn't do this against a slow crowd, I did this against the best of the best, on the biggest stage with the biggest pressure'.\"\n\nLyles' whole career may boil down to that famous lunge for the line, but he says it's not something he has ever focused on.\n\n\"No, I do not practise dipping all that much,\" he said.\n\n\"I would say I have a decent history with dipping at the line. Throughout my high-school career and stuff like that, a lot of races have come down to dips. I've been able to win.\"\n\nBriefly, ever so briefly, Thompson thought the glory could be his.\n\n\"I couldn't see him, but I thought he was seeing me,\" Thompson said of Lyles.\n\n\"He said, 'Hey Kishane I thought you got it,' and I said, 'I am not sure'.\n\n\"This is the closest medal.\"\n\nIt was almost cruel for Thompson to be asked if the medal should be shared between them.\n\n\"I think the sport is too competitive, no offence to any other sport. It's too competitive for us to share a gold medal.\" he said.\n\n\"I'm feeling very good, honestly. My body language will not show it because I am not an expressive guy, but I am glad.\n\n\"I know that Jamaica would have wanted me to get the gold, everybody love winners. I would have loved to win today, but big up to the whole field.\"\n\nIn an astonishing race, defending champion Marcell Jacobs of Italy was fifth in 9.85sec, Botswana's Letsile Tebogo sixth in 9.86sec, American Kenny Bednarek seventh in 9.88sec and Jamaican Oblique Seville eighth in 9.91sec.\n\nMost of them will also be running in the 200m -- and the world will be desperately hoping to see The United States?\n\n\"Don't get me wrong. I love the US at times. But that ain't the world. That is not the world - we are the world.\"\n\nThose comments didn't sit well with several NBA stars, with a handful hitting back at Lyles' comments last year.\n\n\"Somebody help this brother,\" NBA superstar Kevin Durant said in the most condescending of ways.\n\nOn Monday (AEST) inside the Stade de France, Team USA sat in the stands watching the action unfold as Lyles dished it up to them in a savage display.\n\nThe moment wasn't lost on those watching on with social media losing it at Lyles getting one up on the NBA stars who had to sit and watch it all unfold.\n\nComplex Sports wrote on X: \"I know the NBA \"World Champions\" hate to see a gold medal winning Noah Lyles coming.\"\n\nOne account wrote: \"The fact that Noah Lyles said what he did about the NBA \"World Champions\" and then went out and got a World Champion Gold Medal himself is actually one of the most savage moments I've seen in sports.\"\n\nNBA star Josh Hart kept it real after Lyles' win as he wrote: \"Lol na he an Olympic gold medallist. He can talk for life.\"\n\nSome fans were quick to point out that Team USA are the clear-cut favourites to secure the gold medal in the basketball.\n\nWhat has been overlooked however is the irony will be that if they do they claim the gold, it will only further enhance Lyles' comments from last year.\n\nLyles can double down and walk away from Paris with a second individual gold medal in his pet event, the 200m.\n\nThe heats for the men's 200m will kick off on Tuesday morning with the final set to take place on Friday from 4:30am (AEST).\n\nWhether or not the NBA stars will be in attendance remains to be seen.\n\nThe only thing that would make this feud ever more delicious would be Lyles sitting courtside at a Team USA game with the gold medal around his neck.", "source": {"uri": "8259168987", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "22:49:27", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T22:49:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T22:48:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.615686297416687, "url": "https://www.foxsports.com.au/olympics/noah-lyles-wins-100m-gold-after-nba-sledge-world-champions-debate/news-story/c50ba6c45be08713415b3776454be5d2", "title": "'World champion of what?': Noah Lyles buries demons, dodges NBA firestorm with 100m gold", "body": "Noah Lyles banished his Tokyo demons -- and avoided a likely backlash over his now-infamous NBA 'world champion' comments -- as he stormed to Olympic 100m glory in Paris in his continuing bid to fill the void left by Usain Bolt.\n\nLyles followed up on his treble gold (100m, 200m and 4x100m relay) at last year's world championships in Budapest by winning the 100m at the Stade de France in 9.79 seconds in a dramatic photo finish.\n\nIt ended a 20-year wait for an American gold in the blue riband event. Justin Gatlin was the last sprinter, man or woman, to win Olympic 100m gold.\n\nWorld Athletics president Sebastian Coe has dubbed Lyles, whose contract renewal with Adidas this season was described as the biggest since Bolt's with Puma, an \"absolute rock star\".\n\nDread-locked rapper more than rock star, the 27-year-old American's efforts in the Hungarian capital were captured in Netflix's docuseries entitled \"Sprint\".\n\nA second season is being filmed with the Paris Games as the backdrop. The cameras firmly shine the spotlight on the self-assured Lyles, who looks more than ready to bring track back into the wider public consciousness and whose brashness was clear for all to hear in a litany of quotable soundbites in the first series.\n\n'WORLD CHAMPION' DEBATE IGNITED\n\n\"You have to have the mindset of a god,\" Lyles said of being a top sprinter in \"Sprint\".\n\n\"I'm a true believer in that the moment isn't bigger than me, the moment was made for me.\" While many pundits insist that such an outlook is hardly rare for elite athletes, there is no doubt his brazen approach rubs many other people up the wrong way, not least legions of NBA basketball players -- and their fans -- after Lyles had questioned their claim to be real \"world champions\".\n\nLyles made some inflammatory remarks during the World Athletics Championships when asked about he state of athletics on a global scale.\n\n\"You know the thing that hurts me the most?\" he began. \"I have to watch the NBA Finals and they have 'world champion' on their heads.\n\n\"Don't get me wrong. I love the US at times. But that ain't the world. That is not the world - we are the world.\n\n\"We have almost every country out here fighting, thriving and putting on a flag to show that they are represented.\n\n\"There ain't no flags in the NBA. We got to do more. We got to be presented to the world.\n\n\"I love the track community, but we can only do so much within our own bubble. There's a whole world out there.\"\n\nThe comments did not go down well with the NBA community, with many players -- including Kevin Durant, Devin Booker, Damian Lillard and Aaron Gordon -- hitting back hard.\n\nLyles may well have been setting himself up for more vitriol had he not saluted on his 100m favouritsm -- with some on social media turning on him over an underwhelming heats performance. However he got the job done -- albiet by 0.005 seconds -- and New York Knicks star Josh Hart tweeted Lyles could now \"talk for life\".\n\nLyles, who has openly talked about his struggles with mental health and depression in recent years, admits that his growing fame has become a problem in the Olympic Village.\n\n\"I've become kind of popular in the village and unfortunately that has come with its own set of challenges in being able to find my own space within the village, whether that's eating or training in the gym,\" he said.\n\nHis gold in Paris at least atones for his disappointing Tokyo experience, where he came away with a bronze in the 200m.\n\n\"That bronze still burns a hole in my chest,\" Lyles said.\n\n\"I will be carrying it around during Paris just to remind me that this is not the colour we are coming back with.\" Lyles, who suffered from chronic asthma as a child, insisted he thrives under public scrutiny.\n\n\"The more eyes on me, the better I perform, or at least that's what my therapist says. When the TV cameras are on me and people are there, I am not losing.\" The American is still hoping to complete an audacious bid for medals in four events in Paris, adding the 4x400m relay to his repertoire.\n\nHe ruffled feathers in the world indoors in Glasgow in March when, after claiming 60m silver behind teammate Christian Coleman, he was selected for the 4x400m relay squad that also won silver.\n\nIt was a call-up that left the US federation accused of favouritism. \"Let's just say a lot of people in the US were very, very, very upset that I ran the 4x400 and to that I would say, 'run faster, push me out!',\" Lyles said.\n\nBolt retired from the sport in 2017 having won 11 world and eight Olympic golds. Lyles, whose Budapest sprint double was the first since Bolt's at the Beijing worlds in 2015, said: \"Usain Bolt has done it and him saying to me that he sees what I am doing and he respects it, it is amazing.\n\n\"I am the guy who wants to move past being track-famous. I want people to see me on the track, but in GQ and my docu-series, and realise I'm a cool guy too.\n\n\"Medals are the first step because then people pay attention to you. \"Then you can go into different directions: fashion, music. You can start collaborating with other people, artists and the world.\"\n\nLyles arrived in Paris knowing full well that he needed to continue his fine form, simply because to continue garnering attention, he needs to keep winning medals -- the Olympics are the ultimate global championships for the American spectator.\n\nThat was Bolt's allure: his ability to dominate and win multiple gold medals at global championships.\n\nLyles has bagged one -- a real one. It was so close, in fact, that NBC's announcers thought someone else had won it. The race had to go to a review and Lyles was named the victor.\n\nLyles, who is from Alexandria, Virginia, ran a 9.79, tied with Jamaica's Kishane Thompson. But Lyles was five one thousands of a second faster, according to the official review.\n\nHe's an Olympic gold medalist in the 100m dash.\n\nThe race is one of the coolest in the history of the Summer Games. It doesn't get much closer than this.\n\n\"NOAH LYLES' OLYMPIC DREAM COMES TRUE! 100M GOLD MEDALIST,\" NBC wrote.\n\nLyles' Summer Games aren't over, either.\n\nThe American sprinter is expected to contend for the gold medal in the men's 200m dash later in the Summer Games. That race is set to occur on Thursday at 2:30 p.m. E.T. and it'll air live on NBC.\n\nBut for now, the United States can celebrate Lyles' win in the 100m dash. He's looking to become the 10th man to win the sprint double in the same Olympics, joining a group that includes Jesse Owens (1936).\n\nThat Lyles would be on the start line for this event in Paris was expected after he won the 100m in last year's world championships. But it was never guaranteed. Lyles has been open about his mental health struggles during and after his first Olympic experience three years ago in Tokyo. Lyles was a contender for the 100m but finished seventh at Trials and did not make the team. In the 200m, Lyles' specialty, he settled for Olympic bronze and then opened up to reporters about depression and anxiety. He had both as a child, and in 2020 he shared on Twitter that he had been taking antidepressants. Lyles, who has asthma, compared the isolation of the pandemic to almost being like a constant asthma attack. He was open, too, about coming off his medication because he felt it was negatively impacting his training heading into Tokyo.
