{"uri": "8259103601", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "21:14:00", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T21:14:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T21:13:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://metro.co.uk/2024/08/04/noah-lyles-reveals-told-kishane-thompson-olympic-100m-photo-finish-21359942/", "title": "Noah Lyles reveals what he told Kishane Thompson after Olympic 100m photo finish", "body": "The United States sprinter is the new Olympic champion following a dramatic end to the men's 100m final in Paris on Sunday evening.\n\nA photo finish was required to split Lyles and Thompson, who was the favourite heading into the race after his impressive time of 9.80 seconds earlier in the semi final.\n\nBut Lyles finished 0.005 seconds ahead of Thompson and the 27-year-old has now won the first Olympic gold medal of his career.\n\n'It was a very close race,' Lyles told Jamaican broadcaster SportsMax TV after his victory.\n\n'I'm glad I had Oblique Seville next to me because I was like, 'yo, I need someone to put that pressure on me early'. I know that in a lot of races he's been one or two lanes away from me and he's been able to be get out just in that acceleration phase and I've just been missing it. I was like, 'nah, now that you're right next to me I'll make sure I cover that'.\n\n'And then after I passed him I saw Kishane out there I was like just do what I do, hit my top-end speed, let it work.\n\n'To be honest, I didn't know if I had it. I leaned but I didn't know I had it.\n\n'Me and Kishane were at the end waiting for our names to come up and I came back and I said, 'I'll be honest, man, I think you got that one'.\n\n'But my name came up and I was like, 'oh my gosh, I'm amazing'.\n\n'I've waited a long time, I've seen Jamaican's dominate the 100m and 200m for so long and I remember growing up saying, 'when it's my turn I'm going to make sure that the US is on top'. And here it is, here's my time, my journey, my moment, it's such a beautiful thing to see.'\n\nIn a separate interview with the BBC, Lyles admitted he was frustrated with his performance in the semi final earlier on Sunday evening after he finished second behind Jamaica's Oblique Seville.\n\n'A guy in biomechanics comes down and before I came out here, he said it was going to be this much, that's how close it is going to be and gosh was he right,' Lyles said.\n\n'I had to take every round as it was and I was a little upset after the first round so I came with the aggression and after I ran that 83 and I was done with the aggression.\n\n'My sports therapist told me you need to let go, you're holding on. Let go and release it.'", "source": {"uri": "metro.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Metro"}, "authors": [{"uri": "chris_davie@metro.co.uk", "name": "Chris Davie", "type": "author", "isAgency": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://www.ibtimes.com/american-noah-lyles-wins-mens-olympic-100m-gold-3738886", "title": "American Noah Lyles Wins Men's Olympic 100m Gold", "body": "World champion Noah Lyles roared to victory in 9.79sec to claim gold in a dramatic men's Olympic 100m final in Paris on Sunday.\n\nLyles became the first American, male or female, to win the event since Justin Gatlin won in the 2004 Athens Games.\n\nIn a photo-finish, Jamaica's Kishane Thompson claimed silver, just five-thousandths of a second off Lyles' pace.\n\nLyles' US teammate Fred Kerley took bronze in 9.81sec, just one-hundredth ahead of South African Akani Simbine, who timed 9.82sec.\n\nDefending champion Marcell Jacobs of Italy was fifth in 9.85sec, Botswana's Letsile Tebogo sixth in 9.86sec, American Kenny Bednarek seventh in 9.88sec and Jamaican Oblique Seville eighth in 9.91sec in an astonishing race.\n\nStarting in lane seven, outside Seville and inside Tebogo, Lyles got off to an average start but was soon into his stride pattern.\n\nHead tucked down through to the 40-metre mark, the American opened up, but the whole field pushed him all the way.\n\nAs Lyles dipped for the line with Thompson charging alongside him, the crowd erupted and a photo-finish was called before Lyles was confirmed as gold medallist.\n\nThere was an electric pre-race atmosphere in a 69,000-capacity Stade de France, a light show and booming bass-heavy music keeping the crowd entertained as the sprinters made the final adjustments to their starting blocks.\n\nThe lights were then shut off, the sprinters leaving the track to remake their entrance like prize fighters in a colosseum.\n\nCalled out over the tannoy, each sprinter was individually introduced behind an image of their name above their flag.\n\nThompson roared, hands clenched in fists as his head rolled back. Kerley patted his heart.\n\nLyles bounded out like a kangaroo, bouncing 20 metres down the track. Jacobs was the definition of cool, raising both arms and calmly walking to his blocks.\n\nThen came the moment where the sprinters set, at the starter's beck and call.\n\nThe wait seemed interminable. The music continued, the crowd clapped in unison as if to hurry the starter, then the sprinters stood in their lanes, rocking from foot to foot and the tension was palpable.\n\nThe cameras panned one more and then it was time, the only sound that of a helicopter's wings whirring overhead.\n\nThe shot was fired and the field moved as if one up the purple track.\n\nThe photo-finish officials {"uri": "8259262147", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "01:14:29", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T01:14:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T01:13:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://www.hindustantimes.com/sports/olympics/noah-lyles-wins-100m-final-by-5-thousandths-of-a-second-usain-bolt-colosseum-captures-photo-finish-paris-olympics-2024-101722804869213.html", "title": "Noah Lyles wins 100m final by 5 thousandths of a second as Usain Bolt's Colosseum captures photo-finish at Olympics", "body": "Showman Lyles was seen wearing sunglasses, a hat and even a mask to reduce the unwanted attention he garnered in the build-up to the blockbuster 100m men's final at the Olympic Village. Making a sluggish start, the American clocked at 10.04 seconds and was behind Louie Hinchliffe, the British sprinter coached by Carl Lewis. Flashing his Team USA-themed nail polish and making signs like an elite WWE superstar, Lyles was nothing but a crowd-puller in the semi-finals of the 100m event at the Paris Games.\n\nALSO READ: Catch HT's comprehensive coverage of the 2024 Paris Olympics here\n\nDespite the massive hype, the 27-year-old capped off his second-sluggish start as the US sprinter finished behind Jamaica's Oblique Seville in the semi-finals. Two months before the Games, sprinter Seville stared down Lyles at the Racers Grand Prix. Seville again gave Lyles a death stare in the semi-finals of the Paris Olympics. What happened in the final after the showdown between the two sprinters is history.\n\nLyles emerged victorious in the closest-ever Olympic 100-metre final by five-thousandths of a second. In a photo finish, Lyles eclipsed Jamaica's Kishane Thompson with a personal best of 9.79 seconds -- the same timing as the Jamaican, only separated by the width of a vest. Interestingly, Lyles clocked at 9.784sec to Thompson's 9.789sec, although both sprinters were listed as 9.79sec after the nerve-shredding summit clash. American Fred Kerley bagged bronze in 9.81, and South Africa's Akani Simbini finished fourth in the final standings.\n\nWhat separated the gold and silver medallists in the men's 100 final at the Paris Games? World champion Lyles timed his dip to perfection to upstage Thompson by the barest of margins. If the dash had been 99 metres, Thompson would have sealed Jamaica's fourth 100m win in five Olympics. The men's 100m final was the blue-riband event at the Olympics during the Usian Bolt era.\n\nDubbed the undisputed sprint king, Bolt finished his career with eight Olympic gold medals -- one was later revoked as Nesta Carter was found guilty of doping. Bolt holds the world records for the 100m and 200m events. The celebrated sprinter shattered the world record by winning the 100m event at the Beijing Olympics. Bolt earned three gold medals (100m, 200m, and 4x100m) at the London 2012 Games and three at the Rio 2016 Games.\n\nThe invincible sprinter claimed his third straight Olympic 100m gold at the Rio Games. Bolt's 100m Olympic record (9.63 seconds) at the London 2012 Olympics is still untouched, and the sprint legend also holds the world record of 9.58, which he set back in 2009. USA's Lyles is eyeing to become the first sprinter to win both the 100m and 200m events at the Olympics since Bolt. Will Bolt's Colosseum capture another photo finish in Paris? {"uri": "8259564310", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "06:47:07", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T06:47:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T06:45:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://nybreaking.com/noah-lyles-was-dead-last-but-team-usas-track-star-rose-like-a-gladiator-to-win-gold-in-the-greatest-mens-olympic-100m-final-ever-writes-ian-herbert/", "title": "Noah Lyles Was Dead Last But Team USA's Track Star Rose Like A Gladiator To Win Gold In The Greatest Men's Olympic 100m Final Ever, Writes IAN HERBERT - Ny Breaking News", "body": "He arrived at this place like a meteor, entering the arena before his name was announced, jumping up and down on the court like a maniac. The others were getting ready and trying to calm their beating hearts. Noah Lyles was just flailing his arms to get the crowd going.\n\nThe problem with such an entry - one that transcends anything we've ever seen from the ultimate theatrical maestro Usain Bolt - is the potential for arrogance.\n\nLyles has been praising himself for so long that he has built a tower of pressure on himself that stretches all the way to the Parisian night sky. And for a long time, by the standards of this race of all races, it looked like it was going to come crashing down on his head.\n\nTen metres into this extraordinary Olympic final, he was last. Forty metres into it, he was last. And then, with the start that had always been his weakness, he rose like a gladiator, past two brilliant, unsuspecting Jamaicans who believed they could restore Bolt's spirit, to win the greatest, closest men's 100m final of them all.\n\nSome thought he had shown a genius by picking up the tape, although he himself did not find it that difficult. \"I thought I was leaning too late,\" he said. \"I don't practice dipping that much.\"\n\nNoah Lyles won gold in the best ever men's 100m final at the Olympics as he responded fantastically\n\nLyles won by five thousandths of a second to capture his first Olympic gold medal\n\nThe American star was full of confidence before the race and he managed to secure the glory\n\nYour browser does not support iframes.\n\nYour browser does not support iframes.\n\nYour browser does not support iframes.\n\nFor 15 enormous seconds, Lyles didn't know he had won and in the mist of uncertainty he was silenced for the first time. He simply stood on the shoulder of Kishane Thompson, the Jamaican who had seemingly won this, staring at the stadium screen as a seven-way photo finish ensued. And then it was confirmed.\n\nHe had won by five thousandths of a second in a time of 9.784. Only 0.012 of a second separated the eight who raced. Michael Johnson had predicted it would be 'the most open in 15 years'. And then some.\n\nIt is the 27-year-old's first Olympic gold. It is the United States' first Olympic gold on the queen's distance since Justin Gatlin in Athens in 2004.\n\nDon't be fooled by the pomp and circumstance of \"The Big Noise,\" as Lyles was recently dubbed on the cover of a magazine, or by the tattoo on his abs that reads \"icon,\" which he says reminds him of \"what I want to be known for when I die.\"\n\nBecause sports is a brutal equalizer. It only perpetuates winners. No one cares about your red-and-black painted nails and your rap playlist if you're not a winner. And everything about track and field is a precursor to this Sunday night, every four years. This race transcends everything.\n\nThat's why the bronze medal in the 200 meters that Lyles took home from Tokyo, where he wasn't even on the U.S. team, was such a disappointment to him.\n\nHe has carried that bronze with him everywhere he has raced as a memento of his failure, as he sees it, and he even showed it off at his press conference late last night. He had been battling demons before Tokyo and had come off antidepressants to get in shape.\n\nHe knew there were chinks in his own armor. Like Bolt, he's never been an exciting starter at this distance, despite all the work his coach Lance Brauman has done with him. He's been behind in his three 100m races here. There were delays on the track as they tried to get the house lights back on after the pre-race light show. A protester was escorted off the track.\n\nAfter ten meters of this extraordinary Olympic final he was last, but Lyles managed to win\n\nKishane Thompson looked to have won the race, but ultimately had to settle for silver\n\nTeam GB's Zharnel Hughes disappeared from view after finishing sixth in the third semi-final\n\nLouie Hinchliffe became the first athlete in Olympic history to fail to reach the final with a speed of less than ten seconds\n\nThe only clue Lyles gave about how he found grace under pressure as the race seemed to accelerate away from him came from advice his therapist had given him. \"You have to relax. Let go. Be yourself.\"\n\nIn reality, Outrageous Belief brought him home. This is a man who holds to a mindset that only the best athletes have, where losing doesn't seem like the remotest possibility. It also helped that he was in lane 7, away from the center. \"I couldn't really see what was going on out there.\"\n\nWhat a contrast to the fate of the Britons, mere mortals, who had competed in the semi-finals. Sheffield runner Louie Hincliffe, who had pushed Lyles into second place in the first round of the 100m, became the first athlete in Olympic history to fail to reach the final with a speed of less than ten seconds. Zharnel Hughes was eliminated after finishing sixth in the third semi-final, with a time of 10.01.\n\nThe final produced the best possible outcome for track and field. Lyles and his outsized ego can draw attention and money to a sport that needs them both, as Bolt and Johnson once did. The sport needs its egos.\n\nLyles declared last night, without any irony, that he now wants his own shoe. 'Even Michael Johnson didn't have his own sneaker.'\n\nHe's not done yet. He wants gold in the 200m, the 4x100m and the 4x400m and the description of the moment he saw he had won the race tells us he won't be lacking in confidence. 'When I saw my name pop up,' he said. Thompson had run impressive times in the heats and semi-finals, leaving many fans convinced he was the favourite.\n\nThe naked eye shows the Jamaican sprinter reached the line first, but after what looked like an extremely long wait, Lyles was awarded the win, sparking emotional celebrations.\n\nSo, how did Lyles win? Legit.ng explains.\n\nFirst of all, and for context, it is important to note that, save for the finishing line, Lyles did not lead the race at any point. In fact, at the 30-metre mark, he was the last one of the eight athletes. He rose to third at the 70-metre mark behind Thompson and eventual bronze medalist Fred Kerley.\n\nWith 10 metres to go, the world champion from Budapest was second to Thompson in another remarkable exhibition of his top-end speed. They crossed the line at the same time and were made to wait to see who had won.\n\nEnter technology.\n\nIn such tight cases, World Athletics employs the Total Athletics Operating System thanks to its partnership with Seiko, a watch company.\n\nThe technology measures athletes' times to the +/ -- 1/10,000th of a second by examining things like starting, timing, photo finish, wind measurement, and electronic distance measurement.\n\nThe photo-finish rule was used in the men's 100m final where \"a \"slit-video\" system scans an ultra-thin segment of the track precisely aligned with the finish line -- scans it 2,000 times per second, providing an unbroken image of each athlete crossing the line,\" as captured on World Athletics website.\n\nNow, and this is perhaps the most important part, Thompson appeared to cross the line first, but Lyles led with his torso, which is the body part used to determine the winner.\n\n\"The winner of the race is the athlete whose torso crosses the finish line first. Any other body parts that may cross before the torso, such as head, hands and feet, will not count.\"\n\nAs the debate rages on, Lyles will revel in his new status as an Olympic gold medalist. he {"uri": "8260092858", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "12:33:41", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T12:33:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T12:32:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://blackamericaweb.com/2024/08/05/noah-lyles-gold-medal-100m-paris-olympics/", "title": "Noah Lyles Wins 100M Gold Medal At Paris Olympic Games In A Photo Fini", "body": "Source: Alex Pantling / Getty\n\nOn Sunday, Noah Lyles silenced his doubters by proving he's the fastest man in the world.\n\nLyles clocked a personal best of 9.78 seconds to win the Gold Medal in the 100-meter dash at the 2024 Paris Olympic Games in a photo finish. He edged out Jamaica's Kishane Thompson by just 0.005 seconds. Lyles' teammate Fred Kerley earned bronze with a time of 9.81 seconds, finishing just ahead of South Africa's Akani Simbine, who completed the race in 9.82 seconds.\n\nRELATED: Saint Lucia's Julien Alfred Upsets Sha'Carri Richardson, Wins 100m Gold At The 2024 Paris Olympic Games\n\nRELATED: Black Athletes Shine At The 2024 Paris Olympics, Inspiring The Next Generation Through Representation & Resilience\n\nThis race marked the closest 100m Final in the Modern Olympics since the 1980 Moscow Games, where Britain's Allan Wells narrowly defeated Silvio Leonard for the Gold.\n\nLyles' victory also ended a 20-year drought for U.S. athletes in the event, with the last Gold Medal being earned by Justin Gatlin in the 2004 Athens Olympics.\n\nLyles had raised concerns about his chances when he lost his quarter-final heat to NCAA 100m champion Louie Hinchliffe of Great Britain. Lyles admitted to underestimating his competitors but told NBC Sports, \"I think I'm more excited now that I didn't win that heat. I'm pretty scared for everybody else right now.\"\n\nAnd his confidence was justified.\n\nOn social media, some were delighted to see Lyles falter in the prelims due to his controversial comments in August 2023 about NBA players being called \"World Champions\" after winning the NBA Finals. Lyles had stated, \"You know, the thing that hurts me the most is that I have to watch the NBA Finals, and they have 'world champion' on their head. World champion of what? The United States? Don't get me wrong. I love the US at times. But that ain't the world. We [World Athletics Championships] are the world. We have almost every country out here fighting and thriving and putting on a flag to show that they are represented. There ain't no flags in the NBA.\"\n\nDue to his outspoken nature, some hoped Lyles would not succeed. But now, he stands as the fastest man in the world.\n\nNoah Lyles Wins 100M Gold Medal At Paris Olympic Games In A Photo FinishSaint Lucia's Julien Alfred Upsets Sha'Carri Richardson, Wins 100m Gold {"uri": "8259086013", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "20:51:50", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T20:51:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T20:50:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://www.ocregister.com/2024/08/04/noah-lyles-wins-first-u-s-mens-olympic-100-gold-in-20-years/", "title": "Noah Lyles wins first U.S. men's Olympic 100 gold in 20 years.", "body": "SAINT-DENIS, France - Noah Lyles rocked back and forth impatiently in front of his starting blocks before the Olympic Games 100 meter final Sunday night and then took a step and then another in front of the starting line, as if he had waited long enough.\n\nHe outstretched both his hands mid-chest level, both palms up and curling his fingers back and forth in a beckoning movement seeming to say bring it on, bring it on.\n\nBring on all the doubts, the conventional wisdom that he didn't have the start to claim sprinting's greatest prize.\n\nLyles, fulfilling the promise the sport first recognized more than a decade ago, taking it all on, the doubts and the demons, won the closest Olympic 100 final in history by a mere by five-thousandths of a second.\n\nLyles, last out of the starting blocks, wearing custom-made gold adidas shoes, didn't claim the first Olympic 100 gold medal won by an American man since 2004 until the last step of the race, out-leaning Jamaica's Kishane Thompson at the line.\n\nBoth men were clocked officially at 9.79 seconds and it would be several moments before a review of the photo finish gave Lyles the edge 9.784 to 9.789.\n\nWith the victory Lyles, 27, kept alive his hopes of becoming the first man not named Usain Bolt to sweep the Olympic 100 and 200 titles since Carl Lewis did it in Los Angeles 40 years ago.", "source": {"uri": "ocregister.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Orange County Register"}, "authors": [{"uri": "scott_m_reid@ocregister.com", "name": "Scott M. {"uri": "8259881685", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "10:21:22", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T10:21:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T10:20:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://www.myjoyonline.com/paris-2024-i-battle-asthma-and-depression-olympics-champion-lyles-reveals/", "title": "Paris 2024: I battle asthma and depression - Olympics champion, Lyles reveals - MyJoyOnline", "body": "Olympics champion, Noah Lyles, has revealed lifetime challenges he's battled to become a world champion.\n\nThe American, who beat of competition from Jamaica's Kishane Thompson and fellow countryman and teammate, Fred Kerley on Sunday night to dethrone Marcel Jacobs in a nail-biting contest took to X to share his life struggles to inspire others.\n\nHis message was clear: obstacles don't define you. \"I have Asthma, allergies, dyslexia, ADD, anxiety, and Depression,\" he revealed on X. \"But I will tell you that what you have does not define what you can become. Why Not You!\"\n\nThe race was a nail-biter, ending in a photo finish. Lyles edged out his rival by .005s.\n\n\"We were waiting for the names to pop up,\" Lyles recounted. \"I even told Thompson, 'I think you got that one, big dawg!' But something told me to lean, and I did. It was that kind of race.\"\n\nThis victory marks the first time an American has won the 100m at the Olympics since Justin Gatlin in 2004. Lyles, however, isn't done yet; he's set his sights on the 200 meters, with hopes of adding another gold to his collection on Wednesday.\n\nFred Kerley, another American sprinter, claimed the bronze, adding to the USA's medal tally. For Lyles, this victory was more than a race; it was a testament to his belief in himself. \"I've done worse and I've run faster 60s. Ah, dang. Dang, I'm amazing. That's crazy. That's crazy,\" he said, almost in disbelief. \"I thought I was a little better than that. But that goes to prove that reaction times do not win races.\"\n\nIn the throes of his post-race celebration, Lyles removed his name tag and held it high for the crowd to see, a symbol of his journey Lyles paced the track with his hands draped over his head. Finally, the numbers came up. Lyles won in 9.784 seconds to edge out the Jamaican by five-thousandths of a tick of the clock.\n\nAmerica's Fred Kerley came in third at 9.81. The top seven all finished within .09 of each other.\n\nThis was the closest 1-2 finish in the 100 since at least Moscow in 1980 -- or maybe even ever. Back then, Britain's Allan Wells narrowly beat Silvio Leonard in an era when the electronic timers didn't go down into the thousandths of a second.\n\nPeople are also reading... It was so close.\"\n\nLyles became the first American to win the marquee event in Olympic track since Justin Gatlin in 2004.\n\nThe 9.784 also marks a personal best for Lyles, who has been promising to add his own brand of excitement to track and certainly delivered this time.\n\nHe will be a favorite later this week in the 200 meters -- his better race -- and will try to join Usain Bolt as the latest runner to win both Olympic sprints.\n\nFor perspective, the blink of an eye takes, on average, .1 second, which was 20 times longer than the gap between first and second in this one.\n\nWhat was the difference? Maybe Lyles' closing speed and his lean into the line.\n\nHe and Thompson had two of the three slowest bursts from the blocks, and Thompson had what sufficed for a \"lead\" at the halfway point. The photo finish actually shows Kerley's orange shoe well in front of the line. But it's the chest breaking the barrier that counts, and Lyles beat everyone by a sliver.\n\nIt would take more than a mere 9.7(84) seconds to decide who would supplant Marcell Jacobs as the next Olympic champion.\n\nLyles patted Thompson on the shoulder while the wait grew -- from 10, to 20, then nearly 30 seconds. When the American learned he'd added this to the 100 meters he won at world championships last year, he pulled off his name tag and raised it to the sky, then brought his hands to his side and pointed at the camera.\n\n\"America, I told you I got this!\" he yelled into the camera.\n\nYes, he's the World's Fastest Man. Just not by a lot.\n\nGold (and bronze) for Ukrainian high jumpers\n\nYaroslava Mahuchikh won Olympic gold in the high jump for her war-torn country of Ukraine and, as a bonus, had company. Her teammate Iryna Gerashchenko won the bronze and the teammates hopped, skipped and jumped around the track parading their blue-and-yellow flags in a heartfelt celebration.\n\nMahuchikh needed fewer tries to clear the winning height of 2 meters than Australia's Nicola Olyslagers, and so, added the sport's biggest prize of all -- Olympic gold -- to her world championship and world record.\n\nKerr vs Ingebrigtsen is a go for heated men's 1,500\n\nThe best rivalry in track will culminate Tuesday when reigning world champion Josh Kerr of Britain takes on defending Olympic champion Jakob Ingebrigtsen of Norway.\n\nThey squared off in Sunday's semifinal, too, and Ingebrigtsen edged out the Brit, looking over to him twice as they surged down the homestretch, to win a race that felt like it meant more than it should have in 3:32.38.\n\n\"They should be expecting one of the most vicious and hardest 1,500s the sport's seen in a very long time,\" Kerr said.\n\nDid Ingebrigtsen agree?\n\n\"Depends who you ask, maybe,\" he said. \"I mean, racing is what you want it to be.\"\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree {"uri": "8259120561", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "21:42:21", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T21:42:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T21:36:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6000000238418579, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/olympics/article-13708225/Noah-Lyles-rose-like-gladiator-win-greatest-100-metres-mens-final.html", "title": "Noah Lyles wins the greatest men's Olympic 100m final ever", "body": "Lyles won by five thousandths of a second as he claimed his first Olympic gold\n\nHe arrived in this place like a meteor, entering the arena even before his name had been called, jumping up and down the track like a man possessed. The others readied themselves and tried to still their beating hearts. Noah Lyles just twirled his arms around, whipping up the audience.\n\nThe problem with an entry like that -- an entry transcending anything we had even seen from the master of theatre Usain Bolt -- is the potential for hubris.\n\nLyles has been talking himself up for so long that he had built a tower of pressure on himself, stretching up to the blue Paris sky. And for a very long time, by the standards of this race of all races, it seemed to be crashing right down on his head.\n\nAfter 10 metres of this extraordinary Olympic final, he was last. After 30 metres he was last. And then, when the start which has always been his weakness was in the past, he rose like a gladiator, powering beyond two brilliant, unsuspecting Jamaicans who believed that they could restore the spirit of Bolt, to win the greatest, closest 100 metres men's final of them all.\n\nFor 20 enormous seconds, Lyles didn't know that fact. He was silenced for once. He just stood on the shoulder of Kishane Thompson, the Jamaican who seemed to have this won, staring at the stadium screen as a seven-way photo finish ensued.\n\nNoah Lyles won gold in the greatest men's Olympic 100m final ever as he responded superbly\n\nLyles won by five thousandths of a second as he managed to claim his first Olympic gold\n\nThe USA star was full of confidence before the race and he managed to secure glory\n\nYour browser does not support iframes.\n\nYour browser does not support iframes.\n\nYour browser does not support iframes.\n\nAnd then it was confirmed. In the stadium where Lyles made his 100m debut two years ago, and won, he won by five-thousandths of a second. Just 0.12 seconds divided the eight who raced. Michael Johnson had predicted it would be 'the most open in 15 years'. And some.\n\nIt is the 27-year-old's first Olympic gold. It is the United States' first Olympic gold over the queen distance since Justin Gatlin's at Athens in 2004.\n\nDon't be entirely deceived by the Lyles pomp and ceremony. The 'big noise' as one of the magazine covers describes his self-promotion, or the tattoo on his abs stating 'icon', which he says reminds him of 'what I want to be known for when I die.'\n\nBecause sport is a brutal leveller. It only sustains winners. No one cares about your red and black lacquered nails and your rap playlist when you're not a winner. And everything in athletics is a prelude to this Sunday night, every four years. This race transcends all else.\n\nIt's why the 200m bronze medal Lyles took home from Tokyo was a source of devastation to him. He'd struggled with demons before that summer, weaning himself off anti-depressants in an attempt to get himself in shape.\n\nBehind that monumental ego, he knew there were chinks in his armour. Like Bolt, he has never been an electrifying starter at this distance, for all the work that his coach Lance Brauman has done with him. He trailed in all three races which have delivered this gold.\n\nBut his belief saw him home. 'Everybody's healthy, everybody came prepared for the fight and I want to prove that I'm the man amongst all of them. I'm the wolf among wolves.'\n\nWhat a contrast this provided to the Britons who had competed in the semi-finals.\n\nAfter ten metres of this extraordinary Olympic final, he was last but Lyles managed to win\n\nKishane Thompson looked to have won the race but ended up having to settle for silver\n\nTeam GB's Zharnel Hughes vanished from the picture after finishing sixth in third semi-final\n\nLouie Hinchliffe became the first athlete in the Olympic history not to make the final with a sub ten-second speed\n\nBuoyed by the experience of pushing Lyles into second place in the first round and performing close to the limit of his best in the semi-final, Sheffield runner Louie Hinchcliffe could not make the greatest race. Hinchliffe became the first athlete in Olympic history not to make the final with a sub ten-second speed, finishing third in a time of 9.97 -- two-hundredths of a second off his personal best -- but still didn't make the final. It was a sign of what a night of speed this was going to be.\n\n'Maybe I should have been more relaxed,' Hinchcliffe said. 'I was a bit tense at the end.'\n\nIt didn't augur well for Zharnel Hughes, the Briton who won a semi-final in Tokyo and reached the final there. Hughes hadn't broken ten seconds all season and vanished from the picture after finishing sixth in the third semi-final, finishing in 10.01.\n\nThey picked purple for this beautiful, vast Olympic track as a reference to the lavender fields of the south of France and Lyles has the scent of much more than this. His race in Paris.\n\nHe covets gold at 200m, his bolthole and the 'wife' to his 'mistress' the 100m, as he likes to call it.\n\nAnd perhaps the 4x100m and 4x400m -- a harvest which would place him among the giants, Jesse Owens and Carl Lewis, crowned four times in 1936 and 1984.\n\nHis description of the moment he saw he had won this race tells us that he won't lack in confidence. 'To see my name pop,' he said. That was the margin between the American Noah Lyles and the Jamaican Kishane Thompson, who both crossed the line in 9.79sec. After a long wait, and plenty of racing hearts. Lyles was declared the winner.\n\nAnother American, Fred Kerley, took bronze in 9.81, with the South African Akani Simbine fourth.\n\nWhen Lyles won the world 200m title in 2022 he set his sights on a daring new goal: becoming a global star and influencer. It sounded like a preposterous dream. But then he won three gold medals at the 2023 world championships in Budapest. And, with the Netflix cameras and boom mics in tow, he also emerged as the co-star of the docu-series Sprint. Now, after this, everything is on the table for him.\n\nLyles had been last after 15 metres, his start less explosive than his main rivals. But over the last few metres he closed on Thompson in front of him before getting the dip on the line.\n\nWhen Netflix made Sprint, which has brought the adrenalised thrills of the 100 metres to an entire new audience, it never even bothered to speak to either Thompson or Oblique Seville. Instead most of its focus was directed at those with a star spangled banner on their vest, including Lyles and Kerley.\n\nIt meant that when the sprinters were introduced to the 75,000 crowd at the Stade du France with a dazzling show and the soundtrack of Kavinsky, Lyles and Kerly were given the biggest cheers.\n\nAs they were introduced, Thompson roared like the king of the jungle, while Kerley put his fingers to his lips. Lyles, meanwhile, bounded halfway down the track, hollering in excitement.\n\nNormally the sprinters do not have to wait long to start after that. Mandatory Credit: Yukihito Taguchi-USA TODAY Sports\n\nNoah Lyles made history at the Stade de France, crossing the finish line first in the 100-meter sprint finals with a time of 9.79. His career-best performance ensured that he finished 0.005 seconds ahead of Jamaica's Kishane Thompson to win the 100-meter Olympic title.\n\nAside from earning the gold medal, the American returned the accolade to the United States 20 years after Justin Gatlin won it at the 2004 Athens Olympics.\n\nFred Kerley took bronze with a 9.81, and Team USA's double podium was an amazing moment for Americans all over the world who dedicated their time and attention to the competition, as reported by Track & Field Gazette on X.\n\nThe 100-meter grid for the finals was confirmed following the semi-final heat 3, which included the top eight athletes with the fastest timings across all heats. Everyone on the track had an impressive resume, but they were all vying for the dazzling gold medal, which was being defended by Lamont Marcell Jacobs.\n\nKerley had the fastest response time when the race started, but the American was quickly overtaken by Thompson, who claimed the lead. The Jamaican prodigy maintained his form, but as they approached the final few meters of the race, everyone in the front row was uncomfortably close to one another.\n\nHowever, the fans at the Stade de France witnessed both the Jamaican prodigy and the six-time world champion cross the finish line in the exact same time, 9.79 seconds.\n\nBoth athletes were watching the huge screen, waiting for the final verdict, and Lyles defeated his young Jamaican rival by five-thousandths of a second to become the 100-meter Olympic champion.\n\nEmotions were running high for the Olympic gold medalist, who redeemed himself for his bronze medal finish at the Tokyo Olympics three years ago. This accomplishment was a significant milestone in Lyles' excellent athletic career, but his focus had already switched entirely to the 200-meter sprint.\n\nNoah Lyles has already silenced many skeptics and naysayers who questioned his performance in the 100-meter Olympic event. However, his objectives at the Paris Olympics are far from finished, as the athlete has set his sights on the 200-meter sprint.\n\nThe heats for the category begin in a few hours, and he will compete in Heat 6. {"uri": "8259515427", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "06:06:42", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T06:06:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T06:05:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "url": "https://www.indiatoday.in/sports/olympics/story/paris-olympics-2024-sprint-noah-lyles-100-m-gold-therapist-call-2576956-2024-08-05", "title": "How call to therapist helped Noah Lyles claim Olympics gold in Paris", "body": "After years of rebuilding his mental health, Noah Lyles reached the pinnacle of his sport, clinching the Olympic gold in the 100 meters on Sunday. A crucial phone call with his therapist after a tense semi-final round was instrumental in his victory.\n\nLyles delivered a stellar performance, winning the 100 meters gold by a mere five-thousandths of a second with a time of 9.79 seconds. The final was intensely competitive, with Jamaican sprinter Oblique Seville finishing last despite clocking 9.91 seconds. In the semi-final, Seville had outpaced Lyles, necessitating a shift in mindset for Lyles ahead of the final.\n\nParis Olympics 2024: India Schedule | Full Coverage | Medal Tally\n\nSpeaking after the win, as quoted by Reuters, Lyles detailed how he had a call with his therapist who told him to let go, relax and be himself in the final race.\n\n\"I wouldn't say nervous - I'd say I was extremely curious as to what was going to happen. That's how me and my therapist phrase it. I'm curious as to what I'm going to do, how am I going to pull this off,\" he told reporters.\n\n\"I came in third-fastest from the semis. I'm like 'This is going to be serious, this is not going to be easy'. And I had said OK, my therapist said 'You need to let go, you need to relax and you need to be yourself'.\"\n\nThe U.S. sprinter, who has openly shared his mental health journey, knew the importance of being mentally prepared. Lyles' familiarity with the highs and lows of his sport stems from a personal journey of overcoming depression, a struggle he faced three years ago. The three-time 200m world champion's journey hit a low point in 2021 when he failed to qualify for the 100 meters at the U.S. Olympic trials. Determined to become the fastest man on earth, he focused on rebuilding both his body and mind.\n\nThis victory in Paris marks the culmination of Lyles' relentless effort and dedication to his mental and physical well-being, underscoring the importance of mental health in achieving athletic excellence.\n\n\"I did this against the best of the best, on the biggest stage, with the biggest pressure,\" Lyles said. \"And I wasn't even entered in the 100 in 2021. You know, here I am, first Olympics in the 100, going around now the Olympic champion.\"\n\nLyles will now be in action in the 200 m event as he bids to complete a rare sprint double at the Olympics. {"uri": "2024-08-443888909", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "21:33:33", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T21:33:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T17:40:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "url": "https://siouxcityjournal.com/photo-finish/article_f5bccb50-274c-54f7-9ad1-da17257c5f2d.html", "title": "PHOTO FINISH", "body": "Noah Lyles, of the United States, celebrates after winning the men's 100-meter final.\n\nEDDIE PELLS Associated Press\n\nSAINT-DENIS, France -- Noah Lyles won the Olympic 100 meters by .005 seconds Sunday, waiting some 30 seconds after the finish of one of the closest sprints in history to find out he'd beaten Kishane Thompson of Jamaica.\n\nThe word \"Photo\" popped up on the scoreboard next to the names of Lyles, Thompson and five others after they crossed the line. Lyles paced the track with his hands draped over his head. Finally, the numbers came up. Lyles won in 9.784 seconds to edge out the Jamaican by five-thousandths of a tick of the clock.\n\nAmerica's Fred Kerley came in third at 9.81. The top seven all finished within .09 of each other.\n\nThis was the closest 1-2 finish in the 100 since at least Moscow in 1980 -- or maybe even ever. Back then, Britain's Allan Wells narrowly beat Silvio Leonard in an era when the electronic timers didn't go down into the thousandths of a second.\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nTom and Molly Bedell's West Lake Okoboji home sells for state record $9.5M Sierra signage going up at former Sioux City Bed Bath & Beyond 'We'll miss the place': Home on Sioux City's north side on market for first time in decades A shellfish guest: Chesapeake blue crab found at Sioux City Library Sioux City's original guitar hero to be celebrated with a three-night musical extravaganza A favorite Sioux City deli stages a comeback with a new lobby and full menu of sandwiches Olympic Athletics Results: USD's Chris Nilsen finishes 11th in pole vault group Elk Point man killed in North Sioux City crash Body found in Floyd River in Sioux City Police release name of man pulled from Floyd River Simon Max Kaplan Toast on Hill offering classy breakfast and lunch to Okoboji Lakes visitors 'Exhausting, heartbreaking, devastating': Racism at Wayne school pushes family out of Nebraska Five rescued after tree falls on Sioux City home; wind storm knocks out power, causes outages New Woodbury jail expected to be complete second week in August\n\nThank goodness they do now.\n\n\"I thought I had (him) cleared,\" Thompson said. \"But I wasn't sure. It was so close.\"\n\nLyles became the first American to win the marquee event in Olympic track since Justin Gatlin in 2004.\n\nThe 9.784 also marks a personal best for Lyles, who has been promising to add his own brand of excitement to track and certainly delivered this time.\n\nHe will be a favorite later this week in the 200 meters -- his better race -- and will try to join Usain Bolt as the latest runner to win both Olympic sprints.\n\nFor perspective, the blink of an eye takes, on average, .1 second, which was 20 times longer than the gap between first and second in this one.\n\nWhat was the difference? Maybe Lyles' closing speed and his lean into the line.\n\nHe and Thompson had two of the three slowest bursts from the blocks, and Thompson had what sufficed for a \"lead\" at the halfway point. The photo finish actually shows Kerley's orange shoe well in front of the line. But it's the chest breaking the barrier that counts, and Lyles beat everyone by a sliver.\n\nIt would take more than a mere 9.7(84) seconds to decide who would supplant Marcell Jacobs as the next Olympic champion.\n\nLyles patted Thompson on the shoulder while the wait grew -- from 10, to 20, then nearly 30 seconds. When the American learned he'd added this to the 100 meters he won at world championships last year, he pulled off his name tag and raised it to the sky, then brought his hands to his side and pointed at the camera.\n\n\"America, I told you I got this!\" he yelled into the camera.\n\nYes, he's the World's Fastest Man. Just not by a lot.\n\nGold (and bronze) for Ukrainian high jumpers\n\nYaroslava Mahuchikh won Olympic gold in the high jump for her war-torn country of Ukraine and, as a bonus, had company. Her teammate Iryna Gerashchenko won the bronze and the teammates hopped, skipped and jumped around the track parading their blue-and-yellow flags in a heartfelt celebration.\n\nMahuchikh needed fewer tries to clear the winning height of 2 meters than Australia's Nicola Olyslagers, and so, added the sport's biggest prize of all -- Olympic gold -- to her world championship and world record.\n\nKerr vs Ingebrigtsen is a go for heated men's 1,500\n\nThe best rivalry in track will culminate Tuesday when reigning world champion Josh Kerr of Britain takes on defending Olympic champion Jakob Ingebrigtsen of Norway.\n\nThey squared off in Sunday's semifinal, too, and Ingebrigtsen edged out the Brit, looking over to him twice as they surged down the homestretch, to win a race that felt like it meant more than it should have in 3:32.38.\n\n\"They should be expecting one of the most vicious and hardest 1,500s the sport's seen in a very long time,\" Kerr said.\n\nDid Ingebrigtsen agree?\n\n\"Depends who you ask, maybe,\" he said. \"I mean, racing is what you want it to be.\"\n\nLove\n\n0\n\nFunny\n\n0\n\nWow\n\n0\n\nSad\n\n0\n\nAngry\n\n0\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local {"uri": "8259569677", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "06:51:19", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T06:51:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T06:50:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://www.pulsesports.ng/athletics/story/ill-remember-that-in-paris-noah-lyles-delivers-on-his-promise-to-oblique-seville-with-astonishing-olympic-100m-gold-2024080501523085413", "title": "'I'll remember that in Paris' - Noah Lyles delivers on his promise to Oblique Seville with astonishing Olympic 100m gold", "body": "Two months ago, Oblique Seville stared down Noah Lyles at the Racers Grand Prix and Noah Lyles made it known he wouldn't forget to return the gesture in Paris. The American delivered on this promise with the Olympic gold medal, while the Jamaican speedster finished last.\n\nNoah Lyles has fulfilled his promise to Oblique Seville, following his astonishing victory to win the Olympic 100m in Paris, while the Jamaican finished last.\n\nTheir fierce rivalry began at the Racers Grand Prix in June, when Seville claimed a famous win over the American champion in a new Personal Best (PB), Meeting Record (MR), and a then world-leading time of 9.82s, as Lyles finished closely behind in 9.85s.\n\nTaking the memorable victory on home soil, the Jamaican looked over at Lyles before the finish line, which became a viral jest of defeating him in a race. This moment riled up the six-time world champion and he'll later send a message to Seville on his X page.\n\n\"Oh yah... I'll remember this! See you in Paris @ObliqueSeville,\" he wrote.\n\nWith the open call-out, a rivalry was established with Lyles was under the obligation to deliver on his promise by getting an act of revenge against the Jamaican speedster.\n\nThe 100m semifinals in Paris will be their first clash since their last viral moment. This time, Seville had the edge again blazing to a new PB of 9.81s to Lyles's 9.83s, with both incidentally doing the same gesture to each other crossing the finish line to make the final.\n\nConsequently, when it mattered most competing for the ultimate price, Lyles surpassed all expectations and proved why he will always be the man to beat, as he produced his best career performance for victory to win USA's first men's Olympic 100m title in 20 years since Justin Gatlin.\n\nThe American speedster saved his best 100m race for the last, storming to the finish line in a new PB of 9.79s for his first Olympic gold medal ahead of Kishane Thompson in an identical time. However, Lyles had the edge by a reaction of 0.005.\n\nFred Kerley resurfaced on why he's a former world champion by claiming the bronze medal in 9.81s. Meanwhile, Seville couldn't replicate his best season's performances, dropping dead last in 9.91s.\n\nLyles backed up his promise with an astounding victory and come what may, the American track star will surely be in the limelight as always the man to beat for many years coming.", "source": {"uri": "pulsesports.ng", "dataType": "news", "title": "Pulse Sports Nigeria"}, "authors": [], "concepts": He was ready for this moment.", "body": "SAINT-DENIS, France -- Eight of the fastest men in the world got ready to line up. When the gun went off, Noah Lyles illustrated in 9.79 (.784) seconds that he's the fastest man in the world -- and the most equipped to handle the moment.\n\n\"Everybody on the field came out knowing they could win this race. That's the mindset we have to have,\" Lyles said after winning the Olympic 100 final. \"Iron sharpens iron. It wasn't no slow year in the 100.\"\n\nLyles told USA TODAY Sports that the disappointment of only earning a bronze medal in the 200 at the Tokyo Olympics \"ignited a fire\" within him. But he was pipped at the line by Noah Lyles of the United States, who ran a similar time of 9.79 seconds.\n\nThe Jamaican and the American were separated by 5000th of a second in a photo finish with Lyles clocking 9.79 (.784) compared to Thompson's 9.79 (.789).\n\nPhoto finish of the Olympic men's 100m finals. (Photo: the Olympics)\n\nSpeaking with Nationwide's sports editor, Wayne Walker, after the race, Thompson says he's 'grateful' to have become an Olympic silver medallist while remaining injury free.\n\nThompson said he was impatient in crossing the line in Paris.\n\nThe 23-year-old says he has no regrets about the outcome of the 100m finals.\n\nKishane Thompson, Olympic 100m silver medallist.\n\nThompson's silver medal is the first medal for a Jamaican man at a major global event since Usain Bolt won bronze in the 100m at the World Championships in 2017.\n\nMeanwhile, Lyles won the first Olympic gold medal for a US man since Justin Gatlin won gold at the 2004 Olympics. Usain Bolt in 2008, 2012 and 2016 and Italy's Marcell Jacobs at the 2020 event have won the Olympic medals since.\n\nLyles' countryman Fred Kerley won the bronze in a season's best time of 9.81 seconds.\n\nJamaica's Oblique Seville, who entered the final as a medal contender, appeared to have re-aggravated a groin injury, slowing to finish in eight place in a time of 9.91 seconds.\n\nSouth Africa's Akani Simbine finished fourth in a time of 9.82 seconds to set a new national record. The defending Olympic champion, Jacobs finished fifth in season's best 9.85 seconds.\n\nBotswana's Letsile Tebogo set a new national record of 9.86 seconds for sixth while the third American in the race Kenneth Bednarek clocked 9.88 seconds to finish in seventh.\n\nJamaica now has three medals in Paris. Triple jumper, Shanieka Ricketts, also won silver in the women's event on Saturday to become the first woman to win a medal in a field event for Jamaica at the Olympics.\n\nAnd national record holder and national champion in the shot put, Rajindra Campbell, won bronze in the event on Saturday. {"uri": "8259053976", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "20:09:26", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T20:09:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T20:08:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://www.foxnews.com/sports/usa-sprinter-noah-lyles-wins-first-olympic-gold-epic-mens-100m-final", "title": "USA sprinter Noah Lyles wins first Olympic gold in epic men's 100M final", "body": "After dominating the world championships last year, Noah Lyles finally has his Olympic gold medal.\n\nAfter talking the talk for quite some time, the Gainesville, Fla., native is now walking the walk, as he won the men's 100-meter final on Sunday in Paris.\n\nLyles crossed the finish line in 9.79784 seconds, a personal best, and winning by five-thousandths of a second.\n\nCLICK HERE FOR MORE SPORTS COVERAGE ON FOXNEWS.COM\n\nA long photo finish review was necessary to officially crown Lyles champion, as he looked on intently alongside Jamaican Kishane Thompson.\n\nLyles is the first American to win the event at the Olympics since Justin Gatlin did so in 2004. It's the fifth gold medal won by Americans on Sunday (golfer Scottie Scheffler, cyclist Kristen Faulkner, swimmer Bobby Finke, and the women's 4x100 medley relay team).\n\nThe 27-year-old ran a 9.83 in the semifinal, automatically qualifying by finishing second in that race. He caught some flack on Saturday for finishing in second place in a heat, saying that his \"plan\" was to finish in first from there on out. That didn't happen - but it'll all be forgotten about now, as he finished first when it mattered most.\n\nOf course, some will argue he brought the hate upon himself when he quipped that NBA champions do not have the right to call themselves world champions. That comment alone has caused him to be hated by American sports fans just as much, maybe more, than he is loved by them. But, perhaps this victory can change the tide.\n\nUS WOMEN'S 4X100M MEDLEY RELAY TEAM WINS GOLD, SETS WORLD RECORD IN LAST OLYMPIC SWIMMING EVENT OF PARIS GAMES\n\nLyles will now turn his focus on the 200m (he's said his \"dream goal\" is to break Usain Bolt's world record of 19.19) and the 4x100m relay. It remains up in the air about whether he will be part of the 4x400m relay, but he was a part of the silver-medal winning team at this year's world indoor championships.\n\nIn an interview with Fox News Digital back in March, Lyles said a friend told him, \"'Forget three, you need to go after four. Do something no one's ever done.'\"\n\n\"When you want to talk about being the greatest, that's what you have to achieve. So, I announced that that is a goal of mine to complete; why not do it on the biggest stage, the Olympics?\" Lyles said of a potential fourth Olympic event.\n\nTrack legend Carl Lewis recently told Fox News Digital that the sport \"needs\" Lyles to dominate these games.\n\n\"I think the sport needs someone like him that's a champion. He's the defending champion, the fastest man in the world right now, and we need someone to grab onto. I think he's the perfect guy to do that, and I'm excited about that,\" Lewis told Fox News Digital in a recent interview.\n\nCLICK HERE TO GET THE FOX NEWS APP\n\n\"I think track does better when we do have a superstar. That's why I think if Noah were to win, he would elevate the sport as well. As opposed to saying 'I wonder who's going to win,' people want to say 'I want him' or 'I don't want him.' They want to root for someone, or root against someone. I think it creates more intensity when you have someone that dominates, and that's been throughout history. . . . {"uri": "8259905193", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "10:36:09", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T10:36:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T10:35:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://www.irishnews.com/sport/olympic-champion-noah-lyles-reveals-he-thought-kishane-thompson-had-him-in-photo-finish-100-metre-victory-XNKHIWVCNNBS7D5TIUPJVPWTMQ/", "title": "Olympic Champion Noah Lyles reveals he thought Kishane Thompson \"had him\" in photo finish 100 metre victory", "body": "The US champion edged the Jamaican by just by just five thousandths of a second.\n\nUSA's Noah Lyles, the newly-crowned US Olympic champion revealed he thought Jamaica's Kishane Thompson had beaten him to 100 metres gold following their photo finish in Paris.\n\nEvery fan in the Stade de France waited in anticipation for the final results before Lyles was announced as the winner by just five thousandths of a second, with a winning time of 9.79.784 seconds.\n\nSharing his thoughts following his victory, Lyles said: \"I knew that when the time came, for me to be able to say 'this is the final, this is where I need to put it together' I was going to do it.\"\n\n\"I did think (Thompson) had it at the end. I went up to him after, while we were waiting, and I even said 'I think you've got that, good going,' and then my name popped up and I'm like 'oh my gosh, I'm amazing'.\"\n\n\"I'm going to be honest, I wasn't ready to see it (his name) and that's the first time I've ever said that. I wasn't ready to see it,\" he said.\n\n\"He was quite a few lanes down, he was in four, I was in seven so it was hard for me to picture where we were.\"\n\nThe 2023 Budapest world 100m and 200m champion has triumphed after only attaining bronze in his previous Olympics appearance in Tokyo's 200m event.\n\nLyles shared his struggles with depression and balancing antidepressants and their benefits with their negative side effects, such as weight gain affecting his performance which led him to wean of the treatment before the competition.\n\nDuring the event's build-up, the Gold Medallist revealed his difficulties in Tokyo, informing media: \"Usually I would say to myself, 'it's showtime' but I found myself thinking 'this is not it. This is not fun. This is not cool. This is not what I wanted.'\"\n\nLyles had seemingly conquered his adversity in Paris, thumping his chest at the start line and pumping up the electrified crowd, clearly revelling in the moment.\n\nThe American got off to the joint slowest start, with an 0.178 reaction time alongside Botswana's Letsile Tebogo.\n\nAfter being informed of this compelling detail, Lyles said: \"Slowest reaction time - that's crazy! I thought I was a little better than that but that goes to prove that reaction time does not win races.\"\n\nLyle entered the Olympics with the third-fastest time at 100m this year behind Thompson's world-leading 9.77 and Kenyan Ferdinand Omanyala's 9.79.\n\nThompson qualified fastest of the semi-finalists in 9.80, his compatriot Seville Oblique just behind him in a personal-best 9.81 and Lyles two hundredths of a second behind. Oblique was the only man who did not have to wait for his place to be confirmed - the last-placed man in 9.91.\n\nThe Floridian will be looking to do the double in the 200 metres when he competes in the event's heats stages at 6.55pm on Monday 5 August.\n\nTeam GB sprinter Louie Hinchliffe, who alongside Zharnel Hughes, saw his bid for Olympic 100m gold come to an end in the semi-finals said: \"It was a good experience, not the result that I wanted. Definitely a lot to learn. I haven't seen the race back.\n\n\"I am disappointed. The time is OK but it's where I finished in the race. I will come back stronger next year. I will not regress. It's my first year on the scene. There is a lot more to come.\"\n\n\"Definitely, definitely LA, I will be there (in the final). Next year as well. There are a lot of world championships between then and now. There is a lot of time.\"\n\nHughes has another chance to try for a first Olympic medal when the men's 200m heats begin on Monday.\n\nHe said: \"I am a fighter. I am very determined and that's why I wanted to give it a go. {"uri": "8260053965", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "12:09:38", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T12:09:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T12:08:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://www.indiatoday.in/sports/olympics/story/paris-olympics-noah-lyles-kishane-thompson-photo-finish-100m-final-rules-explained-2577227-2024-08-05", "title": "Explained: How Noah Lyles beat Thompson for Gold in closest Olympic 100m final", "body": "It was the closest men's 100m final in modern Olympic history as Paris 2024 witnessed one of the greatest races on Sunday, August 5. USA's Noah Lyles defeated Jamaica's Kishane Thompson by a fraction of a second, 0.005 seconds to be precise to bag the title of the fastest man going around.\n\nIt was a sensational photo finish as Noah Lyles came back from behind to win the Olympic men's 100m title. The difference between Gold medalist Noah Lyles and Oblique Seville was just 0.22 seconds.\n\nNoah Lyles was the slowest to get off the block and the last amongst the 8 runners at the 30m mark. However, the world 100m and 200m champion kicked on and edged Kishane Thompson, who topped the semi-finals, by a whisker. The victory was sealed by the barest of margins in a spectacular photo finish.\n\nParis Olympics, Day 9 Highlights | Full Schedule | Medal Table\n\nIt appeared that Kishane Thompson's boot went past the finish line first, but Lyles aced the finishing position, getting his torso ahead. The crowd at the Stade de France held its breath along with the runners to learn the result of the men's 100m race after the photo finish. They were made to wait for a few seconds before the official result was displayed on the big screen, much to the delight of Lyles and the American fans in Paris.\n\nWondering how Noah Lyles won the Gold? Not able to decipher the positions from the photo finish? Don't worry. Read on.\n\nInitially, it appeared that Thompson might have won, but after a thorough review of the photo finish images, Lyles was declared the winner with a time of 9.79 seconds, just five-thousandths of a second ahead of Thompson. This victory highlighted the rules governing photo finishes in athletics and the most critical aspect of it -- the torso crossing the finish line first.\n\n1. Slit-Video System: The primary technology used to determine the winner in a photo finish is the slit-video system. This system scans an ultra-thin segment of the track precisely aligned with the finish line, capturing images 2,000 times per second. This provides an unbroken image of each athlete crossing the line, which is then coordinated with the athlete's time.\n\n2. Backup Camera: In addition to the slit-video system, there is a backup camera positioned on the other side of the field. This camera ensures that the finish is captured even if a runner is obscured by another athlete.\n\n3. Flash Timer: The flash timer, which clocks the final times of athletes, has a margin of error. At worst, this error can be within 0.01 or 0.02 of the official time. This margin is crucial in extremely close finishes like the one between Lyles and Thompson.\n\n4. Torso Crossing: The most critical aspect of a photo finish is the body part that must cross the finish line. According to Olympic rules, it is the torso (or trunk) of the athlete that must cross the line, not the head, arms, legs, or feet. This is why some runners lean forward when crossing the line, ensuring their torso crosses first.\n\n5. Diving Across the Finish Line: While it is legal for runners to dive across the finish line, it is not significantly faster than running the last few steps. Studies have shown that acceleration decreases while a runner is in the air, making diving less effective than it might seem.\n\n6. Review Process: In the event of a close finish, officials review the images captured by the slit-video system and backup camera to determine the winner. This review process ensures that the athlete who crosses the finish line first, as defined by the torso crossing, is declared the winner.\n\nNoah Lyles, who has proved his mettle at the biggest stage, will now be favourites to win the sprint double in Paris.", "source": {"uri": "indiatoday.in", "dataType": "news", "title": "India Today"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8259091376", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "21:00:47", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T21:00:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T20:59:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5843137502670288, "url": "https://lacrossetribune.com/photo-finish/article_1c382f14-8f57-508d-a610-a9e841921d48.html", "title": "PHOTO FINISH", "body": "Noah Lyles, of the United States, celebrates after winning the men's 100-meter final.\n\nEDDIE PELLS Associated Press\n\nSAINT-DENIS, France -- Noah Lyles won the Olympic 100 meters by .005 seconds Sunday, waiting some 30 seconds after the finish of one of the closest sprints in history to find out he'd beaten Kishane Thompson of Jamaica.\n\nThe word \"Photo\" popped up on the scoreboard next to the names of Lyles, Thompson and five others after they crossed the line. Lyles paced the track with his hands draped over his head. Finally, the numbers came up. Lyles won in 9.784 seconds to edge out the Jamaican by five-thousandths of a tick of the clock.\n\nAmerica's Fred Kerley came in third at 9.81. The top seven all finished within .09 of each other.\n\nThis was the closest 1-2 finish in the 100 since at least Moscow in 1980 -- or maybe even ever. Back then, Britain's Allan Wells narrowly beat Silvio Leonard in an era when the electronic timers didn't go down into the thousandths of a second.\n\nPeople are also reading... Onalaska man faces felony charge after injury hit-and-run in La Crosse New public hearing date set to discuss overnight unsheltered sleeping areas in La Crosse Valley View Mall in La Crosse closed for third consecutive day following power outage Steve Cahalan: Red Lobster building to be razed to make way for car wash Finnottes Candies owner marks end of 37-year business with final sales and memories Steve Cahalan: Blair Meat Market expands, Red Lobster restaurant to be razed for new car wash Homeless and dying: La Crosse veteran diagnosed with heart failure finds peace in final weeks New retreat house for pilgrims and visitors at Shrine of Our Lady Guadalupe would house up to 66 guests La Crosse man faces charges for driving under the influence of marijuana La Crosse County Jail inmate faces felony charge for jail assault VP Kamala Harris to visit western Wisconsin with running mate next week Defense attorney raises insanity plea for man accused of killing his wife in their town of Shelby home La Crosse man charged with felony drug possession after cocaine seized during traffic stop John Paul Gillespie 'The truck is their house': Onalaska trucking instructor offers free CDL classes for homeless jobseekers\n\nThank goodness they do now.\n\n\"I thought I had (him) cleared,\" Thompson said. \"But I wasn't sure. It was so close.\"\n\nLyles became the first American to win the marquee event in Olympic track since Justin Gatlin in 2004.\n\nThe 9.784 also marks a personal best for Lyles, who has been promising to add his own brand of excitement to track and certainly delivered this time.\n\nHe will be a favorite later this week in the 200 meters -- his better race -- and will try to join Usain Bolt as the latest runner to win both Olympic sprints.\n\nFor perspective, the blink of an eye takes, on average, .1 second, which was 20 times longer than the gap between first and second in this one.\n\nWhat was the difference? Maybe Lyles' closing speed and his lean into the line.\n\nHe and Thompson had two of the three slowest bursts from the blocks, and Thompson had what sufficed for a \"lead\" at the halfway point. The photo finish actually shows Kerley's orange shoe well in front of the line. But it's the chest breaking the barrier that counts, and Lyles beat everyone by a sliver.\n\nIt would take more than a mere 9.7(84) seconds to decide who would supplant Marcell Jacobs as the next Olympic champion.\n\nLyles patted Thompson on the shoulder while the wait grew -- from 10, to 20, then nearly 30 seconds. When the American learned he'd added this to the 100 meters he won at world championships last year, he pulled off his name tag and raised it to the sky, then brought his hands to his side and pointed at the camera.\n\n\"America, I told you I got this!\" he yelled into the camera.\n\nYes, he's the World's Fastest Man. Just not by a lot.\n\nGold (and bronze) for Ukrainian high jumpers\n\nYaroslava Mahuchikh won Olympic gold in the high jump for her war-torn country of Ukraine and, as a bonus, had company. Her teammate Iryna Gerashchenko won the bronze and the teammates hopped, skipped and jumped around the track parading their blue-and-yellow flags in a heartfelt celebration.\n\nMahuchikh needed fewer tries to clear the winning height of 2 meters than Australia's Nicola Olyslagers, and so, added the sport's biggest prize of all -- Olympic gold -- to her world championship and world record.\n\nKerr vs Ingebrigtsen is a go for heated men's 1,500\n\nThe best rivalry in track will culminate Tuesday when reigning world champion Josh Kerr of Britain takes on defending Olympic champion Jakob Ingebrigtsen of Norway.\n\nThey squared off in Sunday's semifinal, too, and Ingebrigtsen edged out the Brit, looking over to him twice as they surged down the homestretch, to win a race that felt like it meant more than it should have in 3:32.38.\n\n\"They should be expecting one of the most vicious and hardest 1,500s the sport's seen in a very long time,\" Kerr said.\n\nDid Ingebrigtsen agree?\n\n\"Depends who you ask, maybe,\" he said. \"I mean, racing is what you want it to be.\"\n\nLove 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your {"uri": "8260031314", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "11:56:23", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T11:56:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T11:55:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5843137502670288, "url": "https://www.daytondailynews.com/nation-world/after-winning-olympic-thriller-by-a-whisker-noah-lyles-looks-for-an-encore-in-his-favorite-event/SZVAYRPZTBAFNPK76K3RDGAV7Q/", "title": "After winning Olympic thriller by a whisker, Noah Lyles looks for an encore in his favorite event", "body": "There's a good argument that the rest of his stay at these Paris Games won't be anywhere near as nip-and-tuck.\n\nWith the Olympics still abuzz over his .005-second victory in the 100, Lyles didn't have much time to rest before moving to his next event. He is a heavy favorite in the 200 meters, his better race, and a race he has not lost since the Olympic final in Tokyo three years ago, where he finished third. Opening heats for the 200 were set for Monday night.\n\nLyles' willingness -- make that, desire -- to be the front man for a sport that yearns for new fans feels like a game-changer to Seb Coe, the World Athletics president who called Sunday's race \"if not perfect, about as close to perfect as you can get.\"\n\n\"If I'm wearing a promoter's hat, then him winning last night was important, because he's now creating a narrative that's heading us back into Usain Bolt territory,\" Coe said. \"That's hugely important.\"\n\nIn a typically candid and engaging post-race news conference, Lyles made no secret that he is in this to promote his sport, but also wants more.\n\nHe has been a front man for the popular Netflix documentary \"SPRINT,\" and has brought a sense of fashion back to the track, making \"walk-ins\" a thing and bedazzling his hair with white pearls on race day.\n\nNow, he's got a message for his shoe sponsor, Adidas.\n\n\"I want my own shoe,\" he said. \"I want my own trainer. I'm dead serious. I want a sneaker. There ain't no money in spikes, there's money in sneakers. I feel like for how many medals we bring back and the notoriety we get, the fact that hasn't happened, that's crazy for me. I feel like that needs to happen.\"\n\nThe 100 was the biggest hurdle for Lyles to overcome. It is not his best race, and it's the one he took up shortly after Tokyo with the goal of becoming more than a mere sprinter, but a larger-than-life personality, both on and off the track.\n\nLyles also figures to feature prominently in the men's 4x100 relay but that's anything but a gimme.\n\nRiddled with poor work with the baton, a lack of consistent training habits, a doping positive and the constant spectre of trying to beat Bolt, the U.S. has not won, and kept, a single Olympic medal in this event since 2004. It hasn't captured gold since 2000.\n\nThe relay is a bigger threat to Lyles' quest to win three gold medals, the way Bolt did in all three of his appearances, than the 200 meters.\n\nLyles figures to get his biggest challenge in the 200 from Kenny Bednarek, who finished ahead of Lyles in Tokyo and, more recently, pushed him at a fast Olympic trails that Lyles won in 19.53.\n\nBotswana's Letsile Tobogo, American Erryion Knighton and defending champion Andre De Grasse are also in the mix. One interesting wager would be whether Lyles has more of a chance of losing the race or lowering his American record of 19.31. {"uri": "8259091521", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "21:00:14", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T21:00:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T20:59:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5843137502670288, "url": "https://mcdowellnews.com/photo-finish/article_132bf593-eaa4-5796-b5f1-76fa686de05c.html", "title": "PHOTO FINISH", "body": "SAINT-DENIS, France -- Noah Lyles won the Olympic 100 meters by .005 seconds Sunday, waiting some 30 seconds after the finish of one of the closest sprints in history to find out he'd beaten Kishane Thompson of Jamaica.\n\nThe word \"Photo\" popped up on the scoreboard next to the names of Lyles, Thompson and five others after they crossed the line. Lyles paced the track with his hands draped over his head. Finally, the numbers came up. Lyles won in 9.784 seconds to edge out the Jamaican by five-thousandths of a tick of the clock.\n\nAmerica's Fred Kerley came in third at 9.81. The top seven all finished within .09 of each other.\n\nThis was the closest 1-2 finish in the 100 since at least Moscow in 1980 -- or maybe even ever. Back then, Britain's Allan Wells narrowly beat Silvio Leonard in an era when the electronic timers didn't go down into the thousandths of a second.\n\nPeople are also reading... Sheetz gas station, convenience store planned for Marion Marion police offering free food, fun at National Night Out Sheriff: Man wanted for break-in, assault at McDowell County home Roses Discount Store in Marion set to close in August McDowell calendar: Trump Road Rally goes from Morganton to Marion, and more events Sheriff: Marion man intentionally hit pedestrian with car West Marion speaker on McDowell's strategic planning: No Black or Brown people on committee McDowell Tech president talks food, pets and church in meeting with local officials Family of missing Burke woman pleads for her return; $1K reward offered Public meeting on 1,300-acre Burke, McDowell business site set for Aug. 6 Biscuitville named top fast-food chain for breakfast - again Bad for business? Professor says book challenges in Catawba County could lead to economic uncertainty NC Gov. Cooper opted out of Harris VP vetting, in part over worry about GOP lieutenant, sources say Stony Point woman charged with stealing $16,000 from Taylorsville church Their boys died after a high-speed pursuit by police. Now these Greensboro families want answers.\n\nThank goodness they do now.\n\n\"I thought I had (him) cleared,\" Thompson said. \"But I wasn't sure. It was so close.\"\n\nLyles became the first American to win the marquee event in Olympic track since Justin Gatlin in 2004.\n\nThe 9.784 also marks a personal best for Lyles, who has been promising to add his own brand of excitement to track and certainly delivered this time.\n\nHe will be a favorite later this week in the 200 meters -- his better race -- and will try to join Usain Bolt as the latest runner to win both Olympic sprints.\n\nFor perspective, the blink of an eye takes, on average, .1 second, which was 20 times longer than the gap between first and second in this one.\n\nWhat was the difference? Maybe Lyles' closing speed and his lean into the line.\n\nHe and Thompson had two of the three slowest bursts from the blocks, and Thompson had what sufficed for a \"lead\" at the halfway point. The photo finish actually shows Kerley's orange shoe well in front of the line. But it's the chest breaking the barrier that counts, and Lyles beat everyone by a sliver.\n\nIt would take more than a mere 9.7(84) seconds to decide who would supplant Marcell Jacobs as the next Olympic champion.\n\nLyles patted Thompson on the shoulder while the wait grew -- from 10, to 20, then nearly 30 seconds. When the American learned he'd added this to the 100 meters he won at world championships last year, he pulled off his name tag and raised it to the sky, then brought his hands to his side and pointed at the camera.\n\n\"America, I told you I got this!\" he yelled into the camera.\n\nYes, he's the World's Fastest Man. Just not by a lot.\n\nGold (and bronze) for Ukrainian high jumpers\n\nYaroslava Mahuchikh won Olympic gold in the high jump for her war-torn country of Ukraine and, as a bonus, had company. Her teammate Iryna Gerashchenko won the bronze and the teammates hopped, skipped and jumped around the track parading their blue-and-yellow flags in a heartfelt celebration.\n\nMahuchikh needed fewer tries to clear the winning height of 2 meters than Australia's Nicola Olyslagers, and so, added the sport's biggest prize of all -- Olympic gold -- to her world championship and world record.\n\nKerr vs Ingebrigtsen is a go for heated men's 1,500\n\nThe best rivalry in track will culminate Tuesday when reigning world champion Josh Kerr of Britain takes on defending Olympic champion Jakob Ingebrigtsen of Norway.\n\nThey squared off in Sunday's semifinal, too, and Ingebrigtsen edged out the Brit, looking over to him twice as they surged down the homestretch, to win a race that felt like it meant more than it should have in 3:32.38.\n\n\"They should be expecting one of the most vicious and hardest 1,500s the sport's seen in a very long time,\" Kerr said.\n\nDid Ingebrigtsen agree?\n\n\"Depends who you ask, maybe,\" he said. \"I mean, racing is what you want it to be.\"\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree 'I was so tired. All the time. Even thinking was a drain. somebody take their dog out?\"'\n\nLyles, who was diagnosed with ADD and dyslexia as a child, also endured 'ruthless' bullying while at school.\n\n'[It was] an emotional beating, that's the stuff that
