{"uri": "8259317507", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "02:38:40", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T02:38:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T02:34:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "url": "https://wfin.com/fox-sports/usa-sprinter-noah-lyles-wins-first-olympic-gold-in-epic-mens-100m-final/", "title": "USA sprinter Noah Lyles wins first Olympic gold in epic men's 100M final - WFIN Local News", "body": "After talking the talk for quite some time and dominating the world championships last year, the Gainesville, Florida, native is now walking the walk, as he won the men's 100-meter final on Sunday in Paris.\n\nLyles crossed the finish line in 9.79784 seconds, a personal best, and winning by five-thousandths of a second.\n\nCLICK HERE FOR MORE SPORTS COVERAGE ON FOXNEWS.COM\n\nA long photo finish review was necessary to officially crown Lyles champion, as he looked on intently alongside Jamaican Kishane Thompson, whom the broadcast thought won with the naked eye.\n\nLyles then draped an American flag around his shoulders to take a well-deserved, very long victory lap - American Fred Kerley got the bronze with 9.81.\n\nLyles is the first American to win the event at the Olympics since Justin Gatlin did so in 2004. It's the fifth gold medal won by Americans on Sunday (golfer Scottie Scheffler, cyclist Kristen Faulkner, swimmer Bobby Finke, and the women's 4\u00d7100 medley relay team).\n\nThe 27-year-old ran a 9.83 in the semifinal, automatically qualifying by finishing second in that race. He caught some flak on Saturday for finishing in second place in a heat, saying that his \"plan\" was to finish in first from there on out. That didn't happen - but it'll all be forgotten about now, as he finished first when it mattered most.\n\nOf course, some will argue he brought the hate upon himself when he quipped that NBA champions do not have the right to call themselves world champions. That comment alone has caused him to be hated by American sports fans just as much, maybe more, than he is loved by them. But, perhaps this victory can change the tide.\n\nUS WOMEN'S 4X100M MEDLEY RELAY TEAM WINS GOLD, SETS WORLD RECORD IN LAST OLYMPIC SWIMMING EVENT OF PARIS GAMES\n\nLyles will now turn his focus on the 200m (he's said his \"dream goal\" is to break Usain Bolt's world record of 19.19) and the 4x100m relay. It remains up in the air about whether he will be part of the 4x400m relay, but he was a part of the silver-medal winning team at this year's world indoor championships.\n\nIn an interview with Fox News Digital in March, Lyles said a friend told him, \"'Forget three, you need to go after four. Do something no one's ever done.'\"\n\n\"When you want to talk about being the greatest, that's what you have to achieve. So, I announced that that is a goal of mine to complete; why not do it on the biggest stage, the Olympics?\" Lyles said of a potential fourth Olympic event.\n\nTrack legend Carl Lewis recently told Fox News Digital that the sport \"needs\" Lyles to dominate these games.\n\n\"I think the sport needs someone like him that's a champion. He's the defending champion, the fastest man in the world right now, and we need someone to grab onto. I think he's the perfect guy to do that, and I'm excited about that,\" Lewis told Fox News Digital in a recent interview.\n\nCLICK HERE TO GET THE FOX NEWS APP\n\n\"I think track does better when we do have a superstar. That's why I think if Noah were to win, he would elevate the sport as well. As opposed to saying 'I wonder who's going to win,' people want to say 'I want him' or 'I don't want him.' They want to root for someone, or root against someone. I think it creates more intensity when you have someone that dominates, and that's been throughout history.... {"uri": "8259072818", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "20:35:00", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T20:35:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T20:32:48Z", "dataType": "news", wins 100m gold by a whisker", "body": "By Mitch Phillips\n\nPARIS, Aug 4 (Reuters) -\n\nAfter all the talk and all the hype, Noah Lyles delivered when it mattered most when he won a superlative Olympic 100 metres final by five thousandths of a second on Sunday to give the United States the title for the first time in 20 years.\n\nIn one of the most competitive finals of all time, there was a blanket finish, with the stadium scoreboard initially flashing a photo finish for the first seven athletes.\n\nIt then confirmed Lyles as the winner in a personal best 9.79 seconds, the same time as Jamaica's Kishane Thompson, but ahead by a fraction.\n\nIf the race had been 99 metres Thompson would have been celebrating, but fast-finishing Lyles kept his form superbly and timed his dip expertly to add Olympic gold to his world title.\n\nHe ripped his bib name from his shirt and held it aloft, announcing himself, as he had always promised, as the fastest man in the world.\n\n\"It's the one I wanted, it's the hard battle, it's the amazing opponents,\" said Lyles, the first American Olympic 100m champion since Justin Gatlin in 2004.\n\n\"Everybody came prepared for the fight and I wanted to prove that I'm the man among all of them, I'm the wolf among wolves.\"\n\nCompatriot Fred Kerley took bronze in 9.81 and Akani Simbini of South Africa was fourth, making it a remarkable six fourth or fifth finishes in global championships, albeit with the consolation of a national record of 9.83.\n\nDefending champion Lamont Marcell Jacobs of Italy, heavily strapped, finished fifth in 9.85 and, such was the quality of the race, that eighth-placed Oblique Seville of Jamaica still clocked 9.91 seconds.\n\nIt was the first time eight men have broken 10 seconds in a wind-legal 100 metres {"uri": "2024-08-443844733", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "19:57:33", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T19:57:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T18:45:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "url": "https://www.standardmedia.co.ke/sports/sports/article/2001500303/paris-2024-omanyala-stunned-out-of-olympics-100m-final", "title": "Paris 2024: Omanyala stunned, out of Olympics 100m final", "body": "African champion Ferdinand Omanyala is out of Paris Olympics.\n\nOmanyala missed out on the medal bracket after failing to make the finals of the 100m sprints when he finished a distant eighth during the semifinals heats on Sunday night.\n\nThe Commonwealth champion clocked 10.08 seconds at Stade de France to finish behind the current World fastest man Kishane Thompson who won the heat in an impressive 9.80 seconds.\n\nUSA's Fred Kerley finished second after clocking 9.84 seconds to also qualify for the finals.\n\nSouth Africa's Akani Simbine and Botswana's Letsile Tebogo will also be in the finals alongside Noah Lyles and Seville Oblique from Jamaica.\n\nUS sprinter Noah Lyles suffered a second straight slow start, beaten into second in his 100m semi-final by the Jamaican. Oblique clocked 9.81 seconds while Lyles ran 9.83 seconds.\n\nThe shock 100m winner in Tokyo, Italy's Marcell Jacobs, also scraped through to the final, where Jamaica's Kishane Thompson will start as fastest qualifier after notching 9.80sec.\n\nNo US athlete has won the 100m since Justin Gatlin at the 2004 Athens Games and the Americans are still smarting after Julien Alfred from tiny St.Lucia beat hot favourite Sha'Carri Richardson in the women's 100m final on Saturday.\n\nThe outspoken Lyles claims to be the rightful sprinting heir to the legendary Usain Bolt and has vowed to \"transcend\" his sport.\n\nBut he will have to improve on his two performances so far, 10.04sec in the heat and 9.83sec in the semi-final.", "source": {"uri": "standardmedia.co.ke", "dataType": {"uri": "8259172231", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "22:54:36", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T22:54:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T22:53:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5764706134796143, "url": "https://richmond.com/sports/alexandrias-lyles-wins-mens-100-meters-in-photo-finish/article_af960be1-eb43-555b-b8e2-fe92cf159c50.html", "title": "Alexandria's Lyles wins men's 100 meters in photo finish", "body": "SAINT-DENIS, France -- Noah Lyles won the Olympic 100 meters by .005 seconds Sunday, waiting some 30 seconds after the finish of one of the closest sprints in history to find out he'd beaten Kishane Thompson of Jamaica.\n\nThe word \"Photo\" popped up on the scoreboard next to the names of Lyles, Thompson and five others after they crossed the line in the 100.\n\nLyles, 27, paced the track with his hands draped over his head. Finally, the numbers came up. Lyles won in 9.784 seconds to edge out Thompson by five-thousandths of a tick of the clock.\n\nLyles said he thought he had given the win away by dipping at the line too soon, so he went up to Thompson and told him, \"Bro, I think you got that one.\"\n\n\"But then my name popped up and I'm like 'Oh my gosh, amazing!'\" said Lyles, who was a high school track star in Virginia when he ran for T.C. Williams High School (now known as Alexandria City High).\n\nPeople are also reading... Hendrick, Richmond-area short-track racing star, dies at 70 Outer Banks wild stallion hit, killed on the beach Chesterfield teacher charged with assaulting student Database: Over 300 city employees have purchasing cards. Here's what they bought in 2023. Teel: Jeff Jones hosts special Virginia basketball reunion Search for missing 12-year-old swimmer on Outer Banks ends in tragedy Virginia Department of Education is over legal staffing limit by 25 UPDATE: Police ID victim, announce arrest in shooting involving Chesterfield couple Chesterfield's new 3-story middle school opens as largest in region N.Va. housing costs drive exodus to Richmond area, out of state 'We're so spoiled': Families love Henrico's newest park Henrico homeowners upset by Goochland quarry expansion 3 Richmond offices paid city spokesperson's former business partner 'It helped me a lot': Suni Lee has 'needed' heart-to-heart with teammates before Team USA won gold Kings Dominion's new roller coaster is revealed\n\nAmerica's Fred Kerley came in third at 9.81.\n\n\"That's probably one of the most beautiful races I've been in,\" he said.\n\nThe top seven all finished within .09 of each other.\n\nThis was the closest 1-2 finish in the 100 since at least Moscow in 1980 -- or maybe even ever. Back then, Britain's Allan Wells narrowly beat Silvio Leonard in an era when the electronic timers didn't go down into the thousandths of a second. The same was true in 1932, when Eddie Tolan won the Olympics' first ever photo finish.\n\n\"I thought I had (him) cleared,\" Thompson said. \"But I wasn't sure. It was so close.\"\n\nLyles became the first American to win the marquee event in Olympic track since Justin Gatlin in 2004.\n\nThe 9.784 also marks a personal best for Lyles, who has been promising to add his own brand of excitement to track and certainly delivered this time.\n\nHe will be a favorite later this week in the 200 meters -- his better race -- and will try to join Usain Bolt as the latest runner to win both Olympic sprints.\n\nLyles and Thompson had two of the three slowest bursts from the blocks, and Thompson had what sufficed for a \"lead\" at the halfway point. The photo finish actually shows Kerley's orange shoe well in front of everything at the finish line. But it's the chest breaking the barrier that counts, and Lyles beat everyone by a sliver.\n\nWhen the American learned he had added the Olympic title to the 100 meters he won at world championships last year, he pulled off his name tag and raised it to the sky, then brought his hands to his side and pointed at the camera.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | Omny Studio\n\n\"America, I told you I got this!\" he yelled into the camera.\n\nAlso Sunday, Blacksburg resident Cole Hocker and former Virginia Tech standout Neil Gourley advanced to Tuesday's final of the men's 1,500 meters.\n\nHocker, a former University of Oregon star who has trained at Virginia Tech since November, finished third in his 12-man semifinal heat with a time of 3:32.54. The top six runners in each heat advanced to Tuesday's final.\n\nGourley, running for Great Britain, finished third in the other semifinal heat with a time of 3:32.11.\n\nGourley, a Scotland native, was third overall. Hocker, a Pennsylvania native running in his second Olympics, was 10th overall.\n\nAs a senior, Gourley ran the anchor leg for the Tech distance medley relay team that won gold at the 2018 NCAA indoor championships.\n\nGold (and bronze) for Ukrainian high jumpers\n\nYaroslava Mahuchikh won Olympic gold in the high jump for her war-torn country of Ukraine and, as a bonus, had company. Her teammate Iryna Gerashchenko won the bronze and the teammates hopped, skipped and jumped around the track parading their blue-and-yellow flags in a heartfelt celebration.\n\nMahuchikh needed fewer tries to clear the winning height of 2 meters than Australia's Nicola Olyslagers, and so, added the sport's biggest prize of all -- Olympic gold -- to her world championship and world record.\n\nKerr vs. Ingebrigtsen set for men's 1,500\n\nThe best rivalry in track will culminate Tuesday when reigning world champion Josh Kerr of Britain takes on defending Olympic champion Jakob Ingebrigtsen of Norway.\n\nThey squared off in Sunday's semifinal, too, and Ingebrigtsen edged out the Brit, looking over to him twice as they surged down the homestretch, to win a race that felt like it meant more than it should have in 3:32.38.\n\n\"They should be expecting one of the most vicious and hardest 1,500s the sport's seen in a very long time,\" Kerr said.\n\nDid Ingebrigtsen agree?\n\n\"Depends who you ask, maybe,\" he said. \"I mean, racing is what you want it to be.\"\n\nGallery: Richmond Crusade for Voters holds forum for mayor candidates\n\nThe Roanoke Times contributed to this report.\n\nMore coverage\n\nSPORTS: UVa's Gretchen Walsh wins another relay gold medal. {"uri": "8259145710", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "22:15:42", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T22:15:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T22:12:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5764706134796143, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/pa/article-13708345/Olympic-100-metres-champion-Noah-Lyles-feared-photo-finish-gone-against-him.html", "title": "Olympic 100 metres champion Noah Lyles feared photo finish had gone...", "body": "Newly-crowned Olympic champion Noah Lyles revealed he thought Jamaica's Kishane Thompson had beaten him to 100 metres gold following their photo finish in Paris.\n\nEvery occupant of the 80,000-seat Stade de France seemed to inhale at once before a roar erupted as the 27-year-old American's name appeared first on the screen, then announced to the stadium as the victor by just five thousandths of a second, a winning time of 9.79.784 seconds.\n\nThe 27-year-old rang the victory bell hard, fait accompli after setting out to settle the \"fastest man\" debate once and for all in France.\n\nLyles, whose US team-mate Fred Kerley took bronze, said: \"I knew that when the time came, for me to be able to say 'this is the final, this is where I need to put it together' I was going to do it.\n\n\"I did think (Thompson) had it at the end. I went up to him after, while we were waiting, and I even said 'I think you've got that, good going,' and then my name popped up and I'm like 'oh my gosh, I'm amazing'.\n\n\"I'm going to be honest, I wasn't ready to see it (his name) and that's the first time I've ever said that. I wasn't ready to see it.\n\n\"He was quite a few lanes down, he was in four, I was in seven so it was hard for me to picture where we were.\"\n\nThe American world 100m and 200m champion's triumph comes three summers after he entered the postponed Tokyo 2020 Olympics as the 200m favourite and world champion - but only claimed bronze.\n\nAfterwards, he opened up about a lifelong battle with depression and the challenges of balancing the benefits of antidepressant medication with side effects that led to weight gain and affected his ability to perform - ultimately electing to wean off the treatment before those Games.\n\nEarlier this week, he acknowledged he performs better in front of a full house, remembering the moment on the start line in Tokyo when he would usually say to himself \"it's showtime\", but instead found himself thinking \"this is not it. This is not fun. This is not cool. This is not what I wanted.\"\n\nLyles had no such trouble in Paris, where he thumped his chest at the start line and pumped up the electrified crowd, clearly revelling in the occasion, before they fell so quiet at the start of the race that it was possible to hear a plane passing overhead.\n\nThen the man whose weakness is often said to be his starts got off to the joint slowest, an 0.178 reaction time alongside Botswana's Letsile Tebogo.\n\nLyles, only learning that fact from a journalist, said: \"Slowest reaction time - that's crazy! I thought I was a little better than that but that goes to prove that reaction time does not win races.\"\n\nUSA\u00b4s Noah Lyles celebrates winning the men\u00b4s 100m final (David Davies/PA).\n\nHe entered these Olympics with the third-fastest time at 100m this year behind Thompson's world-leading 9.77 and Kenyan Ferdinand Omanyala's 9.79, and as a result found himself in a position of needing to back up his signature bravado on Sunday night.\n\nThompson qualified fastest of the semi-finalists in 9.80, his compatriot Seville Oblique just behind him in a personal-best 9.81 and Lyles two hundredths of a second behind.\n\nOblique was the only man who did not have to wait for his place to be confirmed - the last-placed man in 9.91.\n\nLyles is in Paris with a point to prove, embroiled in a debate before the Games about who was currently fastest man on the planet - not that he ever had any doubts.\n\nThe Floridian - who is looking to do the double in the 200 metres - emphatically reiterated his answer, this time with his feet instead of his rhetoric.\n\nGreat Britain's Louie Hinchliffe (left) and USA's Noah Lyles during the men's 100 metres semi-finals (Martin Rickett/PA).\n\nEarlier, Team GB sprinters Louie Hinchliffe and Zharnel Hughes saw their bid for Olympic 100m gold come to and end in the semi-finals.\n\nHinchliffe said: \"It was a good experience, not the result that I wanted. Definitely a lot to learn. I haven't seen the race back.\n\n\"I am disappointed. The time is OK but it's where I finished in the race. I will come back stronger next year. I will not regress. It's my first year on the scene. There is a lot more to come.\n\nIt was a good experience, not the result that I wanted. Definitely a lot to learn. Louie Hinchliffe\n\n\"Definitely, definitely LA, I will be there (in the final). Next year as well. There are a lot of world championships between then and now. There is a lot of time.\n\nHughes has another chance to try for a first Olympic medal when the men's 200m heats begin on Monday.\n\nGreat Britain\u00b4s Zharnel Hughes after finishing sixth in his men\u00b4s 100 metres semi-final (Martin Rickett/PA).\n\nHe said: \"I am a fighter. I am very determined and that's why I wanted to give it a go. {"uri": "8259397831", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "04:11:34", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T04:11:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T04:10:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5764706134796143, "url": "https://sportstar.thehindu.com/olympics/paris-2024/news/paris-olympics-2024-noah-lyles-wants-usa-athletics-to-cash-in-on-his-100m-win/article68487066.ece", "title": "Paris Olympics 2024: Lyles wants US athletics to cash in on 100m triumph", "body": "Noah Lyles wants his thrilling Olympic 100m victory to have a transformative effect on his sport in the United States -- starting with a Michael Jordan-style sports shoe deal.\n\nThe 27-year-old American catapulted himself into a new level of stardom on Sunday after ending the USA's 20-year wait for a gold medal in the Olympics' most coveted title.\n\nLyles has frequently complained of track and field's low profile in the United States, where the NBA, NFL and baseball dominate the sporting landscape.\n\nBut Lyles believes his nerve-shredding victory on Sunday, and the success of the recent Netflix documentary series \"Sprint\", present an opportunity for his sport -- and himself -- to cash in.\n\n\"I want to see a continuation of the ability to take advantage of moments for our sport,\" Lyles told a press conference.\n\n\"'Sprint' came out, it did amazing and I know that season two is already being filmed. They've been doing a good job and getting already our name out.\n\n\"What we need to do as a sport is take advantage and say 'Hey, we need to make this as available as possible for people to come and watch', so you don't have to go to back alley websites to try and find or pay to watch websites to get a hold of this.\n\nALSO READ | Noah Lyles sprints the talk to 100m glory in Paris Olympics 2024\n\n\"This needs to be accessible because this is a world sport. So we need to be able to show it to the world.\"\n\nFrom a personal point of view, Lyles says he hopes his success can prompt a major sports equipment manufacturer to put his name on his own branded shoe in the style of NBA great Jordan's deal with Nike.\n\nLyles noted that few US track and field athletes, including the likes of 1996 Olympic 400m and 200m champion Michael Johnson, ever had that opportunity.\n\n\"I want my own shoe,\" Lyles said. \"I want my own trainer. Dead serious. I want a sneaker. There ain't no money in spikes.\n\n\"Even Michael Johnson didn't have his own sneaker. I feel like for how many medals we bring back, the notoriety we get, the fact that hasn't happened is crazy to me.\n\n\"So that needs to happen.\"\n\nLyles meanwhile was simply relieved to deliver on his promise of victory after boldly stating all season that he was \"unbeatable\".\n\n\"It feels good to back it up,\" Lyles said. \"I've seen tons of scenarios where athletes come in as a favourite and it doesn't work out for them.\"\n\nLatest on SportstarParis Olympics 2024: Lyles wants US athletics to cash in on 100m triumph AFPParis Olympics 2024: US men eliminated from 3x3 competition after {"uri": "8259457339", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "05:13:36", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T05:13:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T05:12:50Z", "dataType": "news", "body": "After all the talk and all the hype, Noah Lyles duly delivered when it mattered most when he won a superlative Olympic 100 metres final by five thousandths of a second on Sunday to give the United States the title for the first time in 20 years.\n\nIn the most competitive final of all time, there was a blanket finish, with the stadium scoreboard initially flashing a photo to separate the first seven athletes and Lyles believing he had lost.\n\nHe was then confirmed him as the winner in a personal best 9.79 seconds, the same time as Jamaica's Kishane Thompson, but ahead by the width of a vest.\n\nIf the race had been 99 metres Thompson would have been celebrating a fourth Jamaican win in five Olympics, but fast-finishing Lyles kept his form superbly and timed his dip expertly to add Olympic gold to his world title.\n\nHe ripped his bib name from his shirt and held it aloft with his red, white and blue varnished fingernails, announcing himself, as he had always promised he would be, as the fastest man in the world.\n\n\"It's the one I wanted, it's the hard battle, it's the amazing opponents,\" said Lyles, the first American Olympic 100m champion since Justin Gatlin in 2004.\n\n\"Everybody came prepared for the fight and I wanted to prove that I'm the man among all of them, I'm the wolf among wolves.\"\n\nIt was the first time eight men have broken 10 seconds in a Lyles is racing in the sixth heat in the first round, which starts at 1:55 p.m. ET/10:55 a.m. PT. Assuming Lyles moves on, he'll race in the semifinals on Wednesday, Aug. 7 at 2:02 p.m. ET/11:02 a.m. PT.\n\nThe men's 200m final is scheduled for Thursday, Aug. 8 at 2:30 p.m. ET/11:30 a.m. PT.\n\nLyles' personal best time in the men's 200m is 19.31 and his best this season is 19.53. He won the bronze medal in the men's 200m in Tokyo in 2020. He's a favorite to win the gold but will have tough competition. Lyles is the three-time reigning world champion in the 200m.\n\nThe last American man to win the men's 200m was Shawn Crawford in 2004. Lyles would be in good company to win both the 100m and 200m at the same Olympics. The last man to do it was Usain Bolt in 2016 in Rio.\n\nUsain Bolt holds the world record in the men's 200m with a time of 19.19 set in 2009. Bolt also holds the Olympic record in the men's 200m with a time of 19.30 set in 2008.\n\nThe men's 200m final is scheduled for Thursday, Aug. 8 at 2:30 p.m. ET from the Stade de France in Paris.\n\nRound one of the men's 200m features six heats. The top three in each heat will move on to the semifinals.\n\nAthletes who didn't qualify from round 1 will have a chance to qualify in the repechage round the next day. The repechage round will feature four heats. The top athlete in each heat will move on to the semifinals along with the athletes with the fastest two times who have not qualified yet.\n\nThere are three semifinal heats for the men's 200m with eight athletes in each. The top two athletes in each semifinal plus the top two athletes not already qualified will move onto the final.\n\nNoah Lyles competed in the men's 100m and is now set to take on the 200m and 4x100m relay while in Paris.\n\nHere's what his upcoming schedule likely looks like:\n\nLyles' races will also be shown either live or on replay in primetime on NBC.", "source": {"uri": "nbcchicago.com", {"uri": "8259137454", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "22:02:37", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T22:02:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T22:01:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.572549045085907, "url": "https://www.expressandstar.com/sport/uk-sports/2024/08/04/olympic-100-metres-champion-noah-lyles-feared-photo-finish-had-gone-against-him/", "title": "Olympic 100 metres champion Noah Lyles feared photo finish had gone against him", "body": "The American revealed he thought Jamaica's Kishane Thompson had beaten him to 100 metres gold.\n\nNewly-crowned Olympic champion Noah Lyles revealed he thought Jamaica's Kishane Thompson had beaten him to 100 metres gold following their photo finish in Paris.\n\nEvery occupant of the 80,000-seat Stade de France seemed to inhale at once before a roar erupted as the 27-year-old American's name appeared first on the screen, then announced to the stadium as the victor by just five thousandths of a second, a winning time of 9.79.784 seconds.\n\nThe 27-year-old rang the victory bell hard, fait accompli after setting out to settle the \"fastest man\" debate once and for all in France.\n\nLyles, whose US team-mate Fred Kerley took bronze, said: \"I knew that when the time came, for me to be able to say 'this is the final, this is where I need to put it together' I was going to do it.\n\n\"I did think (Thompson) had it at the end. I went up to him after, while we were waiting, and I even said 'I think you've got that, good going,' and then my name popped up and I'm like 'oh my gosh, I'm amazing'.\n\n\"I'm going to be honest, I wasn't ready to see it (his name) and that's the first time I've ever said that. I wasn't ready to see it.\n\n\"He was quite a few lanes down, he was in four, I was in seven so it was hard for me to picture where we were.\"\n\nThe American world 100m and 200m champion's triumph comes three summers after he entered the postponed Tokyo 2020 Olympics as the 200m favourite and world champion - but only claimed bronze.\n\nAfterwards, he opened up about a lifelong battle with depression and the challenges of balancing the benefits of antidepressant medication with side effects that led to weight gain and affected his ability to perform - ultimately electing to wean off the treatment before those Games.\n\nEarlier this week, he acknowledged he performs better in front of a full house, remembering the moment on the start line in Tokyo when he would usually say to himself \"it's showtime\", but instead found himself thinking \"this is not it. This is not fun. This is not cool. This is not what I wanted.\"\n\nLyles had no such trouble in Paris, where he thumped his chest at the start line and pumped up the electrified crowd, clearly revelling in the occasion, before they fell so quiet at the start of the race that it was possible to hear a plane passing overhead.\n\nThen the man whose weakness is often said to be his starts got off to the joint slowest, an 0.178 reaction time alongside Botswana's Letsile Tebogo.\n\nLyles, only learning that fact from a journalist, said: \"Slowest reaction time - that's crazy! I thought I was a little better than that but that goes to prove that reaction time does not win races.\"\n\nHe entered these Olympics with the third-fastest time at 100m this year behind Thompson's world-leading 9.77 and Kenyan Ferdinand Omanyala's 9.79, and as a result found himself in a position of needing to back up his signature bravado on Sunday night.\n\nThompson qualified fastest of the semi-finalists in 9.80, his compatriot Seville Oblique just behind him in a personal-best 9.81 and Lyles two hundredths of a second behind.\n\nOblique was the only man who did not have to wait for his place to be confirmed - the last-placed man in 9.91.\n\nLyles is in Paris with a point to prove, embroiled in a debate before the Games about who was currently fastest man on the planet - not that he ever had any doubts.\n\nThe Floridian - who is looking to do the double in the 200 metres - emphatically reiterated his answer, this time with his feet instead of his rhetoric.\n\nEarlier, Team GB sprinters Louie Hinchliffe and Zharnel Hughes saw their bid for Olympic 100m gold come to and end in the semi-finals.\n\nHinchliffe said: \"It was a good experience, not the result that I wanted. Definitely a lot to learn. I haven't seen the race back.\n\n\"I am disappointed. The time is OK but it's where I finished in the race. I will come back stronger next year. I will not regress. It's my first year on the scene. There is a lot more to come.\n\n\"Definitely, definitely LA, I will be there (in the final). Next year as well. There are a lot of world championships between then and now. There is a lot of time.\n\nHughes has another chance to try for a first Olympic medal when the men's 200m heats begin on Monday.\n\nHe said: \"I am a fighter. I am very determined and that's why I wanted to give it a go. I got the training in but the races is what I needed to get me race sharp.\"", "source": {"uri": "expressandstar.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Express & Star"}, "authors": [], "concepts": Commentators originally believed Jamaica's Kishane Thompson won (watch the moment here), and Lyles could be seen pacing after the race, watching the scoreboard for almost 30 seconds before his name popped up as the winner. His time: 9.784 seconds, to Thompson's 9.789. As ESPN reports, that's a difference of 0.005 seconds, or five-thousandths of a second. Lyles' lean made the difference; USA Today reports his shoulder and clavicle crossed the finish line first, as can be seen in images of the finish. {"uri": "8259151191", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "22:20:55", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T22:20:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T22:20:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5647059082984924, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/us-star-lyles-wins-mens-220748781.html", "title": "US star Lyles wins men's 100m gold as Mahuchikh tops high jump", "body": "America sprinter Noah Lyles lived up to the hype when it mattered but needed a photo finish before being confirmed as the fastest man in the world with Olympic 100 metres gold on Sunday.\n\nWorld champion Lyles stirred up the crowd when he entered the Stade de France and then came from behind to pip Jamaica's Kishane Thompson by five-thousandths, with both clocking 9.79 seconds.\n\nThat was a personal best for Lyles who celebrated wildly after being confirmed as winner. It was also the first US men's 100m gold since Justin Gatlin's success 20 years ago in Athens.\n\nThe women's high jump was also a very close affair, with top favourite Yaroslava Mahuchikh needing countback to beat Australia's Nicola Olyslagers.\n\nThe third gold of the night went to Canadian world champion Ethan Katzberg in the men's hammer throw.\n\nLyles delivers when it matters\n\nLyles won a 100m, 200m and 4x100m treble at the 2019 and 2023 worlds and came to Paris with the aim of repeating it at the Olympic stage, with his popularity also soaring via the Sprint documentary film.\n\nHe was beaten in his heat and semi-final but had promised fireworks for the final.\n\nSeason leader Thompson had his usual fast start and led at the halfway mark but Lyles and the others the closed in.\n\nLyles pipped Thompson right at the line, and former world champion Fred Kerley got bronze two-hundredths back, gto go with Tokyo silver.\n\nTokyo winner Marcell Jacobs of Italy was fifth and even seventh-placed Kenneth Bednarek of the US just nine-hundredths off the top.\n\nWhat they said\n\n\"It's been a rollercoaster, ups and downs. I'm usually a guy who likes to come out blazing in all my rounds, especially in the 200m. But the 100m, it's my first time here on the Olympic stage,\" Lyles said.\n\n\"I think back to Tokyo when I messed up handling the rounds. From then on, I was like, 'I'm never going to do that again. I'm going to handle this correctly and practise over the years',\" he said inn reference to the last Games where he had to settle for 200m bronze.\n\nIt's accumulated to this point. You only need one. As long as that's the last one, that's all that matters.\"\n\nThompson said: \"I wasn't patient enough with myself to let my speed bring me at the line, in the position that I know I could have gone to, but I have learnt from it.\"\n\nAsked whether he thought the gold should have shared, he said: think the sport is too competitive, no offence to any other sport. It's too competitive for us to share a gold medal.\n\n\"I'm feeling very good, honestly. My body language will not show it because I am not an expressive guy, but I am glad.\"\n\nIt will be a quick turnaround for Lyles and others as the 200m heats are scheduled for Monday night.\n\nTight high jump\n\nMahuchikh meanwhile added Olympic gold to her Tokyo bronze and the 2023 world title but it was closer than expected for the athlete who had recently bettered the long standing world record to 2.10m at another Paris venue.\n\nMahuchikh and Olyslagers cleared 2.00 metres but Mahuchikh did so in her first attempt while Olyslagers needed three to get silver as at the 2022 worlds.\n\nTwo more athletes from Ukraine and Australia made the podium as Iryna Gerashchenko and 2022 world champion Eleanor Patterson shared bronze with 1.98m apiece and the same amount of jumps.\n\n\"Finally, I got this gold medal,\" said Mahuckikh who gave Ukraine a second Paris gold, following the women's sabre fencing team. The medals are to give Ukrainians some joy amid the ongoing Russian invasion.\n\nHammer, prelims and Monday\n\nIn the hammer throw, Katzberg was in a league of his own and the only man to go beyond 80m, winninng with 84.12m from Hungary's Bence Halasz and Mykhaylo Kokhan who got Ukraine's third medal on the night.\n\nIn preliminary action which started in the morning, women's 100m champion Julien Alfred of St Lucia coasted into the 200m semi-finals.\n\nWorld champion Femke Bol won her 400m hurdles heat the day after giving the Netherlands mixed relay gold, with American Tokyo winner and world record holder Sydney McLaughlin-Levrone also through en route to one of the most anticipated gold medal showdowns.\n\nBritish gold medal favourite Keely Hodgkinson cruised into Monday's women's 800m final; and compatriot world champion Josh Kerr into the 1,500m final alongside Norway's Tokyo champion Jakob Ingebrigtsen.\n\nThe other finals Monday are the men's pole vault with Swedish superstar Armand Duplantis, the women's 5,000m with Kenyan great Faith Kipyegon and Dutch ace Sifan Hassan, and the women's discus.", "source": {"uri": "sports.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "2024-08-443877882", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "21:08:42", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T21:08:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T21:02:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5647059082984924, "url": "https://www.france24.com/en/sport/20240804-us-sprinter-noah-lyles-clinches-olympic-gold-in-men-s-100m-final", "title": "US sprinter Noah Lyles clinches Olympic gold in men's 100m final", "body": "US sprinter Noah Lyles Sunday took gold in the closest 100m final in modern Olympic history, becoming the first American to win the event since the 2004 Athens Games.\n\nNoah Lyles snatched a photo-finish victory in the closest 100m final in modern Olympic history on Sunday to end the United States' 20-year wait to recapture the world's most prestigious sprinting crown.\n\nIn a nerve-shredding final at the Stade de France, Lyles, the charismatic 27-year-old from Florida, took gold by a fraction from Jamaica's Kishane Thompson.\n\nLyles' winning margin boiled down to just five thousandths of a second, with the American clocked at 9.784sec to Thompson's 9.789sec, though both men's times will be listed as 9.79sec.\n\nIt was the narrowest margin of victory since electronic timing has been used at the Olympics.\n\nLyles' compatriot Fred Kerley took bronze in 9.81sec.\n\nThe race was so close that the electronic scoreboard in the arena simply read \"photo\" beside seven of the eight finalists.\n\nAfter an agonising wait of several seconds, Lyles' victory was confirmed, sparking wild celebrations from the reigning 100m and 200m world champion who is regarded as one of the global superstars as athletics.\n\n\"It's the one I wanted,\" an elated Lyles told Eurosport moments after his win.\n\n\"It's the hard battle, it's the amazing opponents. Everybody's healthy, everybody came prepared for the fight and I wanted to prove that I'm the man amongst all of them. I'm the wolf amongst wolves.\"\n\nLyles admitted though that even he had doubted whether he had clinched the gold.\n\n\"I went up to Kishane and I was like, 'I'm gonna be honest, bro, I think you had that one,'\" Lyles said.\n\n\"And I was fully prepared to see his name pop up and to see my name pop up, I'm like goodness gracious. I'm incredible.\"\n\nThe win completes a rollercoaster three years for Lyles, who had left the pandemic-hit Tokyo Olympics in tears after a disappointing campaign, citing his mental health struggles and battles with depression.\n\nThe American is now targeting an Olympic double with victory in the 200m next week.\n\nUkraine medal rush\n\nLyles' win was the sensational final act of another thrilling day in the Olympic athletics arena that saw three gold medals handed out.\n\nIn other action, Ukraine's Yaroslava Mahuchikh lived up to her pre-Paris Games billing to win the women's high jump.\n\nThe world champion and world record holder managed a best of 2.00 metres to win on countback from Australia's Nicola Olyslagers.\n\nAnother Australian, Eleanor Patterson, claimed joint bronze with another Ukrainian, Iryna Gerashchenko, both on 1.95m.\n\nIn the men's hammer, Canadian world champion Ethan Katzberg won after unleashing a mammoth heave with his first throw to clinch the gold medal.\n\nThe 22-year-old from British Columbia registered 84.12m with his opening effort to leave his rivals trailing throughout the competition.\n\nThat was four metres further than his nearest rival, Hungary's Bence Halasz, who took silver with a throw of 79.97m. Ukraine's Mykhaylo Kokhan collected bronze with a throw of 79.39m.\n\nElsewhere Sunday, Sydney McLaughlin-Levrone and Femke Bol eased through the opening round of the women's 400m hurdles to remain on an Olympic collision course.\n\nUS star McLaughlin-Levrone, the reigning Olympic champion and world record holder, cruised through her heat to win in 53.60sec.\n\nBol meanwhile shrugged off the after-effects of her dazzling performance in Saturday's 4x400m mixed relay to coast through her heat in a leading 53.38sec.\n\nAnother mouthwatering duel is looming in the women's 800m, where Britain's Keely Hodgkinson, a silver medallist in Tokyo three years ago, is poised for an epic battle with Kenya's 2023 World Champion Mary Moraa on Monday.\n\nHodgkinson delivered an ice-cool performance to win her semi-final in 1min 56.86sec, the fastest time of the round. Moraa advanced after winning her heat in 1:57.86.\n\nIn the opening round of the men's 400m, Britain's Matt Hudson-Smith got his bid for gold off to a smooth start, winning his heat in 44.78sec.\n\nUS sprinter Michael Norman set the early first round pace however with the quickest time, a brisk 44.10sec. Norman's US team-mate Quincy Hall was second-fastest with a time of 44.28sec.", "source": {"uri": "france24.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "France 24"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": After the race, the Miami Dolphins wide receiver took to social media with a simple message for Lyles.\n\n\"Good shiiii Noah,\" Hill wrote on X.\n\nBefore he turned his focus solely on football, Hill was a world-class track and field athlete. He ran the 200 meter in 20.14 seconds as an 18-year-old high schooler, ranking him sixth in the United States in 2012. His personal best in the 100m is 10.19 seconds.\n\nMost recently, Hill ran the 60m in 6.70 seconds at the USA Track and Field Masters Indoor Championships in 2023. That time was six hundredths off the personal best he recorded when he notched second at the Big 12 Indoor Championships for Oklahoma State in 2014.\n\nLyles will participate in 200m qualifying on {"uri": "8259284907", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "01:48:51", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T01:48:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T01:47:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5647059082984924, "url": "https://www.thedailystar.net/sports/sports-special/paris-olympics-2024/news/lyles-wants-us-athletics-cash-100m-triumph-3669901", "title": "Lyles wants US athletics to cash in on 100m triumph", "body": "Noah Lyles wants his thrilling Olympic 100m victory to have a transformative effect on his sport in the United States -- starting with a Michael Jordan-style sports shoe deal.\n\nThe 27-year-old American catapulted himself into a new level of stardom on Sunday after ending the USA's 20-year wait for a gold medal in the Olympics' most coveted title.\n\nLyles has frequently complained of track and field's low profile in the United States, where the NBA, National Football League and baseball dominate the sporting landscape.\n\nBut Lyles believes his nerve-shredding victory on Sunday, and the success of the recent Netflix documentary series \"Sprint\", present an opportunity for his sport -- and himself -- to cash in.\n\n\"I want to see a continuation of the ability to take advantage of moments for our sport,\" Lyles told a press conference.\n\n\"'Sprint' came out, it did amazing and I know that season two is already being filmed. They've been doing a good job and getting already our name out.\n\n\"What we need to do as a sport is take advantage and say 'Hey, we need to make this as available as possible for people to come and watch', so you don't have to go to back alley websites to try and find or pay to watch websites to get a hold of this.\n\n\"This needs to be accessible because this is a world sport. So we need to be able to show it to the world.\"\n\nFrom a personal point of view, Lyles says he hopes his success can prompt a major sports equipment manufacturer to put his name on his own branded shoe in the style of NBA great Jordan's deal with Nike.\n\nLyles noted that few US track and field athletes, including the likes of 1996 Olympic 400m and 200m champion Michael Johnson, ever had that opportunity.\n\n\"I want my own shoe,\" Lyles said. \"I want my own trainer. Dead serious. I want a sneaker. There ain't no money in spikes.\n\n\"Even Michael Johnson didn't have his own sneaker. I feel like for how many medals we bring back, the notoriety we get, the fact that hasn't happened is crazy to me.\n\n\"So that needs to happen.\"\n\nLyles meanwhile was simply relieved to deliver on his promise of victory after boldly stating all season that he was \"unbeatable\".\n\n\"It feels good to back it up,\" Lyles said. \"I've seen tons of scenarios where athletes come in as a favourite {"uri": "8259064138", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "20:22:41", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T20:22:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T20:20:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5607843399047852, "url": "https://www.the42.ie/noah-lyles-100m-olympics-paris-6455337-Aug2024/", "title": "American Noah Lyles wins men's Olympic 100m gold", "body": "WORLD CHAMPION NOAH Lyles roared to victory in 9.79sec to claim gold in a dramatic men's Olympic 100m final in Paris on Sunday.Lyles became the first American, male or female, to win the event since Justin Gatlin won in the 2004 Athens Games.\n\nIn a photo-finish, Jamaica's Kishane Thompson claimed silver, just five-thousandths of a second off Lyles' pace.\n\nLyles' US teammate Fred Kerley took bronze in 9.81sec, just one-hundredth ahead of South African Akani Simbine, who timed 9.82sec.\n\nDefending champion Marcell Jacobs of Italy was fifth in 9.85sec, Botswana's Letsile Tebogo sixth in 9.86sec, American Kenny Bednarek seventh in 9.88sec and Jamaican Oblique Seville eighth in 9.91sec in an astonishing race.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nStarting in lane seven, outside Seville and inside Tebogo, Lyles got off to an average start but was soon into his stride pattern.\n\nHead tucked down through to the 40-metre mark, the American opened up, but the whole field pushed him all the way.\n\nAs Lyles dipped for the line with Thompson charging alongside him, the crowd erupted and a photo-finish was called before Lyles was confirmed as gold medallist.\n\nThere was an electric pre-race atmosphere in a 69,000-capacity Stade de France, a light show and booming bass-heavy music keeping the crowd entertained as the sprinters made the final adjustments to their starting blocks.\n\nThe lights were then shut off, the sprinters leaving the track to remake their entrance like prize fighters in a colosseum.\n\nCalled out over the tannoy, each sprinter was individually introduced behind an image of their name above their flag.\n\nThompson roared, hands clenched in fists as his head rolled back. Kerley patted his heart.\n\nLyles bounded out like a kangaroo, bouncing 20 metres down the track. Jacobs was the definition of cool, raising both arms and calmly walking to his blocks.\n\nThen came the moment where the sprinters set, at the starter's beck and call.\n\nThe wait seemed interminable. The music continued, the crowd clapped in unison as if to hurry the starter, then the sprinters stood in their lanes, rocking from foot to foot and the tension was palpable.\n\nThe cameras panned one more and then it was time, the only sound that of a helicopter's wings whirring overhead.\n\nThe shot was fired and the field moved as if one up the purple track.\n\nRead Next Related Reads Irish trio eliminated from kayak cross ahead of Olympic quarter-finals Rhys McClenaghan has his sights set on more apparatus and more medals at LA 2028\n\nThe photo-finish officials examined the evidence and {"uri": "8259136252", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "22:02:17", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T22:02:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T22:00:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5607843399047852, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/olympic-100-metres-champion-noah-215203938.html", "title": "Olympic 100 metres champion Noah Lyles feared photo finish had gone against him", "body": "Newly-crowned Olympic champion Noah Lyles revealed he thought Jamaica's Kishane Thompson had beaten him to 100 metres gold following their photo finish in Paris.\n\nEvery occupant of the 80,000-seat Stade de France seemed to inhale at once before a roar erupted as the 27-year-old American's name appeared first on the screen, then announced to the stadium as the victor by just five thousandths of a second, a winning time of 9.79.784 seconds.\n\nThe 27-year-old rang the victory bell hard, fait accompli after setting out to settle the \"fastest man\" debate once and for all in France.\n\nLyles, whose US team-mate Fred Kerley took bronze, said: \"I knew that when the time came, for me to be able to say 'this is the final, this is where I need to put it together' I was going to do it.\n\n\"I did think (Thompson) had it at the end. I went up to him after, while we were waiting, and I even said 'I think you've got that, good going,' and then my name popped up and I'm like 'oh my gosh, I'm amazing'.\n\n\"I'm going to be honest, I wasn't ready to see it (his name) and that's the first time I've ever said that. I wasn't ready to see it.\n\n\"He was quite a few lanes down, he was in four, I was in seven so it was hard for me to picture where we were.\"\n\nThe American world 100m and 200m champion's triumph comes three summers after he entered the postponed Tokyo 2020 Olympics as the 200m favourite and world champion - but only claimed bronze.\n\nAfterwards, he opened up about a lifelong battle with depression and the challenges of balancing the benefits of antidepressant medication with side effects that led to weight gain and affected his ability to perform - ultimately electing to wean off the treatment before those Games.\n\nEarlier this week, he acknowledged he performs better in front of a full house, remembering the moment on the start line in Tokyo when he would usually say to himself \"it's showtime\", but instead found himself thinking \"this is not it. This is not fun. This is not cool. This is not what I wanted.\"\n\nLyles had no such trouble in Paris, where he thumped his chest at the start line and pumped up the electrified crowd, clearly revelling in the occasion, before they fell so quiet at the start of the race that it was possible to hear a plane passing overhead.\n\nThen the man whose weakness is often said to be his starts got off to the joint slowest, an 0.178 reaction time alongside Botswana's Letsile Tebogo.\n\nLyles, only learning that fact from a journalist, said: \"Slowest reaction time - that's crazy! I thought I was a little better than that but that goes to prove that reaction time does not win races.\"\n\nHe entered these Olympics with the third-fastest time at 100m this year behind Thompson's world-leading 9.77 and Kenyan Ferdinand Omanyala's 9.79, and as a result found himself in a position of needing to back up his signature bravado on Sunday night.\n\nThompson qualified fastest of the semi-finalists in 9.80, his compatriot Seville Oblique just behind him in a personal-best 9.81 and Lyles two hundredths of a second behind.\n\nOblique was the only man who did not have to wait for his place to be confirmed - the last-placed man in 9.91.\n\nLyles is in Paris with a point to prove, embroiled in a debate before the Games about who was currently fastest man on the planet - not that he ever had any doubts.\n\nThe Floridian - who is looking to do the double in the 200 metres - emphatically reiterated his answer, this time with his feet instead of his rhetoric.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8259656545", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "07:53:10", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T07:53:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T07:52:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5607843399047852, "url": "https://www.newsbytesapp.com/news/sports/olympics-fastest-male-athletes-to-complete-100m-race/story", "title": "Fastest male athletes to complete the 100m race at Olympics", "body": "The men's 100-meter final at the 2024 Paris Olympics was a grueling one. All eight sprinters crossed the finish line in an almighty heap and the winner was decided subsequently. USA's Noah Lyles claimed the gold by a whisker as he was just ahead of second-placed Kishane Thompson of Jamaica. Let's decode the fastest male athletes to complete the 100m race at the Olympics.\n\nJamaican legend Usain Bolt claimed eight medals at the Olympics, all gold. The sprinter covered 100 meters in just 9.63 seconds in the final of the 2012 London Games. This remains an all-time Olympic record. Bolt also holds the second spot on this list, having clocked 9.69 seconds in the final of the 2008 event, which took place in Beijing.\n\nIn Yohan Blake, we have another Jamaican on this list. He clocked 9.75 seconds in the 2012 London Games final but had to settle for the silver as Bolt walked away with the gold. Notably, that was Blake's debut Olympics campaign. Meanwhile, the bronze in that race went to USA's Justin Gatlin, who timed 9.79 seconds. Gatlin hence stands fourth on the all-time list.\n\nThe 2024 men's 100-meter final was a crazy affair as Lyles triumphed by an extremely narrow margin. Both Lyles and Thompson bobbed over the line in 9.79 seconds and it took several replays to decide the winner. The official results showed just how close it was. {"uri": "8259145698", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "22:18:38", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T22:18:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T22:12:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5607843399047852, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/reuters/article-13708367/Olympics-Athletics-Thompson-close-Jamaica-US-rivalry-rumbles-on.html", "title": "Olympics-Athletics-Thompson so close as Jamaica-US rivalry rumbles on", "body": "By Helen Reid\n\nPARIS, Aug 4 (Reuters) - Jamaica's Kishane Thompson came so close to emulating his compatriot Usain Bolt and becoming Olympic 100 metres champion on Sunday but American Noah Lyles denied him by a heartbeat.\n\nThompson led for most of the race and clocked the same 9.79 time as Lyles who won by five thousandths of a second in a photo finish after timing his dip to cross the line to perfection.\n\nEven Lyles admitted he thought Thompson, who came into the final as the fastest man this year, had beaten him.\n\n\"He said, 'Hey Kishane I thought you got it' and I said, 'I'm not sure',\" Thompson said.\n\n\"I wasn't patient enough with myself to let my speed bring me at the line, in the position that I know I could have gone to, but I have learned from it.\"\n\nAsked if he thought the pair should share the medal, Thompson said: \"I think the sport is too competitive, no offence to any other sport. It's too competitive for us to share a gold medal.\"\n\nThompson's time - 9.789, against Lyles' 9.784 - was two hundredths of a second off his personal best of 9.77 set in June.\n\nThe Lyles-Thompson showdown was the latest chapter in a sprint rivalry between the U.S. and Jamaica that has gripped the sport for almost two decades.\n\nBolt won three successive 100 and 200 metres Olympic golds, and Yohan Blake weighed in with a silver in 2012. In world championships, Bolt and Blake won four 100s in a row between from 2009 to 2015 while Bolt nailed four successive 200s and helped his country to four sprint relay golds.\n\nIt was a domination the United States could not match during the best part of a century as the sprint superpower, and with Jamaica's women also routinely filling the top step of their podiums, the Caribbean nation was on top of the world.\n\nSince Bolt's retirement in 2017, however, Jamaica's gold rush has dried up, and a succession of male sprinters have been built up as \"the new Bolt\", a pressure they could surely do without.\n\n\"I know that Jamaica would have wanted me to get the gold, everybody loves winners,\" Thompson said. \"I would have loved to win today, but big up to the whole field.\"\n\nFellow Jamaican Oblique Seville, who had beaten Lyles to win their semi-final on Sunday, was left in tears after finishing last, albeit in an impressive time of 9.91 seconds. {"uri": "2024-08-444260004", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "08:33:15", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T08:33:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T07:26:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5607843399047852, "url": "https://www.insidethegames.biz/articles/1147458/lyles-wants-to-use-his-victory-to-t", "title": "Lyles wants to use 100m victory to transform American athletics", "body": "After his spectacular victory in the 100 metres event held at Paris 2024, Noah Lyles wants to drive a transformation in American athletics. The sprinter is calling for greater visibility and financial support for the sport in his country, to restore the international glory it once had.\n\nLast Sunday, the 27-year-old American sprinter broke the title drought that the United States had been maintaining for a couple of decades in the 100m race, perhaps the most prestigious event of the Games. The victory was especially significant for Lyles, who has repeatedly criticised the low profile of athletics in his country, where sports such as the NBA, NFL and baseball dominate the media attention and fan base.\n\nLyles hopes that his gold medal, coupled with the success of the Netflix documentary series 'Sprint', will provide an opportunity for athletics, and himself, to gain more visibility and financial support. \"I want to see a continuation of the ability to seize moments for our sport. Sprint was a success and I know they are already filming the second season. They've done a good job of getting the word out about our sport,\" Lyles told a press conference.\n\nThe Olympic champion stressed the importance of making the sport more accessible to everyone. \"We need to make this as accessible as possible for people, so they don't have to search on hard-to-find websites or pay to watch it. This is a global sport and we need to show it to the world,\" he said.\n\nLyles emphasised that in order for athletics to grow in popularity and reach a wider audience, it is essential to facilitate access to competitions and events. According to the sprinter, this greater accessibility could be the key to increasing the fan base and ultimately attracting more sponsors and commercial opportunities.\n\nFrom a personal perspective, Lyles hopes that his success will lead a major sporting goods manufacturer to create a line of shoes with his name on them, emulating Michael Jordan's famous deal with Nike. According to the runner, few American athletes have had the opportunity to have their own brand of footwear. \"I want my own shoe,\" Lyles declared. \"I want my own shoe. I really do. There's no money in the spikes of athletic shoes. Even Michael Johnson didn't have his own shoe. It's amazing to me that, with the amount of medals we win and the notoriety we get, that hasn't happened yet. So that needs to change.\"\n\nLyles stressed the importance of recognising the value and contribution of track athletes, as he understands that track athletes, despite their achievements, do not receive the same level of recognition and financial rewards as athletes in other disciplines. A shoe deal would not only be a significant personal achievement for the American, but could also open the door for other runners to receive similar opportunities.\n\nFinally, Lyles expressed relief at fulfilling his promise of victory, after proclaiming all season that he was \"unbeatable\". \"It's satisfying to be able to back up my words,\" Lyles said. \"I've seen a lot of cases where athletes come in as favourites and things don't end up going their way.\" His ability to handle pressure and live up to expectations has cemented his status as one of the world's top athletes, and his victory could be the catalyst American athletics needs to reach new heights.\n\nLyles has ended America's long wait for a gold medal in the 100m sprint, as the last time an American won gold in this category was in Athens in 2004, with Justin Gatlin. {"uri": "8259185663", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "23:15:55", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T23:15:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T23:14:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5607843399047852, "url": "https://sportstar.thehindu.com/olympics/paris-2024/news/noah-lyles-kishane-thompson-who-actually-won-100m-final-paris-olympics-2024-rules-athletics-photo-finish-explainer/article68486318.ece", "title": "Noah Lyles or Kishane Thompson: Athletics photo finish rules explained - Paris 2024 Olympics 100m final analysis", "body": "World champion Noah Lyles roared to victory in 9.79sec to claim gold in a dramatic men's Olympic 100m final in Paris on Sunday.\n\nLyles won in the closest Olympic 100m finish in modern history as just five thousandths of a second separated him from Jamaica's Kishane Thompson.\n\nBoth were given the rounded-up time of 9.79sec but the American's name carried the all-important (.784) to Thompson's (.789.)\n\nSpectators and the athletes themselves were stunned with the result with Thompson having led majority of the race. The photo finish image appears to show Thompson's leg ahead of the the finish line further than Lyles. So how then did Lyles take the gold?\n\nHere's a breakdown of the simple rules of a photo finish in athletics.\n\nHow does World Athletics - the body governing international athletics - explain a photo finish?\n\nAs the runners approach the finish line, a \"slit-video\" system scans an ultra-thin segment of the track precisely aligned with the finish line -- scans it 2,000 times per second, providing an unbroken image of each athlete crossing the line -- and coordinates it with the athlete's time.\n\nIn addition to that, there's a back-up camera on the other side of the field in case a runner is hidden or blocked by another runner.\n\nThe flash timer that clocks the final times of athletes has a margin of error which at worse can throw up an error within 0.01 or 0.02 of the official time.\n\nNow the most important part to determine the official timing which in turn decides the race is the body part that has to cross the finish line.\n\nIn the 100m final in the Paris Olympics, Thompson's foot looks like it breached first. But the body part that has to cross the finish line for an official registration of timing is the torso of the athlete. The torso or the trunk of a person includes the chest, abdomen, pelvis, and the back.\n\nLatest on SportstarNoah Lyles wins 100m final: How is a photo finish decided in Olympics?Team SportstarTNPL {"uri": "8259316936", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "02:35:08", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T02:35:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T02:33:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5568627715110779, "url": "https://www.dnaindia.com/sports/report-meet-world-s-fastest-man-noah-lyles-who-won-men-s-100m-olympic-gold-beats-jamaica-s-kishane-by-3100421", "title": "Meet world's fastest man Noah Lyles who won men's 100m Olympic Gold, beats Jamaica's Kishane by...", "body": "Lyles needed to produce something special in the biggest race of his career. He tapped into his prime and delivered his personal best performance in front of a jam-packed crowd at the Stade de France.\n\nThe United States' Noah Lyles won the men's 100-meter final at the Paris Olympics on Saturday, August 4, making him the fastest man in the world. In one of the most thrilling 100-meter finals in Games history, Jamaica's Kishane Thompson took home the silver medal, narrowly missing out on the gold. USA's Fred Kerley won the bronze, and Italy's highly strapped Tokyo Olympics champion Jacobs Lamont Marcell came in fifth.\n\nKnown for his explosive acceleration and finishing power, Lyles set an amazing time to win the gold, just missing out on Thompson, who made an equally remarkable but ultimately unsuccessful attempt to settle for silver. The picture finish demonstrated the intense rivalry in the Olympic Games and emphasised the razor-thin margins that determine success in the world of sprinting.\n\nIn a race that wrapped up within a blink of an eye, Noah clocked of 9.784s to walk away with the gold. He was just 0.16 seconds of breaking the legendary Usain Bolt's Olympic record of 9.63s. Jamaica's Kishane Thompson settled for silver after falling short by a fraction of a second in one of the closest 100m races in the history of the Summer Games.\n\nNoah's compatriot Fred Kerley clinched the bronze medal with his season-best timing of 9.81s. Following his triumph, Noah became the first United States athlete to bag a gold since Justin Gatlin stood at the top of the podium in 2004 in the 100m race.\n\nAthletes had to wait for some time for the results as all eight sprinters participating in the event were separated by the tiniest of the margins for the gold medal. In the end, it was declared that Noah had 0.005s ahead of Kishane to finish at the top of the podium. Following the announcement, the crowd erupted in a roar and went berserk, applauding the American sprinter for his remarkable triumph.\n\nHe ripped his name from his shirt and held it high in the air. South Africa's Akane Simbine once again missed out on a podium finish by a whisker as he finished fourth. In the Tokyo and Rio Olympics, Simbine was close but fell short of getting his hands on an Olympic medal in the event. {"uri": "2024-08-443888525", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "21:32:16", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T21:32:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T21:20:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5529412031173706, "url": "https://www.independent.ie/sport/olympics/noah-lyles-relishes-role-as-the-main-character-after-earning-title-of-the-worlds-fastest-man/a676807235.html", "title": "Noah Lyles relishes role as the main character after earning title of the world's fastest man", "body": "He talks a big game, to the annoyance of many, but Noah Lyles has always backed it up.\n\nSo it was at the Stade de France last night as the reigning world champion powered to victory in the sport's blue-riband event, the Olympic 100m final, just five thousandths of a second ahead of Jamaica's Kishane Thompson - both men clocking 9.79 (+1.0m/s).\n\nLyles, 27, is never one to get on with things in a hurry, despite now being the undisputed fastest man in the world, the back end of his race being what separates him from the rest. Generally, all the US star needs is to have a sniff at halfway and then his rivals are running scared. That was exactly what transpired here.\n\nAfter a decent semi-final earlier in the night, when he clocked 9.83 behind Jamaica's Oblique Seville (9.81), Lyles emerged for the final wired to the hilt, hopping around in front of his blocks, geeing up the crowd.\n\nThe others were more subdued, but Lyles has long considered himself the main character in this sport and as he stood behind his blocks, awaiting starter's orders, he continued yelping, psyching himself up with self-talk, doing his best to unsettle his rivals.\n\nThompson, who had the world lead at 9.77, got off to a decent start but the giant Jamaican had yet to face pressure like this, needing to stay relaxed as an Olympic gold medal appeared within grasp. Around the same time Lyles loomed up in his peripheral vision, Thompson tightened up, and in the 100m there's no bigger threat to top-end speed than tension.\n\nAfter the finish, Lyles faced a nerve-racking period of waiting, gazing, hoping, before he saw the result he had spoken into existence. Noah Lyles: Olympic champion.\n\n\"You couldn't have asked for a bigger moment,\" he said.\n\nLyles admitted he was \"a little upset\" after clocking just 10.04 in his heat.\n\n\"I came with the aggression and after I ran the 9.83, I said I was done with that and my sports therapist said, 'You gotta let go, release it'.\"\n\nThat he did, staying admirably relaxed in the final and running his way into the history books. Given his form, it will come as a huge surprise if he doesn't add 200m gold.\n\n\"There's plenty more [to come],\" he said. \"I hope you guys like Noah, because I got a lot more coming.\"\n\nElsewhere, Cathal Doyle produced a fine performance in the 1,500m semi-finals, the Clonliffe athlete finishing 10th in a lifetime best of 3:33.15, moving him second on the Irish all-time list.\n\nDoyle ran in the middle of the pack as 400m was reached in a swift 57 seconds and 800m in 1:55, but he got shuffled to the back on the third lap, passing the bell 12th.\n\nHe unleashed his typically strong final lap to close on the leaders down the back straight, turning for home with just a few metres to find to reach an Olympic final via a top-six finish. But in his third race in three days - having won the repechage the day before - he had little left to offer.\n\n\"I'm not a million miles off the top 12 in the world,\" he said. \"Obviously, I was a tiny bit disappointed when I saw the time, I wanted a 3:32 and three races in a row is not ideal. But I thought I'd feel worse.\n\n\"I positioned myself well, got myself up and in the mix. The legs started pinching earlier than I'd hoped and it's hard when everyone is going for it - the whole field at the same pace. Usually, I can just drift past people.\n\n\"But I didn't give up, I fought and got back in the mix and with 250 to go I was like, 'Shit, do I have a chance here?'\"\n\nDoyle had reason to reflect with pride on his first global championship.\n\n\"This is my first year where I've had barely any niggles. It's another year of more training. I switched coach in October and I joined a new group. With another year of being around them, I'll hopefully move myself to Brighton, find a job or an income so I can go over and stay with them full-time. That will bring me on again even more.\"\n\nMeanwhile, in the first 1,500m semi-final, Jakob Ingebrigtsen of Norway and Josh Kerr of Britain served up an appetiser for what's ahead in tomorrow's final.\n\nAfter a slow opening lap, Ingebrigtsen, the reigning Olympic champion, swept to the front and kept the pace strong thereafter. With Kerr tracking his every move, the pair kept a lid on things and didn't let their egos take over down the home straight.\n\nIngebrigtsen coasted to the finish in 3:32.88, with Kerr looking equally relaxed just behind in 3:32.46.", "source": {"uri": "independent.ie", "dataType": "news", "title": "Irish Independent"}, "authors": [{"uri": "cathal_dennehy@independent.ie", "name": "Cathal Dennehy", {"uri": "8259162980", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "22:40:51", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T22:40:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T22:39:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5529412031173706, "url": "https://www.theguardian.com/sport/article/2024/aug/04/noah-lyles-proves-the-perfect-star-for-the-perfect-stage-this-is-his-games", "title": "Noah Lyles proves the perfect star for the perfect stage: this is his Games | Barney Ronay", "body": "American sprinter has been talking about this for so long, sketching out his legend in plain sight. It took 30 paces to make it real\n\nNoah Lyles always said he was a star. He told anyone who would listen, from coaches, to fellow athletes, to the population of the world via the high-rolling Netflix film Sprint. Well, now they really are going to have to believe him, as on a lovely soft powder blue night in Saint Denis, Lyles produced one of the most startling Olympic sprint final finishes to claim the Paris 2024 men's 100m gold medal.\n\nLyles, the US and world No 1, had been an extraordinary presence in the build-up to this race. He is almost overwhelmingly charming in the flesh, all superstar sheen and utterly disarming honesty about his own flaws, his own superhero strengths, always on, always capturing the main stage. By the time he reached the start line in Paris for the men's final - along with the women's race, the keynote of this entire two-week circus - there was a sense of a man right on the edge. But of what exactly?\n\nIn the event it required an extraordinary act of will mid-race to seize this moment. With 50 metres run in Paris Lyles was in seventh place. The day was starting to stretch and fray at the edges, to take on a different shape in those strangely still mid-race seconds.\n\nLyles might have begun to tighten and lose his forward thrust. Instead he produced an astonishing slingshot finish, surging through the field to take the race by five thousandths of a second. And so the Olympic Games, always so hungry for product, light, heat, has a new star.\n\nLyles is 27. This is his Games, his moment in the crosshairs, the perfect star, and the perfect stage. In the moments before the race the Stade had been drenched in a spectacular light show. A middle aged man in sunglasses had appeared on the big screen to do some DJ-ing, as though only this could possibly increase the glamour, the electricity of the moment.\n\nThe real challenge to Lyles here was Kishane Thompson from Jamaica, a wonderful emerging talent. Thompson is so new to this level he doesn't even have a proper biography on the IOC website (it basically says, Gender: Male. Function: athlete).\n\nBut he had looked awesome in the semi-finals, running as though the air was frankly a little too thin for his liking. Here he came out and roared like a lion. Lyles did something wild, running off down the track, bouncing and whirling, grabbing great handfuls of air. Hmm. Was that a good idea? Was it actually worth doing anything else at this stage?\n\nIt is no secret that there are wider pressures in play here. Seb Coe and World Athletics always had a plan for these Olympic Games. The entire staging is in effect a product relaunch for track and field as a whole.\n\nThe epic years of the cold war opposition are long gone, that period where the sprint records were held up as a kind of barometer of human progress, like the arms race or the moon landings. Usain Bolt's brilliance kept the circus afloat. But really this spectacle has become second tier since Rio 2016.\n\nIt shouldn't be like this. Sprinting is a perfect spectator sport, so simple, so accessible. This is primal stuff. The humans are running. The humans are running fast. Who is the fastest human? But on a scale of talent versus fame the world's greatest sprinters are also among the world's least recognisable elite athletes.\n\nThe answer is to create stars. And World Athletics has invested. Only this week Coe could be heard talking in Paris about the Netflix documentary Sprint, of which he is an executive producer, boasting of its status as the sixth most viewed entity on the platform. It's a nice piece of work, but it is also framed to transform its two most marketable properties, Lyles and Sha'Carri Richardson into global stars, a twin pronged assault linked to these Games.\n\nUnfortunately life is what tends to happen while you're making plans. There was an indelible glory to Julien Alfred's gold in the women's 100m on Saturday night, a first ever medal for St Lucia. But it also contained a note of mischief. The best part of sport is that it just won't follow the script.\n\nSo we came to Lyles and the men's race. The sky above the lip of the roof was still pink as the athletes knelt at their blocks. Sprinters come in different genres. Most follow the angry avenger template, always chasing something. Then we have the prey, the sprinter who seems instead to be fleeing. Britain's newest star Louie Hinchliffe runs like he's being chased by a swarm of bees.\n\nThompson is a classic floater, the sprinter who will kill you with grace. That ease of movement is in at own way an act of aggression, telling you always about strength in reserve. Lyles is a hybrid. He moves with wonderful grace, has astonishing efficiency once he gets past his drive phase, up into full flow.\n\nHis weakness is his start, which was again terrible here. Thomson eased away, eating up the air in front of him, his own moment approaching. At which point, something strange happened, the entire field seeming to tense up, to go backwards while moving at preternatural speed. Only Lyles didn't. He has been talking about this for so long, sketching out his legend in plain sight. It took 30 paces to make it real. And from here the future seems wide open.", "source": {"uri": "theguardian.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Guardian"}, "authors": [{"uri": "barney_ronay@theguardian.com", "name": "Barney
