{"uri": "8259386295", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "03:59:48", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T03:59:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T03:58:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5529412031173706, "url": "https://www.enca.com/sport/lyles-wins-olympic-100m-gold-closest-finish-modern-history", "title": "Lyles wins Olympic 100m gold in closest finish in modern history", "body": "\"I'm usually a guy who likes to come out blazing in all my rounds, especially in the 200m. But the 100m, it's my first time here on the Olympic stage.\"\n\nThe relatively unknown Thompson, the fastest man this year with a best of 9.77sec, said he hadn't been \"fresh enough\" over the final 30 metres.\n\n\"I couldn't really see Lyles, I wasn't sure,\" 23-year-old Thompson said of the photo-finish. \"It was that close.\n\n\"I'm going to take it and move forward from here,\" he said. \"Everybody loves a winner so I would have loved to win today, but I loved the competition overall.\"\n\nLyles' US teammate Fred Kerley took bronze in 9.81sec, just one-hundredth ahead of South African Akani Simbine, who timed 9.82sec.\n\n\"I don't feel any frustration because I'm facing the best in the world,\" said Kerley, the 2022 world champion and Olympic silver medallist over 100m three years ago at the Tokyo Games.\n\n\"At the end of the day, not many people can say they came to the Olympic Games,\" Kerley said. \"Whoever came off the best is the best. It's my second time around and I'm going off with a medal.\"\n\nIn an astonishing race, defending champion Marcell Jacobs of Italy was fifth in 9.85sec, Botswana's Letsile Tebogo sixth in 9.86sec, American Kenny Bednarek seventh in 9.88sec and Jamaican Oblique Seville eighth in 9.91sec.\n\nStarting in lane seven, outside Seville and inside Tebogo, Lyles got off to an average start but was soon into his stride pattern.\n\nHead tucked down through to the 40-metre mark, the American opened up, but the whole field pushed him all the way.\n\nAs Lyles dipped for the line with Thompson charging alongside him, the crowd erupted and a photo-finish was called before Lyles was confirmed as gold medallist.\n\nThere was an electric pre-race atmosphere in a 69,000-capacity Stade de France, a light show and booming music keeping the crowd entertained as the sprinters adjusted their starting blocks.\n\nThe lights then went off and the sprinters leaving the track to remake their entrance like prize fighters in a colosseum, with each sprinter individually introduced behind an image of their name above their flag.\n\nThompson roared, hands clenched in fists as his head rolled back. Kerley patted his heart.\n\nLyles bounded out like a kangaroo, bouncing 20 metres down the track. Jacobs was the definition of cool, raising both arms and calmly walking to his blocks.\n\nThen came the moment where the sprinters set, at the starter's beck and call.\n\nThe wait seemed interminable. The music continued, the crowd clapped in unison, then the sprinters stood in their lanes, rocking from foot to foot and the tension was palpable, while the only sound was that of a helicopter whirring overhead.\n\nThe shot was fired and the field moved as if one up the purple track to the dramatic denouement.\n\nThe photo-finish officials examined the evidence and Lyles walked away with gold to bury the demons of the Tokyo Olympics three years ago where he harvested a mere 200m bronze.\n\nAsked whether he was confident of doubling up in the 200m, an event in which he is a three-time world champion, Lyles was in no doubt.\n\n\"100 percent,\" he said. \"That's my better event and now that I've got a new PR in the 100, I'm ready to take it to the 200.\"", "source": {"uri": I want a sneaker ... Ain't no money in spikes. Even Michael Johnson didn't have a sneaker,\" he told reporters, referring to the U.S. sprinter who won four gold medals.\n\nLyles, who crossed the finish line in 9.79 seconds, used the new personal best moment to place pressure on sportswear giants who have prioritized other sports like basketball and soccer more than lesser known track and field. It's the latest response for Lyles who has felt slighted by the lack of mainstream attention he receives despite being a generational talent. Earlier this year, Lyles signed a lucrative contract extension with Adidas, reportedly the richest in track and field since Usain Bolt's deal with Puma, but he remains outspoken that he and his sport deserve more.\n\n\"America, I told you. I got next!\" he said after winning the event. He re-emphasized that he was the world's fastest man with the first-place finish. It garnered attention from multiple celebrities and sports stars, including former NBA guard Dwyane Wade, who periodically paints his nails like Lyles.\n\nLyles became the first American to win the 100-meter event at the Olympics since Justin Gatlin did it 20 years ago. It was his first of two individual events at the summer Olympics as he looks to become the first since Bolt to win the 100 meter and 200 meter in the same Olympics.\n\nIn the meantime, he is using this moment to create more marketing exposure for himself and the sport itself which has struggled to gain mainstream fandom due to a lack of visibility and commercial infrastructure. The 27-year-old has quickly grown to become one of the most beloved and controversial American sprinters of all time.\n\nAfter he won a gold medal in three events at the World Athletics Championships in Budapest last August, he spoke out about NBA players crowning themselves as world champions. Some of the NBA's stars clapped back on social media. {"uri": "2024-08-443876873", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "21:06:35", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T21:06:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T16:56:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5490196347236633, "url": "https://www.firstcoastnews.com/article/sports/olympics/what-body-part-has-to-cross-the-finish-line-first-can-you-dive-across-the-finish-line/507-37eaa856-41f8-4b9b-8c71-5cd6d198f455", "title": "What part of the body has to cross the finish line first in track?", "body": "The title of \"World's Fastest Man\" at the Paris Olympics came down to just .005 seconds.\n\nPARIS, France -- The finish to the men's 100 meters at the 2024 Paris Olympics was one of the closest in Summer Games history.\n\nAmerican Noah Lyles took the title of the \"World's Fastest Man\" by just .005 seconds and it was determined by a photo finish. On the TV broadcast, it was hard to tell whether Lyles or Jamaica's Kishane Thompson crossed first.\n\nAfter some 30 seconds, it was announced Lyles won in 9.784 seconds to edge out the Jamaican by five-thousandths of a second. The breathtaking race had many wondering what were the specific rules surrounding photo finishes and what counts as crossing the finish line at the Olympics.\n\nThe Olympic rules state, a runner crosses the finish line when their torso crosses, which is different from their head. That's why some runners lean forward when they cross the line, so their torso crosses first.\n\nYes, it is legal for runners to dive across the finish line, but it's dangerous and not much faster than just running those last few steps.\n\nFor example, in ESPN's Sports Science feature about running or sliding in baseball, they found the jump is faster when the runner first takes off, but acceleration actually decreases while they're in the air.\n\nNoah Lyles won Sunday's excruciatingly close sprint to beat Kishane Thompson of Jamaica.\n\nAn Olympic-sized track is 400 meters around, which is just shy of a quarter of a mile.\n\nFour hundred meters, or one lap around a track, equals about a quarter-mile.", "source": {"uri": "firstcoastnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "WTLV {"uri": "8259940321", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "10:58:30", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T10:58:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T10:57:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5490196347236633, "url": "https://www.livemint.com/sports/0005-seconds-this-is-how-noah-lyles-won-the-closest-finish-in-100m-history-11722854443532.html", "title": "0.005 seconds: This is how Noah Lyles won the closest Finish in 100m History", "body": "SAINT-DENIS, France -- It took Noah Lyles 9.79 seconds to run 100 meters on Sunday night. It took 29.47 seconds for him to find out that he actually won.\n\nOnce the closest, tensest men's 100-meter final in modern Olympic history was over, the real drama was only beginning.\n\nThe race was so tight that the man who crossed the line first suspected that he'd finished second. Lyles put a hand on the shoulder of Jamaica's Kishane Thompson to congratulate him. Thompson stared at the Stade de France scoreboard, willing the photo finish to go his way. \"Come on, man!\" he shouted.\n\nSome 70,000 spectators held their breath. In the time it took to crown the winner, Lyles and Thompson could have run 100 meters three more times.\n\nThat was when one of the most advanced scoring systems in any sport on the planet got to work.\n\nTo determine that Lyles had won by a margin of five thousandths of a second, it took three judges, three high-speed cameras -- and a willingness to make the fastest men alive stand around and wait.\n\nDuring those agonizing moments, the runners' fates were in the hands of a team from Omega Timing, which has been responsible for tracking every fraction of a second at the Olympics for nearly a century.\n\nThis year, the company that operates with Swiss precision debuted something called Scan'O'Vision Ultimate, a new ultra-high-speed camera. And on Sunday night, as Lyles and Thompson crossed the finish line at almost exactly the same time, there were two of those cameras positioned to shoot down the finish line from outside the track, while a third sat inside the oval capturing the reverse shot.\n\nEach one of those cameras had a single job: taking 40,000 images per second of a race that would come down to a photo finish.\n\nThe impossible closeness of the race -- barely a tenth of a second separated first and last place -- made it \"a perfect showcase for our technology,\" said Omega CEO Alain Zobrist.\n\nAfter the runners crossed the line, three federation judges worked alongside an operator of each camera. A runner is deemed to have crossed the finish line when his torso breaks the vertical plane rising from it. The judges asked the operators to toggle forward and backward in time until they found the exact instant the winner crossed.\n\nWhile the judges studied the smallest slivers of time, the athletes suffered a test of their patience more exhausting than sprinting 100 meters. In fact, the judges worked for three times as long as the race itself before determining that Lyles had crossed the line in 9.784 -- or 0.005 second faster than Thompson.\n\n\"I wasn't ready to see it,\" Lyles admitted. \"That's the first time I've ever said that in my head.\"\n\nIt is the athletes' job to move as fast as humanly possible. The judges have the opposite job: to go as slowly as they need to, to get the result right.\n\n\"It's not about speed,\" Zobrist said. \"It's about publishing the right results. You double-check, triple-check before you press the enter button\" -- the button pressed by the lead judge that flashes the winner's name on the scoreboard -- \"because there is no going back.\"\n\nToday's sprinters should consider themselves lucky. There was a time when Lyles would've had to wait much longer to learn he'd become a gold medalist. In the 1940s, when the photo finish began, the cameras had actual film in them. After the runners broke the line, photographers had to walk next door to a darkroom to figure out what just happened.\n\n\"It could take up to two hours to know who actually won the race,\" Zobrist said.\n\nElsewhere in today's Olympics, judges turn to decidedly old-school techniques to define the margins between victory and defeat. At Roland Garros, tennis umpires don't use the Hawk-Eye tracking system. Instead, the umpire scampers down to the court, walks over to the line and inspects the dusky red clay for the imprint of a tennis ball.\n\nBut eyeballing won't suffice in races where 0.01 seconds can make all the difference.\n\nIn 2008, Omega's technology revealed that Michael Phelps had beaten the second-place finisher in the 100-meter butterfly by exactly that margin.\n\nAnd on Sunday, that same tech ruled on a race that even the sprinters themselves didn't know who won. In fact, it was functionally impossible for any person, watching with their own eyes, to see who'd captured the title of world's fastest man. The human eye takes about 0.1 seconds to blink. In that time, Omega's cameras capture 400 images.\n\n\"It was hard for me to picture where we were,\" Lyles said of the moment that made him an Olympic icon.\n\nHe didn't have to.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-08-443884812", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "21:24:55", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T21:24:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T21:20:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.545098066329956, "url": "https://www.thesun.co.uk/sport/29680952/noah-lyles-olympics-2024-100m-usain-bolt-dave-kidd/", "title": "Noah Lyles a breathless self-publicist but he'll be global star like Usain Bolt", "body": "An Olympic legend labelled it the greatest ever Olympic 100-metre race\n\nNOAH LYLES had ants in his pants, a spring in his step and nothing but gold in his eyes.\n\nWhile his seven rivals for the title of the world's fastest man chilled out on the starting line, this hyperactive American showman raced half way up the track, leapt up and down and beat his chest when they announced his name.\n\nYou feared that the world champion and favourite might have shot his bolt before this blue-riband race had even started - especially when he trailed the field almost halfway through.\n\nBut Lyles switched on the after-burners and dipped at the finishing line in a personal best time of 9.784secs - five thousandths of a second in front of his rival Kishane Thompson of Jamaica.\n\nThen Lyles, 27, had to wait for longer than the race actually took before he was revealed as the winner.\n\nSuddenly it was Noah's Arc de Triomphe in the French capital.\n\nLyles is a breathless self-publicist, the star of a Netflix documentary, with braids in his hair and paint on his fingernails.\n\nHe might now become a global star to emulate Usain Bolt, the world-record holder and three-time Olympic 100m champion.\n\nBolt used to win these stellar events at a canter but for Lyles it was as tight as a gnat's back passage.\n\nThe Florida man was stone-last after 40m but then kicked into action for the night of his life.\n\nCASINO SPECIAL - BEST CASINO WELCOME OFFERS\n\nThese are sport's blink-and-you'll-miss-them men. And that winning margin - just a half of a hundredth of a second - is the difference between glory and heartache.\n\nAnd this is one of sport's greatest spectacles. The deathliest of hushes when they crouch at the blocks, penetrated by the loudest of bangs from the starting pistol, followed by the maddest of dashes for the line.\n\nThe Stade de France was rammed to its 67,000 Olympic capacity and these were the hottest tickets in town.\n\nA stunning light show had preceded the race on a lightning-fast purple track.\n\nLyles and Thompson - who had clocked the fastest time of 2024 - had been expected to contest gold and silver and so it proved.\n\nIt was the fastest field ever - Jamaica's Oblique Seville was eighth and last in 9.91secs.\n\nAnd former 400m champion Michael Johnson declared it the 'greatest of all time', adding 'you could throw a blanket over the finishing line. We didn't even know who won for a few minutes'.\n\nLyles' fellow American Fred Kerley won bronze to add to the silver he won in Tokyo three years ago.\n\nIn the semi-finals, there was heartbreak for Britain's mullet-man Louie Hinchliffe, who had beaten Lyles in Saturday's heat but who paid for a sluggish start and came in third behind Seville and the world champion in 9.97sec, failing to qualify as a fastest loser.\n\nBut Yorkshireman Hinchliffe, 22, promised to make the final in Los Angeles in 2028.\n\nHinchliffe said: \"It was a good experience but I've definitely got a lot to learn. I should have been more relaxed going into it and I was a bit tense at the end. There were a lot of mistakes.\n\n\"I am disappointed. I could have made it a bit easier to make the final.\n\n\"I will come back stronger next year. I will not regress. It's my first year on the scene.\n\n\"Definitely, definitely LA, I will be there in the final - and there are a lot of world championships between then and now.\n\n\"But it was a sub-10-second run. I didn't completely fold.\"\n\nAnd his fellow Brit Zharnel Hughes - a world bronze medalist last year - was way off the pace after a hamstring injury, finishing sixth in the final semi in 10.01sec.\n\nHughes, who goes again in the 200m, said: \"I had a hamstring injury. It is not the easiest thing to come back from.\n\n\"Everything had to be rushed. After the injury you start to get the treatment right away. Race sharpness is my issue.\n\n\"If we had more races, I am a better performer than this. Last year we ended with 9.88 on the podium and with a bronze. I know what I am capable of.\n\n\"I had to be battling with an injury. It kind of sucks, last minute just before the Olympics. But I am a fighter. I'm very determined and that's why I wanted to give it a go.\n\n\"I'm going back to the Village. I am not going to stick around for the final. It makes no sense. It will just make you upset. As a competitive athlete, you want to be a part of the mix. I rarely miss out on finals. So this one is hard to swallow.\"\n\nHughes, as it happened, missed a classic.\n\nLyles was determined that the world would know his name after this night.\n\nIt is likely that we'll never hear the end of him now.", "source": {"uri": "thesun.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Sun"}, "authors": [{"uri": "dave_kidd@thesun.co.uk", "name": "Dave Kidd", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], {"uri": "8259701242", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "08:23:39", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T08:23:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T08:22:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.545098066329956, "url": "https://www.news9live.com/sports/others-sports/noah-lyles-wins-by-0-005-seconds-what-is-photo-finish-and-how-is-it-decided-in-olympics-2643972", "title": "Noah Lyles wins by 0.005 seconds: What is photo finish and how is it decided in Olympics?", "body": "New Delhi: In what was the closest ever 100m final in modern history, American sprinter Noah Lyles clinched the elusive gold medal at the Paris Olympics 2024. It was an incredible finish to the race as Lyles managed to win the gold medal by the barest of margins. The difference between the gold and the silver medal was five-thousandths of a second.\n\nLyles managed to beat Jamaica's Kishane Thompson by 0.005 seconds in what was a dramatic photo finish at the Paris Games. Both sprinters were eventually given a rounded-up timing of 9.79 seconds each but what separated the two was .005 difference in their overall timing.\n\nLyles finished with .784 to Thompson's .789 which saw him finish on the top spot on the podium. Thompson led in the majority of the race but it was Lyles' stunning acceleration towards the end which saw him emerge on top, leaving the fans and his fellow competitors in disbelief.\n\nA photo finish is a term often used to describe an incredibly close race where multiple competitors are finishing a particular race at the same time. In such a case, a photo of the athletes crossing the finishing line is examined and observed to determine the winner. Photo finish is used as the naked eye can't catch the action where the difference could be a few milliseconds or even less.\n\nAt the Olympics and all other major events organised by World Athletics, a slit-video system is used when the runners approach the finish line during an event. The slit-video system has the ability to scan an ultra-thin segment of the track with the finish line. It can scan up to 2000 times per second which helps in determining the timing of each athlete crossing the line.\n\nThere are multiple cameras installed to get different angles in case an athlete's view is blocked by another. But it is not only the foot crossing the finishing line that determines the winner. An athlete's torso has to cross the line for the final timing to be registered. The torso or trunk of a person includes the chest, abdomen, pelvis, and back.\n\nDuring the 100m final at the Paris Olympics, it was Thompson who led for the majority of the race and his foot appeared to have hit the finishing line first. However, it was Lyles who took the gold medal as his torso surpassed the finishing line ahead of the Jamaican, handing him a victory by the barest of margins.", "source": {"uri": "news9live.com", {"uri": "8259575462", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "06:55:09", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T06:55:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T06:54:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5411764979362488, "url": "https://www.rediff.com/sports/report/paris-olympics-therapy-call-powers-noah-lyles-to-100m-gold/20240805.htm", "title": "Therapy call powers Noah Lyles to Olympic 100m gold", "body": "IMAGE: Noah Lyles celebrates after winning the gold medal in the men's 100m at the Paris Olympics on Sunday. Photograph: Dylan Martinez/Reuters\n\nA phone call with his therapist after a worrying semi-final helped propel Noah Lyles to the top of the Olympic podium on Sunday, after years of rebuilding his mental health to reach the pinnacle of his sport.\n\nThe American put on the performance of a lifetime to take the 100 metres gold by five-thousandths of a second in 9.79, in a blistering final where a 9.91 from Jamaican Oblique Seville was only good enough to finish last.\n\nIMAGE: Kenneth Bednarek, Noah Lyles and Kishane Thompson check for the official results. Photograph: Dylan Martinez/Reuters\n\nSeville had crossed the line ahead of Lyles in their semi-final, and the US sprinter said he needed to get into the right mindset for his medal race.\n\n\"I wouldn't say nervous - I'd say I was extremely curious as to what was going to happen. That's how me and my therapist phrase it. I'm curious as to what I'm going to do, how am I going to pull this off,\" he told reporters.\n\n\"I came in third-fastest from the semis. I'm like 'This is going to be serious, this is not going to be easy'. And I had said OK, my therapist said 'You need to let go, you need to relax and you need to be yourself'.\"\n\nIMAGE: It was the first time eight men have broken 10 seconds in a wind-legal 100 metres race. Photograph: Dylan Martinez/Reuters\n\nLyles was familiar with all the highs and lows of his sport long before he arrived in Paris, and has publicly discussed the work he put into his mental health to rebound from the pit of depression he found himself in three years ago.\n\nThe three-times 200m world champion failed even to qualify for the shorter sprint at the US Olympic trials in 2021, and rebuilt himself - body and mind - with the singular goal of becoming the fastest man on earth.\n\nIMAGE: Noah Lyles has publicly discussed the work he put into his mental health to rebound from the pit of depression he found himself in three years ago. Photograph: Dylan Martinez/Reuters\n\n\"I did this against the best of the best, on the biggest stage, with the biggest pressure,\" Lyles said. \"And I wasn't even entered in the 100 in 2021. You know, here I am, first Olympics in the 100, going around now the Olympic champion.\"\n\nLyles will compete next in the 200m as he bids for a rare Olympic sprint double, with the opening rounds set Kerley patted his heart.\n\nLyles bounded out like a kangaroo, bouncing 20 metres down the track. Jacobs was the definition of cool, raising both arms and calmly walking to his blocks.\n\nThen came the moment where the sprinters set, at the starter's beck and call.\n\nThe wait seemed interminable. {"uri": "2024-08-443885104", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "21:25:28", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T21:25:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T20:50:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5372549295425415, "url": "https://www.fox28spokane.com/lyles-wins-olympic-100m-thriller-to-end-us-drought/", "title": "Lyles wins Olympic 100m thriller to end US drought", "body": "Noah Lyles snatched a photo-finish victory in the closest 100m final in modern Olympic history on Sunday to end the United States' 20-year wait to recapture the world's most prestigious sprinting crown.\n\nIn a nerve-shredding final at the Stade de France, Lyles, the charismatic 27-year-old from Florida, took gold by a fraction from Jamaica's Kishane Thompson.\n\nLyles' winning margin boiled down to just five thousandths of a second, with the American clocked at 9.784sec to Thompson's 9.789sec, though both men's times will be listed as 9.79sec.\n\nIt was the narrowest margin of victory since electronic timing has been used at the Olympics.\n\nLyles' compatriot Fred Kerley took bronze in 9.81sec.\n\nThe race was so close that the electronic scoreboard in the arena simply read \"photo\" beside seven of the eight finalists.\n\nAfter an agonising wait of several seconds, Lyles' victory was confirmed, sparking wild celebrations from the reigning 100m and 200m world champion who is regarded as one of the global superstars as athletics.\n\n\"It's the one I wanted,\" an elated Lyles told Eurosport moments after his win.\n\n\"It's the hard battle, it's the amazing opponents. Everybody's healthy, everybody came prepared for the fight and I wanted to prove that I'm the man amongst all of them. I'm the wolf amongst wolves.\"\n\nLyles admitted though that even he had doubted whether he had clinched the gold.\n\n\"I went up to Kishane and I was like, 'I'm gonna be honest, bro, I think you had that one,'\" Lyles said.\n\n\"And I was fully prepared to see his name pop up and to see my name pop up, I'm like goodness gracious. I'm incredible.\"\n\nThe win completes a rollercoaster three years for Lyles, who had left the pandemic-hit Tokyo Olympics in tears after a disappointing campaign, citing his mental health struggles and battles with depression.\n\nThe American is now targeting an Olympic double with victory in the 200m next week.\n\n- Ukraine medal rush -\n\nLyles' win was the sensational final act of another thrilling day in the Olympic athletics arena that saw three gold medals handed out.\n\nIn other action, Ukraine's Yaroslava Mahuchikh lived up to her pre-Paris Games billing to win the women's high jump.\n\nThe world champion and world record holder managed a best of 2.00 metres to win on countback from Australia's Nicola Olyslagers.\n\nAnother Australian, Eleanor Patterson, claimed joint bronze with another Ukrainian, Iryna Gerashchenko, both on 1.95m.\n\nIn the men's hammer, Canadian world champion Ethan Katzberg won after unleashing a mammoth heave with his first throw to clinch the gold medal.\n\nThe 22-year-old from British Columbia registered 84.12m with his opening effort to leave his rivals trailing throughout the competition.\n\nThat was four metres further than his nearest rival, Hungary's Bence Halasz, who took silver with a throw of 79.97m. Ukraine's Mykhaylo Kokhan collected bronze with a throw of 79.39m.\n\nElsewhere Sunday, Sydney McLaughlin-Levrone and Femke Bol eased through the opening round of the women's 400m hurdles to remain on an Olympic collision course.\n\nUS star McLaughlin-Levrone, the reigning Olympic champion and world record holder, cruised through her heat to win in 53.60sec.\n\nBol meanwhile shrugged off the after-effects of her dazzling performance in Saturday's 4x400m mixed relay to coast through her heat in a leading 53.38sec.\n\nAnother mouthwatering duel is looming in the women's 800m, where Britain's Keely Hodgkinson, a silver medallist in Tokyo three years ago, is poised for an epic battle with Kenya's 2023 World Champion Mary Moraa on Monday.\n\nHodgkinson delivered an ice-cool performance to win her semi-final in 1min 56.86sec, the fastest time of the round. Moraa advanced after winning her heat in 1:57.86.\n\nIn the opening round of the men's 400m, Britain's Matt Hudson-Smith got his bid for gold off to a smooth start, winning his heat in 44.78sec.\n\nUS sprinter Michael Norman set the early first round pace however with the quickest time, a brisk 44.10sec. Norman's US team-mate Quincy Hall was second-fastest with a time of 44.28sec.\n\nrcw/gj\n\nFOX28 Spokane\u00a9", "source": {"uri": "fox28spokane.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "FOX 28 Spokane"}, They just do. I don't know why.\n\n\"It's just if somebody says they want to do something great, someone's right there next to say they can't do it.\n\n\"I can give zero cares about what other people think.\n\n\"Because they don't know me, they don't know my story, they don't know what I do, they don't know how hard I work, how talented I am. he finished a disappointing third at the 2021 Olympics in Tokyo.\n\nOf the 10 fastest 200-metre times in the world since the Tokyo games three years ago, he has run eight of them.\n\n\"I'm going to motivate myself regardless,\" Lyles added.\n\n\"I'm going to win regardless.\n\n\"I didn't need a rival at worlds to run 19.3, because there was nobody close to me when that happened.\"\n\nLyles {"uri": "8259118463", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "21:34:58", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T21:34:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T21:34:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5372549295425415, "url": "https://metro.co.uk/2024/08/04/olympic-organisers-slammed-nervy-delay-noah-lyles-100m-final-victory-21359996/", "title": "Olympic organisers slammed for nervy delay before Noah Lyles' 100m final victory", "body": "Steve Cram, Colin Jackson and Denise Lewis joined in voicing their frustrations after the athletes involved in the men's 100m final were made to wait an age for the start of the race.\n\nDespite being outside of the medal places with 50 metres remaining, Noah Lyles clawed his way back to beat Jamaica's Kishane Thompson and fellow countryman Fred Kerley, who claimed silver and bronze respectively.\n\nRemarkably, it was the first time in history that all eight men broke the 10-second barrier in a wind-legal race, with just five thousandths of a second separating Lyles and Thompson in a sensational photo finish.\n\nThe competitors were forced to wait several minutes for the starting gun in nervous scenes before the race - and the athletes faced another anxious wait to learn the winner at its conclusion.\n\nIt's been claimed that a protestor attempted to gain access to the track prior to this evening's showpiece, but this happened before the athletes had even made their entrances was not the reason for the race time having to be pushed back slightly at the Stade de France.\n\n'The tension is building. I've never seen them kept this long on the start line,' Cram said on BBC Sport's commentary of the race.\n\n'They've been introduced to the crowd, they've had the hero walk-ins, something which Lyles has almost made his own, and we're waiting for something here, but I'm not sure what. This isn't helping the guys, this is too long.'\n\nFormer British hurdler Jackson added: 'I'm looking down at the track to see if there are any issues, any problems, because we know this race was supposed to start at least three minutes ago...\n\n'There doesn't seem to be anything happening.\n\n'This is very frustrating for them because this is the biggest race of the year.'\n\nIn the BBC Sport studio, Lewis - who won gold for Britain at the Sydney Games in 2000, said the athletes had been made to wait 'way too long' for the start of the race.\n\nAsked whether she had seen anything like the delay before, Lewis told BBC Sport: 'No and I have to say that it's a little bit unfair to the athletes themselves.\n\n'You get yourself to that arousal point where you're in the zone, you're absolutely wanting to give everything and then that is just waining slightly, the longer you're left out there.\n\n'This is finite margins we're talking about and that for me was just way too long.'\n\nJessica Ennis-Hill, meanwhile, argued that the delay may actually have made for a more exciting race.\n\n'But then I suppose just look at the times,' the London 2012 hero said in response to Lewis' comments.\n\n'That wait and that adrenaline we felt, they felt it too and it produced a fantastic face.'\n\nSpeaking shortly after his sensational win, Lyles said he had to take each round as it came after underwhelming showings in the heats and in the semi-finals.\n\n'I had to take each round as it was. I was a little upset after the first round so I came with the aggression and then after I ran that 9.83, I was like, \"Alright, the aggression, we're done with that\",' he explained.\n\n'My sports therapist said, \"You have to let go, you're holding on... let you and release it!\".\n\n'There's plenty more to come. I hope you guys liked it because I've got a lot more coming.'\n\nMORE : Noah Lyles reveals what he told Kishane Thompson after Olympic 100m photo finish\n\nMORE : Incredible picture shows Noah Lyles NBC's play-by-play announcer Leigh Diffey called Thompson the winner in the moment during its broadcast.\n\nHowever, a winner was not immediately declared as replays and photos were being closely scrutinized. The Jamaican sprinter certainly seemed to think he won, until Lyles came over to tell him that the finish was being reviewed.\n\nThen the photo and slow-motion replay evidence came in and showed that Lyles was indeed the winner. It was close, so very close. Plenty of comparisons were immediately made: By a hair, by a breath, by the blink of the eye. The photo from the Associated Press captures it perfectly.\n\nIn the aftermath, many viewers - fans and media alike - criticized NBC for being so quick to call Thompson the winner. {"uri": "2024-08-443884829", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "21:24:56", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T21:24:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T21:17:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5333333611488342, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/other-sports/athletics/noah-lyles-olympics-100m-final-33393906", "title": "Noah Lyles backed up action seconds before 100m Olympic final to claim gold", "body": "\"If you don't have main-character energy, track and field ain't for you.\"\n\nThose were the recent words of the new Olympic 100 metres champion to a TV crew making a fly-on-the-wall documentary about athletics.\n\nIt is fair to say Noah Lyles has main-character energy. On the glitziest, grandest Olympic stage of all, a showman turned up to win the showcase event.\n\nHe talked a lot of talk, Lyles, but, somehow, walked the walk. His 9.79 seconds was no world record - not even close, obviously. It was no Olympic record - not even close, obviously. At 9.58 and 9.63 seconds respectively, they both belong to the master showman, Usain Bolt.\n\nBut here is why it was one of the greatest runs in an Olympic 100 metres final ... 27-year-old Lyles has never run faster in his life.\n\nGoing beyond what you have ever done before at the most pressurised moment of your sporting career - that is what makes Olympic champions, that is what defines them.\n\nAnd this sort of performance in the most extraordinary of races is all about self-belief, all about confidence, all about bravado.\n\nLyles - from Gainesville, Florida - clearly has all these qualities in abundance. That is why he will be the star of that Netflix documentary.\n\nThat is why, ahead of the race, he was dancing down the track when his rivals were composing themselves and politely acknowledging the announcement of their names.\n\nLyles decided to let his adrenaline loose before the crack of the starting pistol. And for a couple of seconds of a race that was described as the best he had ever seen by none other than Michael Johnson, it looked like that bravado would backfire.\n\nBut Lyles has always said he is the best closer in the business, a nerveless finisher. So it proved.\n\nWant to talk about timing? He did not win any of his heats or semi-final. That is what you call timing your run to perfection.\n\nAs Lyles gallivanted around the Stade de France track - waving the paper name-plate that he had tugged from his vest and draped in the US flag - you could spare a thought for send-placed Kishane Thompson, the frighteningly good, young Jamaican, who had been denied by five thousandths of a second.\n\nThat is not even a blink of the eye. But you could spare a thought for every other athlete in this most remarkable of dashes.\n\nHopefully, Louie Hinchcliffe hung around to watch the closest contest in the event's storied history, getting a feel for what should lie ahead for this talented young British sprinter. Hinchcliffe was only 0.04 seconds away from making the final and, considering his inexperience, the University of Houston sprinter and his coach Carl Lewis should be delighted with his campaign in Paris.\n\nBut the standard to which Hinchcliffe has to aspire has been set by Lyles, whose confidence will now be stratospheric heading into the 200 metres and the relay.\n\nAs if it needed a boost.\n\nFor all his talent, Lyles has never had a fraction of the global pull that an athlete such as Bolt had. That is what he longs for. He has wanted to be a worldwide superstar for a long time.\n\nBut to do that, you not only need to be supremely talented and supremely confident - brash, even - you need to deliver iconic, landmark moments.\n\nAnd now, the man with the main-character energy has done just that.\n\nFollow all the action on day 9 of the Paris Olympics with Mirror Sport's live blog\n\nThis article contains affiliate links, we will receive a commission on any sales we generate from it. {"uri": "8259153661", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "22:25:14", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T22:25:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T22:23:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.529411792755127, "url": "https://www.channelnewsasia.com/sport/lyles-rides-rollercoaster-100m-gold-4526336", "title": "Lyles rides rollercoaster to 100m gold", "body": "PARIS :A phone call with his therapist after a worrying semi-final helped propel Noah Lyles to the top of the Olympic podium on Sunday, after years of rebuilding his mental health to reach the pinnacle of his sport.\n\nThe American put on the performance of a lifetime to take the 100 metres gold by five-thousandths of a second in 9.79, in a blistering final where a 9.91 from Jamaican Oblique Seville was only good enough to finish last.\n\nSeville had crossed the line ahead of Lyles in their semi-final, and the U.S. sprinter said he needed to get into the right mindset for his medal race.\n\n\"I wouldn't say nervous - I'd say I was extremely curious as to what was going to happen. That's how me and my therapist phrase it. I'm curious as to what I'm going to do, how am I going to pull this off,\" he told reporters.\n\n\"I came in third-fastest from the semis. I'm like 'This is going to be serious, this is not going to be easy'. And I had said OK, my therapist said 'You need to let go, you need to relax and you need to be yourself'.\"\n\nLyles was familiar with all the highs and lows of his sport long before he arrived in Paris, and has publicly discussed the work he put into his mental health to rebound from the pit of depression he found himself in three years ago.\n\nThe three-times 200m world champion failed even to qualify for the shorter sprint at the U.S. Olympic trials in 2021, and rebuilt himself - body and mind - with the singular goal of becoming the fastest man on earth.\n\n\"I did this against the best of the best, on the biggest stage, with the biggest pressure,\" Lyles said. \"And I wasn't even entered in the 100 in 2021. You know, here I am, first Olympics in the 100, going around now the Olympic champion.\"\n\nLyles will compete next in the 200m as he bids for a rare Olympic sprint double, with the opening rounds set {"uri": "8259083932", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "20:48:44", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T20:48:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T20:47:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.529411792755127, "url": "https://www.eastidahonews.com/2024/08/noah-lyles-takes-the-olympic-gold-in-the-100-meter-dash-by-the-slimmest-of-margins/", "title": "Noah Lyles takes the Olympic gold in the 100-meter dash by the slimmest of margins - East Idaho News", "body": "Saint-Denis, France (CNN) -- An American is once again the world's fastest man.\n\nNoah Lyles earned that title and the gold medal in the men's 100-meter dash by the slimmest of margins - just five-thousandths of a second - on Sunday night outside Paris, exploding down the track at the Stade de France and leaning in to cross the finish line ahead of favorite Kishane Thompson of Jamaica.\n\nThe victory ends a 20-year Olympic drought in the event for the USA, when Justin Gatlin won the 100-meter race in Athens. It also cements Lyles as the premier American superstar in this sport as the charismatic 27-year-old sprinter had already been one of the premier faces of track and field with his blazing speed and viral moments.\n\nThompson, who was the betting favorite in the race, took the silver medal and American Fred Kerley took home the bronze.\n\nIt was a sterling version of the signature Olympic race. Taking place on the same night as the women's high jump final and the men's hammer throw final, along with qualifying heats in multiple other races, the showpiece event didn't begin until all those other competitions were done for the day.\n\nWhen the time came, the lights went out in the Stade de France just as the sun had nearly set outside Paris. And then it lit back up as wristbands on the 80,000 spectators in the stadium began to flash, creating another one of the dazzling light shows that these Paris Olympics are becoming known for.\n\nDrama and theater on show in Saint-Denis\n\nEach competitor received an introduction, but Lyles took it like no other, bounding nearly halfway down the track to hype up the crowd and let off a little emotion. Lyles has gone viral in the past for such pre-race moves like pulling out Yu-Gi-Oh! cards before key races, but this time it was only his energy on display.\n\nWhen all the competitors had entered the track, they stood waiting for what felt like an eternity as dramatic music played throughout the stadium.\n\nEventually, the music stopped and the competitors settled into the starting blocks. The stadium fell completely silent - tens of thousands and all one could hear was the wind - before the horn sounded. A mighty roar cut the tension as the sprinters hung together in a tight pack through the first 50 meters of the race.\n\nThere was some separation in the back half of the less-than-10-second contest - the first 100-meter Olympic final in which running a 10-second qualifying heat would not guarantee passage to the final race and the first where every competitor ran sub-10 seconds with a legal wind, according to World Athletics - but not nearly enough for it to be clear who won when the runners crossed the finish line.\n\nThe pack of panting sprinters gathered at the northeastern bend in the track, doubled over catching their breath while they stared up at the big screen, waiting for results. For a while, it only read \"Photo,\" indicating a photo finish.\n\nAnd then the update came through: Lyles had done it.\n\nHe took off again, bounding around the track in ecstasy.", "source": {"uri": He is a great star of athletics, he encourages the spectacle that surrounds the race, but he also has the mentality to win in the race that is not his great speciality, which is the 200m.\n\nThompson didn't get off to the best start, but he did excel for much of the race. They did not know who had won.\n\nThe official time for both of them is 9.79. It is a personal best for Lyles, who becomes the new sprint king. He clocked 9.81, his best time of the season, earning him the bronze medal. "sim": 0.529411792755127, "url": "https://metro.co.uk/2024/08/05/noah-lyles-speaks-olympic-100m-final-delay-track-invader-detained-21360176/", "title": "Noah Lyles speaks out on Olympic 100m final delay after track invader is caught", "body": "The build-up to the men's Olympic 100m final on Sunday night was disrupted after an individual attempted to gain access to the track.\n\nNoah Lyles won gold for the United States after a dramatic photo finish was required to separate him and Jamaica's Olympic debutant Kishane Thompson, who was favourite heading into the race after posting the fastest time of anyone in the three semi finals.\n\nLyles finished 0.005 seconds ahead of Thompson to win the first Olympic gold medal of his career, while fellow United States sprinter Fred Kerley took bronze.\n\nBefore the start of the 100m final, spectators inside the Stade de France were treated to a stunning light show before the eight sprinters were individually introduced by the stadium announcer.\n\nHaving made their way to the track, the athletes were then forced to endure a wait in excess of three minutes before they were ordered to position themselves on the starting blocks.\n\nDramatic music was playing inside the Stade de France while the sprinters waited ahead of the start line, however, the delay was considered excessive by both commentators and fans.\n\nBut it has since emerged that moments before the sprinters walked out from the backstage area for the 100m final, a person was tackled by security as they attempted to get on the track.\n\nThe individual, who was wearing a T-shirt which read, 'free Palestine, free Ukraine' on the front, was led away by four members of security staff.\n\nWhen it was pointed out that someone had attempted to gain access to the track before the start of the 100m final, Lyles said in his post-race press conference: 'Is that what we were waiting for?\n\n'I didn't see anybody try to get on the field. But I was wondering what we were waiting for, not gonna lie.\n\n'But, in the meantime, the crowd were constantly getting more and more hyped. It didn't feel as if it was completely dead.'\n\nKerley, who was also in the press conference with Lyles, shrugged and added: 'We didn't see nothing.'\n\nThompson also shook his head when asked if he had seen any commotion before the start of the race.\n\nIt has not been officially confirmed that the track invader was the reason behind the delay.\n\nFormer Team GB hurdler Colin Jackson said during the BBC's coverage of the race: 'I'm looking down at the track to see if there are any issues, any problems, because we know this race was supposed to start at least three minutes ago. There doesn't seem to be anything happening.\n\n'This is very frustrating for them because this is the biggest race of the year.'\n\nDenise Lewis, who won gold in the heptathlon at Sydney 2000, also said during the BBC's coverage: 'I have to say that it's a little bit unfair to the athletes themselves.\n\n'You get yourself to that arousal point where you're in the zone, you're absolutely wanting to give everything and then that is just waning slightly, the longer you're left out there.\n\n'This is the finite margins we're talking about and that for me was just way too long.'\n\nMORE : {"uri": "8259099619", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "21:11:07", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T21:11:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T21:08:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5254902243614197, "url": "https://www.marca.com/en/olympic-games/track-and-field/2024/08/04/66afdd6d22601d5c4a8b45be.html", "title": "Men's 100m final winner: Noah Lyles beat Thompson at 2024 Olympics", "body": "The United States reigns again in the 100 meters. Twenty years after Justin Gatlin's gold medal in Athens 2004, Noah Lyles has won in a race so close that it was necessary to wait for the photo finish to know the winner. There were only 12 hundredths of a second between the first and the last, with all of them under 10 seconds, something that had never happened before in a race with legal wind.\n\nLyles, with 1.0 downwind, overtook the Jamaican Kishane Thompson on the finish line, but nobody celebrated until after a few seconds, waiting for a result that ruled that the three-time world champion in Budapest 2023 -100, 200 and 4x100- had been five thousandths faster than the new West Indian jewel.\n\n9.79 (.784) for the American -personal record-, the greatest icon of world speed since the retirement of Usain Bolt, and 9.79 (.789) for Thompson. Third was Fred Kerley, world gold medalist in Eugene 2022, with 9.81, ahead of South African Akani Simbine (9.82) and the previous Olympic champion, Italian Marcel Jacobs (9.85), who ended up limping and with a bandage on his left leg.\n\nYou have to go back to Moscow 1980, the Games that the United States boycotted, to see the top two in the same hundredth. Back then, when there were no tiebreaker thousandths, the British Allan Wells won with 10.25, followed by Cuban Silvio Leonard. An image then showed that Wells had crossed the finish line 76 millimeters earlier.\n\nLyles, who in these Games will be looking for a second gold in the 200m and even assault Bolt's world record, is the first sprinter to repeat the 100m crown in two consecutive major competitions since the retirement of the Jamaican giant.\n\nThompson, who arrived in the Parisian capital as the fastest athlete of the year thanks to his 9.77 achieved on June 28 at the Jamaican trials, will have to settle for a silver that will not have left him very satisfied.Especially because in the semifinals, held two hours earlier, he had been the fastest (9.80) followed by his compatriot Oblique Seville (9.81), who in the final did not live up to expectations and finished last with 9.91.\n\nA penultimate round in which up to 12 athletes went under 10 seconds, among them the Canadian Andre De Grasse, bronze medalist in the last two Games, who was one of the four who did not advance to the final.Never before had an {"uri": "8259741022", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "08:51:46", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T08:51:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T08:50:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5215686559677124, "url": "https://www.lemonde.fr/en/sports/article/2024/08/05/paris-olympics-noah-lyles-wins-100-m-on-photo-finish-for-first-olympic-title_6709614_9.html", "title": "Paris Olympics: Noah Lyles wins 100 m on photo finish for first Olympic title", "body": "Sometimes, the width of a chest hair can make or break a destiny. American sprinter Noah Lyles proved the point on Sunday, August 4, on the purple track of the Stade de France, when he won his first Olympic title in the 100 m by a paltry margin of five thousandths of a second (9.784 seconds to 9.789 seconds) over Jamaica's Kishane Thompson.\n\n\"That's probably one of the most beautiful races I've been in,\" said Fred Kerley, the American silver medallist at the Tokyo Games in 2021 and 100 m world champion in 2022, who took third place (9.81). Italy's Lamont Marcell Jacobs, the surprise Olympic champion in 2021, who came fifth (9.85), was visibly disappointed and kept a low profile.\n\n\"I did think Thompson had it at the end,\" a laughing and very talkative Lyles told reporters. \"I went up to him afterward, while we were waiting. I even said, 'Bro I think you got that one, big dog,' and then my name popped up and I'm like, 'Oh, my gosh, I'm amazing!'\" Only the photo finish - based on the frontmost point of the athletes' torsos as they leaned into the finish line - could separate Lyles, 27, from Thompson, 23.\n\nHis victory in the 100 m event enables the Floridian sprinter with painted nails and braided hair adorned with pearls to extend his daring gamble. The author of a 100 m, 200 m and 4 \u00d7 100 m hat-trick at the World Championships in Budapest in 2023, he has raised the bar for Paris 2024 and is aiming for an unprecedented quadruple in the 100 m, 200 m, 4 \u00d7 100 m and 4 \u00d7 400 m events. He is hoping for gold in every event, he said on Sunday.\n\nThe first of those challenges was far from easy. Beaten in the heats on Saturday, August 3, by Britain's Louie Hinchcliffe (9.98 vs. 10.4), while Thompson won his heat in 10 seconds after easing off after 60 meters, Lyles admitted he had been schooled for his very first Olympic 100 m.\n\n\"I guess that's my first lesson in underestimating the power of an Olympics,\" he blamed himself. \"When someone's on the line they say they're going to give their all or nothing, now (...) I'm ready to go.\" In Sunday's semi-final, however, he was only second-fastest (9.83) behind Jamaica's Oblique Seville (9.81).\n\nAn hour or so later, he was beaming at the start of the final. Without even looking at his highly concentrated opponents, the born showman bounced around and asked the crowd to make noise. The organizers had spared no expense in staging the event, plunging the stadium into darkness to let it be illuminated by the multi-colored LED bracelets distributed to the 75,000 spectators.", last-second lean.\n\nThis victory is historic, marking the first time an American has won the Olympic 100 meters since Justin Gatlin in 2004.\n\nBut Lyles isn't stopping here; he's now focused on the But the Jamaican finished a few thousandths of a second behind Lyles.\n\nGiven the insanely close finish, there was initially some confusion about which sprinter ultimately came out on top.\n\nBut as the Olympic committee at the venue sorted out the final result, Diffey sounded definitive on the NBC broadcast that Thompson had won over Lyles.\n\n\"Jamaica's gonna do it!\" the announcer said moments before the American was declared the winner.\n\nFans were completely baffled that the NBC announcer fumbled such a huge moment in one of the Paris Olympics' marquee events.\n\n\"oh that's an all-time announcer fumble\"\n\n\"I cannot recall in a major sporting event for an announcer to blow a call to the magnitude of what just happened on NBC for the mens 100m final.\"\n\n\"Wild that the NBC announcer said live that Thompson won & then went radio silence when the official announcement was made. Amateur hour.\"\n\nThe NBC announcer may have misfired on the mic, but the error took nothing away from Lyles' incredible performance. {"uri": "8259110937", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "21:24:49", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T21:24:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T21:23:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5176470875740051, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/news/national/lyles-wins-olympic-100m-thriller-to-end-us-drought/article_c960ec2b-fc39-533c-ac0e-72a74fd74cf9.html", "title": "Lyles wins Olympic 100m thriller to end US drought", "body": "Canada's Ethan Katzberg secured hammer gold with a huge first throw\n\nNoah Lyles snatched a photo-finish victory in the closest 100m final in modern Olympic history on Sunday to end the United States' 20-year wait to recapture the world's most prestigious sprinting crown.\n\nIn a nerve-shredding final at the Stade de France, Lyles, the charismatic 27-year-old from Florida, took gold by a fraction from Jamaica's Kishane Thompson.\n\nLyles' winning margin boiled down to just five thousandths of a second, with the American clocked at 9.784sec to Thompson's 9.789sec, though both men's times will be listed as 9.79sec.\n\nIt was the narrowest margin of victory since electronic timing has been used at the Olympics.\n\nLyles' compatriot Fred Kerley took bronze in 9.81sec.\n\nThe race was so close that the electronic scoreboard in the arena simply read \"photo\" beside seven of the eight finalists.\n\nAfter an agonising wait of several seconds, Lyles' victory was confirmed, sparking wild celebrations from the reigning 100m and 200m world champion who is regarded as one of the global superstars as athletics.\n\n\"It's the one I wanted,\" an elated Lyles told Eurosport moments after his win.\n\n\"It's the hard battle, it's the amazing opponents. Everybody's healthy, everybody came prepared for the fight and I wanted to prove that I'm the man amongst all of them. I'm the wolf amongst wolves.\"\n\nLyles admitted though that even he had doubted whether he had clinched the gold.\n\n\"I went up to Kishane and I was like, 'I'm gonna be honest, bro, I think you had that one,'\" Lyles said.\n\n\"And I was fully prepared to see his name pop up and to see my name pop up, I'm like goodness gracious. I'm incredible.\"\n\nThe win completes a rollercoaster three years for Lyles, who had left the pandemic-hit Tokyo Olympics in tears after a disappointing campaign, citing his mental health struggles and battles with depression.\n\nThe American is now targeting an Olympic double with victory in the 200m next week.\n\n- Ukraine medal rush - More from this section Australia blames 'serious failures' for lethal Israeli strike on aid convoy Far-right protesters clash with police as UK unrest spreads Nine killed in two Israeli West Bank air strikes\n\nLyles' win was the sensational final act of another thrilling day in the Olympic athletics arena that saw three gold medals handed out.\n\nIn other action, Ukraine's Yaroslava Mahuchikh lived up to her pre-Paris Games billing to win the women's high jump.\n\nThe world champion and world record holder managed a best of 2.00 metres to win on countback from Australia's Nicola Olyslagers.\n\nAnother Australian, Eleanor Patterson, claimed joint bronze with another Ukrainian, Iryna Gerashchenko, both on 1.95m.\n\nIn the men's hammer, Canadian world champion Ethan Katzberg won after unleashing a mammoth heave with his first throw to clinch the gold medal.\n\nThe 22-year-old from British Columbia registered 84.12m with his opening effort to leave his rivals trailing throughout the competition.\n\nThat was four metres further than his nearest rival, Hungary's Bence Halasz, who took silver with a throw of 79.97m. Ukraine's Mykhaylo Kokhan collected bronze with a throw of 79.39m.\n\nElsewhere Sunday, Sydney McLaughlin-Levrone and Femke Bol eased through the opening round of the women's 400m hurdles to remain on an Olympic collision course.\n\nUS star McLaughlin-Levrone, the reigning Olympic champion and world record holder, cruised through her heat to win in 53.60sec.\n\nBol meanwhile shrugged off the after-effects of her dazzling performance in Saturday's 4x400m mixed relay to coast through her heat in a leading 53.38sec.\n\nAnother mouthwatering duel is looming in the women's 800m, where Britain's Keely Hodgkinson, a silver medallist in Tokyo three years ago, is poised for an epic battle with Kenya's 2023 World Champion Mary Moraa on Monday.\n\nHodgkinson delivered an ice-cool performance to win her semi-final in 1min 56.86sec, the fastest time of the round. Moraa advanced after winning her heat in 1:57.86.\n\nIn the opening round of the men's 400m, Britain's Matt Hudson-Smith got his bid for gold off to a smooth start, winning his heat in 44.78sec.\n\nUS sprinter Michael Norman set the early first round pace however with the quickest time, a brisk 44.10sec. Norman's US team-mate Quincy Hall was second-fastest with a time of 44.28sec.\n\nrcw/gj", "source": {"uri": "reformer.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Brattleboro Reformer"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-08-443971445", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "01:26:27", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T01:26:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T01:05:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5176470875740051, "url": "https://www.cnc3.co.tt/thompson-settles-for-silver-in-marquee-event/", "title": "Thompson settles for silver in marquee event", "body": "PARIS -- Kishane Thompson of Jamaica came agonisingly close to capturing gold in the men's 100 metres at the Paris Olympics on Sunday night.\n\nIn one of the closest ever finishes in the event in Olympic history, Thompson and eventual winner Noah Lyles of the United States both clocked 9.79 seconds in a pulsating final that had to be determined by a photo finish.\n\nLyles' teammate Fred Kerley won bronze in 9.81 seconds.\n\nInitially, it appeared as though the burly 23-year-old Thompson had crossed the line first.\n\nHowever, following the use of photofinish technology, Lyles (9.784) was declared the winner, ahead of Thompson (9.789).\n\nLyles, who, together with Thompson, watched the big screen anxiously as they awaited the winner to be announced, raised his hands in triumph before taking off for a lap of honour around the track when the decision was made.\n\nA dejected-looking Thompson could only look on in disbelief.\n\nThompson, who was hoping to become the first Jamaican man to win the event since Usain Bolt in 2016, got off to a fast start and led the field after 65 metres.\n\nHowever, the fastest man over 100 metres this year could not produce his usual burst of speed over the last 30 metres, allowing Lyles to pip him on the line.\n\n\"Honestly, it's not just that I didn't win the gold; it's that I didn't better myself in that sense,\" a devastated Thompson said after the final.\n\n\"Today I really gained a lot of experience running with all these great competitors. Big up to all of them. But I really beat myself today in that I didn't trust myself or my speed to bring myself to the line in the first place.\"\n\nMeanwhile, Lyles, who became the first man from the USA to win the event since Justin Gatlin at the 2004 Olympics in Athens, Greece, was ecstatic.\n\n\"I went up to Kishane, and I was like, 'I'm going to be honest, I think you had that one',\" a beaming Lyles told Eurosport after the race. \"I was fully prepared to see his name pop up. and to see my name pop, I'm like, 'Goodness gracious, I'm incredible'.\"\n\nMeanwhile, there was also heartbreak for Jamaica's Shericka Jackson, who was a no-show for the qualifying rounds in the women's 200 metres.\n\nJackson, the two-time reigning 200-metre world champion, came into the Olympics nursing a hamstring injury and pulled out of the event just moments before she was scheduled to run in Heat 3.\n\nThe newly crowned 100-metre champion, Julien Alfred of St Lucia, eased into the next round after comfortably winning her heat.\n\nRunning out of Heat 1, Alfred cruised to victory in 22.41 seconds, well ahead of second-placed Gemima Joseph of France (22.72), while Sweden's Julia Henriksson (22.79) was the other automatic qualifier.\n\nJamaica's Niesha Burgher also booked her spot in the next round after finishing second in Heat 2 in 22.54 seconds, behind Gabrielle Thomas of the USA, who clocked 22.20 to be the fastest qualifier.\n\nFellow Jamaican Lanae-Tava Thomas also advanced, placing second in Heat 5 in a time of 22.70 seconds.\n\nThe Jamaican pair of Carey McLeod and Wayne Pinnock also made it past the first round of qualifying for the men's long jump.\n\nMcLeod leapt 7.90 metres to advance out of Group A, while Pinnock's effort of 7.96 was good enough to qualify from Group B.\n\nTheir teammate, Tajay Gayle, however, was eliminated with a leap of 7.78 metres.\n\nIn the men's 110-metre hurdles, Jamaica's trio of Orlando Bennett, Rasheed Broadbell, Hansle Parchment, and Antoine Andrews of the Bahamas all advanced to the next round of qualifying.\n\nRushell Clayton of Jamaica won her heat in the women's 400-metre hurdles to easily advance, while her teammates Shiann Salmon and Janieve Russell, who finished second and third, respectively, in their heats, also booked their spots in the next round.\n\nKirani James of Grenada expectedly cruised into the second round of the men's 400 metres, clocking 44.78 seconds to comfortably win Heat 5.\n\nAlso advancing in the event were Jamaica's Jevaughn Powell and Jereem Richards of Trinidad and Tobago.", "source": {"uri": It was a tight race between him and Jamaican sprinter Jishane Thompson when they crossed the finish line. At first glance, it looked like Thompson won the race, but when video replay showed that Lyles was first, it confirmed that the 20-year drought of a U.S. sprinter failing to win gold came to an end.\n\nLyles' reaction was calm and collected, achieving a personal best time of 9.79 seconds as he edged out Thompson by five thousandths of a second.\n\nThis prompted social media to react to the {"uri": "2024-08-443897797", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "22:00:33", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T22:00:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T20:50:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5176470875740051, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/lyles-wins-olympic-100m-thriller-to-end-us-drought/article_415f7163-d996-5efb-aa63-1f284dd78118.html", "title": "Lyles wins Olympic 100m thriller to end US drought", "body": "Canada's Ethan Katzberg secured hammer gold with a huge first throw\n\nNoah Lyles snatched a photo-finish victory in the closest 100m final in modern Olympic history on Sunday to end the United States' 20-year wait to recapture the world's most prestigious sprinting crown.\n\nIn a nerve-shredding final at the Stade de France, Lyles, the charismatic 27-year-old from Florida, took gold by a fraction from Jamaica's Kishane Thompson.\n\nLyles' winning margin boiled down to just five thousandths of a second, with the American clocked at 9.784sec to Thompson's 9.789sec, though both men's times will be listed as 9.79sec.\n\nIt was the narrowest margin of victory since electronic timing has been used at the Olympics.\n\nLyles' compatriot Fred Kerley took bronze in 9.81sec.\n\nThe race was so close that the electronic scoreboard in the arena simply read \"photo\" beside seven of the eight finalists.\n\nAfter an agonising wait of several seconds, Lyles' victory was confirmed, sparking wild celebrations from the reigning 100m and 200m world champion who is regarded as one of the global superstars as athletics.\n\n\"It's the one I wanted,\" an elated Lyles told Eurosport moments after his win.\n\n\"It's the hard battle, it's the amazing opponents. Everybody's healthy, everybody came prepared for the fight and I wanted to prove that I'm the man amongst all of them. I'm the wolf amongst wolves.\"\n\nLyles admitted though that even he had doubted whether he had clinched the gold.\n\n\"I went up to Kishane and I was like, 'I'm gonna be honest, bro, I think you had that one,'\" Lyles said.\n\n\"And I was fully prepared to see his name pop up and to see my name pop up, I'm like goodness gracious. I'm incredible.\"\n\nThe win completes a rollercoaster three years for Lyles, who had left the pandemic-hit Tokyo Olympics in tears after a disappointing campaign, citing his mental health struggles and battles with depression.\n\nThe American is now targeting an Olympic double with victory in the 200m next week.\n\n- Ukraine medal rush -\n\nLyles' win was the sensational final act of another thrilling day in the Olympic athletics arena that saw three gold medals handed out.\n\nIn other action, Ukraine's Yaroslava Mahuchikh lived up to her pre-Paris Games billing to win the women's high jump.\n\nThe world champion and world record holder managed a best of 2.00 metres to win on countback from Australia's Nicola Olyslagers.\n\nAnother Australian, Eleanor Patterson, claimed joint bronze with another Ukrainian, Iryna Gerashchenko, both on 1.95m.\n\nIn the men's hammer, Canadian world champion Ethan Katzberg won after unleashing a mammoth heave with his first throw to clinch the gold medal.\n\nThe 22-year-old from British Columbia registered 84.12m with his opening effort to leave his rivals trailing throughout the competition.\n\nThat was four metres further than his nearest rival, Hungary's Bence Halasz, who took silver with a throw of 79.97m. Ukraine's Mykhaylo Kokhan collected bronze with a throw of 79.39m.\n\nElsewhere Sunday, Sydney McLaughlin-Levrone and Femke Bol eased through the opening round of the women's 400m hurdles to remain on an Olympic collision course.\n\nUS star McLaughlin-Levrone, the reigning Olympic champion and world record holder, cruised through her heat to win in 53.60sec.\n\nBol meanwhile shrugged off the after-effects of her dazzling performance in Saturday's 4x400m mixed relay to coast through her heat in a leading 53.38sec.\n\nAnother mouthwatering duel is looming in the women's 800m, where Britain's Keely Hodgkinson, a silver medallist in Tokyo three years ago, is poised for an epic battle with Kenya's 2023 World Champion Mary Moraa on Monday.\n\nHodgkinson delivered an ice-cool performance to win her semi-final in 1min 56.86sec, the fastest time of the round. Moraa advanced after winning her heat in 1:57.86.\n\nIn the opening round of the men's 400m, Britain's Matt Hudson-Smith got his bid for gold off to a smooth start, winning his heat in 44.78sec.\n\nUS sprinter Michael Norman set the early first round pace however with the quickest time, a brisk 44.10sec. Norman's US team-mate Quincy Hall was second-fastest with a time of 44.28sec.\n\nrcw/gj\n\nMore from this section\n\nCooking with Bears? The 27-year-old American beat Kishane Thompson from Jamaica by five-thousandths of a second. Fred Kerley from the United States was third.\n\nThe sprinters were left looking up at the official scoreboard after the dash for around 15 seconds as judges tried to decrypt the mass of bodies on the finishing line.\n\nLyles was deemed the victor in a personal best time of 9.784. Thompson was clocked at 9.789 seconds.\n\nThe victory - his first Olympic gold - comes a year after he won the 100m world championship title in Budapest last year.\n\nHe will compete in the 200m as he attempts to become the first man since Usain Bolt in 2016 to win the sprint double at an Olympic Games.\n\nAkani Simbine, who finished fourth and Letsile Tebogo from Botswana who finished sixth set {"uri": "2024-08-443877883", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "21:08:42", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T21:08:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T20:51:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5058823823928833, "url": "https://www.france24.com/en/live-news/20240804-lyles-wins-olympic-100m-thriller-to-end-us-drought", "title": "Lyles wins Olympic 100m thriller to end US drought", "body": "In a nerve-shredding final at the Stade de France, Lyles, the charismatic 27-year-old from Florida, took gold by a fraction from Jamaica's Kishane Thompson.\n\nLyles' winning margin boiled down to just five thousandths of a second, with the American clocked at 9.784sec to Thompson's 9.789sec, though both men's times will be listed as 9.79sec.\n\nIt was the narrowest margin of victory since electronic timing has been used at the Olympics.\n\nLyles' compatriot Fred Kerley took bronze in 9.81sec.\n\nThe race was so close that the electronic scoreboard in the arena simply read \"photo\" beside seven of the eight finalists.\n\nAfter an agonising wait of several seconds, Lyles' victory was confirmed, sparking wild celebrations from the reigning 100m and 200m world champion who is regarded as one of the global superstars as athletics.\n\n\"It's the one I wanted,\" an elated Lyles told Eurosport moments after his win.\n\n\"It's the hard battle, it's the amazing opponents. Everybody's healthy, everybody came prepared for the fight and I wanted to prove that I'm the man amongst all of them. I'm the wolf amongst wolves.\"\n\nLyles admitted though that even he had doubted whether he had clinched the gold.\n\n\"I went up to Kishane and I was like, 'I'm gonna be honest, bro, I think you had that one,'\" Lyles said.\n\n\"And I was fully prepared to see his name pop up and to see my name pop up, I'm like goodness gracious. I'm incredible.\"\n\nThe win completes a rollercoaster three years for Lyles, who had left the pandemic-hit Tokyo Olympics in tears after a disappointing campaign, citing his mental health struggles and battles with depression.\n\nThe American is now targeting an Olympic double with victory in the 200m next week.\n\nUkraine medal rush\n\nLyles' win was the sensational final act of another thrilling day in the Olympic athletics arena that saw three gold medals handed out.\n\nIn other action, Ukraine's Yaroslava Mahuchikh lived up to her pre-Paris Games billing to win the women's high jump.\n\nThe world champion and world record holder managed a best of 2.00 metres to win on countback from Australia's Nicola Olyslagers.\n\nAnother Australian, Eleanor Patterson, claimed joint bronze with another Ukrainian, Iryna Gerashchenko, both on 1.95m.\n\nIn the men's hammer, Canadian world champion Ethan Katzberg won after unleashing a mammoth heave with his first throw to clinch the gold medal.\n\nThe 22-year-old from British Columbia registered 84.12m with his opening effort to leave his rivals trailing throughout the competition.\n\nThat was four metres further than his nearest rival, Hungary's Bence Halasz, who took silver with a throw of 79.97m. Ukraine's Mykhaylo Kokhan collected bronze with a throw of 79.39m.\n\nElsewhere Sunday, Sydney McLaughlin-Levrone and Femke Bol eased through the opening round of the women's 400m hurdles to remain on an Olympic collision course.\n\nUS star McLaughlin-Levrone, the reigning Olympic champion and world record holder, cruised through her heat to win in 53.60sec.\n\nBol meanwhile shrugged off the after-effects of her dazzling performance in Saturday's 4x400m mixed relay to coast through her heat in a leading 53.38sec.\n\nAnother mouthwatering duel is looming in the women's 800m, where Britain's Keely Hodgkinson, a silver medallist in Tokyo three years ago, is poised for an epic battle with Kenya's 2023 World Champion Mary Moraa on Monday.\n\nHodgkinson delivered an ice-cool performance to win her semi-final in 1min 56.86sec, the fastest time of the round. Moraa advanced after winning her heat in 1:57.86.\n\nIn the opening round of the men's 400m, Britain's Matt Hudson-Smith got his bid for gold off to a smooth start, winning his heat in 44.78sec.\n\nUS sprinter Michael Norman set the early first round pace however with the quickest time, a brisk 44.10sec. Thompson expressed mixed emotions, proud yet disappointed, and recounted the razor-thin margin that separated him from the title. Despite the loss, Thompson made history for Jamaica.\n\nKishane Thompson let out a scream after crossing the finish line, momentarily believing he had won the Olympic 100-meter final. By the narrowest of margins, Thompson was edged out for gold by American Noah Lyles, with times of 9.79 seconds needing precise calculation to determine the winner.\n\nThompson expressed mixed feelings, saying, \"I'm a bit disappointed, but I am happy at the same time. I am going to take it as what it is and move forward from here.\" He downplayed the idea of sharing the gold medal, stating the sport's competitive nature.\n\nThe race was a dramatic showdown, with all sprinters separated by just .12 seconds. {"uri": "8259985178", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "11:25:39", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T11:25:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T11:24:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.501960813999176, "url": "https://www.givemesport.com/why-many-americans-dont-like-noah-lyles/", "title": "The reason why 'millions of Americans' hate Noah Lyles despite 100m gold medal", "body": "Highlights Noah Lyles ignited controversy with his remarks on NBA world champions, sparking debate among athletes and fans. Some NBA stars slammed Lyles' comments, while others, including sprinter Sha'Carri Richardson, supported his perspective. Lyles' outspoken nature isn't new, having previously stirred controversy with his bold statements, leaving a mark in the sports world.\n\nAmerican track star Noah Lyles caused controversy in a press conference in 2023 by claiming that NBA stars do not deserve to be called world champions due to the fact that only American teams play in the league, and those comments are what has led to many Americans disliking the athlete.\n\nIn a press conference last year, the 27-year-old said: \"You know the thing that hurts me the most? I have to watch the NBA Finals, and they have 'world champion' on their heads. World champion of what? The United States? Don't get me wrong. I love the US at times, but that ain't the world. That is not the world - we are the world. We have almost every country out here fighting, thriving and putting on a flag to show that they are represented. There ain't no flags in the NBA. We got to do more. We got to be presented to the world. I love the track community, but we can only do so much within our own bubble. There's a whole world out there.\"\n\nReaction to Noah Lyles' World Champions Comment\n\nLyle's comments, unsurprisingly, did not go down well with many within the NBA. A backlash was led by Kevin Durant, with the two-time MVP responding to his claims by posting on his X account: \"Somebody help this brother out.\" Draymond Green, a four-time world champion of the sport, also responded by saying on Instagram: \"When smart goes wrong.\"\n\nGIVEMESPORT's Key Statistic: The 100m final at the Paris Olympics was the first time ever that every athlete ran under 10 seconds.\n\nNBA journalist Stephen A Smith, meanwhile, said: \"The NBA currently features 120 players from 40 countries and six continents on its roster for last season, and it's increased now. So how is that not global? How is that not the world champions? The best players from around the world descend upon America to join the National Basketball Association. The international players, rather than electing to stay in their respective countries ... to play basketball, they want to come to the NBA because it's the best basketball league on the planet.\"\n\nLyle's comments did receive some support, however. Fellow sprinter Sha'Carri Richardson said: \"I'm standing with Noah on this one. The organisation [NBA] have players from different countries, but do they compete against different countries? You have to go against the world in order to be a world champion.\"\n\nMen's 100m final\n\nPosition\n\nAthlete\n\nCountry\n\nTime\n\n1.\n\nNoah Lyles\n\nUSA\n\n9.79\n\n2.\n\nKishane Thompson\n\nJAM\n\n9.79\n\n3.\n\nFred Kerley\n\nUSA\n\n9.81\n\n4.\n\nAkani Simbine\n\nRSA\n\n9.82\n\n5.\n\nLamont Jacobs\n\nITA\n\n9.85\n\n6.\n\nLetsile Tebogo\n\nBOT\n\n9.86\n\n7.\n\nKenneth Bednarek\n\nUSA\n\n9.88\n\n8.\n\nOblique Seville\n\nJAM\n\n9.91\n\nPeople from outside sport have also applauded the comments, with television personality Piers Morgan saying via X: \"The cojones of this guy calling out NBA stars for pretending to be world champions - when they're not! - then beating the world to be Olympic 100m champion - are gigantic. Congrats @LylesNoah you talked the talked and just walked the walk.\"\n\nNoah Lyles' Controversial History\n\nThis isn't the first time that comments from Lyles have caused controversy. At the World Championships last year, he took aim at his own sport by criticising previous champions, including Usain Bolt, who retired in 2017: \"As I look around this World Championships, I don't see Bolt, I don't see Asafa (Powell). I don't see Yohan (Blake) and he's still running. Where are all these great champions? We look at them, as we're walking through the tunnel, at all of these previous world champions.
