The athletes stood staring at the screens for 20 seconds before a result was clear.\n\n\"You couldn't have asked for a bigger moment,\" Lyle said. \"A guy in biomechanics comes down and before I came out here, he said it was going to be this much, that's how close it is going to be and gosh was he right.\n\n\"I had to take every round as it was and I was a little upset after the first round so I came with the aggression and after I ran that 83 and I was done with the aggression. {"uri": "2024-08-443921684", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "23:03:29", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T23:03:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T21:15:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.501960813999176, "url": "https://theprint.in/sport/olympics-athletics-showman-lyles-wins-100m-gold-by-five-thousandths-of-a-second/2207892/", "title": "Olympics-Athletics-Showman Lyles wins 100m gold by five thousandths of a second", "body": "He was then confirmed him as the winner in a personal best 9.79 seconds, the same time as Jamaica's Kishane Thompson, but ahead by the width of a vest.\n\nIf the race had been 99 metres Thompson would have been celebrating a fourth Jamaican win in five Olympics, but fast-finishing Lyles kept his form superbly and timed his dip expertly to add Olympic gold to his world title.\n\nHe ripped his bib name from his shirt and held it aloft with his red, white and blue varnished fingernails, announcing himself, as he had always promised he would be, as the fastest man in the world.\n\n\"It's the one I wanted, it's the hard battle, it's the amazing opponents,\" said Lyles, the first American Olympic 100m champion since Justin Gatlin in 2004.\n\n\"Everybody came prepared for the fight and I wanted to prove that I'm the man among all of them, I'm the wolf among wolves.\"\n\nIt was the first time eight men have broken 10 seconds in a wind-legal 100 metres race.\n\nTHOMPSON DISAPPOINTED\n\n\"I am a bit disappointed, but I am happy at the same time,\" Thompson said. \"I wasn't patient enough with myself to let my speed bring me at the line, in the position that I know I could have gone to, but I have learnt from it.\"\n\n\"I know that Jamaica would have wanted me to get the gold, everybody love winners. I would have loved to win today, but big up to the whole field.\"\n\nAmerican Fred Kerley took bronze in 9.81 and Akani Simbini of South Africa was fourth, making it a remarkable six fourth or fifth-placed finishes in global championships, albeit with the consolation of a national record of 9.83.\n\nDefending champion Lamont Marcell Jacobs of Italy, heavily strapped, finished fifth in 9.85 and Letsile Tebogo of Botswana also set a national record with 9.86 in sixth place.\n\nSuch was the quality of the race, that eighth-placed Oblique Seville of Jamaica still clocked 9.91 seconds.\n\nSeville had finished ahead of Lyles in 9.81 in the semi-final when the American looked to be at full stretch.\n\nHowever, the biggest showman in the sport and the star of the runaway success Netflix SPRINT series, has become a serious championship operator over the shorter distance, having won three 200m world titles and bronze over that distance at the last Olympics.\n\n\"I think back to Tokyo when I messed up handling the rounds. From then on, I was like, 'I'm never going to do that again. I'm going to handle this correctly and practice over the years',\" he said. \"It's accumulated to this point.\"\n\nLyles, 27, is targeting a possible four golds in Paris, in the 100m, his favourite 200m, the 4x100m relay and, possibly, the 4x400m relay.\n\nThat would emulate illustrious compatriots Jesse Owens and Carl Lewis, who achieved the feat at a single Games but with long jump instead of the longer relay.\n\nFormer world champion Kerly ran an excellent race to add bronze to his Tokyo silver medal.\n\n\"That was a great race and anyone could have won it,\" he said. \"I feel that I executed as best as I could. I came here for the gold and nothing else but, hey, everybody came here for the same thing and only one can win. Whoever came off the best, is the best.\"\n\n(Reporting by Mitch Phillips, editing by Ed Osmond)", "source": {"uri": "theprint.in", "dataType": "news", "title": "ThePrint"}, "authors": [{"uri": medal to late coach", "body": "Noah Lyles was quick to dedicate his Olympic gold medal to his late coach Rashawn Jackson after winning in the 100m final.\n\nThe American snatched the gold medal from Jamaica's Kishane Thompson on Sunday night by just 0.005 seconds following a dramatic surge.\n\nHis victory means he has added to the bronze medal he picked up at Tokyo 2020 in the 200m - another event he will looking to scoop the gold in.\n\nAnd in an interview following the epic race, the 27-year-old made sure to pay tribute to Jackson, who passed away earlier this summer, where he could be heard letting his emotions get the better of him.\n\nIt was Jackson who helped make Lyles the sprinter he is today having coached him at Alexandria City High School.\n\nLyles penned a heartfelt social media post following his death in July, and speaking after his 100m triumph, he failed to contain his emotions.\n\nSpeaking to reporters, Lyles said: \"It's an amazing moment, I don't think it's completely sunk in to be honest.\n\n\"I have so many homes, and Alexandria [city in Virginia] is definitely one of them, Charltotte, North Carolina, Orlando, Florida, Clermont, Gainesville [both Florida].\n\n\"There's so many places that I have ties to, and my coach, Rashawn Jackson, he recently died.\n\n\"I remember when I was running on the back stretch and I was like, 'This one is for you man.'\"\n\nIt was at that point where Lyles could be heard breaking down.\n\nThrough apparent tears, he continued: \"I thought he was going to be here to see it, I'm going to be honest.\n\n\"But I know that he's watching, but I really thought he was going to be here in the flesh.\n\n\"He believed that I was going to be a 100m runner just as much as I was going to be a 200m runner.\"\n\nCommenting on his quest to win gold medals in the 200m and 4x100m relay, he added: \"Shoot, I'm on cloud nine because I just got the hardest one out of the way.\n\n\"The 100m is by far {"uri": "2024-08-444392979", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "10:28:59", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T10:28:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T10:05:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4980392158031464, "url": "https://jamaica-star.com/article/sports/20240805/%E2%80%98i-wasn%E2%80%99t-patient-enough%E2%80%99-thompson-reflects-after-winning-100m-silver-medal", "title": "'I wasn't patient enough' - Thompson reflects after winning 100m", "body": "Jamaica's Kishane Thompson (right) and teammate Oblique Seville moments after the men's 100m final at the Stade de France in Paris, France, yesterday. Thompson finished second, while Seville placed eighth.\n\nIn the closest race of his young career, Kishane Thompson was thousandths of a second away from ending Jamaica's eight-year men's 100 metres Olympic Games gold-medal drought.\n\nThompson finished second in yesterday's Olympic 100m final at the Stade de France, clocking 9.79 seconds.\n\nHe was edged out in a photo finish by reigning World champion, the United States' Noah Lyles, who was also clocked at 9.79 and a thousandth of a second faster.\n\nLyles' American teammate Fred Kerley was third in 9.81 seconds.\n\nThe other Jamaican in the final, Oblique Seville, was eighth in 9.91 seconds, with all competitors clocking sub-10 times.\n\nThompson was in good form going into the final, clocking 9.80 in his semi-final. However, he said that missing out on the ultimate prize was a matter of impatience.\n\n\"I wasn't patient enough with my speed and with myself so I could let my speed bring me at the line in the position that I know I could have. But I have learned from it,\" Thompson said.\n\nBefore yesterday, Jamaica's men had not won an Olympic medal in the 100m event since 2016 when Usain Bolt claimed gold in 9.81 seconds over American Justin Gatlin (9.89) and Canadian Andre De Grasse (9.91). Also, no Jamaican male had won a major global medal of any kind since the 2017 World Championships when Bolt won bronze in 9.95 seconds. Gatlin won in 9.92 ahead of countryman Christian Coleman (9.94).\n\nDespite being edged to the line, Thompson was reflective on how far he has come, given his injury woes of the past.\n\n\"I am feeling super grateful. I know that my body language doesn't show but I am super grateful. I know that Jamaica would have wanted me to get the gold. Everybody loves a winner. I would have loved to win today (yesterday),\" Thompson said.\n\nLyles, who captured America's first Olympic title since 2004, acknowledged the significance of his victory.\n\n\"It was a crazy moment because I thought that Kishane had that and I was like, I really am going to have to swallow my pride, which I don't have a problem doing. Respect is respect,\" Lyles said. \"Everybody in the field came out knowing that they can win this race. When I saw my name it was like I didn't do this against a slow crowd, I did this against the best of the best.\"\n\nEarlier in the morning, Jamaica had its third consecutive withdrawal as Shericka Jackson did not face the starter for the women's 200m. Jackson's fitness was in question leading up to the Games and she had already opted out of the 100m. Shelly-Ann Fraser-Pryce was also withdrawn from the women's 100m semi-finals.\n\nIn the women's 200m first round, Lanae-Tava Thomas (22.70) and Niesha Burgher (22.54) progressed to this afternoon's semi-finals with second-place finishes in their respective heats. Gabby Thomas (22.20) was the fastest in first-round action.\n\nMeanwhile, World Championships silver medallist Wayne Pinnock (7.96m) and World Indoor Championship bronze medallist Carey McLeod (7.90m) advanced to the final of the men's long jump. Greece's Miltiadis Tentoglou led all qualifiers with 8.32m.\n\nReigning Olympic champion Hansle Parchment placed fourth in his heat and had to endure a nervous wait, but still advanced to the semi-finals of the men's 110m hurdles as a non-automatic qualifier with a 13.43-second clocking. Fellow Jamaicans Orlando Bennett (13.35) and Commonwealth Games champion Rasheed Broadbell (13.42) advanced automatically with second-place finishes in their respective heats. American Grant Holloway registered the fastest time in qualifying, 13.01 seconds.\n\nIn the women's 400m hurdles, national champion Rushell Clayton (54.32), Shian Salmon (53.95) and Janieve Russell (54.67) secured passage to the semi-finals with automatic qualifying performances. The Netherlands' Femke Bol led all qualifiers with 53.38. Race favourite American Sydney McLeughlin-Levrone and countrywoman Jasmine Jones both clocked 53.60.", "source": {"uri": "jamaica-star.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Jamaica Star"}, He was just 0.16 seconds of breaking the legendary Usain Bolt's Olympic record of 9.63s.\n\nArmed not just with lightning-fast legs, but also with the unwavering spirit, Noah has proved that he is more than just a sprinter -- he is a symbol of resilience.\n\nHe had a bad start and did not lead at any point in the race. Only until the final stride, he paced up, as though running for life and clinched the gold by winning by fraction of a second.\n\nThe race was so close that every runner finished the race in 9 seconds and seven of the eight sprinters saw \"PHOTO\" next to their name on the large scoreboard inside the Stade de France. The term indicates a closer inspection of the finish is required. In this case, the timing was extended to the thousandth of a second to determine the winner. In the end, it was declared that Noah had 0.005s ahead of Kishane to finish at the top of the podium. Lyles finished in 9.784 seconds and Thompson in 9.789.\n\nIn that moment, the world was watching as he celebrated, draping the American flag around his shoulders. He looked into the crowd with a beaming smile and shouted, \"America, I told you, I got this!\" It was a declaration not just of victory but of perseverance, a loud message echoing to anyone who had ever felt different or faced obstacles.\n\nAfter the awe-inspiring run with a over a million motivations Lyles' victory resonated far beyond the track. He took to Twitter, sharing a heartfelt message to his followers: \"I have Asthma, allergies, dyslexia, ADD, anxiety, and Depression. But I will tell you that what you have does not define what you can become. Why Not You!\" His words struck a chord, inspiring countless individuals who grappled with their shadows.\n\nNoah's journey to Olympic gold was not simply about breaking records in the sport; it was about breaking barriers in life. He faced criticism and skepticism along the way, particularly after stirring the pot with bold comments about the world of sports. Yet, in that Olympic moment, every doubt transformed into a testament of his character.\n\nHis triumph served not only as a personal victory but a collective celebration for all those who dare to challenge their limits. The applause and cheers of the crowd surged through him, and he understood the significance of his win: it wasn't just his victory, but a victory for all who dare to dream against the odds. However at the finish line, Lyles leaned ahead of Kishane Thompson of Jamaica to earn the title as \"World's Fastest Man\" (Lyles' 9.78 time was also a personal best). Kerley took bronze, and was only .03 behind the gold medalist. The 9.81 was also enough to secure him his second Olympic medal, as Akani Simbine of South Africa was only .01 behind. Jacobs clocked a time of 9.85, while finishing fifth.\n\nKerley, Lyles, and Kenny Bednarik (7th place, 9.88) will return to the track later this week, and will try to give the United States 4x100m Relay team its first gold medal since the 2000 Sydney Olympics.\n\nThis week's relays could also include Ghanan sprinter Benjamin Azamati, who recently finished a historic career at West Texas A&M. Azamati finished ninth in his heat during Sunday afternoon's 100m semifinals, unable to advance.\n\nThe Olympic journey for Red Raider runner Antoine Andrews, who represents the Bahamas, is off to a positive start. In Sunday's first round of the Men's 110m Hurdles, Andrews was on the better side of a photo finish, along with three others who crossed the line at 13.43 (only .03 behind Zhuoyi Xu of China). Andrews was the best of the four, and he finished second in the overall heat, well enough to earn a spot in Wednesday's semifinals. If the outcome hadn't worked in his favor, Andrews would've had a second and final chance in Tuesday's repechage round.\n\nCoverage of the 2024 Paris Olympics can be seen on KCBD-TV and Peacock and Noah Lyles, Kishane Thompson, Marcell Jacobs... here is a review of the contenders for a very open race.\n\nWith Usain Bolt no longer on the track, the men's 100m is still on the look for a new undisputed king. It could very well be the Americans, particularly 27-year-old Noah Lyles. At the recent Budapest World Championships, Lyles won the 100 m, 200 m and 4x100 m in a resounding hat-trick of victories. In Paris, he'll even be aiming for a quadruple with the 4x400m as a bonus.\n\nAnother US runner to watch out for is Fred Kerley, world champion in 2022 and silver medallist in the Tokyo Games, who is back in form at just the right time.\n\nBehind these two arrows from the other side of the Atlantic, a number of men are taking on the role of challenger. There are, of course, the Jamaicans: Kishane Thompson, the new 22-year-old nugget who just clocked the best performance of the year in 9'77 in June, and 23-year-old Oblique Seville, who already beat Noah Lyles in June.\n\nAnd behind them, we also find African athletes. Botswanan prodigy Letsile Tebogo, aged just 21, became the first African to medal in the 100 m at last year's World Championships in Budapest, where he took silver. He is joined by Kenya's Ferdinand Omanyala, African record-holder in 9'77, who has the distinction of being licensed in France, in Miramas (Bouches-du-Rh\u00f4ne).\n\nLast but not least, we'll be keeping a close eye on Italian Marcell Jacobs, the 29-year-old defending champion. After two injury-plagued seasons, he's back in form and was crowned European champion in June. To the disappointment of the home crowd, for the first time since 1932, no Frenchman has qualified for this distance this year.\n\n(L'\u00c9quipe)", "source": {"uri": "theweek.in", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8259148364", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "22:17:00", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T22:17:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T22:16:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4901960790157318, "url": "https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/olympics/noah-lyles-kishane-thompson-paris-jamaica-zharnel-hughes-b2591102.html", "title": "Olympic 100 metres champion Noah Lyles feared photo finish had gone against him", "body": "Every occupant of the 80,000-seat Stade de France seemed to inhale at once before a roar erupted as the 27-year-old American's name appeared first on the screen, then announced to the stadium as the victor by just five thousandths of a second, a winning time of 9.79.784 seconds.\n\nThe 27-year-old rang the victory bell hard, fait accompli after setting out to settle the \"fastest man\" debate once and for all in France.\n\nLyles, whose US team-mate Fred Kerley took bronze, said: \"I knew that when the time came, for me to be able to say 'this is the final, this is where I need to put it together' I was going to do it.\n\n\"I did think (Thompson) had it at the end. I went up to him after, while we were waiting, and I even said 'I think you've got that, good going,' and then my name popped up and I'm like 'oh my gosh, I'm amazing'.\n\n\"I'm going to be honest, I wasn't ready to see it (his name) and that's the first time I've ever said that. I wasn't ready to see it.\n\n\"He was quite a few lanes down, he was in four, I was in seven so it was hard for me to picture where we were.\"\n\nThe American world 100m and 200m champion's triumph comes three summers after he entered the postponed Tokyo 2020 Olympics as the 200m favourite and world champion - but only claimed bronze.\n\nAfterwards, he opened up about a lifelong battle with depression and the challenges of balancing the benefits of antidepressant medication with side effects that led to weight gain and affected his ability to perform - ultimately electing to wean off the treatment before those Games.\n\nEarlier this week, he acknowledged he performs better in front of a full house, remembering the moment on the start line in Tokyo when he would usually say to himself \"it's showtime\", but instead found himself thinking \"this is not it. This is not fun. This is not cool. This is not what I wanted.\"\n\nLyles had no such trouble in Paris, where he thumped his chest at the start line and pumped up the electrified crowd, clearly revelling in the occasion, before they fell so quiet at the start of the race that it was possible to hear a plane passing overhead.\n\nThen the man whose weakness is often said to be his starts got off to the joint slowest, an 0.178 reaction time alongside Botswana's Letsile Tebogo.\n\nLyles, only learning that fact from a journalist, said: \"Slowest reaction time - that's crazy! I thought I was a little better than that but that goes to prove that reaction time does not win races.\"\n\nHe entered these Olympics with the third-fastest time at 100m this year behind Thompson's world-leading 9.77 and Kenyan Ferdinand Omanyala's 9.79, and as a result found himself in a position of needing to back up his signature bravado on Sunday night.\n\nThompson qualified fastest of the semi-finalists in 9.80, his compatriot Seville Oblique just behind him in a personal-best 9.81 and Lyles two hundredths of a second behind.\n\nOblique was the only man who did not have to wait for his place to be confirmed - the last-placed man in 9.91.\n\nLyles is in Paris with a point to prove, embroiled in a debate before the Games about who was currently fastest man on the planet - not that he ever had any doubts.\n\nThe Floridian - who is looking to do the double in the 200 metres - emphatically reiterated his answer, this time with his feet instead of his rhetoric.\n\nHinchliffe said: \"It was a good experience, not the result that I wanted. Definitely a lot to learn. I haven't seen the race back.\n\n\"I am disappointed. The time is OK but it's where I finished in the race. I will come back stronger next year. I will not regress. It's my first year on the scene. There is a lot more to come.\n\n\"Definitely, definitely LA, I will be there (in the final). Next year as well. There are a lot of world championships between then and now. There is a lot of time.\n\nHughes has another chance to try for a first Olympic medal when the men's 200m heats begin on Monday.\n\nHe said: \"I am a fighter. I am very determined and that's why I wanted to give it a go. five-thousandths seconds as both sprinters finished with a time of 9.79 seconds at the Stade de France.\n\nLyles' official time was 9.784 with Thompson finishing with a time of 9.789, while USA's Fred Kerley took bronze as he clocked 9.81 seconds.\n\nOn Saturday, St Lucia's Julien Alfred stormed to 100m gold in the women's event.\n\nAlfred crossed the line in 10.72 seconds under the falling rain at It was his first Olympic gold.\n\nCLICK HERE FOR MORE SPORTS COVERAGE ON FOXNEWS.COM\n\nLyles is best known for his colorful personality and one who wears his emotions on his sleeve; before the opening ceremony, he wrote \"ICON\" on his nails (again talking the talk and walking the walk).\n\nBut what most people don't know is the struggles he's been through, and he used that as motivation to, well, anyone who needs it.\n\n\"I have Asthma, allergies, dyslexia, ADD, anxiety, and Depression. But I will tell you that what you have does not define what you can become. Why Not You!\" Lyles posted on Sunday evening (early Monday morning in Paris).\n\nLyles crossed the finish line in 9.79784 seconds, a personal best. When the result was official, he had seven words: \"America, I told you, I got this!\" Amazingly, he was tied for the worst reaction time, and he was even in last place at the 40-meter mark.\n\nIt was the fifth gold medal won by Americans on Sunday (golfer Scottie Scheffler, cyclist Kristen Faulkner, swimmer Bobby Finke and the women's 4x100 medley relay team).\n\nSIMONE BILES REVEALS 1 QUESTION THAT'S 'REALLY GOTTA STOP' BEING ASKED TO OLYMPIC ATHLETES\n\nLyles now turns his focus on the 200-meter (he's said his \"dream goal\" is to break Usain Bolt's world record of 19.19) and the 4x100-meter relay.\n\nTrack legend Carl Lewis recently told Fox News Digital that the sport \"needs\" Lyles to dominate these games.\n\n\"I think the sport needs someone like him that's a champion. He's the defending champion, the fastest man in the world right now, and we need someone to grab onto. I think he's the perfect guy to do that, and I'm excited about that,\" Lewis told Fox News Digital in a recent interview.\n\nCLICK HERE TO GET THE FOX NEWS APP\n\n\"I think track does better when we do have a superstar. {"uri": "2024-08-443901192", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "22:06:58", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T22:06:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T22:01:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4823529422283173, "url": "https://www.comingsoon.net/guides/features/1822432-noah-lyles-necklace-diamond-jewelry-chain-link-jpg", "title": "Noah Lyles Necklace: What Is His Diamond Chain-Linked Jewelry?", "body": "Fans want to know more about the Noah Lyles necklace after the sprinter won the coveted 100m dash at the 2024 Paris Olympics. At first glance, the chain-linked piece of jewelry looks studded with diamonds and is made out of three different types of metal. Lyles has a penchant for fancy jewels, be it necklaces or rings, so we can expect him to wear even more bling in the future. Here are more details on the necklace Noah Lyles wore at the 2024 Olympic Games.\n\nWhat is the Noah Lyles necklace made out of?\n\nThe necklace Noah Lyles wore during his gold medal-winning 100m sprint looks to made out of white metal with mariner links that are adorned with three types of gemstones. He has also worn this linked chain in the past, specifically during the 100-meter dash at the 2023 World Athletics Championships.\n\nFrom what we can assume, the chain is mostly out of some kind of white metal alloy, which is typically platinum, white gold, silver, or another gray metal when it comes to jewelry. The mariner links, which refer to the large oval chains used to anchor ships, are each separated by a line. The chain itself is worn very close to Lyles' neck, so that it doesn't hang or flop around while he is sprinting. The jewels themselves look to be diamonds, alternating between yellow, black, and white varieties of the stone, done in pav\u00e9, which is a way of setting diamonds on metal so that they cover most of the metal.\n\nInterestingly, though, Lyles hasn't said much about what his necklace is specifically made out of nor who is responsible for creating it. It's possible that the chain is a piece of custom jewelry made by The Village Jeweler, which is based in Gainesville, Florida. In a Facebook post in 2021, the company posted pictures of Lyles wearing a ring with rose gold accents and gemstones representing the Olympic rings. The jeweler also posted a 2021 TikTok video of Lyles speaking with GQ about a custom rose gold and diamond Cuban link necklace he purchased from its store.\n\nAt any rate, this chain-link necklace has become something of a good luck charm for Noah Lyles. {"uri": "8259142580", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "22:09:33", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T22:09:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T22:08:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.47843137383461, "url": "https://www.dailyecho.co.uk/sport/national/24496924.olympic-100-metres-champion-noah-lyles-feared-photo-finish-gone/", "title": "Olympic 100 metres champion Noah Lyles feared photo finish had gone against him", "body": "Every occupant of the 80,000-seat Stade de France seemed to inhale at once before a roar erupted as the 27-year-old American's name appeared first on the screen, then announced to the stadium as the victor by just five thousandths of a second, a winning time of 9.79.784 seconds.\n\nThe 27-year-old rang the victory bell hard, fait accompli after setting out to settle the \"fastest man\" debate once and for all in France.\n\nLyles, whose US team-mate Fred Kerley took bronze, said: \"I knew that when the time came, for me to be able to say 'this is the final, this is where I need to put it together' I was going to do it.\n\n\"I did think (Thompson) had it at the end. I went up to him after, while we were waiting, and I even said 'I think you've got that, good going,' and then my name popped up and I'm like 'oh my gosh, I'm amazing'.\n\n\"I'm going to be honest, I wasn't ready to see it (his name) and that's the first time I've ever said that. I wasn't ready to see it.\n\n\"He was quite a few lanes down, he was in four, I was in seven so it was hard for me to picture where we were.\"\n\nThe American world 100m and 200m champion's triumph comes three summers after he entered the postponed Tokyo 2020 Olympics as the 200m favourite and world champion - but only claimed bronze.\n\nAfterwards, he opened up about a lifelong battle with depression and the challenges of balancing the benefits of antidepressant medication with side effects that led to weight gain and affected his ability to perform - ultimately electing to wean off the treatment before those Games.\n\nEarlier this week, he acknowledged he performs better in front of a full house, remembering the moment on the start line in Tokyo when he would usually say to himself \"it's showtime\", but instead found himself thinking \"this is not it. This is not fun. This is not cool. This is not what I wanted.\"\n\nLyles had no such trouble in Paris, where he thumped his chest at the start line and pumped up the electrified crowd, clearly revelling in the occasion, before they fell so quiet at the start of the race that it was possible to hear a plane passing overhead.\n\nThen the man whose weakness is often said to be his starts got off to the joint slowest, an 0.178 reaction time alongside Botswana's Letsile Tebogo.\n\nLyles, only learning that fact from a journalist, said: \"Slowest reaction time - that's crazy! I thought I was a little better than that but that goes to prove that reaction time does not win races.\"\n\nHe entered these Olympics with the third-fastest time at 100m this year behind Thompson's world-leading 9.77 and Kenyan Ferdinand Omanyala's 9.79, and as a result found himself in a position of needing to back up his signature bravado on Sunday night.\n\nThompson qualified fastest of the semi-finalists in 9.80, his compatriot Seville Oblique just behind him in a personal-best 9.81 and Lyles two hundredths of a second behind.\n\nOblique was the only man who did not have to wait for his place to be confirmed - the last-placed man in 9.91.\n\nLyles is in Paris with a point to prove, embroiled in a debate before the Games about who was currently fastest man on the planet - not that he ever had any doubts.\n\nThe Floridian - who is looking to do the double in the 200 metres - emphatically reiterated his answer, this time with his feet instead of his rhetoric.", "source": {"uri": Lyles' assertion was that NBA champions, or champions of any national sports league, for that matter, cannot truly assert themselves as world champions unless they do so on an Olympics stage.\n\nWhile Lyles' comments can be easily refuted by the fact that the best players in the world almost always take their talents to the NBA, that didn't stop folks on X, formerly Twitter, from watching closely on Sunday as Lyles took the track for the 100 meter dash, with some hoping that he would slip up and not be able to call himself world champion by his own lofty definition.\n\nEvidently, one of those people was New York Knicks guard/forward Josh Hart, who took to his own X account to send a message prior to the event.\n\n\"I'm a hater just so yall know,\" Hart wrote alongside a laughing emoji.\n\nHowever, fans who were hoping to watch Lyles fail had no such luck, as the American sprinter took home the gold medal by a mere fraction of a second.\n\nAfterward, Hart made sure to show his respect to the gold medalist.\n\n\"Respect,\" he wrote simply.\n\nHart also responded to a post from another user who was hoping to watch Lyles fail in the upcoming 200 meter race.\n\n\"Lol na he an Olympic gold medalist. He can talk for life,\" wrote Hart.\n\nThe question of whether an NBA team can be considered a \"world\" champion is one that doesn't really have a clear answer. As previously noted, most of the best players from countries outside of the United States tend to opt to play in the NBA, and it is highly, highly unlikely that any team comprised of non-NBA players would be able to keep it within 30 against the reigning NBA champion Boston Celtics, let alone beat them.\n\nHowever, the Olympics are the closest thing we have to determining a true \"world\" {"uri": "8259515836", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "06:06:55", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T06:06:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T06:06:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4745098054409027, "url": "https://www.mangalorean.com/paris-olympics-disappointed-but-happy-at-the-same-time-says-jamaicas-thompson-after-close-finish-in-100m-final/", "title": "Paris Olympics: 'Disappointed but happy at the same time', says Jamaica's Thompson after close finish in 100m final - Mangalorean.com", "body": "Paris Olympics: 'Disappointed but happy at the same time', says Jamaica's Thompson after close finish in 100m final\n\nParis: Kishane Thompson, the fastest man in the world so far this year with the 9.77 (his personal best), said he is a \"bit disappointed\" but happy at the same time after taking silver in men's 100m race, missing out on gold by just five thousandths of a second at the Paris Olympics.\n\nIn the deepest men's 100m race of all time, the six-time world gold medallist Noah Lyles dipped to victory in a PB of 9.79 at Stade de France.\n\n\"I'm super grateful. I came out here and finished injury free. I think you guys know my past issues with injuries, so I am a bit disappointed. But I am happy at the same time. I am going to take it as what it is and move forward from here,\" said Thompson.\n\n\"I wasn't patient enough with myself to let my speed bring me at the line, in the position that I know I could have gone to, but I have learnt from it,\" he added.\n\nIt was the first time that eight men have finished sub-10 in the same wind legal race and 0.12 is the smallest ever gap between first and eighth in an Olympic or world men's 100m final.\n\nThompson and his compatriot Oblique Seville had already made history, running the fastest ever Olympic 100m semifinal times. Seville made a statement by clocking a PB of 9.81 to win the first semifinal, 0.02 ahead of Lyles. But Thompson responded by running 9.80 to take the third semifinal.\n\nThompson arrived at the men's final as the world leader this season in the event, with his 9.77 time at Jamaican Nationals in late June, but had limited international experience due to a variety of injuries in recent years. He only made his Diamond League debut last July, and has never ran in a world championships.\n\nThe new Olympic silver medallist said he's taking his runner-up performance on the Olympic stage as a learning experience, \"I made it here. And to give off one of my best performances, if not my best, I'm really grateful for it.\n\n\"I made a mistake. I know my mistakes now. {"uri": "8259143461", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "22:11:35", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T22:11:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T22:09:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4705882370471954, "url": "https://www.aninews.in/news/sports/others/paris-olympics-noah-lyles-takes-away-gold-by-whisker-in-mens-100m-final20240805033012/", "title": "Paris Olympics: Noah Lyles takes away gold by whisker in men's 100m final", "body": "Paris [France], August 5 (ANI): The United States' Noah Lyles sprinted away with the gold medal in the final of men's 100m final at the ongoing Paris Olympics.\n\nLyles needed to produce something special in the biggest race of his career. He tapped into his prime and delivered his personal best performance in front of a jam-packed crowd at the Stade de France.\n\nIn a race that separated the gold and the silver medallists by a matter of milliseconds, Noah emerged victorious and became the fastest man in the men's 100m final.\n\nIn a race that wrapped up within a blink of an eye, Noah clocked of 9.784s to walk away with the gold. He was just 0.16 seconds of breaking the legendary Usain Bolt's Olympic record of 9.63s.\n\nJamaica's Kishane Thompson settled for silver after falling short by a fraction of a second in one of the closest 100m races in the history of the Summer Games. Noah's compatriot Fred Kerley clinched the bronze medal with his season-best timing of 9.81s.\n\nFollowing his triumph, Noah became the first United States athlete to bag a gold since Justin Gatlin stood at the top of the podium in 2004 in the 100m race.\n\nAthletes had to wait for some time for the results as all eight sprinters participating in the event were separated by the tiniest of the margins for the gold medal.\n\nIn the end, it was declared that Noah had 0.005s ahead of Kishane to finish at the top of the podium. Following the announcement, the crowd erupted in a roar and went berserk, applauding the American sprinter for his remarkable triumph. He ripped his name from his shirt and held it high in the air.\n\nSouth Africa's Akane Simbine once again missed out on a podium finish by a whisker as he finished fourth. In the Tokyo and Rio Olympics, Simbine was close but fell short of getting his hands on an Olympic medal in the event.\n\nNoah won the 100m and 200m in last year's World Championships. After securing gold in the 100m, he will look to seal his second gold at Paris in the 200m race event. {"uri": "8260001137", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "11:35:57", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T11:35:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T11:35:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4705882370471954, "url": "https://sportstar.thehindu.com/olympics/paris-2024/news/paris-2024-olympics-noah-lyles-100m-final-race-athletics-sebastian-coe/article68488230.ece", "title": "Paris 2024 Olympics: Noah Lyles hugely important to athletics, says Coe", "body": "The men's 100 metres at the Paris Olympics on Sunday was as close to riveting perfection as you can get, said World Athletics president Sebastian Coe, and further entrenched American Noah Lyles as a consummate front man for the sport.\n\nThe exuberant American captured gold by five hundredths of a second in the most competitive men's 100m final in Olympic history, with just 0.12 seconds separating the eight sprinters in a blanket finish.\n\n\"Well, if it's not perfect, it's about as close to perfect as you'll get,\" Coe said on Monday.\n\nLyles, who raced in braids and white beads, his nails painted in stars, put on a show, ripping his race bib from his chest and holding it aloft when he was announced the victor.\n\n\"(Lyles) is hugely important,\" said Coe. \"Look, I have to be relatively agnostic, but if I'm wearing a promoter's hat, then him winning last night was important because he's now creating a narrative that is heading us back into Usain Bolt territory.\n\n\"It's a recognisable face, a face that have now got young people talking about. And I know that not just from being in the stadium here, but from friends of mine who've got young kids. They're now talking about Noah Lyles in the same breath as some of the highest-profile sports men and women in the world.\"\n\nCoe, a two-time Olympic champion in the 1,500 metres, laughed when told that Lyles wants his own sneaker - common among professional basketball players, not sprinters - saying: \"Ain't no money in spikes. Even Michael Johnson didn't have a sneaker.\"\n\n\"He is recognising that he is beginning to transcend the sport, which is really what we want them all to do,\" Coe said.\n\nParticularly impressive in Lyles' performance was that the 27-year-old did not look best in the semifinal less than two hours earlier.\n\nAlso read | Noah Lyles wins 100m final: How is a photo finish decided in Olympics?\n\n\"Like all great individuals in sport and great teams, they tend when it really matters to find a way of winning, and that's what he did last night. He was never ahead in that race until the last frame of that photo,\" Coe said.\n\n\"What he probably mastered better than anybody else, was what was in his head for an hour and 40-something minutes between the semi and the final.\"\n\nHad Sunday's sprint final been a swimming race, Lyles and silver medallist Kishane Thompson would have shared gold, since swimming times only go to the hundredth of a second.\n\n\"If you have the technology, you have to use it,\" Coe said. \"Metrology is a very clear and definite science, and you need to make sure that if you have that technology, you use it.\n\n\"You speak to my kids or younger, they're not fazed by the fact that somebody got across the line in five thousands of a second, they think it's rather cool actually.\"\n\nAthletics has drawn huge crowds to the Stade de France for both the evening and traditionally less-popular morning sessions.\n\n\"The great thing about athletics, and it's one of the assets we mustn't ever overlook, is that our fans are not tribal,\" Coe said. \"Every home fan wants their home team to do as well as they possibly can. {"uri": "8259836224", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "09:53:46", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T09:53:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T09:52:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4705882370471954, "url": "https://www.bernerzeitung.ch/animation-compare-all-gold-sprinters-since-1896-700464634410", "title": "Animation: Compare all gold sprinters since 1896", "body": "The fastest man in the world comes from the USA. World champion Noah Lyles is the Olympic champion in the 100 metres. The 27-year-old from the USA sprinted to gold in Saint-Denis near Paris in front of 70,000 spectators in the final in 9.79 seconds. Lyles is the first 100 metre Olympic champion from the USA since Justin Gatlin won gold 20 years ago in Athens.\n\nSilver went to Jamaican shooting star Kishane Thompson, who clocked 9.79 seconds and only missed out on gold by a thousandth of a second. Bronze went to Fred Kerley from the USA in 9.81 seconds.\n\nHowever, gold medallist sprinter Noah Lyles cannot match Usain Bolt's records.\n\nThe Jamaican made history in Rio de Janeiro in 2016 when he became the first 100-metre sprinter to win the gold medal at the Olympic Games three times in a row. He ran the 100 metres in Rio in 9.81 seconds, a time that Lyles has now beaten in Paris. However, Bolt was significantly faster in Beijing 2008 (9.69 seconds) and London 2012 (9.63 seconds).\n\nIn 1980, Britain's Allan Wells was the last sprinter to win the gold medal by more than 10 seconds.\n\nThe first Olympic 100 metre champion, Tom Burke, took 12 seconds to cover the distance in 1896 - which today would be more than 20 metres behind Bolt at the finish line.\n\nThis development is due to constantly improving equipment, nutrition and training methods.\n\nIn the early days of the 100-metre race, the time was still stopped by hand and the clocks were only accurate to tenths of a second. The first electric timekeeping took place in 1932, but only as an experiment. Officially, the hand-stopped times were used. It was not until 1972 that the electronic, more accurate version of timekeeping was officially introduced - one of the reasons why the times became somewhat slower again. In 1984, Carl Lewis was the first sprinter to stay under 10 seconds, even with electronics. Since then, no 100-metre winner at the Olympics has stayed above this magic mark.\n\nA new face became Olympic champion in the women's event on Saturday evening: Julien Alfred from the small Caribbean state of St Lucia, who only turned professional last year, won gold in 10.72 seconds. She beat the big favourite and world champion Sha'Carri Richardson (USA, 10.87), while her team-mate Melissa Jefferson won bronze (10.92).\n\nFlorence Griffith-Joyner remains the Olympic record holder with 10.54 seconds. {"uri": "8259467373", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "05:24:09", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T05:24:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T05:21:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4588235318660736, "url": "https://jamaica-gleaner.com/article/lead-stories/20240805/silver-lining", "title": "Silver lining", "body": "2. Kishane Thompson (left) assists teammate Oblique Seville of Jamaica moments after the men's 100m finals.\n\nJamaica's eight-year men's 100m major global title drought appeared to have ended under the lights in Paris, France, yesterday. But when the dust settled, by the barest of margins, American Noah Lyles claimed the ultimate prize.\n\nLyles added the Olympic title to the World crown he won last year in Budapest, Hungary, with a personal best effort of 9.79 seconds and a photo-finish time of 9.784. Kishane Thompson, in his first major global final, mined silver while also finishing in 9.79, but with a photo-finish time of 9.789 seconds - .005 behind Lyles. Lyles' teammate, American Fred Kerley, was third in a season's best 9.81 seconds. Jamaica's Oblique Seville, in his third major global final, was eighth in 9.91.\n\nWith Thompson's silver, Jamaica procured its first Olympic medal in the event since Usain Bolt's win in 2016 and its first major global medal for the men's 100m since Bolt's bronze medal in 2017. Although it was not the colour that he would have liked, Thompson was not just appreciative of the medal, but of being able to complete a season in good health.\n\n\"I am super grateful. I came out here injury free. I think that you know my history with injuries. I am a bit disappointed, but I am super grateful and happy at the same time,\" Thompson said.\n\nHe consoled Seville after the race, and Seville hailed his compatriot in his post-race interview with Television Jamaica.\n\nLyles' victory meant that the United States took back the men's 100m Olympic crown it last claimed in 2004.\n\nNatoya Goule-Toppin did not advance to the finals of the women's 800m after finishing sixth in 1:59.14 minutes. Reports emerged that the result is under protest due to an alleged barge [interference], which caused Goule-Toppin to fall behind.\n\nEarlier in the morning, Jamaica suffered another withdrawal as Shericka Jackson did not face the starter of the women's 200m. Jackson's fitness was in question leading up to the Games and she had opted out of the 100m. Lanae Tava Thomas and Niesha Burgher progressed to this afternoon's semi- finals, with second-place finishes in their respective heats.\n\nWorld championships silver medallist Wayne Pinnock and world indoor championship bronze medallist Carey McLeod advanced to the finals of the men's long jump. Pinnock's mark of 7.96 and McLeod's mark of 7.90 were good enough to finish in the top 12 of qualifying. Former world champion Tajay Gayle missed out on the final after his mark of 7.78m was only good enough for 19th place.\n\nReigning Olympic champion Hansle Parchment had to endure a nervous wait but advanced to the semi-finals of the men's 110m hurdles as a non-automatic qualifier after finishing fifth in his heat in 13.43. Orlando Bennett and Commonwealth Games champion Rasheed Broadbell advanced automatically with second-place finishes. Parchment said that while it wasn't the best race, he was committed to improving after getting a race under him.\n\n\"It wasn't the best execution, but I am in the next round, so I have that to look towards now. So I have to put my mind towards that,\" Parchment said\n\nAll three Jamaicans secured passage to the semi-finals of the women's 400m hurdles, registering automatic qualifications. National champion Rushell Clayton won her heat in 54.32, and Shian Salmon finished second in her heat in 53.95. Lyles pipped Jamaica's Kishane Thompson by five thousandths of a second, and even last-placed Oblique Seville finished in 9.91 seconds, which would have earned him fourth place in Tokyo.\n\nBEIJING 2008\n\nDespite opening his arms in celebration long before the line, Usain Bolt roared to the title in Beijing's Bird's Nest Stadium in a new world record time of 9.69 seconds. With his win the Jamaican, who celebrated with his now-trademark 'Bolt' celebration, brought a bright new era to a race too often blighted by drug controversies. Richard Thompson of Trinidad was a distant second, and Brian Dix of the US third.\n\nBARCELONA 1992\n\n\"It's Linford Christie!\" roared BBC commentator David Coleman as the Great Britain star surged through in the final stages to become the first British winner of the race since Harold Abrahams in 1924. With the absence of two-time defending champion Carl Lewis who was stricken by a virus at the US Trials, Christie started as one of the favourites, and he won in a time of 9.96 seconds ahead of Namibia's Frankie Fredericks.\n\nSEOUL 1988\n\nBen Johnson blazed over the line in a new world record time of 9. 79 seconds in a race in which, for the first time, four of the eight finalists broke the 10-second barrier. But within three days of his triumph, Johnson tested positive for anabolic steroids and was stripped of his title, with second-placed Carl Lewis promoted to gold. The 1988 has subsequently come to be known as 'The Dirtiest Race in History'.\n\nMUNICH 1936\n\nUnder the eyes of Adolf Hitler, Jesse Owens reigned supreme in Berlin, and his win in the 100 metres, in a time of 10.3 seconds, proved to be his first of four gold medals at the Games. Owens had run 10.2 seconds in his quarter-final but was denied a new world record due to wind assistance. {"uri": "8259505307", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "05:58:23", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T05:58:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T05:56:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4549019634723663, "url": "https://www.socialnews.xyz/2024/08/05/paris-olympics-disappointed-but-happy-at-the-same-time-says-jamaicas-thompson-after-close-finish-in-100m-final/", "title": "Paris Olympics: 'Disappointed but happy at the same time', says Jamaica's Thompson after close finish in 100m final", "body": "Paris, Aug 5 (SocialNews.XYZ) Kishane Thompson, the fastest man in the world so far this year with the 9.77 (his personal best), said he is a \"bit disappointed\" but happy at the same time after taking silver in men's 100m race, missing out on gold by just five thousandths of a second at the Paris Olympics.\n\nIn the deepest men's 100m race of all time, the six-time world gold medallist Noah Lyles dipped to victory in a PB of 9.79 at Stade de France.\n\n\"I'm super grateful. I came out here and finished injury free. I think you guys know my past issues with injuries, so I am a bit disappointed. But I am happy at the same time. I am going to take it as what it is and move forward from here,\" said Thompson.\n\n\"I wasn't patient enough with myself to let my speed bring me at the line, in the position that I know I could have gone to, but I have learnt from it,\" he added.\n\nIt was the first time that eight men have finished sub-10 in the same wind legal race and 0.12 is the smallest ever gap between first and eighth in an Olympic or world men's 100m final.\n\nThompson and his compatriot Oblique Seville had already made history, running the fastest ever Olympic 100m semifinal times. Seville made a statement by clocking a PB of 9.81 to win the first semifinal, 0.02 ahead of Lyles. But Thompson responded by running 9.80 to take the third semifinal.\n\nThompson arrived at the men's final as the world leader this season in the event, with his 9.77 time at Jamaican Nationals in late June, but had limited international experience due to a variety of injuries in recent years. He only made his Diamond League debut last July, and has never ran in a world championships.\n\nThe new Olympic silver medallist said he's taking his runner-up performance on the Olympic stage as a learning experience, \"I made it here. And to give off one of my best performances, if not my best, I'm really grateful for it.\n\n\"I made a mistake. I know my mistakes now. In track, it's about the torso crossing the line, and Lyles' torso clearly crossed before Thompson's did.\n\nNBC announcer Leigh Diffey, who returned for his sixth Olympics broadcast, was calling track and field for the second time at the Summer Games. {"uri": "8259162411", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "22:40:34", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T22:40:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T22:38:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4509803950786591, "url": "https://ca.sports.yahoo.com/news/noah-lyles-coach-pumped-star-223523047.html", "title": "How Noah Lyles' coach pumped up his star before he ran to Olympic gold in 100 meters", "body": "SAINT-DENIS, France -- Before Noah Lyles walked onto the track in the men's 100-meter final Sunday night, his coach Lance Brauman told him that the next time they saw one another, Lyles would be an Olympic champion.\n\n\"I said 'Hey, a showman shows up when the show's on,'\" Brauman recalled. \"And that's what he did.\"\n\nLyles surged to a thrilling and momentous Olympic gold medal Sunday, cementing his place as the fastest man in the world by beating Kishane Thompson of Jamaica in a photo finish that might go down as the closest final in Olympic history. The jumbotron at Stade de France showed both men with a time of 9.79 seconds, while the actual margin between them was almost impossibly slim: Five thousandths of a second.\n\nBrauman, who has coached Lyles for years, watched it all unfold from a spot on the back stretch near the finish line, grappling with the kind of nerves and excitement that only the Olympic final can provide.\n\nAt around the 60-meter mark, he said he felt really good about Lyles' positioning. At 80 meters, he thought \"holy cow, he's right there.\" At 90, he started to worry. It was a much closer race than he thought.\n\n\"I thought he was going to run a (personal best). I have for the past three weeks,\" Brauman said. \"It was just a matter of, was he going to run a big enough PB to win the race? And he did.\"\n\nBrauman said he had to move from his seat to get a better view of the jumbotron. When asked about the time, 9.79, he noted that it was the fastest time to win an Olympic 100-meter final by someone not named Usain Bolt. But he also added that \"I didn't give a (expletive) what the time was, to be totally honest with you.\" Brauman just cared that Lyles crossed the line first.\n\nDitto for the 27-year-old's form at the end, where he might have had a slight lean. (Contrary to preconceived notions, sprinting coaches teach their pupils to run up straight and power through the line, as leaning can cause deceleration.)\n\n\"I haven't seen it on film,\" Brauman said when asked if Lyles broke his form at the finish line. \"If I go back and look at it? Maybe. But I don't really give a (expletive) right this second.\"\n\nBrauman cracked a smile. He's usually pretty reserved but said he went bonkers when he saw that Lyles had become an Olympic champion - a title that eluded him at the 2021 Tokyo Games and has, in part, motivated him in the three years since.\n\nBrauman said this race, like all of Lyles' wins in recent years, isn't about his coaching or the message he offered before the race. But it is special to him. And, at least for now, the meticulous, affable coach with a Southern drawl said the usual analysis of Lyles' technique and form could wait.\n\n\"In races like that, you just got to do what you have to do to get to the line first,\" Brauman said. \"He has a knack for it. And he did a hell of a job today.\"\n\nContact Tom Schad at tschad@usatoday.com or on social media @Tom_Schad.\n\n\u25b6 The USA TODAY app gets you to the heart of the news -- fast.Download for Several fans think that movie might be Pixar's \"Cars.\"\n\nOn Sunday, U.S. sprinter Noah Lyles won his first Olympic gold medal by besting Jamaican Kishane Thompson by five-thousandths of a second at Stade de France in Paris. Lyles had a final time of 9.784 seconds, while Thompson was at 9.789. The third-place finisher, American Fred Kerley, finished with a final time of 9.81.\n\nThe finish was so close that the NBC announcer botched the call and initially declared Thompson the winner (video here).\n\nThe photo finish had fans on X remembering a scene from the movie \"Cars,\" which was produced by Pixar and released by Disney in 2006.\n\nIn the movie, protagonist Lightning McQueen forces a tie with his two competitors by sticking his tongue out to reach the finish line.\n\nLyles didn't use any tongue trickery to win his race. But fans couldn't help but notice how each sprinter's uniform colors eerily resembled the colors of the cars in the movie.\n\nIn the \"Cars\" movie, the race was so close that they had to re-do the race.\n\nIn real life, the Olympics had the benefit of extremely high-definition cameras to determine a true winner without needing a restart.", "source": {"uri": "larrybrownsports.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Larry Brown Sports"}, "authors": [{"uri": "r_p_salao@larrybrownsports.com", "name": "R.P. {"uri": "8259694214", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "08:18:46", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T08:18:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T08:18:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4470588266849518, "url": "https://www.jamaicaobserver.com/2024/08/05/oh-so-close-20240805-0808-251440/", "title": "OH, SO CLOSE! - Jamaica Observer", "body": "PARIS, France -- It may not have been the medal he was aiming for in the final of the Men's 100m at the Olympic Games on Sunday, but Jamaican rising sprint star Kishane Thompson says he is grateful for winning the silver medal. Thompson's medal was the first for a Jamaican man in the sprint events at a major global championship since the legendary Usain Bolt won bronze at the World Championships in 2017.\n\nIt was the third medal won by Jamaica at the Paris Olympics after triple jumper Shanieka Ricketts won silver and shot putter Rajindra Campbell got a bronze on Saturday.\n\nThe 23-year-old Thompson, who is the fastest man in the world this year with his time of 9.77 seconds, was the red-hot favourite to win the gold medal. However, after leading for almost the entire race, the gold medal was snatched away from him by the fast-finishing American and world sprint double champion Noah Lyles, who won the event in a photo-finish with a time of 9.79, in front of a packed house inside Stade de France. The same time was given to Thompson.\n\nLyles' teammate Fred Kerley was third with a season's best of 9.81. Jamaica's other competitor in the final, Oblique Seville, was eighth in 9.91.\n\n\"I am super grateful because I came out here and finished injury-free; I think you guys know my past with injuries,\" said Thompson. \"I am a bit disappointed but I am super grateful and happy at the same time, and I am just going to take it for what it is and just move forward from here,\" he said.\n\nThompson highlighted that he was not pleased with his execution of the race. He noted he had not been patient enough throughout the contest, which led to him losing the gold medal.\n\n\"I wasn't patient enough with my speed and myself to let my speed bring me to the line in the position that I know I could have gone to, but I will learn from it,\" he said. \"I should have been more relaxed and patient with myself.\"\n\nHe said that while he tried his best to win the gold medal for the country, it was just not his day.\n\n\"I am feeling super grateful, and maybe my body language doesn't show it because I am not an expressive guy, but I am glad. I know that Jamaica would have wanted me to get the gold, and everybody loves winners, and I would have loved to win, but big up to the whole field [of] competitors,\" Thompson stated.\n\nNational champion Natoya Goule failed to secure a spot in the final of the women's 800m competition after finishing sixth in 1:59.14. The race was won by World Champion Mary Moraa of Kenya in 1:57.86, ahead of Ethiopia's Worknesh Mesele in 1:58.06, and Cuba's Daily Cooper Gaspar in 1:58.39.", "source": {"uri": "jamaicaobserver.com", {"uri": "8259088478", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "20:56:14", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T20:56:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T20:54:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4470588266849518, "url": "https://www.abc.net.au/news/2024-08-05/olympics-100m-sprint-paris-2024-games-noah-lyles/104182284", "title": "The shortest race and the longest of glories  --  how a brash American bent time to claim 100m Olympic gold", "body": "We all know the feeling. Wasted, lethargic hours waiting for that one moment, that one thing you've been looking forward to for an age.\n\nOr perhaps there's not enough time.\n\nSuddenly that long-anticipated moment approaches with all the subtlety and hesitancy of a coal train in full flight.\n\nThat is the Olympics.\n\nFour long years (usually) between those moments that everyone remembers.\n\nFour years of waiting.\n\nThat is what Noah Lyles, dramatic champion of the 100m sprint in Paris, was feeling.\n\nHaving missed the event in Tokyo after finishing seventh at the US trials, Lyles was more determined than ever to achieve his goal of adding his name to the list of champions and take the crown as 100/200 sprint king left vacant by Usain Bolt.\n\nAfter all the years of training, all the years of dreaming, before he knew it, he was on the blocks, staring down the purple track, 70,000 pairs of eyes staring intently at him and seven others, everyone holding their breath, silently waiting.\n\nThis is when those seconds begin to stretch again, the gap between being introduced to the crowd and the starter taking control, a time of contemplation in the near-silence.\n\nThen, the robotic-sounding voice tonelessly orders the runners: \"To your marks.\"\n\nMore time. The final seconds will stretch indeterminably as feet are placed on blocks.\n\nThis is where the best runners bend time to their own will, though.\n\nThis is for the final mind games.\n\nFor a race that takes 10 seconds or less to complete, so much is run and done before even stepping onto the track.\n\nThe hype. The posturing. The talk.\n\nIt all has to happen before the race gets underway -- there is simply no time from the moment the gun goes until it's all over.\n\nThat's why the 100m remains the blue ribband event of the Olympics, its winner lauded like no other.\n\nIs it curious that the shortest event on the program carries such immense gravitas?\n\nThe Olympic motto -- Faster. Higher. Stronger -- has it right.\n\nRight at the front. Faster is what people want and, with the 100m, faster is what people get.\n\nIts simplicity is its charm.\n\nRun from this point, to this point: No bends. No obstacles. No complications.\n\nIt's not only in people's dreams that they can sprint. Even a mad dash to the bus stop serves the same purpose as racing down the track -- albeit with slightly less riding on it.\n\nIt will only be a second before the gun, but the pause, heavy with anticipation makes it seem like an age.\n\nThe crowd has been silent now for only a matter of seconds but the air hangs heavy, a pregnant pause weighted like few in world sport -- the great inhale before the roar.\n\nThis is what all the training, all the hours on the track and in the gym, all those frustrating minutes on the treatment table, has been gearing for.\n\nOff goes the gun.\n\nTime, so malleable up until this point, becomes brutally fixed, metronomically determining who will wheel away in the immortal glory that comes with being an Olympic champion.\n\nBut first, the semifinals. There was a bit more time to wait.\n\nIn the first semifinal, Oblique Seville flew out of the blocks, a personal best of 9.81 awaited him.\n\nSeville looked to his right as he closed towards the line, glancing at American favourite Noah Lyles who, slow off the blocks, was finishing quickly on his left to finish in 9.83.\n\nLyles, the personable yet brash 27-year-old hoping to complete the sprint double in Paris, seemed to be a touch surprised as he stared across to his right at the streaking flash of yellow.\n\nThe world champion was yet to cross the line first in a race at this Games.\n\nIn the second semifinal, Akani Simbine and Letsile Tebogo edged out the defending Olympic champion Lamont Marcell Jacobs.\n\nSurprise winner in Tokyo, Italian Jacobs has had a rough three years since that golden night in Japan.\n\nNow, he has a wait to see if he will be one of the two fastest non-automatic qualifiers to progress. It would only be a wait of a handful of minutes to see if he would make the final.\n\nIt would feel like hours. Three years of waiting. Three years of work, condensed into 10 short minutes. All the 29-year-old's hopes resting on the efforts of others.\n\nKishane Thompson up in the next semifinal, the Jamaican flying home in 9.80, ahead of Fred Kerley of America in 9.84.\n\nJacobs could breathe again. His time of 9.92 was enough to qualify, as was American Kenneth Bednarek's 9.93.\n\nTwo Jamaicans. Three Americans. A South African, Botswanan and Italian.\n\nLittle over an hour to wait before a date with destiny.\n\nWhile the crowd experienced the ups and downs of other finals, these sprinters were out back. Recovering.\n\nBut, it was not long before they were back on the track again, time racing as fast as their beating hearts.\n\nTime for the mind games once more.\n\nJacobs and Lyles at polar opposites, the defending champion calm, the upstart making a scene, leaping and jumping and revving up the crowd.\n\nThe referee holds them for an age, allowing the crowd to reach a crescendo and let the tension build even more.\n\nThe shortest race obviously needs the longest build up.\n\nSilence at last. The only sound the buzzing of a helicopter above the Stade de France.\n\nAnother delay.\n\nThen a roar from the bowels of the stadium, 70,000 people screaming for their lives and the life-changing moment they were hoping to see.\n\nThey crossed the finish in a line. \"Photo\" flashed up on the scoreboard. {"uri": "8260016373", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "11:46:08", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T11:46:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T11:44:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.43529412150383, "url": "https://www.news18.com/olympics/paris-olympics-champion-noah-lyles-heading-sprint-back-into-usain-bolt-territory-says-world-athletics-chief-8990876.html", "title": "Paris Olympics Champion Noah Lyles Heading Sprint Back Into 'Usain Bolt Territory', Says World Athletics Chief - News18", "body": "Coe meanwhile said Lyles' win by just 0.005sec on Sunday -- the narrowest margin of victory in a 100m final in modern Olympic history -- had demonstrated his greatness.\n\nWorld Athletics chief Sebastian Coe said Monday newly crowned Olympic sprint king Noah Lyles has given a boost to the sport not seen since the glory years of Usain Bolt.\n\nSpeaking to reporters after Lyles won an epic men's 100m final at the Stade de France on Sunday, Coe said the charismatic American was now \"hugely important\" for athletics.\n\nLyles, 27, revels in his role as one of the great showmen of track and field, and was a central character in the recent Netflix docu-series \"Sprint\".\n\nCoe said reigning 100m and 200m world champion Lyles was on course to fill the void created by the departure of Jamaican icon Bolt, the eight-time Olympic gold medallist who retired in 2017.\n\n\"I have to be relatively agnostic, but if I'm wearing a promoter's hat, then him winning last night was important because he's now creating a narrative that is heading us back into the Usain Bolt territory,\" Coe said.\n\n\"That is hugely important. Because he's a recognizable face. It's a face that I've now got young people talking about. And I know that not just from being in the stadium here or being in the athletics world.\n\n\"I know what they're talking about. I know friends of mine who've got young kids, they're now talking about Noah Lyles in the same breath as some of the highest profile sports men and women in the world.\"\n\nTranscending athletics\n\nLyles himself greeted his victory on Sunday with a call for athletics to do a better job of promoting itself.\n\nThe Florida-based sprinter also hopes to leverage his Olympic success by securing a Michael Jordan-style sports shoe deal.\n\n\"I can understand that,\" Coe said. \"That's between him and his shoe company. But look, what he is recognizing and reflecting on is that he is beginning to transcend his sport, which is really what we want them all to do.\"\n\nCoe meanwhile said Lyles' win by just 0.005sec on Sunday -- the narrowest margin of victory in a 100m final in modern Olympic history -- had demonstrated his greatness.\n\n\"What he has is what all great individuals and great teams in sport have -- when it really matters, they find a way to win, and that's what he did last night,\" Coe said.\n\n\"He was never ahead in that race until the last frame of that photo finish, but he found a way. He didn't look outstanding in the first round, and his semi final was okay, but last night was his kingdom.\"\n\nCoe added that Lyles' enthusiastic embrace of his role as an entertainer was an example to other stars of the sport.\n\n\"I've always said, performance is your passport, but promotion is everything,\" Coe said. \"It's not enough to be just another Olympic champion or another world champion.\n\n\"He wants to fill a stadium and he also wants to fill a press conference.\n\n\"And actually, what he has to say is profoundly important for the sport. And there are things he has said that have got us all thinking slightly differently on occasions.\"", "source": {"uri": "news18.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "News18"}, "authors": [], "concepts": {"uri": "8259923802", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "10:47:55", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T10:47:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T10:47:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.43529412150383, "url": "https://cyprus-mail.com/2024/08/05/american-sprinter-lyles-hugely-important-to-athletics-says-coe/", "title": "American sprinter Lyles hugely important to athletics, says Coe", "body": "The men's 100 metres at the Paris Olympics on Sunday was as close to riveting perfection as you can get, said World Athletics president Sebastian Coe, and further entrenched American Noah Lyles as a consummate front man for the sport.\n\nThe exuberant American captured gold by five hundredths of a second in the most competitive men's 100m final in Olympic history, with just 0.12 seconds separating the eight sprinters in a blanket finish.\n\n\"Well, if it's not perfect, it's about as close to perfect as you'll get,\" Coe said on Monday.\n\nLyles, who raced in braids and white beads, his nails painted in stars, put on a show, ripping his race bib from his chest and holding it aloft when he was announced the victor.\n\n\"(Lyles) is hugely important,\" said Coe. \"Look, I have to be relatively agnostic, but if I'm wearing a promoter's hat, then him winning last night was important because he's now creating a narrative that is heading us back into Usain Bolt territory.\n\n\"It's a recognizable face, a face that have now got young people talking about. And I know that not just from being in the stadium here, but from friends of mine who've got young kids. They're now talking about Noah Lyles in the same breath as some of the highest-profile sports men and women in the world.\"\n\nCoe, a two-time Olympic champion in the 1,500 metres, laughed when told that Lyles wants his own sneaker -- common among professional basketball players, not sprinters -- saying: \"Ain't no money in spikes. Even Michael Johnson didn't have a sneaker.\"\n\n\"He is recognising that he is beginning to transcend the sport, which is really what we want them all to do,\" Coe said.\n\nParticularly impressive in Lyles' performance was that the 27-year-old did not look best in the semi-final less than two hours earlier.\n\n\"Like all great individuals in sport and great teams, they tend when it really matters to find a way of winning, and that's what he did last night. He was never ahead in that race until the last frame of that photo,\" Coe said.\n\n\"What he probably mastered better than anybody else, was what was in his head for an hour and 40-something minutes between the semi and the final.\"\n\nHad Sunday's sprint final been a swimming race, Lyles and silver medallist Kishane Thompson would have shared gold, since swimming times only go to the hundredth of a second.\n\n\"If you have the technology, you have to use it,\" Coe said. \"Metrology is a very clear and definite science, and you need to make sure that if you have that technology, you use it.\n\n\"You speak to my kids or younger, they're not fazed by the fact that somebody got across the line in five thousands of a second, they think it's rather cool actually.\"\n\nAthletics has drawn huge crowds to the Stade de France for both the evening and traditionally less-popular morning sessions.\n\n\"The great thing about athletics, and it's one of the assets we mustn't ever overlook, is that our fans are not tribal,\" Coe said. \"Every home fan wants their home team to do as well as they possibly can. But it's not a deal-breaker.\"", "source": {"uri": "cyprus-mail.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Cyprus Mail"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sebastian_Coe", {"uri": "8259578589", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "06:58:15", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T06:58:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T06:57:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4313725531101227, "url": "https://www.sportbible.com/athletics/olympics-usa-noah-lyles-100m-sprint-kishane-thompson-191774-20240805", "title": "Fans lash out at 'unforgivable' incident that happened moments before men's 100m final at Olympic Games", "body": "Noah Lyles went on to secure Olympic gold but the pre-race build-up has been heavily criticised.\n\nAn incident in the build-up to Sunday night's Olympic 100m final has been criticised by many, but an explanation appears to have emerged online.\n\nNoah Lyles secured his first Olympic gold medal at the Stade de France after finishing 0.005 seconds ahead of Jamaica's Kishane Thompson.\n\nIt was a dramatic end to what was an eventful race. In the build-up, spectators inside the stadium watched on as dramatic music and a light show echoed around the arena.\n\nBut to the annoyance of many, including those inside the BBC studio, Lyles and his fellow sprinters were forced to wait around three minutes before being positioned on the starting blocks.\n\nColin Jackson, a two-time world champion hurdler who earned a silver medal at the 1988 Olympics, was baffled by the delay.\n\n\"I'm looking down at the track to see if there are any issues, any problems, because we know this race was supposed to start at least three minutes ago,\" he said during the BBC's pre-race coverage.\n\n\"There doesn't seem to be anything happening. This is very frustrating for them because this is the biggest race of the year.\"\n\nDenise Lewis, who won gold in the heptathlon at Sydney 2000, added: \"I have to say that it's a little bit unfair to the athletes themselves.\n\n\"You get yourself to that arousal point where you're in the zone, you're absolutely wanting to give everything and then that is just waning slightly, the longer you're left out there.\n\n\"This is the finite margins we're talking about and that for me was just way too long.\"\n\nThe scenes were also criticised by many viewers.\n\nOne fan wrote: \"The lengthy delay before the start of the men's 100m final is unforgivable - the blue riband event, the world's fastest men, nerves already stretched, made to wait and wait for minute after agonising minute.\"\n\nA second said: The wait for this 100m men's final feels like a LIFETIME,\" while a third commented: \"Ok. This is ridiculous how long they are making the runners wait for this 100m final.\"\n\nA fourth wrote: \"Sensational 100m final. A joke of a delay to the showpiece after a great intro. But they all delivered. 9.91 seconds in EIGHTH!!! And 9.79 for BOTH 1st and 2nd... thousandths of a second!! Superb watch.\"\n\nA fifth added: \"That delay before the 100m final was very bad. What was the need?\"\n\nIt has since emerged that the delay was seemingly caused by an individual who attempted to gain access to the track.\n\nThe person in question, wearing a t-shirt that read, 'free Palestine, free Ukraine', was eventually led away by four members of security after being tackled to the ground.\n\nSpeaking after winning gold in Paris, race winner Noah Lyles was informed about the person who appeared to delay proceedings at the Stade de France.\n\n\"Is that what we were waiting for?\" he said in his post-race press conference alongside Kishane Thompson and Fred Kerley.\n\n\"I didn't see anybody try to get on the field. But I was wondering what we were waiting for, not gonna lie. But, in the meantime, the crowd were constantly getting more and more hyped. It didn't feel as if it was completely dead.\"\n\nAt the time of writing, it has not been confirmed that the track invader sparked the delay on Sunday night but as seen above, images of the incident in Olympic men's 100m - Jamaica Observer", "body": "KINGSTON, Jamaica -- Kishane Thompson delivered a silver medal as he ran 9.79 seconds (1.m/s), the same time as winner Noah Lyles of the USA in the final of the men's 100m at the Olympics at Stade de France in Paris on Sunday.\n\nIt was the third medal won by Jamaica at the Olympics after triple jumper Shaneika Ricketts won a silver and shot putter Rajindra Campbell got a bronze on Saturday.\n\nThompson's medal was the first for a Jamaican man in any major global championships since Usain Bolt's bronze at the World Championships in 2017.\n\nRunning only the eighth race of the season, the 23-year-old held his nerves to win his first medal at any level in only his second major final.\n\nOblique Seville, who looked supreme in the semi-finals, finished eighth in 9.91 seconds.\n\nAfter being held for what seemed to be a longer than usual time at the start line, Thompson was just edged on the finish line by the American who added the Olympic title to the World Championships he won in Budapest last year, the two being separated by a thousandth of a second.\n\nFormer World Athletics champion, Fred Kerley was third with a
